webTitle: Spurs woo fans with freeze on ticket prices

fields.headline: Spurs woo fans with freeze on ticket prices
fields.trailText: Tottenham Hotspur are to freeze ticket prices for next season. The move was announced in the plc's interim financial results for the six months ended January 31, which revealed a dip in profits.
fields.body:
Tottenham Hotspur are to freeze ticket prices for next season. The move was announced in the plc's interim financial results for the six months ended January 31, which revealed a dip in profits.

Despite an increase in turnover of 34%, the disposal of surplus players led to a 28% drop in profits to £2m.

The chairman Alan Sugar said: "In recognising the cost to our loyal supporters of attending matches, the board have decided that there is to be no increase in ticket prices."

The Fulham manager Paul Bracewell has blasted his striker Barry Hayles for deserting their promotion challenge to play for the Cayman Islands: "Barry knew that we had two strikers injured but he still decided to go."

Fifa's plans to harmonise the world football calendar have been branded "unworkable and impractical" by the Premier League.

"We regard the idea of a single, set calendar being imposed on world football as unworkable," said the league's spokesman Mike Lee.

The Derby manager Jim Smith yesterday called on the Football Association to ban players found guilty of violent conduct for six matches. "There's no place for it," said Smith. "I think getting two games is ridiculous, they should get six games if they are going to stamp it out, which they need to."

Slaven Bilic yesterday rejoined his home-town club, Hajduk Split, 48 hours after having his Everton contract terminated. And Peter Johnson finally ended his six-year association with Everton by resigning as a director.

fields.headline: Reading lead drive against agents
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough and Tottenham will follow Reading in officially warning their academy players not to sign up with individual agents and instead to put their careers in the hands of the Professional Footballers' Association.
fields.body:
Reading are spearheading a drive to reduce the influence of agents within the game after officially warning their academy players not to sign up with individual agents and instead to put their careers in the hands of the Professional Footballers' Association.

The move gathered momentum yesterday when Middlesbrough and Tottenham confirmed that they would follow Reading's lead.

Alan Pardew became the first manager to warn his players collectively about dealing with individual agents at a meeting with academy players and their parents at Reading's Madejski Stadium on Tuesday night. Similar discussions will take place at Tottenham on Monday and Middlesbrough will follow shortly.

"I think all the other clubs will follow our lead," Pardew said yesterday. "We are all seeing the same problem on our academy grounds. The rich pickings in the Premier League are all taken up by a few agents so the rest have now tried to move into youth football. We have tried to pre-empt this."

Pardew fears that young players are getting tied to deals from which they cannot escape and suffer financially when negotiating contracts. He warned the youngsters that he would much prefer to negotiate their first contract at the club with the PFA rather than an agent.

"At the moment I am having to sit down with lawyers, insurance salesmen and other flash Harrys who are talking figures which are ridiculous," he said. "The most crucial thing for me is that the PFA knows a player's value, so when they are negotiating the first contract they will be realistic. When I negotiate, I want to be talking to a football person who knows where I'm coming from. The PFA know everybody's wages so they know what level a player can expect to get. They won't come to me with pie-in-the-sky figures to start from."

John Stephenson, the director of the academy at Reading, said players would also benefit from signing up to the "cradle to grave attitude" of the PFA.

"There are agents who are unscrupulous while there are others who are entirely scrupulous. But there is a danger that a young player can get himself into a position with deals with agents where he signs away the fortune that he could make in the future. We believe that the PFA would not allow this to happen."

Among the players whom the PFA represents are Chris Sutton and Tim Flowers. Bob Hatton, a former player who is now a financial executive with the PFA and represented the union at the meeting with Reading, said the PFA was as effective as agents at "squeezing the last penny out of clubs". He insisted, too, that it offered other benefits.

"A youngster may sign professional forms when he's 17 and the PFA will subsidise his education until he's 21. I don't see many agents who will put their hands in their pockets and do this. We are also there in the hard times after football, which agents aren't.

"Our great strength is that we have to tell the truth all the time. Some agents can fantasise about what they can do for a player and promise them the earth. We are accountable for what we do and take our job seriously. We work on a different level."

webTitle: Gascoigne recovery hit by ban for three games

fields.headline: Gascoigne recovery hit by ban for three games
fields.trailText: Paul Gascoigne, recovering from a broken forearm, yesterday saw a three-match ban and £5,000 fine added to his injury after the FA cracked down hard on his elbowing of Aston Villa's George Boateng.
fields.body:
Paul Gascoigne, recovering from a broken forearm, yesterday saw a three-match ban and £5,000 fine added to his injury after the FA cracked down hard on his elbowing of Aston Villa's George Boateng.

The former England midfielder, who was carried off after catching Boateng in the head in Middlesbrough's 4-0 home defeat on February 14, must serve the suspension from March 20 - hitting his planned comeback.

Gascoigne did not attend yesterday's FA hearing in Preston but Boro sent a letter, admitting misconduct but pointing out that their player had apologised to Boateng and insisting that the challenge had been "clumsy and careless" rather than malicious.

But the FA's punishment was heavier than that meted out this season to three players guilty of similar offences and also charged on the basis of video evidence. Another Boro player, Brian Deane, and Leicster's Matt Elliott were banned for one game apiece and Wimbledon's Ben Thatcher for two.

Gascoigne is back in training with a light plaster-cast on his arm and Boro had given him an outside chance of making his latest comeback in the derby at Sunderland on March 18.

With the ban starting two days later, however, it is much more likely that he will not return until April 15 - giving him a month's action, at best, before the season ends. Even if he is back for Boro midway through next month it will be only the 32-year-old's third senior game in four months. Before his fateful St Valentine's night date with Villa, Gascoigne had not played for two months.

 Up to 100,000 are expected today to line the 14-mile route from Stoke City's Britannia Stadium to St Peter's Church, where Sir Stanley Matthews' funeral service will be held at 1pm. The club are hoping the service will be broadcast in the stadium to ease congestion.

webTitle: Football fans lose fight for seats

fields.headline: Football fans lose fight for seats
fields.trailText: A group of Newcastle United football fans were yesterday told by a judge that the club was entitled to move them to another part of the ground to watch matches and to give their existing seats to corporate clients.
fields.body:
A group of Newcastle United football fans were yesterday told by a judge that the club was entitled to move them to another part of the ground to watch matches and to give their existing seats to corporate clients.

After a four-day hearing at the high court in Newcastle upon Tyne Mr Justice Blackburne ruled that the small print in the contractual agreement between the fans and the club entitled Newcastle United to move them even though they had paid £500 as part of a bond scheme to secure the seats.

The fans, who are all season ticket holders, claimed that they bought the bonds in 1994 after the club had guaranteed that they could have the same seat for 10 years.

Last October they were informed that they would either have to move to another part of St James' Park, Newcastle's home ground, to watch matches or pay £1,350 to retain their seats. The club said that the move was part of a £45m redevelopment and that extra revenue from corporate clients was needed.

During a four-day hearing the fans claimed that all publicity about the bond scheme and interviews given by club directors had strongly suggested that they would be guaranteed the seats for 10 years. The fans had the backing of the England manager, Kevin Keegan, who was manager at Newcastle United when the bond scheme was launched in 1994.

Jane Duffy, head of the Save Our Seats campaign, said after the hearing: "Today's ruling has irrevocably changed the face of football for the ordinary football supporter. If you are a season ticket holder your club can now remove you because they want to take the easy money from the corporate client."

Six fans had brought the test case on behalf of more than 2,000 bond holders. The judge gave them leave to appeal.

fields.headline: Henry's double triggers Gunners
fields.standfirst:
Arsenal 5 - 1 Deportivo la Coruna
Dixon 5 Henry 30 67 Kanu 78 Bergkamp 83 - Djalminha 55 pen
fields.trailText: Two goals in the last 12 minutes by the substitute Kanu and the outstanding Dennis Bergkamp all but assured Arsenal of a place in the quarter-finals as they overwhelmed the Spanish league leaders Deportivo la Coruna in a display of pace, power and, most importantly, goals.
fields.body:
Two goals in the last 12 minutes by the substitute Kanu and the outstanding Dennis Bergkamp all but assured Arsenal of a place in the quarter-finals as they overwhelmed the Spanish league leaders Deportivo la Coruna in a display of pace, power and, most importantly, goals.

Kanu's strike especially will always live in the memory of the Arsenal faithful. Pouncing on a defensive error he headed the ball clear of the chasing pack of Deportivo's defenders and let it run. With sublime skill, elegance and confidence which verged on arrogance, he just flicked his right foot over the ball twisted his waist and with keeper Songo'o falling on his back the Nigerian walked the ball into the net in what must surely go down as a classic moment in football history. With two touches he covered 30 yards beating defence and goalkeeper and walked the ball in the net. Magic.

Arsenal knew victory was essential to give them real hope of progressing to a tie with Parma or Werder Bremen. And Arsène Wenger must have been confident given that Deportivo had travelled as well as Bergkamp in the lead-up to this tie, losing four of the past five away games.

With the exception of the suspended Patrick Vieira, the Arsenal manager could choose from a full complement of players. And he surprised everyone by dropping not only Kanu and Ray Parlour to the bench but, most significantly, the captain Tony Adams. Last week Adams said he had been "kicking butt" in training. Now he was kicking his heels.

The pre-match explanation from Wenger was that the 33-year-old had a "small physical problem" after his return from an absence of almost two months at the weekend.

The unenviable task of filling Adams's boots fell to the Ukranian Oleg Luzhny. Also drafted in were Gilles Grimandi, Marc Overmars and Thierry Henry, and the pace of the latter two was instrumental to Arsenal's fantastic start.

With Bergkamp also in excellent form, Arsenal were irrestible. Playing at a far quicker tempo than Deportivo would have wanted, and passing and moving with purpose, they were two up inside half an hour.

The first arrived after only five minutes. Henry, a constant menace with his pace, was the architect. He controlled Martin Keown's pass near the left touchline, cut back past the 37-year-old Donato and crossed to the far post where Lee Dixon finished with a powerful header. Arsenal went close on several more occasions in an exciting, open start during which Deportivo also showed they could not be underestimated on the counter-attack. Bergkamp showed wonderful technique to control a long Dixon pass on his chest before twisting to send in volley which the Cameroonian goalkeeper Jacques Songo'o scrambled across his line to save.

Not long after, two Bergkamp corners further exposed Deportivo's vulnerability in the air. From the first Martin Keown sent a header inches over. Then Henry headed just over. Although David Seaman was briefly called into action to save a long-range free-kick from the Brazilian Flavio in the 25th minute, the home side's second arrived just before the half-hour.

Bergkamp sent his compatriot Overmars scampering down the right flank and from Overmars's cross Henry nipped in front of two defend ers to score at the near post. But for two alert saves by Songo'o from Bergkamp, the first at his near post and the second outside his area with his feet, Arsenal would have been out of sight by half-time.

It was hard to believe Deportivo were the best team in Spain. There was no doubting their skill in attack, where the Argentine Turu Flores showed flashes of magic on the left flank. But the defence looked shaky every time Arsenal poured forward and within a minute of the start of the second half Overmars had again forced Songo'o into a save.

There was bad news for Arsenal in the 52nd minute when Martin Keown was booked for a foul on Turu Flores which means he misses next week's second leg.Then shortly after wards, Deportivo won a penalty. Freddie Ljungberg was adjudged to have fouled Flavio and Djalminha impudently chipped in a penalty which briefly changed the complexion of the tie.

Things turned dramatically back in Arsenal's favour in the 65th minute when Djalminha, booked shortly before, was sent off after a clash with Grimandi. The Brazilian reacted angrily to a tackle by the Frenchman and, as he got off the ground, appeared to butt Grimandi in the chest. Grimandi. who may have been guilty of over-reacting, was booked as Djalminha received his second yellow card.

To Highbury's relief and delight, Arsenal wasted little time in making their numerical advantage count. Emmanuel Petit swung in a left-footed free-kick from the right flank and Henry rose unmarked to head in emphatically at the far post.

Arsenal l (4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Keown, Luzhny, Silvinho; Overmars, Grimandi, Petit, Ljungberg; Bergkamp, Henry.

Deportivo La Coruna ( 4-2-3-1): Songo'o; Manuel Pablo, Donato, Naybet, Romero; Mauro Silva, Jokanovic; Flavio, Djalminha, Turu Flores; Makaay.

Referee : A Ouzounov (Bulgaria).

fields.headline: What the world press says
fields.trailText: Urgency escalates in Mozambique
fields.body:
Urgency escalates in Mozambique

Meteorologists are predicting that a second cyclone, Gloria, now hovering in the Indian Ocean, could bring more heavy rains. Floodwaters from South Africa and Zimbabwe continue to spill into Mozambique's overflowing rivers.

"If that [cyclone] comes it will be a total catastrophe for this country," said UN World Food Program spokeswoman Michele Quintaglie. Four weeks of heavy rainfall was followed last week by Cyclone Eline, which battered rural coastal and southern low-lying areas.
Jon Peter, Washington Post

Children hard hit by floods

Children have borne the brunt of the trauma of the flood disaster that has devastated Mozambique. The lucky ones have been rescued after being forced to abandon their homes. But many others have been separated from their parents, and an unknown number remain stranded and face the threat of malnutrition, Unicef told IRIN on Wednesday.

According to UNICEF's Ian Mcleod in the Mozambican capital, Maputo, of the estimated 900,000 people affected by the floods, 180,000 of these are children under five. Out of the 230,000 displaced people who have lost their homes, children account for 46,000 of these.
UN Integrated Regional Information Network (IRIN) on Africa News Online

Mozambique's misery

More storms are forecast. Rain is supposed to fall on rich and poor alike, but this deluge has hit hardest those least able to cope. Mozambique, the poorest country in the region, is the worst affected. This is a cruel reward for all the efforts which had helped to turn this unlucky country into one of the world's fastest-growing economies, at last giving hope to a people who had been reduced, many of them, by two decades of civil war to wearing tree bark and eating wild berries.

The floods have pushed back into poverty large numbers of Mozambicans who had recently begun to lift themselves out of it. Just as bad, the flooding has almost certainly dislodged thousands of landmines and carried them into places previously considered safe. Mozambican peasants usually plant some of their crops on low ground, which is damper and more fertile, and some higher up, in case nearby rivers flood. But this year's floods are so much heavier than usual that not only have the low fields been turned to muddy porridge but much of the hillside crop has also been destroyed.
The Economist

World steps up Moz relief efforts

South Africa, Zimbabwe, Mozambique and Botswana - all victims of the devastating floods over the past months - are expected to meet in Pretoria on Friday to discuss emergency measures to help flood victims. Meanwhile, despite indications that the South African government will not send more than its eight helicopters to Mozambique because it will be "counter-productive", other countries are stepping up their relief efforts -- including sending more helicopters.

The Pentagon mobilised search and rescue helicopters, C-130 aircraft and as many as 900 troops on Thursday to help authorities in Mozambique and elsewhere in southern Africa cope.

European governments have announced plans to send up to 20 extra helicopters, while Germany has decided to send "up to 10 helicopters" to the region. A cargo plane is expected to leave Madrid on Friday or Saturday transporting five Super-Puma helicopters to Mozambique.

The South African governments position has also been criticised given the presence of numerous media helicopters, which are not helping directly with the rescue effort, in flood-stricken areas. .
South Africa's Daily Mail and Guardian

Floods: EU insists it acted quickly

The European Union on Thursday said critics of the West's response to the flood disaster in Mozambique have it wrong, as the EU had quickly committed millions of dollars in relief funding. Michael Laidler, EU ambassador to South Africa, insists the European Commission donated around $800,000 for immediate relief for flood victims within four days of realising the situation in Mozambique was dire. Another $4m will be handed over in the next few weeks.
South Africa's Daily Mail and Guardian

US sends rescue team to help flood-ravaged Mozambique

The United States began sending search-and-rescue teams to Mozambique today and sent additional emergency supplies in response to weeks of severe flooding in southern Africa.

The American aid is expected to eventually involve about 500 people, five MH-53 cargo helicopters and five C-130 transport planes, according to Capt. Bob Pritchard, a spokesman for the United States European Command in Stuttgart, Germany. Ten military specialists from Europe are en route to Mozambique to join a dozen others already there, Captain Pritchard said.

President Clinton said in a statement, "All Americans have been deeply moved by the tragic events in southern Africa."
New York Times

Mozambique: A country overwhelmed and destitute

South Africa answered with speed to calls for help emanating from Mozambique, but international organisations and the Mozambican government keep encouraging other countries to follow its lead. Because now is the time to act with urgency. The number of victims is still unknown, but already the World Food Programme estimates that more than one million Mozambicans have lost all possessions and 350,000 people have asked for emergency care. Approximately 100,000 people are still stuck in the midst of flooded grounds.

"In a few days the catastrophe made more damage than 16 years of civil war," sums up a humanitarian official. And as refugees flee the submerged zones, dysentery and cholera threaten to still add to the suffering already endured by Mozambicans.
Libération's Cape Town correspondent Maria Malagardis

UN Integrated Regional Information Network (IRIN) on Africa News Online Mozambique's misery More storms are forecast. Rain is supposed to fall on rich and poor alike, but this deluge has hit hardest those least able to cope. Mozambique, the poorest country in the region, is the worst affected. This is a cruel reward for all the efforts which had helped to turn this unlucky country into one of the world's fastest-growing economies, at last giving hope to a people who had been reduced, many of them, by two decades of civil war to wearing tree bark and eating wild berries. The floods have pushed back into poverty large numbers of Mozambicans who had recently begun to lift themselves out of it. Just as bad, the flooding has almost certainly dislodged thousands of landmines and carried them into places previously considered safe. Mozambican peasants usually plant some of their crops on low ground, which is damper and more fertile, and some higher up, in case nearby rivers flood. But this year's floods are so much heavier than usual that not only have the low fields been turned to muddy porridge but much of the hillside crop has also been destroyed. The Economist World steps up Moz relief efforts South Africa, Zimbabwe, Mozambique and Botswana - all victims of the devastating floods over the past months - are expected to meet in Pretoria on Friday to discuss emergency measures to help flood victims. Meanwhile, despite indications that the South African government will not send more than its eight helicopters to Mozambique because it will be "counter-productive", other countries are stepping up their relief efforts -- including sending more helicopters. The Pentagon mobilised search and rescue helicopters, C-130 aircraft and as many as 900 troops on Thursday to help authorities in Mozambique and elsewhere in southern Africa cope. European governments have announced plans to send up to 20 extra helicopters, while Germany has decided to send "up to 10 helicopters" to the region. A cargo plane is expected to leave Madrid on Friday or Saturday transporting five Super-Puma helicopters to Mozambique. The South African governments position has also been criticised given the presence of numerous media helicopters, which are not helping directly with the rescue effort, in flood-stricken areas. . South Africa's Daily Mail and Guardian Floods: EU insists it acted quickly The European Union on Thursday said critics of the West's response to the flood disaster in Mozambique have it wrong, as the EU had quickly committed millions of dollars in relief funding. Michael Laidler, EU ambassador to South Africa, insists the European Commission donated around $800,000 for immediate relief for flood victims within four days of realising the situation in Mozambique was dire. Another $4m will be handed over in the next few weeks. South Africa's Daily Mail and Guardian US sends rescue team to help flood-ravaged Mozambique The United States began sending search-and-rescue teams to Mozambique today and sent additional emergency supplies in response to weeks of severe flooding in southern Africa. The American aid is expected to eventually involve about 500 people, five MH-53 cargo helicopters and five C-130 transport planes, according to Capt. Bob Pritchard, a spokesman for the United States European Command in Stuttgart, Germany. Ten military specialists from Europe are en route to Mozambique to join a dozen others already there, Captain Pritchard said. President Clinton said in a statement, "All Americans have been deeply moved by the tragic events in southern Africa." New York Times Mozambique: A country overwhelmed and destitute South Africa answered with speed to calls for help emanating from Mozambique, but international organisations and the Mozambican government keep encouraging other countries to follow its lead. Because now is the time to act with urgency. The number of victims is still unknown, but already the World Food Programme estimates that more than one million Mozambicans have lost all possessions and 350,000 people have asked for emergency care. Approximately 100,000 people are still stuck in the midst of flooded grounds. "In a few days the catastrophe made more damage than 16 years of civil war," sums up a humanitarian official. And as refugees flee the submerged zones, dysentery and cholera threaten to still add to the suffering already endured by Mozambicans. Libération's Cape Town correspondent Maria Malagardis

webTitle: U-turn on water and telecoms "sickens" top Tory

fields.headline: U-turn on water and telecoms "sickens" top Tory
fields.trailText: March 3 2000: Angela Browning threatens to "puke"
fields.body:
The government was yesterday forced into a humiliating withdrawal of the telecom and water industries from its utilities bill following concerns over duplication of regulation.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers announced that the bill, intended to provide a better deal for consumers and boost regulation, would now cover gas and electricity alone.

The decision to include the other two elements in separate legislation provoked a row in parliament after Mr Byers was accused of going back on a manifesto commitment.

Conservatives condemned the decision as an `outrage' and an `affront to democracy' as one backbencher ripped up a copy of the bill. Liberal Democrats attacked the changes as a `shambles'.

Opposition spokeswoman Angela Browning lambasted Mr Byers for his constant refusal to apologise for the decision. `If I hear the secretary of state say once more he makes no apology I think I shall puke.'

The government insisted it had responded to the concerns of business. However, opposition MPs say that, while the changes are logical, ministers failed to heed warnings months ago that the legislation needed changing.

The utilities bill, which is at report stage in its passage through the Commons, was intended to cover the four privatised utilities. It aims to achieve a fair balance between the interests of consumers and shareholders, provide new powers for regulators and establish an independent consumer council for each utility sector.

The legislation was showcased in last November's Queen's speech as the department of trade and industry's flagship bill, intended to bring down electricity prices, in particular, by 10%.

Following the government rethink, regulations dealing with the telecommunications industry will now be dealt with in communications white paper published later this year.

Regulations for water will be dealt with in a water bill expected in this autumn's Queen's speech.

webTitle: Pinochet flies home a free man

fields.headline: Pinochet flies home a free man
fields.trailText: Augusto Pinochet was due to set foot on Chilean soil this morning for the first time in more than 17 months, bringing to an end any realistic chance of prosecuting the former dictator for crimes against humanity.
fields.body:
Augusto Pinochet was due to set foot on Chilean soil this morning for the first time in more than 17 months, bringing to an end any realistic chance of prosecuting the former dictator for crimes against humanity.

Last night human rights groups criticised Jack Straw's decision to halt extradition proceedings against the general on medical grounds, but declared that the Pinochet case was the most important precedent for international justice since the Nuremberg trials.

Amnesty International, which has been at the heart of attempts to bring Gen Pinochet to justice, said: "The fact that Augusto Pinochet was arrested - almost unthinkable 17 months ago - has sent a powerful message: no one is above international law, even when national laws offer protection from prosecution."

The departure of the Chilean airforce jet carrying the 84-year-old general from RAF Waddington in Lincolnshire at 1.15pm yesterday brings to a close one of the most intense legal and political dramas of modern times.

The general was informed of the decision that brought the saga to an end at 8am yesterday, when the home office faxed his lawyers with the news that the home secretary had decided not to extradite him.

Mr Straw, who has spent the past week considering representations on the medical report that found Gen Pinochet had suffered extensive brain damage as a result of a series of strokes, said nothing had persuaded him to change his original assessment that the general was unfit to stand trial.

News of the decision was greeted with derision by those still hoping that the former Chilean dictator would be put on trial, but in Santiago supporters of the general, many of whom had been up since the early hours waiting for the announcement, reacted with joy.

As soon as the solicitor general had announced that no charges would be brought against Gen Pinochet in the British courts he was free to go. Although Spain, Belgium, France and Switzerland - who all have outstanding extradition warrants against him - could theoretically have launched last-minute legal challenges to the the decision, none was forthcoming.

Baltasar Garzon, the campaigning Spanish judge who has orchestrated international attempts to bring Gen Pinochet to justice, made a final, futile attempt to stop the general leaving Britain, faxing a nine-page request to the crown prosecution service asking for an immediate appeal over Mr Straw's decision.

But Spain's foreign minister, Abel Matutes, reiterated the long-held position of the Spanish government that it would not authorise a legal challenge to Mr Straw's decision. The CPS said it could only act on instructions received through official diplomatic channels.

Joan Garces, a lawyer for Spanish victims of Gen Pinochet's regime, described Mr Straw's decision as "a political deal allowing for impunity".

Bernard Bertossa, the Geneva state prosecutor who filed an arrest warrant for the general's arrest, said he was extremely disappointed by the ruling. The Belgian foreign minister, Louis Michel, said the lengthy legal battle served "to show dictators past and future that history can catch up with them".

The incoming Chilean president, Ricardo Lagos, insisted this week that Gen Pinochet could be put on trial in the country. "If that were not the case, it would mean that our democracy is castrated," he said. But most outside observers expect Gen Pinochet to fade into the political background as he lives out his final days.

Defending his decision in the Commons yesterday, moments after the general's plane had taken off, Mr Straw said that throughout the saga he had been keenly aware of the gravity of the crimes committed by Gen Pinochet and of the desire for justice by those who suffered at the hands of the former Chilean regime.

But he said: "The trial of an accused in the condition diagnosed in Senator Pinochet, on the charges which have been made against him in this case, could not be fair in any country, and would violate article six of the European convention on human rights."

Mr Straw added: "This case has understandably aroused great debate and feeling, and its impact has been felt worldwide.

It has established, beyond question, the principle that those who commit human rights abuses in one country cannot assume that they are safe elsewhere. That will be its lasting legacy."

In a move that is likely to have far-reaching implications for future extradition cases, Mr Straw announced he intended to publish a consultation paper on options for streamlining extradition procedures in Britain.

After the decision Tony Blair told the cabinet that Mr Straw had dealt with the Pinochet affair "right by the book".

Lady Thatcher, a staunch supporter of Gen Pinochet throughout, said his reward from the government for being a friend of Britain during the Falklands war was "to be held prisoner for 16 months".

webTitle: Farmers say right-to-roam legislation will bring chaos

fields.headline: Farmers say right-to-roam legislation will bring chaos
fields.standfirst: The Countryside and Rights of Way Bill
fields.trailText: Farmers warned today that new laws giving ramblers access to four million acres of countryside would cause "chaos".
fields.body:
Farmers warned today that new laws giving ramblers access to four million acres of countryside would cause "chaos".

President of the National Farmers' Union Ben Gill called for cash to help pay for extra security he claims is needed to make the legislation work.

The long-awaited Countryside and Rights of Way Bill published today also introduces new safeguards for rare habitats - sites of special scientific interest, or SSSIs - and introduces tougher penalties, including prison sentences, for crimes against wildlife.

Environment minister Michael Meacher, announcing the proposals, said the "historic" bill signalled a radical improvement on rights of way. He rejected the suggestion that it would cost farmers a lot of money.

"The government's plans will not threaten landowners' and managers livelihoods," he said, stressing that the public would have a responsibility to "abide by sensible restrictions" and respect property.

Mr Gill said the bill placed huge new responsibilities on local councils and offered inadequate safeguards to farmers who manage open-access land.

"Without adequate funding, farmers will have to meet the cost of the government's aspirations. The minister says he does not believe the cost of the bill will be significant. I cannot agree with his statement," he said.

Farmers and landowners say they will need expensive extra security to protect vulnerable livestock from the threat of stray dogs. Although, under the provisions, they will be allowed to close land during the lambing season, weekends and public holidays are excluded.

"The lambing season does not stop for weekends or holidays," Mr Gill countered.

Mr Meacher said the law would also be changed to ensure that landowners could not be sued by walkers who injured themselves in accidents on their land - although farmers might be liable if ramblers hurt themselves on farm machinery.

Landowners will be able voluntarily to dedicate land not covered by the bill for public access, for example woodland and riverside.

Rights of way will be modernised, with new networks drawn up by local authorities. There is a new offence of "reckless disturbance" aimed mainly at curbing the menace of scrambler motorbikes.

The bill fulfils a Labour party manifesto pledge. Walkers have long complained of blocked footpaths and unreasonable attitudes from landowners, while SSSIs have suffered mainly through neglect.

Kate Ashbrook, head of the Ramblers Association's freedom to roam team, said the bill was "without doubt the most important piece of countryside legislation in 50 years... This is a dream come true for the British people, and on their behalf we thank the government for keeping its manifesto promise."

Tony Juniper, policy director at Friends of the Earth, said it was a "key step" towards halting the decline of Britain's wildlife.

webTitle: Yard's race squad may take over Telford inquiry

fields.headline: Yard's race squad may take over Telford inquiry
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard's racial task force is prepared to take over the inquiry into the hangings of two black men in Shropshire, Sir John Stevens, the commissioner of the Metropolitan police, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard's racial task force is prepared to take over the inquiry into the hangings of two black men in Shropshire, Sir John Stevens, the commissioner of the Metropolitan police, said yesterday.

If the chief constable of West Mercia, Peter Hampson, agreed, the specialist unit was ready to take a formal involvement in the investigation into the deaths of Harold "Errol" McGowan, 34, and his nephew, Jason, 20, in Telford.

The head of the task force, John Grieve, has been briefed and his officers are giving advice to local detectives.

Sir John and Mr Hampson have discussed the inquiry in recent days, but the chief constable will not countenance handing over responsibility to an outside force. Mr Hampson believes it would seriously affect the confidence of his detectives.

However, the home secretary, Jack Straw, has said he will review the case.

Clifton McGowan, Harold's brother, told Mr Straw at a meeting on Wednesday that the family had no confidence in the West Mercia force's handling of the case.

fields.headline: The price of life
fields.trailText:
As the international aid and rescue effort in Mozambique belatedly gathers 
pace, the British government is embroiled in an unsavoury internal dispute 
over who should pick up the bill.
fields.body:
As the international aid and rescue effort in Mozambique belatedly gathers pace, the British government is embroiled in an unsavoury internal dispute over who should pick up the bill.

Clare Short, the minister for aid and development, revealed in a BBC interview that the ministry of defence had offered her department the use of four RAF Puma helicopters - for £2.2m. It has since emerged that the MoD asked for guidance from the treasury, which advised that the normal rules for interdepartmental deals could be disregarded. But the defence bureaucrats went ahead and asked the full market price for lending its equipment.

The helicopters are now on their way, and the MoD has revised its charge to the department for international development, to £1.2m.

Tony Blair, meanwhile, has announced that the royal navy support vessel Fort George is also making its way to Mozambique with five more Sea King helicopters and emergency supplies. The cost has not yet been disclosed, but according to the prime minister, the government has so far stumped up £7.3m for aid and rescue work.

The squabble over departmental budgets was airily dismissed by a Downing Street spokesman. "There is no dispute. We are delivering more aid, more quickly, than any other country," he said.

But the row is unlikely to subside quickly. Iain Duncan Smith, the Conservative shadow defence minister, is busily making political capital by accusing the prime minister and chancellor of failing to step in to override departmental spending rules.

"They could have done that two days ago. The fact that they didn't get involved in this row; they allowed two ministries to row on for 48 hours before anything has been done, is the real criticism," he said.

The arcane financial procedures used by government departments in the age of market forces are unlikely to become a hot topic in the saloon bars of Britain. But the very idea of bureaucratic haggling over the cost of saving lives is deeply embarrassing for a government which boasts of its coherent and 'joined-up' working.

For two weeks, the public has been bombarded with media images of human suffering in Mozambique. More than £3m has been donated to a joint charity appeal, and more is pouring in by the hour. The pitiful plight of Mozambique has touched the hearts, minds and imaginations of the general public. Getting through to the bureaucrats and their political masters, clearly takes a little longer.

webTitle: Upping sticks, Upping your profile and Upcoming

fields.headline: Upping sticks, Upping your profile and Upcoming
fields.trailText: HUGHES THIS WEEK'S BIG SIGNING?
fields.body:
HUGHES THIS WEEK'S BIG SIGNING?

There hasn't been a big money move in the Premiership for a while now. Not since Colin Hendry joined Coventry for ten bob the other week anyway. So praise be to Stephen Hughes, who has just had a change of heart and agreed to join Everton for three - count 'em - million quid!

The Arsenal reserves and England under-21 midfielder was on the verge of joining the Toffees earlier this week, but player and club could not agree terms and the deal fell through. However, it appears the 23-year-old has decided it would be rather nice to play a game every now and then, and is expected to put pen to paper in a day or two. "We are delighted to have reached an agreement," said Walter Smith, sounding more like a very bored accountant than the manager of a major football club who has just landed his man, "and we hope the transfer will be completed early next week."

It's good news for England as well as Everton - a good prospect was wasting away in Arsenal's reserves. Hughes looked the business when he burst onto the scene with a series of assured displays and a blooter of a goal against Chelsea, but the stifling presence of He Is Emmanuel Petit and Pat Vieira ensured he languished in the reserves. Happily, young Hughes is now free and no longer threatened... hold on, did you just say Everton are reported to be interested in acquiring Rangers midfielder Jorg Albertz? D'oh!

WAKE UP, IT'S A BEAUTIFUL MORNING!

Got up early for the Manchester United v Liverpool game? Suddenly realised you don't have Sky? Well don't go down the pub to watch it - drinking this early just isn't healthy. Follow the game live from 11.30am on Football Unlimited with a nice glass of orange juice instead.

JOHNNY BE PATIENT

He may have presided over the worst result in the history of the fifth-best supported club in the world, but his self-confidence is in as good a shape as ever. John Barnes, the most popular man in Inverness, is raring to get back into the management saddle.

"I want to get back in football and if an opportunity comes along I will jump at it," said the ex-Celtic boss as he addressed a load of students somewhere in Oxfordshire. "It's not important what happened at Celtic," he unwisely opined, in a quote which will come back to haunt him after it has been printed out of context in the Glasgow press. "Things like that happen in football. I always look forward not back." You're telling us nothing we don't already know, John - you didn't spend much time looking backwards when plotting your defence-lite 1-1-8 formation, did you?

However, you can say what you like about Digger, because while his suits are bad, his heart is good. "I want to go into management again, not to prove anyone wrong but because I want to prove myself right," he pleaded without a hint of malice. Mind you, he can afford to be pleasant. When asked if Celtic sent him packing with £1m in his back pocket, Barnes visibly bridled. "People are saying I got a nice pay-off, but I didn't," he insisted. "I didn't even get half that amount." That still qualifies as 'nice' to the Fiver, Johnny boy.

QUOTE OF THE DAY

Patrick Vieira is being chased by Internazionale. But the French star is happy in North London and Inter may be forced to "settle" for Barcelona's Josep Guardiola instead.

Sir Stanley Matthews' funeral took place in Stoke today. Thousands of mourners stood silently outside St Peter's Church as the service was relayed to them via loudspeakers. Footballers through the generations, from Sir Tom Finney to Steven Gerrard, turned out to pay their respects.

The Arsenal reserves and England under-21 midfielder was on the verge of joining the Toffees earlier this week, but player and club could not agree terms and the deal fell through. However, it appears the 23-year-old has decided it would be rather nice to play a game every now and then, and is expected to put pen to paper in a day or two. fields.headline: Most wanted:  Yves Saint Laurent stamps
fields.trailText: For a truly stylish spring romance, we want love letters from Paris. Why? For the stamps, of course.
fields.body: For a truly stylish spring romance, we want love letters from Paris. Why? For the stamps, of course: not content with having his silhouette etched on to the last francs to be minted before the conversion to Euros in 2002, fashion legend Yves Saint Laurent has designed a set of heart-shaped stamps for the French post office. Don't get those on an email, do you now?

fields.headline: The Insider
fields.standfirst: She'd go to the parties, if there were any
fields.trailText: She'd go to the parties, if there were any.
fields.body:
Maybe it's because everyone's still partied out after the big 2000, but Paris is lying low. The Insider would like to tell of soirees every night, endless Krug and wanton dancing till dawn, but the reality is very different. After a month-long stint of fashion shows in four far-flung cities, the fasherati can talk of little else but health spas, chiropodists and colonic irrigation. Healing thyself is high on their list of priorities - and to this end, Mandarina Duck's little "happening" in Paris was well subscribed. The company sponsored three young designers - S Wauchob, Gaspard Yurkievich and Dorothy Perret - to show its small collections in a specially constructed venue with a chill-out zone (very un-Paris) which offered food and drink aplenty, a library full of the latest obscure French style mags and - joy! - free Shiatsu massages. We came. We ate. We stayed longer than was seemly.

Colette on the Rue St Honore is every fashion follower's first stop in Paris: the place to shop for ludicrously expensive clothes and limited-edition eye make-up remover. But the competition gets tougher all the time, and the latest fashionable Paris boutique - Beauty By Et Vous, on the Rue Royale - looks set to pack them in. It certainly did on the opening night: British journalists were delighted to see clothes by avant-garde Brit talents Robert Cary-Williams and Jessica Ogden, jewellery by Jade Jagger and smellies by Penhaligons and Molton Brown holding their own among an eclectic selection of desirable goodies from all over the world. Luckily, the crippling combination of homesickness and champagne dependency could be swiftly dealt with in the bar around the corner.

It was back to Colette the following night for "Rodeo Girl", an exhibition of portraits of American rodeo queens by US photographer Lisa Eisner. A full house of fashionistas braved a ground floor covered in wood shavings to support Eisner, a former American Vogue fashion editor, and take in the technicolour glory of the big-haired, pearly teethed, tight-jean clad rodeo girls - both on the walls and in the flesh, in the form of Miss Texas Rodeo, who had flown in specially. Sponsored by Polo Ralph Lauren, this was an all-American extravaganza: Bud replaced bubbly, while red bandanas took the place of the red velvet rope outside. And as if that wasn't more than enough atmosphere, waiters (serving the world's first, and possibly last, re-fried bean canapes) wore stetsons and T-shirts bearing the slogan: "If it's got tires or tits, it'll give you trouble." Charmed, we're sure.

fields.headline: Pretty in punk
fields.standfirst: As tartan, zips and studs loom large at this week's Paris shows, fashion editor  Laura Craik is happy to find timeless chic amid the anarchy
fields.trailText: As tartan, zips and studs loom large at this week's Paris shows, fashion editor Laura Craik is happy to find timeless chic amid the anarchy.
fields.body:
It was certainly a season of surprises. Comme des Garçons went punk: instead of showing in silence, it was Sneaker Pimps on the stereo and shrunken tartan jackets with Rei Kawakubo's now trademark (and much copied) bunched-up rosettes cascading over the collars and shoulders. Black-and-white layers of tulle sprouted from underneath mini-kilts in what was an aggressive, energetic collection full of zips, buckles and 70s Carnaby Street chic.

Where would designers be this season without the fertile plundering ground that is London street style? "There is nothing safe in this world," sang Billy Idol at the Ungaro show, and indeed he was right. Red leather blousons, tie-dye jeans and punky, studded T-shirts from the designer who dresses society ladies? Whatever next? Even Christian Lacroix, king of the ballgown, seemed to take his inspiration from Human League album covers, sending models out in drainpipe jeans, red stilettos and sequinned T-shirts, hair tied with giant bows.

By contrast, Valentino stuck with what he knows best: how to dress ladies. Pastel suits, cashmere jumpers and slithery eveningwear looked timeless and refreshing amid all the studded chaos. As did Dries Van Noten - a gorgeous show of chunky knits, stiff, patterned skirts, fur-trimmed coats and long, sweeping scarves. Plenty to wear here, and extra points for avoiding the retro trap. Gaultier, too, called his own tune. Trenchcoats, fedoras and mufflers made the models look like sleek private detectives, although we're not sure about the return of the stirrup legging. Knitwear was strong, as were accessories such as elbow-length leather gloves and thin clutch bags.

Something has been troubling me. Brand identity. What is it? How does a design house take its brand through to the 21st century? What makes a label sell: its name or the person behind it? If a designer dies or moves on, though, they find another one to carry on the name. The new designer might have a completely different style, but that doesn't matter because the brand is established enough to withstand the change. People will buy it regardless. Isn't that a funny concept?

Martin Margiela for Hermès adheres to the brand's equestrian roots: fluid cashmere duffles with leather fastenings, soft fur gilets, cropped leather gloves and flat riding boots. Burnt orange, navy, cream and black are the colours of Margiela's stealth wealth. Will anyone under 40 buy it? Perhaps not, but they will buy the Hermès trainers, which they'll wear with their Louis Vuitton bags.

Marc Jacobs is a far more irreverent designer: he cuts up the traditional LV monogram and makes it into sequins. Magnifique! Black leather wraparound skirts worn over cashmere leggings, slouchy petrol-blue jumpers that fell off the shoulder and jaunty black berets were all very 80s, as were drop-waisted dresses and baggy blouson jackets fastened with thick buckles and straps. A little bit bondage, a little bit retro. As for bags - ditch this season's shiny patent number. For autumn, your Louis Vuitton sac comes swinging on a chain with the LV picked out in studs.

So Vuitton has bags, Hermès has trainers . . . Chloe has sunglasses, if the success of last season's lunettes is anything to go by. Stella McCartney is always careful to integrate a wisp or two of Chloe's original spirit into her collection: it appears in chiffon blouses with beaded yokes and in the soft greens and lilacs of her colour palate. This was a strong collection that took as its inspiration nothing more complicated than Stella and her friends. It's what they wear to the pub: pieces culled from boyfriends and Bali and thrown on with typical rich-girl confidence. Cream canvas coats came with raw hems and shaggy fake fur lining, airy batwing blouses were accessorised with pretty African clasps, and jeans - the things that will sell - were drainpipe and emblazoned with a Chloe eagle motif on the bum.

John Galliano pitched his Dior collection at rich American rappers and all those who want to dress like them. Fur boots, crocodile leather skirts, ostrich skin coats, monogrammed trenches, CD buckles and necklaces had all the subtlety of Lil Kim at the VH1 Awards, but they were artfully cut and sure to find a market in today's climate of ghetto fabulousness.

What does Givenchy have that really rakes in the bucks? A cosmetics line and a loyal clientele - who might just find this season's punk aesthetic a little difficult. They should persevere, though. Mohair minidresses, stripy pelmet skirts and leather catsuits apart, there were easy tuxedo jackets and high-necked silk blouses, as well as gorgeous shoes in olive, purple or black with sexy silver ankle chains.

Yves Saint Laurent has Tom Ford, fashion's A-bomb. Poor Alber Elbaz is no more, despite sending out a collection that was vintage YSL reworked for 2000. Toffee-brown leather trenches, boxy pinstripe jackets and floaty chiffon dresses all came belted at the waist and topped with a fedora or tailed with wrinkly leather boots.

Fashion: it eats you up and spits you out. Today's brands are mercilessly consummate. Bald? Fat? Short? Spotty? Better send a body double to take your bows, or stay behind a screen. Design houses can take no risks with the message they put out. To be commercial, you have to be credible first. Sadly for some, it takes more than a shifty round the streets of London and a Clash/ Blondie/Death In Vegas soundtrack to achieve this. You can only fool some of the people some of the time.

fields.headline: Coming up Rosier
fields.standfirst: Yet another maverick young designer has taken the helm of a famous Parisian label. The difference is, this time he's French.  Jess Cartner-Morley meets the man who has taken over from Kenzo
fields.trailText: Yet another maverick young designer has taken the helm of a famous Parisian label. The difference is, this time he's French. Jess Cartner-Morley meets the man who has taken over from Kenzo.
fields.body:
Right now, Paris is enjoying what fashion people call a "moment". After a spell of watching from the sidelines, unamused and tight-lipped as a Victorian governess, while the eccentrics, show-offs and flirts of London, New York and Milan stole the fashion limelight, Paris is back on the sunny side of the street. Not only did this Paris Fashion Week boast a celebrity turnout that easily rivalled Milan's, but the audience, plastered in the city's evergreen monograms of Louis Vuitton's LV and Christian Dior's CD, looked as lovestruck as teenagers at a Ricky Martin concert.

The spring in Paris's step is largely due to the installation of new, ambitious young designers in the city's most prestigious ateliers. Christian Dior, Givenchy and Hermes have been given edge by John Galliano, Alexander McQueen and Martin Margiela. Louis Vuitton and Celine have reclaimed the cachet of a greed-is-good heritage under Marc Jacobs and Michael Kors, while Chloe has found modernity and sex appeal under Stella McCartney. But Galliano, McQueen and McCartney are British, Jacobs and Kors are American, Margiela is Belgian. For all the new blood in town, there has been little sign of French talent finding the spotlight.

Gilles Rosier has just bucked that trend. Long regarded as one of France's most promising design talents, yesterday he presented his first collection as womenswear designer for the 30-year-old house of Kenzo. But then Kenzo is hardly your average Parisian label - founder, Kenzo Takada, was one of the first Japanese designers to arrive on the Paris scene, launching his first collection in 1970. Ahead of his time as a designer, Kenzo was experimenting with ethnic influences long before it became commonplace to do so, and his freeform approach to mixing colour and print gained him almost instant attention and acclaim. By the time he retired last year, naming Rosier as his successor, Kenzo had more than 100 stores worldwide, and one of the most recognisable images in fashion.

Two days before Rosier's first show for Kenzo, and the Place Vendome workshop simmers just below panic level. The cast of models has not yet been finalised: those who have been booked are fitted, preened and polaroided by swarms of assistants and stylists who buzz about, while other tripping hopeful girls chat into their mobiles or coo to their dogs while they wait to be seen. Thirty hours earlier, Rosier was over in the Rue des Victoire presenting his own-name show, an accomplished affair with lean, beautiful tailoring pepped up with hard-edged leather and graphic patterns. All in all, he hasn't been getting much sleep recently, but in the midst of his colourfully-dressed assistants, Rosier, an unassuming figure in taupe carpenter trousers and cotton jumper, is totally alert and focused. If he was American, he'd be psyched.

Rosier, who will be 40 this year, is no newcomer to Paris fashion. Before launching a label under his own name eight years ago, he worked at Pierre Balmain and Christian Dior, and became assistant to Jean Paul Gaultier. He is happy with his first designs for Kenzo, he says, although he's "too exhausted to enjoy it now". There is an unmistakable Kenzo flavour to this collection, in the mixing of ethnic influences, strong colours and patterns: a kilt moves to reveal floral print between the pleats, a coat fastened just above the natural waist with a wraparound tie has a kimono feel to it, a floral-print is carefully layered on a whole outfit for a trompe l'oeil effect. "It's about mixing. The meeting of tribes, the mixing of rustic and precious fabrics. This is the code of Kenzo," explains Rosier.

Rosier is well aware of the importance of the Japanese heritage, not just within Kenzo but throughout Paris. "The Japanese designers changed Paris so much. I've been observing fashion for a long time, and when I was young the French - especially the Parisians - were very conservative; lots of dark colours, lots of grey. Kenzo had a new way of thinking that was always about the meeting of east and west. "I love that dynamic." Too sharp to pore over the founder's archives too slavishly - "It wouldn't be fair to him to copy what he already did" - Rosier wants to explore the east-meets-west theme, "but not to labour the ethnic influence. It's been used too much by people with no talent who don't understand it."

Although he had worked at Kenzo on a freelance basis for three seasons when the designer retired, Rosier was surprised when he was offered the job. "I didn't expect it because a lot of French companies these days look outside for designers. A long time ago, there was a tradition of an assistant working their way up, but in the past decade that has hardly happened in Paris at all. In Paris, it's too much about getting a big name, and not enough about supporting an industry."

It is an irony not lost on Rosier that it took a Japanese-founded Paris label to give a lesser-known French designer a chance.

Rosier is faced with the challenge of holding his own at a label strongly identified with one man's vision. It is a vision Rosier can identify with, luckily. "Kenzo was the first fashion designer who really seized on the idea of the melting pot as a humanitarian ideal. I have so much respect for that."

Rosier admires people with a strong individual style - John Malkovich, for instance - rather than fashion plates; and like Kenzo, takes a zealous interest in the dynamics surrounding him: for the past 12 years he has lived in the Bastille area (by coincidence, around the corner from Kenzo himself) which he loves for its "mix of old Paris and new Paris". Despite his workload, Rosier remains unabsorbed by the fashion world. When asked if he socialises much with fashion people, he looks utterly horrified: "No no no! That would be too boring."

But although Kenzo is still expanding, with a new perfume (called Time for Peace) just launched and a flagship store set to open in New York's SoHo this spring, Rosier is well aware that the brand needs to attract a new generation. This requires equal parts reinvention and reaffirmation. "Because I know that Kenzo wanted me to do something new, I am free to interpret the heritage in a modern way. It's a good time, because colour and print are coming back into fashion just now. So, lucky me."

webTitle: Most everywhere:  not putting your coat on properly

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  not putting your coat on properly
fields.trailText: Draping clothes around your shoulders in any fashion that might be described as nonchalant has long been considered a style no-no. However, wearing your coat cape-style is making a definite comeback among the fashion pack in Paris.
fields.body:
Draping clothes around your shoulders in any fashion that might be described as nonchalant has long been considered a style no-no. Just as tying a sweater around your shoulders is best avoided unless you're at Henley regatta, "shrugging" your coat on without putting your arms in the sleeves is unwise unless you are Grace Kelly. However, wearing your coat cape-style is making a definite comeback among the fashion pack in Paris. Maybe it's the influence of the New Affluence trend on the catwalks: wearing your coat like this makes you look instantly rich. The practical difficulties are enough to deter most sane people, however. You can't put your bag on your shoulder, you can't get anything out of your pockets and your coat might fall off into a puddle.

If you must do the shrug thing, at least make sure you've got the right kind of coat, preferably a cream cashmere jacket or tan leather car coat. Try this in a black winter duffel and you'll look like Darth Vader.

webTitle: New Labour keywords: Renewal, modernisation, and reform

fields.headline: New Labour keywords: Renewal, modernisation, and reform
fields.trailText: I have also compiled a computer 'corpus' of New Labour texts (as well as a smaller one of earlier Labour texts for comparison), which can be searched to give all instances of particular words or phrases.
fields.body:
I have also compiled a computer 'corpus' of New Labour texts (as well as a smaller one of earlier Labour texts for comparison), which can be searched to give all instances of particular words or phrases.

The New Labour corpus includes much of the material listed under Sources, but also additional material (e.g. extra speeches of Blair's). On the basis of a comparison between the New Labour and earlier Labour material, as well as a comparison of New Labour with larger, more general corpora of contemporary English, it is possible to identify 'keywords' of New Labour, words that occur relatively most frequently. The strongest New Labour keywords on the basis of this comparison are:

we
Britain
welfare
partnership
new
schools
people
crime
reform
deliver
promote
business
deal
tough
young

I shall periodically insert into the text a summary of information from the corpus about one or more New Labour 'keywords'. I shall begin here with 'new' and related words.

'New' occurs 609 times in 53 speeches of Tony Blair's between 1997 and 1999 (for comparison, 'modern' occurs 89 times, 'modernise/modernisation' 87 times, and 'reform' 143 times). The most frequent collocations [co-occurances between words in a text] are 'New Labour' (72 instances) and 'New Deal' (70 instances). The sense of political renewal conveyed by 'New Labour' is also evident in references to a 'new politics' (4 instances) and a 'new centre and centre-left' (2 instances). Political renewal is linked to national renewal in the slogan 'New Labour, New Britain', first used at the 1994 Labour Party conference. 'New Britain' is quite frequent (15 examples), and 'new' is also applied (7 times) to other international entities that Britain belongs to (e.g. 'New Europe', 'New Commonwealth'), and even the world (6 instances, e.g. the 'new world we are helping to bring into being'). Political and national renewal are linked to the 'new times' we live in Ü 34 instances, including also 'new era' and 'new millennium'. And there is a striking number of expressions (41 instances in all) for 'new ways of working' in government (that phrase occurs 8 times, 'new ways' 15 times, and 'new approaches' 11 times) and new relationships asso-ciated with them ('new partnership(s)' occurs 13 times). Another prominent set of meanings relates to ideas and attitudes (36 instances in all, including 'new ideas' (7 instances) 'new confidence' (4 instances), 'new sense of hope (or purpose, or urgency)' (5 instances), and there are 20 expres- sions referring to 'new opportunities' or 'new challenges'). Many 'new' Government initiatives are referred to (57 instances in all), such as the 'new active Community Unit', or a 'new National College for School Leadership', though unlike the 'New Deal' the adjective 'new' is not part of the title.

Despite the impression picked up by satirists that 'new' applies to everything and anything ('New Labour, new underwear'), it is used quite selectively for national, political, and governmental renewal in 'new times' which generate new opportunities and challenges and call for new approaches, ideas, and attitudes. It is perhaps 'modernise' that tends to be used more indiscriminately: 'modernisation' applies to the Labour Party, Britain, the Constitution, the Health Service, education and schools, the welfare state, defence, the Common Agricultural Policy, etc. In 25 cases 'modernisation' (or in a few cases 'modernise') is used in a general way without reference to a specific domain (e.g. 'money for modernisation' (the phrase occurs 3 times), or 'it is moderni-sation for a purpose' (5 instances)).

A striking contrast between 'modernisation' and 'reform' is that the former is overwhelmingly used with reference to the UK, whereas the latter is roughly equally used with reference to the EU. There is also a striking difference in terms of what is 'reformed' as opposed to 'modernised': the collocation 'economic reform' occurs 11 times, and 'reform' occurs 12 times with 'markets' ('labour', 'capital', or 'product') as its object, always with reference to the EU. By contrast, 'modernise' occurs only once with 'markets' as its object (and then the reference is to the EU) and once with 'the economy' as its object. So, economic change is 'reform' not 'modernisation', and it applies only at EU level, not in Britain. The only changes in Britain that are referred to as 'reforms' more frequently than 'modernisations' are 'welfare reform' and 'reform of the House of Lords'. Hall refers to the word 'reform' in the former as a 'weasel word' which effectively masks the 'ambiguity and duplicity' of New Labour around welfare reform is the welfare state being wound up, or truly transformed?

fields.headline: Blair's rhetorical style
fields.standfirst:
Blair and Princess Diana
The construction of a leadership personality
fields.trailText:
Blair and Princess Diana
The construction of a leadership personality
fields.body:
Tony Blair's style has been immensely successful. Perhaps the clearest example before the NATO war against Yugoslavia was his widely acclaimed success in 'capturing the popular mood' after Princess Diana's death in the autumn of 1997. Here is the beginning of the short statement he made on that occasion:

I feel like everyone else in the country today - utterly devastated. Our thoughts and prayers are with Princess Diana's family - in particular her two sons, two boys - our hearts go out to them. We are today a nation, in Britain, in a state of shock, in mourning, in grief that is so deeply painful for us.

Why were these words so effective in 'striking a chord' with many people? One important point is that it was not just his words but his overall bodily performance, the way he looked and acted, as well as what he said. But the language was an important factor. Notice in particular that it is a mixed language. There are two threads running through it. Let me 'extract' one of them:

Our thoughts and prayers are with Princess Diana's family, in particular her two sons, our hearts go out to them. We are today a nation in mourning.

This is the conventional sort of language that leaders use to speak on behalf of the nation on such occasions. Blair uses the first person plural ('we'), and predictable, pre-constructed expressions (cliches) - 'thoughts and prayers', 'our hearts go out to them', 'a nation in mourning' (once you hear 'our hearts' for instance on this sort of occasion, you can predict 'go out'). But threaded into this conventional public language is a more personal language (Blair begins speaking for himself, in the first person singular, and about his own feelings) and a more vernacular language. It is as if Blair (with his advisers - the speech has been attributed to Alistair Campbell) had started with the official form of words, then personalised and informalised it. He uses a vernacular language of affect as well as a public one - 'utterly devastated', 'in a state of shock'. Notice also the way he rewords 'her two sons' as 'two boys', which again is a shift between a more formal way of referring to them in terms of their relationship to Diana and a more intimate, family way. Blair says he feels 'like everyone else' - he is not only speaking formally for 'the nation', he is also speaking informally for ordinary people; and part of the power of his style is his ability to combine formality and informality, ceremony and feeling, publicness and privateness.

A crucial part of the success and apparent continuing popularity of Blair's style is his capacity to, as it were, 'anchor' the public politician in the 'normal person' - the necessary posturing and evasions of politics are it seems at least partially redeemed by Blair's capacity to reassert constantly his normal, decent, likeable personality. In his speeches and interviews there is always a mix between the vernacular language of the normal person and the public language of politics. The sort of 'normal person' that comes across is very much 'middle-class' and 'middle-England' in values, outlook and style. Blair's communicative style embodies the 'new politics' of the 'Third Way' in this respect, as also in the way he has learnt how to be 'tough' and how to assert moral authority in the way he speaks.

But Blair's leadership personality and style are not pre-given, they are carefully constructed. For instance, according to Gould, New Labour learnt the political advantage it could gain from being 'tough' and talking about being 'tough' (including using the word so often) from research on focus groups - Blair's 'toughness' has been self-consciously built into his communicative style as a matter of policy and strategy. Blair's apparent and claimed preference for acting on the basis of his political 'instincts' is at odds with the careful calculation of effects on 'public opinion' which goes into every move that he and New Labour make. Blair is, according to his biographer Rentoul, an accomplished showman, an actor. Of course, the circumstances of contemporary politics are not of his making - all politicians have to act, to pretend, or to put it more harshly (though not unfairly) to 'live a lie'.

But individual leaders can respond to those circumstances in various ways - by trying to be more accomplished at pretending than others, or by doing what they can to change the circumstances. Perhaps the charitable view of Blair is that it is not yet clear which he will do, but the fear must be that his is a particularly accomplished show. Certainly, there is some evidence that the claims, which his communicative style implicitly makes, about the way he relates to others are at odds with the way he actually relates to them - stories about Blair as a 'power freak' in the managing of the Government (including the Cabinet), the parliamentary Labour Party, and the Labour Party overall, are at odds with the polite, cooperative, open and relaxed personality conveyed in his communicative style. In this sense, leadership styles can 'lie'. Tony Blair may stand for New Labour in the popular imagination, but New Labour is in fact a rather disparate alliance of different political positions associated with different communicative styles (that of his deputy, John Prescott, for example). Although the emphasis in this book will be on Blair, it is important not to lose sight of these differences. Another important issue to keep in focus is how distinctive New Labour is, both from its predecessors in Britain and from similar political positions in other countries. This is relevant to questions of rhetorical style, as well as to the other two aspects of the language of New Labour I shall be dealing with Ê what similarities, for instance, are there between Margaret Thatcher and Tony Blair, or Bill Clinton and Tony Blair? Is the Blair rhetorical style a purely local and individual achievement, or is it part of a wider cultural change?

But threaded into this conventional public language is a more personal language (Blair begins speaking for himself, in the first person singular, and about his own feelings) and a more vernacular language. It is as if Blair (with his advisers - the speech has been attributed to Alistair Campbell) had started with the official form of words, then personalised and informalised it. He uses a vernacular language of affect as well as a public one - 'utterly devastated', 'in a state of shock'. Notice also the way he rewords 'her two sons' as 'two boys', which again is a shift between a more formal way of referring to them in terms of their relationship to Diana and a more intimate, family way. Blair says he feels 'like everyone else' - he is not only speaking formally for 'the nation', he is also speaking informally for ordinary people; and part of the power of his style is his ability to combine formality and informality, ceremony and feeling, publicness and privateness. A crucial part of the success and apparent continuing popularity of Blair's style is his capacity to, as it were, 'anchor' the public politician in the 'normal person' - the necessary posturing and evasions of politics are it seems at least partially redeemed by Blair's capacity to reassert constantly his normal, decent, likeable personality. In his speeches and interviews there is always a mix between the vernacular language of the normal person and the public language of politics. The sort of 'normal person' that comes across is very much 'middle-class' and 'middle-England' in values, outlook and style. Blair's communicative style embodies the 'new politics' of the 'Third Way' in this respect, as also in the way he has learnt how to be 'tough' and how to assert moral authority in the way he speaks. But Blair's leadership personality and style are not pre-given, they are carefully constructed. For instance, according to Gould, New Labour learnt the political advantage it could gain from being 'tough' and talking about being 'tough' (including using the word so often) from research on focus groups - Blair's 'toughness' has been self-consciously built into his communicative style as a matter of policy and strategy. Blair's apparent and claimed preference for acting on the basis of his political 'instincts' is at odds with the careful calculation of effects on 'public opinion' which goes into every move that he and New Labour make. Blair is, according to his biographer Rentoul, an accomplished showman, an actor. Of course, the circumstances of contemporary politics are not of his making - all politicians have to act, to pretend, or to put it more harshly (though not unfairly) to 'live a lie'. But individual leaders can respond to those circumstances in various ways - by trying to be more accomplished at pretending than others, or by doing what they can to change the circumstances. Perhaps the charitable view of Blair is that it is not yet clear which he will do, but the fear must be that his is a particularly accomplished show. Certainly, there is some evidence that the claims, which his communicative style implicitly makes, about the way he relates to others are at odds with the way he actually relates to them - stories about Blair as a 'power freak' in the managing of the Government (including the Cabinet), the parliamentary Labour Party, and the Labour Party overall, are at odds with the polite, cooperative, open and relaxed personality conveyed in his communicative style. In this sense, leadership styles can 'lie'. Tony Blair may stand for New Labour in the popular imagination, but New Labour is in fact a rather disparate alliance of different political positions associated with different communicative styles (that of his deputy, John Prescott, for example). Although the emphasis in this book will be on Blair, it is important not to lose sight of these differences. Another important issue to keep in focus is how distinctive New Labour is, both from its predecessors in Britain and from similar political positions in other countries. This is relevant to questions of rhetorical style, as well as to the other two aspects of the language of New Labour I shall be dealing with Ê what similarities, for instance, are there between Margaret Thatcher and Tony Blair, or Bill Clinton and Tony Blair? Is the Blair rhetorical style a purely local and individual achievement, or is it part of a wider cultural change? Go back to New Labour, new language?
