webTitle: Final farewell to the wizard of dribble

fields.headline: Final farewell to the wizard of dribble
fields.trailText: Thousands of fans flocked to the Britannia stadium in Stoke this morning to pay their last respects to footballing legend Sir Stanley Matthews, whose funeral was held today.
fields.body:
Thousands of fans flocked to the Britannia stadium in Stoke this morning to pay their last respects to footballing legend Sir Stanley Matthews, whose funeral was held today.

Crowds of people, many dressed in the red and white colours of Stoke, paid tribute to the "wizard of dribble", the Stoke City, Blackpool and England player who died last week after a short illness.

Fans, footballers and dignitaries clapped and sang as the hearse carrying Sir Stanley's body was driven onto the pitch. The funeral procession then began its 12-mile journey through Stoke to St Peter's Church, stopping at Sir Stanley's old primary school - where his footballing career began - his statue in the centre of the city and his Penkhull home.

The coffin, covered in the red and white of Stoke City, was brought into the church by former players Gordon Banks, Sir Bobby Charlton, Sir Tom Finney, Nat Lofthouse and two of Sir Stanley's friends, Pat Brogan and Don Corns. Of the 900 mourners inside, about 300 ordinary fans were given the chance to say a final farewell by footballer's family and his club.

During the one-hour service, Canon Ruddock said Sir Stanley was a man who provided inspiration in the depression of industrial decline in the Potteries and the north-west and elsewhere in the world.

"In the teeth of so much that sought to destroy economies and communities, Stan Matthews and his team-mates were having none of it," he told the congregation.

"Their skill and energy raised sights and aspirations wherever they went. They were not going to be overwhelmed or put down by anyone or anything. "And in the dark days of Apartheid, Stan, through his great teaching talents, brought joy and hope to many oppressed youngsters in the city of Soweto, in South Africa," he said.

The congregation also heard tributes from former Blackpool and England team-mate Jimmy Armfield, professional footballers' association chief executive Gordon Taylor, Stoke City director Peter Coates and the player's grandson, Matthew Gough. Jimmy Armfield said Sir Stanley was the "first real champion" of football who, like Joe Lewis in boxing, Australian cricketer Sir Don Bradman and Fred Perry of tennis, had brought the sport into the modern era.

"He was a man who could reach for the stars and still keep his feet on the ground. He had all the trappings of a champion. He was the role model of every footballer in the land."

Gordon Taylor said Sir Stanley would always be remembered for the 1953 Cup Final describing the 4-3 win for his side Blackpool against Bolton as "football heaven". "That was Stan's Everest," Mr Taylor said. "He had that special magic that anyone who knows football sees in a great player," he added.

The player's grandson, Matthew Gough, said: "He was a very modest man but he would have appreciated this gesture. He will always be remembered as a great footballer but the main thing is that he was one of the people, a really wonderful and really influential man."

Mr Gough read Rudyard Kipling's poem "If" which he said, his grandfather read to him at the age of 13.

"I really believed he strived to attain that," he said.

After the thanksgiving service, Sir Stanley's coffin was taken for a private cremation attended by family and close friends.

fields.headline: The old ultra-violence
fields.standfirst: After a 27-year absence, the infamous Clockwork Orange is back on screen. Peter Bradshaw applauds the return of the late Stanley Kubrick's dazzling, disturbing masterpiece
fields.trailText: Deserves to be called a work of raddled genius, if anything does, with all that the word implies of dysfunction, waywardness and dazzling, delirious insight. It is like seeing a mixture of Jacobean revenge drama, 18th-century picaresque novel, sci-fi porn and horror comic
fields.body:
"Why did they ban Chocolate Orange?" Ali G's stern question last year to James Ferman, the former British film censor, epitomises the alienated, semi-informed bemusement of an entire generation. In 1973, the late Stanley Kubrick instructed Warner Bros to withdraw from UK distribution his extraordinary, flawed masterpiece A Clockwork Orange, based on the Anthony Burgess novel. That remarkable act of selective self-suppression has meant that almost no one under the age of 44 has seen it in this country. And now, for the first time in 27 years, A Clockwork Orange is back on British cinema screens. We can all see for ourselves what the fuss has been about.

For decades, Kubrick's explicit and brilliantly scabrous fable of "ultra-violence" has existed only as a fascinating rumour. It has been a spectral, residual influence here, surfacing in strange, analogous forms. From the Sex Pistols, Bowie and Julien Temple to the Gooners and the Inter-City Firm, the film has persisted in making its shadowy inscriptions on our collective unconscious. Kubrick's diktat was taken very seriously by Warner Bros - what modern commercial auteur could hope now for that level of unquestioning corporate support? - and policed so vigorously that no video copies could legitimately be sold or viewed here; a screening at the (now defunct) Scala cinema in north London in 1993 led to prosecution.

For years, British fans of Kubrick were forced to watch A Clockwork Orange on grainy, exhausted prints at fleapit cinemas in Paris, Amsterdam and New York. It is only quite recently, with the growth of global internet retail, and the availability of a new generation of "multi-regional" DVD player, that we have been able to import the American DVD edition from amazon.com, albeit at the risk of confiscation by customs and excise.

As of next Friday, all this will recede into the legendary past. With it will go the strange dual reality for A Clockwork Orange: it has never been a "lost" or samizdat movie such as, say, Jerry Lewis's The Day the Clown Cried, being so freely available everywhere but here. So as a cinematic text, it has had a status at once marginal and canonical. However, there remains its strange position in the history of censorship. Was Kubrick effectively the victim of censorship, or its most notorious and autocratic perpetrator?

Without question, his film appeared to have been the inspiration for horrifying acts of rape and murder. Copycat delinquents and wannabe yobbos swaggered around London's west end and football terraces in bowlers and eyeliner, and these incidents were gloatingly magnified on the news pages and shrilly denounced in the leader columns. Outspoken judges hammered Kubrick's film, and home secretary Reginald Maudling solemnly requested a private screening.

Certainly, its reception as a film was very different from the purely literary reception Burgess had experienced when the book came out 10 years earlier, in 1962 - part of the huge frenzy of work Burgess embarked on when he thought (wrongly) that he was dying of an inoperable brain tumour. It seemed at this stage to belong to a more cerebral and muted tradition of satire and dystopia: the worlds of Swift, Orwell or Huxley. Provocative, yes, splenetic, certainly, but not incendiary, not an incitement to riot.

The book had no very great circulation until the film version appeared, based, to Burgess's considerable chagrin, on the American edition, which had excised a final, emollient chapter showing the older Alex appearing to repudiate violence. As a film, its context was quite different. It seemed to belong to a newer, 70s cinematic movement, along with Peckinpah's Straw Dogs and Jewison's Rollerball - sleeker, sexier, more troubling in their amoral violence. Kubrick himself could not or would not justify his film, so the job fell to Burgess; the worldly, well-travelled writer was a natural media performer, and one who was aware that he owed fame and fortune to Kubrick.

Only when Burgess was wheeled out did the general public become widely aware of the inspiration for the original text: an assault by four army deserters on his pregnant wife in 1944, an appalling event which he had creatively merged both with the Teds-and-Rockers clashes he witnessed on returning to 60s Britain after many years abroad, and the teenage hooliganism he and his wife had seen on holiday in Russia in 1961. This terrible personal history became a vital part of the Clockwork Orange myth. Burgess now assumed an unquestioned moral authority to speak in the film's defence, for had he and his wife not suffered directly as a result of precisely this sort of violence?

But, for all this, it was never banned. The film's commercial run ended; the moral panic subsided and the unspoken consensus seemed to be that there was no increase in the quantum of crime. Put baldly, the rapists and criminals were doing what they would have done anyway, except with funny make-up. It was only in 1979, when the NFT was unable to screen it for a Kubrick retrospective, that anyone realised what the director had done. Infuriatingly, Kubrick never favoured his audience with a clear explanation, leaving anti-censorship liberals like me unsure whether to revere him or not.

It may be that, with the magnificent self-belief of the artist, and displeased with a British establishment that had misrepresented a serious work of art, he was exercising his prerogative of deciding who gets to see his film and where. Perhaps he was sick and tired of being made the scapegoat for society's violence, or was understandably scared by (rumoured) death threats against his family. But withdrawing his film also looks, then as now, like a monumental loss of nerve, and a catastrophic concession to the pro-censorship lobby. Removing it from distribution here and nowhere else, and, moreover, appearing to retreat to the secrecy of his Hertfordshire hideaway, was arguably a pusillanimous abnegation of responsibility.

Why was it all right for the rest of the world to experience the socio-cultural consequences of A Clockwork Orange - whatever they may be - and not the United Kingdom, where Kubrick happened to live? Did the director believe his film really was dangerous? The only answers are to be found in the film itself, which anticipates in the most extraordinary way the whole question of censorship, screen violence, the imposition of power by the judiciary and media as the agents of the state - all the questions in which Kubrick and his most famous film have been entangled for nearly 30 years.

Seeing this remarkable and very British film for the first time is an exhilarating and disturbing experience. So far from being dated, it seems, in many respects, breathtakingly in advance of almost anything else around in its torsions and its longueurs, its magnificent coups du cinéma, its narrative scope and sweep, and its moments of sheer, bizarre offensiveness "intentional and unintentional".

A Clockwork Orange deserves to be called a work of raddled genius, if anything does, with all that the word implies of dysfunction, waywardness and dazzling, delirious insight. It is like seeing a mixture of Jacobean revenge drama, 18th-century picaresque novel, sci-fi porn and horror comic. Only in its quaint and questionable approach to women and rape is Clockwork Orange a let-down - of which, more in a moment. From the very first shot, of the charismatic tearaway Alex (Malcolm McDowell) smirking at the camera, we are immersed in the disquieting tale of the leader of a menacing gang of costumed "droogs".

They speak in "nadsat", Burgess's quasi-Joycean experimental youth patois, a hybrid of English, Latin and Russian, a literary and linguistic adventure that already puts this picture in an IQ league miles above everything else. They dress in fetishistic costumes and make-up, and stage sadistic beatings and sexual assaults. Alex is finally arrested and subjected to grotesque psychological experiments.

The shock of recognition is what hits you first. Is that a cherubic young Warren Clarke as Alex's mutinous sidekick Dim? Is that a sideburned Steven Berkoff as a thuggish police sergeant? Can that possibly be Michael Bates as the shriekingly malevolent prison guard - an actor that my thirtysomething generation remembers solely as the blacked-up punkah-wallah in the 70s sitcom It Ain't Half Hot Mum? A Clockwork Orange is a virtual gallery of British character actors, including Patrick Magee, Anthony Sharp and Margaret Tyzack.

It is at least partly their presence that gives A Clockwork Orange elements of an early 70s soft-core sex comedy - with McDowell as a kind of Bizarro-world Robin Askwith, larking about with his mates, picking up birds at the local record shop and getting laid. The rape scenes that caused all the flap then are pretty wince-making now: unpleasant and uncomfortable for the wrong reasons.

There are quite a few: a woman is brutally raped to Singin' in the Rain, while the audience is forced into the position of her husband, bound, gagged and made to watch. A woman is almost raped by a rival gang, and there is another sexual assault in the filmed violence Alex is made to watch in prison. A Clockwork Orange shows that the master's penchant for tits-and-panties semi-nudity did not begin with Eyes Wide Shut; there is a lot of raunchy sashaying about from bare-breasted women and the juxtaposition of these swinging moments with fairly crude rape scenes suggests that Kubrick mentally filed rape under "sex" rather than "violence".

The assault on the tramp that begins the film still delivers a spine-tingling shock to the senses: a hypnotically unpleasant moment. After a few liveners in the weird milk-bar, with its pseudo-sexy decor and fashion-shoot lighting, the droogs arrive at a strange, deserted underpass to see a drunk, prostrate tramp singing. When they sneeringly start to applaud, the sense of imminent violence is horrible, chillingly enhanced by its strange, semi-realist setting. This violence has been widely called amoral, and this is probably right; it was a misplaced gallantry for the film's supporters to claim it is "intensely moral".

That is not really true, though there is a queasy slickness to the violence, a balletic ritualisation that arguably acts as a prophylactic, as Alexander Walker has argued. (And the slow-motion scene of the droogs strolling along the marina is very reminiscent of Mr Blue, Mr Orange et al.) But what is also important is that A Clockwork Orange, in its own warped way, shows the consequences of violence, and gives violence an intelligible context. The tramp is not forgotten; he returns at the end and exacts a terrible vengeance. And we learn that the victim of Alex's rape died after the assault, ostensibly of an unrelated illness, but that her grieving widower knows in his heart that the rapist is guilty. It is a strangely affecting moment, unexpectedly drawing on the messiness and pathos of real life.

It is the scenes in prison that take A Clockwork Orange into the realms of inspiration; here it becomes a brilliant essay in cynicism and paranoia, rooted in an age in which Harold Wilson's progressivism had been trounced in the 1970 general election by Ted Heath's "Selsdon" project of political reaction, an age in which race violence was on the increase and the Northern Ireland Troubles had just begun.

Keen to clear "ordinary" criminals like Alex out of prison to make room for political subversives, the government makes him the guinea-pig for a fast-track rehabilitation-brainwash: an aversion therapy in which he is forced to watch scenes of violence, his eyelids clipped open, saline solution dropped into his flinching eyeballs.

The ghosts of Foucault and RD Laing attend Kubrick's vision of the state's economy of violence: how criminal aberrance is countered with clinical, scientific subjection. These scenes are unforgettably horrible and offer a prescient commentary on censorship: here is the traumatised cinemagoer, unable to stop the state flooding his consciousness with screen images of violence.

Is this the censor's world turned upside down? Or actually the power of the censor writ large - the censor's yearning to control and regulate human reaction to screen images? ("It's funny how the colours of the real, real world are not real until you viddy them on film," muses Alex between sessions, anticipating a very modern critical discourse on how we have come to think of screen representations of the world as more real than reality itself.)

Finally, Kubrick shows the nation being scandalised by this technique, via headlines in the Telegraph and the old broadsheet Mail - eerily, just the sort of newspaper hue-and-cry which would drive A Clockwork Orange off the screen.

What an incredible punch Clockwork Orange packs, like a visitor from another planet, among the production-line dullness of most cinema. This is ironic violence, stylised violence, but violence with human consequences and human cost.

The reissuing of A Clockwork Orange is a reclamation of part of movie history. While American movie brats such as Coppola, Scorsese, Friedkin and Altman were making the 70s a thrilling era for movie-making, it turns out that this country had a part to play in it as well. Here in Britain, Kubrick was showing that the spirit of the Easy Riders, Raging Bulls era was conceived not just in Los Angeles, Burbank and Manhattan, but in Radlett and Harpenden and St Albans. For all its flaws and cracks, this is a film that has to be seen, and its re-release is a festival day in the history of British cinema.

A very British nightmare

How the press reacted

"What on earth induced our censors to pass these startling scenes of rape and violence?... You could have understood a shoddy director dragging them in to gloss over his technical deficiencies, but there are no technical deficiencies about Stanley Kubrick and his film is far too good to need bolstering up with such repellent shock tactics."

Cecil Wilson, Daily Mail

"An essentially British nightmare in its attentions to caste, manners, accents and the state of mind created by a kind of weary socialism... A Clockwork Orange is so beautiful to look at and to hear that it dazzles the senses and the mind, even as it turns the old real red vino to ice."

Vincent Canby, New York Times

"Kubrick seems to be conducting a detailed investigation into the social, political, scientific and psychological control mechanisms functioning in contemporary man, and in the society that he has created. Nothing less."

Tony Palmer, Spectator

"Let me report simply that A Clockwork Orange manifests itself on the screen as a painless, bloodless and ultimately pointless futuristic fantasy."

Andrew Sarris, Village Voice

"The belief that our children will reproduce us is what has kept the race going, but seeing Clockwork Orange one's faith is blasted. From it one brings away the fear that our children will kill us all."

Alexander Walker, London Evening Standard

"It is not a film the memory of which you will exactly wish to cherish. You may even, like me, reject the glib and icy pessimism of its message. But you will, I can assure you, find it difficult to put out of mind."

Derek Malcolm, Guardian

 A Clockwork Orange is released on March 17.

 Find out more about Anthony Burgess on Books Unlimited.

From the very first shot, of the charismatic tearaway Alex (Malcolm McDowell) smirking at the camera, we are immersed in the disquieting tale of the leader of a menacing gang of costumed "droogs". They speak in "nadsat", Burgess's quasi-Joycean experimental youth patois, a hybrid of English, Latin and Russian, a literary and linguistic adventure that already puts this picture in an IQ league miles above everything else. They dress in fetishistic costumes and make-up, and stage sadistic beatings and sexual assaults. Alex is finally arrested and subjected to grotesque psychological experiments. The shock of recognition is what hits you first. Is that a cherubic young Warren Clarke as Alex's mutinous sidekick Dim? Is that a sideburned Steven Berkoff as a thuggish police sergeant? Can that possibly be Michael Bates as the shriekingly malevolent prison guard - an actor that my thirtysomething generation remembers solely as the blacked-up punkah-wallah in the 70s sitcom It Ain't Half Hot Mum? A Clockwork Orange is a virtual gallery of British character actors, including Patrick Magee, Anthony Sharp and Margaret Tyzack. It is at least partly their presence that gives A Clockwork Orange elements of an early 70s soft-core sex comedy - with McDowell as a kind of Bizarro-world Robin Askwith, larking about with his mates, picking up birds at the local record shop and getting laid. The rape scenes that caused all the flap then are pretty wince-making now: unpleasant and uncomfortable for the wrong reasons. There are quite a few: a woman is brutally raped to Singin' in the Rain, while the audience is forced into the position of her husband, bound, gagged and made to watch. A woman is almost raped by a rival gang, and there is another sexual assault in the filmed violence Alex is made to watch in prison. A Clockwork Orange shows that the master's penchant for tits-and-panties semi-nudity did not begin with Eyes Wide Shut; there is a lot of raunchy sashaying about from bare-breasted women and the juxtaposition of these swinging moments with fairly crude rape scenes suggests that Kubrick mentally filed rape under "sex" rather than "violence". The assault on the tramp that begins the film still delivers a spine-tingling shock to the senses: a hypnotically unpleasant moment. After a few liveners in the weird milk-bar, with its pseudo-sexy decor and fashion-shoot lighting, the droogs arrive at a strange, deserted underpass to see a drunk, prostrate tramp singing. When they sneeringly start to applaud, the sense of imminent violence is horrible, chillingly enhanced by its strange, semi-realist setting. This violence has been widely called amoral, and this is probably right; it was a misplaced gallantry for the film's supporters to claim it is "intensely moral". That is not really true, though there is a queasy slickness to the violence, a balletic ritualisation that arguably acts as a prophylactic, as Alexander Walker has argued. (And the slow-motion scene of the droogs strolling along the marina is very reminiscent of Mr Blue, Mr Orange et al.) But what is also important is that A Clockwork Orange, in its own warped way, shows the consequences of violence, and gives violence an intelligible context. The tramp is not forgotten; he returns at the end and exacts a terrible vengeance. And we learn that the victim of Alex's rape died after the assault, ostensibly of an unrelated illness, but that her grieving widower knows in his heart that the rapist is guilty. It is a strangely affecting moment, unexpectedly drawing on the messiness and pathos of real life. It is the scenes in prison that take A Clockwork Orange into the realms of inspiration; here it becomes a brilliant essay in cynicism and paranoia, rooted in an age in which Harold Wilson's progressivism had been trounced in the 1970 general election by Ted Heath's "Selsdon" project of political reaction, an age in which race violence was on the increase and the Northern Ireland Troubles had just begun. Keen to clear "ordinary" criminals like Alex out of prison to make room for political subversives, the government makes him the guinea-pig for a fast-track rehabilitation-brainwash: an aversion therapy in which he is forced to watch scenes of violence, his eyelids clipped open, saline solution dropped into his flinching eyeballs. The ghosts of Foucault and RD Laing attend Kubrick's vision of the state's economy of violence: how criminal aberrance is countered with clinical, scientific subjection. These scenes are unforgettably horrible and offer a prescient commentary on censorship: here is the traumatised cinemagoer, unable to stop the state flooding his consciousness with screen images of violence. Is this the censor's world turned upside down? Or actually the power of the censor writ large - the censor's yearning to control and regulate human reaction to screen images? ("It's funny how the colours of the real, real world are not real until you viddy them on film," muses Alex between sessions, anticipating a very modern critical discourse on how we have come to think of screen representations of the world as more real than reality itself.) Finally, Kubrick shows the nation being scandalised by this technique, via headlines in the Telegraph and the old broadsheet Mail - eerily, just the sort of newspaper hue-and-cry which would drive A Clockwork Orange off the screen. What an incredible punch Clockwork Orange packs, like a visitor from another planet, among the production-line dullness of most cinema. This is ironic violence, stylised violence, but violence with human consequences and human cost. The reissuing of A Clockwork Orange is a reclamation of part of movie history. While American movie brats such as Coppola, Scorsese, Friedkin and Altman were making the 70s a thrilling era for movie-making, it turns out that this country had a part to play in it as well. Here in Britain, Kubrick was showing that the spirit of the Easy Riders, Raging Bulls era was conceived not just in Los Angeles, Burbank and Manhattan, but in Radlett and Harpenden and St Albans. For all its flaws and cracks, this is a film that has to be seen, and its re-release is a festival day in the history of British cinema. A very British nightmare How the press reacted "What on earth induced our censors to pass these startling scenes of rape and violence?... You could have understood a shoddy director dragging them in to gloss over his technical deficiencies, but there are no technical deficiencies about Stanley Kubrick and his film is far too good to need bolstering up with such repellent shock tactics." Cecil Wilson, Daily Mail "An essentially British nightmare in its attentions to caste, manners, accents and the state of mind created by a kind of weary socialism... A Clockwork Orange is so beautiful to look at and to hear that it dazzles the senses and the mind, even as it turns the old real red vino to ice." Vincent Canby, New York Times "Kubrick seems to be conducting a detailed investigation into the social, political, scientific and psychological control mechanisms functioning in contemporary man, and in the society that he has created. Nothing less." Tony Palmer, Spectator "Let me report simply that A Clockwork Orange manifests itself on the screen as a painless, bloodless and ultimately pointless futuristic fantasy." Andrew Sarris, Village Voice "The belief that our children will reproduce us is what has kept the race going, but seeing Clockwork Orange one's faith is blasted. From it one brings away the fear that our children will kill us all." Alexander Walker, London Evening Standard "It is not a film the memory of which you will exactly wish to cherish. You may even, like me, reject the glib and icy pessimism of its message. But you will, I can assure you, find it difficult to put out of mind." Derek Malcolm, Guardian  A Clockwork Orange is released on March 17.  Find out more about Anthony Burgess on Books Unlimited.

fields.headline: Hamilton payment postponed
fields.trailText: Neil Hamilton today won a stay on paying costs of £500,000 incurred in his "cash for questions" libel defeat by Mohamed Al Fayed.
fields.body:
Neil Hamilton today won a stay on paying costs of £500,000 incurred in his "cash for questions" libel defeat by Mohamed Al Fayed.

Mr Hamilton and his wife, Christine, were both at the high court in London for the two-hour private hearing before Mr Justice Morland, who presided over the trial in December.

Reading from an agreed statement, the judge said: "Police investigations are being carried out into the circumstances in which certain confidential papers which had been in the possession of Mr Hamilton's lawyers came into the possession of unauthorised persons.

"Against that background, enforcement of the order for costs made against Mr Hamilton at the end of the trial has been stayed pending the outcome of the investigation."

When the deadline of the order expired a week ago, the ex-Tatton MP confirmed that he was not able to pay up, leaving the Harrods owner free to enforce the debt if he chose to do so.

Mr Hamilton hinted that "pretty sensational" developments were in the pipeline. He has previously alleged that Mr Fayed - who denies his claim - had paid £10,000 for documents taken from rubbish bags outside his lawyers' offices.

webTitle: Torture for Straw as dictator's Tory friends exult

fields.headline: Torture for Straw as dictator's Tory friends exult
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special reportLife in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: MPs knew that Jack Straw was sending Pinochet home, but he had to drag himself into the chamber to tell them in person.
fields.body:
MPs knew that Jack Straw was sending Pinochet home, but he had to drag himself into the chamber to tell them in person.

He looked pretty glum, but not half as glum as the MPs behind him. They were as woebegone as I can remember: eyes downcast, arms folded, shoulders hunched. Even junior ministers Mike O'Brien and Charles Clarke looked as cheery as Eeyore stuck on a Virgin train on a wet Tuesday near Widnes.

Of course nothing bucks up the Tories so much as seeing the other lot being hangdog, and they were all fairly merry. Lord Lamont (the head of "Tories for Torture" as Denis MacShane put it later) looked almost jubilant as he watched from the peers' gallery. And he was right to be so. No murderous despot could have hoped for a more loyal friend.

Mr Straw grimly ploughed his way through the vexed history of the affair. He had, he said, assembled a medical team of "outstanding national and international reputation" to give - and I paraphrase - the old bastard a once-over. He was grateful to these doctors. "They have performed a very significant public service," he said, to which Edward Leigh yelled happily: "They got you off the hook, Jack!"

Mr Straw said he had agreed to pass the medics' report to Spain, Belgium, France and Switzerland in strict confidence. "I regret to say that the content of the report was immediately leaked to the press." He looked pained at the venality of foreigners.

"What did you expect?" asked Eric Forth, sarcastically. I suspect Mr Forth doesn't hold with foreigners.

Mr Straw plucked a chestnut of good news from this fire. The case had had a worldwide impact, he said, and "it has established the principle that those who commit human rights abuses in one country cannot assume that they are safe elsewhere."

Since the perpetrator of these abuses was, at that moment, flying home enjoying the complimentary snacks and beverage service, this did not seem quite the perfect moment to make the point.

Ann Widdecombe looked as pleased as Ann Widdecombe ever does, which is roughly as pleased as Medusa on a bad hair day. She blamed the home office, and its "muddle, contradiction and delay", but did not have much to add. Jack Straw reminded her of the gravity of the charges: "He was accused of torture and conspiracy to torture," he said.

"Like Gerry Adams!" yelled another exultant Tory.

It was Jeremy Corbyn's turn. Mr Corbyn, I fear, tends to be predictable and over-excited. When you hear him called, it is like spotting the Socialist Worker logo on placards at a demonstration: you have the cosy feeling that you can probably ignore them.

On this occasion, however, Mr Corbyn was saying what Mr Straw might have said a quarter century ago. "Many people in this country will feel a deep sense of shame that General Pinochet has left British airspace. He has lived in luxury here and gone through the courts; his victims never had the opportunity for justice during his reign of terror."

After the ghost of Jack Straw Past, Mr MacShane sounded for a moment as if he was going off-message. "In accepting the home secretary's decision - 'welcome' would be the wrong word... "

MacShane off-message! The very stars would veer in their courses.

Luckily he was no such thing. Instead he found much cheer and comfort in what had transpired. "Pinochet has already been judged at the bar of world opinion," he began.

Ah, the bar of world opinion! Denis has sunk many a pint there, along with drinking buddies from around the globe, all muttering: "That Pinochet, he should get a good kicking, mate, know warra mean?"

Mr Straw still looked in urgent need of a drink.

webTitle: Pinochet arrives in Chile to mixed welcome

fields.headline: Pinochet arrives in Chile to mixed welcome
fields.trailText:
Former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet arrived back in Chile today, 16 months after he was detained in
Britain on torture charges.
fields.body:
Former Chilean dictator Augusto Pinochet arrived back in Chile today, 16 months after he was detained in Britain on torture charges.

General Pinochet's plane was greeted by Chilean flags, German march music and vociferous debate about his fate.

The general left Britain a free man yesterday after home secretary Jack Straw ruled that the 84-year-old former dictator was mentally and physically unfit to be extradited to Spain for trial on charges of human rights abuses.

Chile's top army brass gathered at the military section of the Santiago airport in a solemn welcome ceremony that displeased the government.

"It appears improper to organise this as if it was a party, in spite of the circumstances under which Pinochet was allowed to leave London," said interior minister Raul Troncoso.

Gen Pinochet left the plane in a wheelchair and was lowered to the tarmac on an improvised lift. Once on the ground, the 84-year-old former ruler stood up to the cheers of a crowd of gathered supporters. Using a cane, he walked over to the group and hugged and kissed several supporters and his grandchildren.

Smiling broadly, Gen Pinochet walked slowly and then boarded an army helicopter with his wife and children for a brief flight to the military hospital, where his daughter Lucia said he would undergo a series of medical tests.

Hundreds more supporters gathered in the streets around the hospital for a mass welcome. Security was tight at the airport and the plane's flight plan was kept secret.

Gen Pinochet was arrested on 16 October 1998 on a warrant by a Spanish judge wanting to try him for human rights violations during his 1973-90 dictatorship. Opponents tried to pave the way for a trial at home, asking the Santiago appeals court to lift the general's congressional immunity so he could be prosecuted.

President Eduardo Frei said "it is now up to the Chilean courts, not those of other countries" to decide "whether Senator Pinochet is responsible for the crimes he is accused of.

"No Chilean citizen is above the law."

Word of Gen Pinochet's release triggered jubilation among his supporters and preparations for a festive welcome. By midday Thursday, hundreds of Chilean flags had begun to appear on homes, buildings and lampposts in what mayor Cristian Labbe called "a spontaneous reaction by people who are happy with the return of the general."

Gen Pinochet's release disappointed opponents of the general. "It is disappointing, but we should not be sad," said Viviana Diaz, who leads an organisation of relatives of dissidents who disappeared after being arrested during Gen Pinochet's 1973-90 rule.

"We should now continue to work for justice," said Ms Diaz, whose father is among more than 1,000 missing detainees.

Demands also mounted for Gen Pinochet to withdraw from political life - a step that will be made easier later this month by a law that would allow him, as a former president, to keep his congressional immunity and salary and a security detail if he resigns his post as senator-for-life. He created that post in the 1980 constitution drafted by his regime.

"If he is so sick that he can't stand trial, he surely cannot be a senator," said leftwing congressman Juan Pablo Letelier.

Even foreign minister Juan Gabriel Valdes, who worked for Gen Pinochet's release, said the former dictator should not remain active in politics.

fields.headline: On the money
fields.standfirst: Film merchandising is big business - bigger than you think. These days, spin-off deals are struck by film studios before the cameras have even stopped rolling. Are we being treated like audiences or consumers?
fields.trailText: Film merchandising is big business - bigger than you think. These days, spin-off deals are struck by film studios before the cameras have even stopped rolling. Are we being treated like audiences or consumers?
fields.body:
He might not be as legendary as the man who turned down the Beatles, but spare a thought for the 20th Century Fox executive who OKed young George Lucas's contract for Star Wars. Lucas's agent wanted him to ask for a then hefty $500,000 upfront. But Lucas chose to ask for the merchandising rights instead. There are no official figures, but one decent estimate for the value of Star Wars products sold pre-Phantom Menace is $4.5 billion, or four times more than the cinema takings of the trilogy. Not all of that went to Lucas, of course, but you can see why he stopped directing films.

These days, everyone knows where merchandising fits into the order of things. Long before its late November US release, the licensing arrangements for the live action version of Dr Seuss's How The Grinch Stole Christmas, starring Jim Carrey, are being finalised. The hoped-for Grinchmania will come courtesy of burgers by Wendy's, credit cards by Visa, chocolate bars by Hershey, cookies by Nabisco, cereals by Kellogg's (of course) and all sorts of toys. The movie advertises the toys, and the toys and the burgers and everything else advertise the movie. And those arrangements are just for the US. Home licensing of the movies is done by the studios themselves: Sony, for instance, have a whole products division called Sony Signatures. But for the rest of the world, they use agencies to find the right chains and manufacturers to work with. One of the biggest is the London-based Copyright Promotions Licensing Group, who worked with Sony on Godzilla and Stuart Little (out in July) and are currently getting excited about the Charlie's Angels movie, which has only just started shooting and isn't due out here until December. Charlie's Angels is a big deal because most merchandising is aimed at kids or sci-fi fans. Sci-fi is ever popular, acknowledges CPLG's managing director Claire Atherton. And kid's movies are easily merchandised. Children see a movie, they want to be part of it and they use "pester power" on their parents. But Charlie's Angels is different. It has real thirtysomething appeal, Atherton says with relish.

While marketing aimed at 70s nostalgics is fair game, it's the targeting of children that gets parents' groups upset. But whatever they would like to believe, there is nothing new about it. Most men who grew up in the 60s or early 70s can bore you about Dinky or Corgi Batmobiles, Thunderbirds and James Bond Aston Martins, not to mention Six Million Dollar Man dolls. But tie-ins started long before that - the grandaddy of the business was Herman Kamen, the man who won the right to license Disney products back in the 30s.

What has changed is scale. In 1980 - after the Star Wars revolution - the sales of all licensed products worldwide were worth $10 billion. By 1998, they were up to $110 billion in the US. Movie tie-ins make up an estimated 22% of that total. The Lion King has generated $1.5 billion and rising in sales of licensed products.

Business is so good that one heretical consultant suggested to McDonalds that they should start regarding toys, not burgers, as their primary product. After all, no-one has ever rioted for a burger, but branches of McDonalds in Singa-pore were smashed up by rabid fans trying to get their hands on Hello Kitty giveaways.

"In our business, I look at box office, but then I relate that back to the sell-through of product at retail," says DreamWorks licensing chief Travis Rutherford. "Though many people say the two are directly related, oftentimes they're not. Box office can outsell product and vice versa." It just makes more sense to make films like Toy Story or A Bug's Life than the live action movies Disney used to do in the 70s. But that's no reason to shed tears over the triumph of commerce over art. "Toyetic" issues aside, you would have to be truly twisted to claim that The Computer Wore Tennis Shoes was better than Toy Story 2.

Just in case this all sounds glibly like a story where everybody wins (apart, obviously, from the sweatshop workers in China who actually make the toys and baseball caps), here's a cautionary tale. The Phantom Menace was meant to be the greatest thing in the whole of movie tie-in history. British publishers Dorling Kindersley were so convinced by this thought that they printed 13 million copies of Star Wars Episode I Incredible Cross-Sections and Star Wars: The Visual Dictionary. In the words of one veteran bookseller: "What the hell were they thinking of? You can't sell that many copies of the Bible!" Dorling Kindersley ended up with ten million unsold books, and an estimated pre-tax loss of $41 million compared to a $19 million profit the previous year. Dorling Kindersley CEO James Middlehurst did the decent thing and resigned. Maybe he's having a quiet drink somewhere with the man from Fox who signed away a fortune to George Lucas all those years ago.

Just in case this all sounds glibly like a story where everybody wins (apart, obviously, from the sweatshop workers in China who actually make the toys and baseball caps), here's a cautionary tale. The Phantom Menace was meant to be the greatest thing in the whole of movie tie-in history. British publishers Dorling Kindersley were so convinced by this thought that they printed 13 million copies of Star Wars Episode I Incredible Cross-Sections and Star Wars: The Visual Dictionary. In the words of one veteran bookseller: "What the hell were they thinking of? You can't sell that many copies of the Bible!" Dorling Kindersley ended up with ten million unsold books, and an estimated pre-tax loss of $41 million compared to a $19 million profit the previous year. Dorling Kindersley CEO James Middlehurst did the decent thing and resigned. Maybe he's having a quiet drink somewhere with the man from Fox who signed away a fortune to George Lucas all those years ago.

fields.headline: The Blue Bedspread
fields.trailText: I could begin with my name, but forget it, why waste time, it doesn't matter in this city of twelve million names. I could begin with the way I look, but what do I say, I am not a young man anymore, I wear glasses, my stomach droops over the belt of my trousers.
fields.body:
I could begin with my name, but forget it, why waste time, it doesn't matter in this city of twelve million names. I could begin with the way I look, but what do I say, I am not a young man anymore, I wear glasses, my stomach droops over the belt of my trousers.

There's something wrong with my trousers. The waist, where the loops for the belt are, folds over every time, so if you look at me carefully while I am walking by, on the street or at the bus stop, you will see a flash of white, the cloth they use as lining riding above my belt, peeping out.

There was a time when I would have got embarrassed, sucked in my stomach, breathed deep, held that breath. Or even shouted at the tailor, refused to pay the balance, bought a firmer belt, tightened it by piercing the leather with a few extra holes. But now, why bother?

All that matters is you, my little child, and all I want at this moment is some silence so that you can sleep undisturbed and I can get over with these stories.

I will have to work fast, there isn't much time.
They are coming to take you soon, the man and the woman. They will give you everything you need; they will take you to the Alipore Zoo, to the Birla Planetarium, show you baby monkeys and mother monkeys; the tiny flashlight, shaped like an arrow, that flashes, darts across the huge, black hemispherical dome. They will make faces at the monkeys, you will laugh; they will tell you where Jupiter is, why we have evening and why we have night.

And then, after several summers and several winters, when the city has fattened, its sides spilled over into the villages where the railway tracks are, where the cycle-rickshaws ply, if you grow up into the fine woman I am sure you will, one day you will stop.
Suddenly.

Something you will see or hear will remind you of something missing in your heart, perhaps a hole, the blood rushing through it, and then, like a machine that rumbles for a second just before it goes click, just before it begins to hum and move, you will stop and ask: Who am I?
They will then give you these stories.

**********

The house where we are, the room in which you sleep, is on the second floor. From the veranda, you can look down on the tram wires; the streetlight, the yellow sodium vapor lamp, is a couple of feet above you. If you strain your eyes, you can see dead insects trapped in the Plexiglas cover. How they got in I don't know.

Across the street, there's an oil-refining mill that shut down after a workers' strike long ago. But its owner, I guess, had some of his heart still left, so he continued to pay an old man to look after the dozen pigeons he kept in a cage near the entrance. Half of them are white, the rest are gray, and at least twice every day I stand on the veranda, nothing to do, watching the birds in the cage fly around and around.

White and gray, white and gray, like tiny clouds blown across a patch of imprisoned sky.

We are on Main Circular Road, which connects the north to the south of the city, the airport to the station, and right through the day buses and trams, trucks and taxis keep passing by, making so much noise that it's only now, well past midnight, that the ringing has stopped in my ears: the horns and the brakes, the angry passengers asking the driver to please slow down or stop, bus conductors coughing and spitting, jangling the bells, shouting their destinations in between.

Now it's just the opposite, silence sits in one corner of the house; when I move my head to the right, when I move it to the left, I can hear the stubble on my chin graze my collar, I can hear my breath, even the crick in my neck, some muscle being pulled, perhaps some bone rubbing against some other bone. I am not a young man anymore.

I am not going to type, since the noise may wake you up, the paper being rolled in, my clumsy fingers pushing the keys, the bell that rings at the end of each line, the paper moving up, the page ready to be rolled out.

And somewhere in the middle, if I wish to erase a word or add a letter, fix a comma, I will have to use the All-Purpose Correction Fluid. This means more noise: I will have to shake the glass bottle, open its cap, pull out the brush, let the white drop fall and then blow it dry with my lips. What if the bottle slips, falls on the floor?

At this hour, every sound gets magnified, every ear gets sharper.
I have heard that there are some babies who sleep undisturbed, even during the fireworks festival, dreaming silently to the noise of Catherine wheels and chocolate bombs. And there are some babies who wake up at the slightest of sounds, whose ears are like little funnels made of something like gossamer, ready to tremble, to catch anything in the night. A dog barking a dozen houses away, the wind blowing through the garbage dump, the ceiling fan, the tap dripping in the bathroom, the man beating his wife in the upstairs flat.

So where do I begin?
With you, the baby in my bedroom, on the blue bedspread, no taller than my arm, your tiny fingers curled up, the night resting like a soft cloud on your body. I shall begin with the phone ringing late at night, the police officer telling me that you have come into this city, unseen and unheard.

And once I have told you this story, I shall tell you more, as and when they come. I shall retell some stories, the ones your mother told me, even those that she told not in words, but in gestures and glances. Like that of the black-and-
yellow Boroline Cream banners catching the wind on Durga Puja day; the dead pigeon, its stain carried all across the city; the albino cockroach hanging, upside down, from the bathroom drain.

Or that evening in the maternity ward, when she stood in the room, your mother, in the hospital's oversize nightdress, looking out of the window at the streetlamps being switched on, one by one.

We shall visit all these places; I shall hold your hand, open all those rooms that need to be opened, word by word, sentence by sentence. I will keep some rooms closed until we are more ready, open others just a chink so that you can take a peek. And at times, without opening a door at all, we shall imagine what lies inside. Like the murder, the screaming, a red handkerchief floating down, just as in the movies.

In short, I will tell you happy stories and I will tell you sad stories. And remember, my child, your truth lies somewhere in between.

webTitle: Croat general sentenced to 45 years for war crimes

fields.headline: Croat general sentenced to 45 years for war crimes
fields.trailText: In its most significant verdict yet, the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal today sentenced Croat general Tihomir Blaskic to 45 years in prison for crimes committed in the Bosnian war.
fields.body:
In its most significant verdict yet, the Yugoslav war crimes tribunal today sentenced Croat general Tihomir Blaskic to 45 years in prison for crimes committed in the Bosnian war.

Blaskic, 39, was in charge of the HVO, the Bosnian Croat army that fought a bitter war against Bosnian government forces. During the conflict the Croats carried out repeated atrocities against Bosnian Muslims, notably at the village of Ahmici, where more than 100 men, women and children were slaughtered.

The verdict was the first against a senior commander by the Hague tribunal after years of dealing with relatively low level officers. The 45-year sentence sends a message that the tribunal plans to deal harshly with senior figures convicted of war crimes during the Bosnian conflict. The sentence should unsettle other suspects named by the tribunal but yet to be apprehended, most notably, Radovan Karadjic, the Bosnian Serb leader.

Blaskic was charged with 20 counts of crimes against humanity, war crimes and grave breaches of the 1949 Geneva conventions, which seek to protect civilians caught in warfare. His trial lasted more than two years. Witnesses included the former UK Liberal Democrat leader, Paddy Ashdown, and the former BBC war reporter, Martin Bell.

The general did not deny that killings took place but he vehemently insisted that he did not order them or have the power stop them. An international tribunal was established in The Hague to deal specifically with war crimes committed during the Bosnia conflict in the early 1990s. The first defendant, Dusko Tadic, was put on trial in 1996.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15 | Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes | Cheat's kitchen | The taste test: fresh pasta | Food on the net | On the menu: Tarocco oranges
fields.body:
Cheapskate . . . where to eat out for under £15

The Borrowdale Gates, Grange-in-Borrowdale, Keswick, Cumbria. Tel: 017687 77204.

This quintessentially English country house hotel serves a model Sunday lunch - three courses, chocolates and coffee for £14.50. It offers an impeccable fish and prawn cake with a foamy chive butter sauce, and memorable home made terrines (game, chicken and cardamom) with melba toast and chutneys. There's the melting lamb slow roasted with endive and red onions in unctuous gravy, or the faultless roast rib of beef and puffy Yorkshire puds for the traditionalist. Killer puddings include warm pecan pie, caramelised rice pudding with cherries, a definitive lemon tart or peaches in brandy with crème frache parfait.

Quick bites . . . where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Black Dog Inn, Dalton-in-Furness, Cumbria. Tel: 01229 462561.

Local Camra Pub of the Year 1998, so that looks after the beer side (Coniston Bluebird, Wye Valley Hereford Pale Ale, Yates Bitter, York's Yorkshire Terrier). And a dedication to local ingredients enlivens the grub side of things, especially bar snacks, so it's hey-ho for Cumbrian air-dried ham, bacon chops and Cumberland sausage. Does the heftier stuff, too - ham hocks and lamb shanks, game casserole and braised rabbit - but if it's the short, sharp snack you're after, there's a true home made soup, buttered kipper, proper ploughman's, hot bacon baps and hand-crafted chips, all for under a fiver.

Cheat's kitchen

Bean stew

Serves 4

1 onion, chopped

2 cloves garlic, chopped

2 cans red kidney beans

2 cans baked beans

1 can chopped tomatoes

300ml beef stock

3 tbsp tomato purée

55g butter

1 tbsp oil

1 Heat butter and oil in pan. Fry onion and garlic until soft.

2 Strain and rinse the beans. Add with the tomato, stock and tomato purée.

3 Simmer gently until it thickens.

4 Serve with sausages.

Mrs Jane King, Co Kildare, Ireland.

 If you have a tip for the Cheat's kitchen, please send it to The Guzzler, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3 ER.

The taste test: fresh pasta

There's pasta alimentare or pasta asciutta - dry pasta made from flour and water which lasts for ever. And there is pasta all'uovo - egg pasta made from flour and eggs, which is made to eat fresh. It's easy to make yourself, but then that's what supermarkets are for: to sell us what we can't be bothered to make ourselves.

Asda spaghetti

£1.39/500g.
At least it tastes as if it contains eggs. Decent firm texture, too.
****

Co-op tagliatelle

99p/250g
Nice clean texture. Hint of egg in there somwhere.
****

Pasta reale festivale

99p/250g
Faint taste of boiled wool, but not bad. Do not mistake for delicious buckwheat pasta.
***

Safeway paglio e fieno

99p/250g
Slightly slippery customer. Utterly neutral in every other way.
** and a half.

Somerfield spaghetti

99p/250g
It's got texture, but nothing else to write home about.
**

Tesco tagliatelle

£1.49/500g
Rather floury. Slightly stale. Poor quality flour?
*

Food on the net

www.teddingtoncheese.co.uk

For those mourning the decline of the cheesemonger, the net could hold the answer. Teddington's sources its cheeses from 12 different countries, and matures the 130 varieties at its own premises. Your order is cut from the round, wrapped in waxed paper along with strict instructions on aftercare and despatched in time for the next day's lunch.

Pros: Perfect condition and perfectly presented (no vacuum packs here). Plus info on suitability for vegetarians, pregnant women, etc, and on the making of the cheeses.

Cons: Delivery charges can be pricey unless you're ordering a lot.

Delivery: Order before noon and it's there the next day.

Charges: £5.95 per order.

On the menu: Tarocco oranges

An orange is an orange is an orange, is it not? Indeed it isn't. The proud, elongated Tarocco belongs to the mutant family of blood oranges, or, as mealy-mouthed supermarkets would have it, Ruby Red Oranges.

You're not suggesting GM sharp practice, are you? No. The Tarocco, and its cousin, the fully rounded Moro, are two of nature's wonders, first recorded in Sicily in the 17th century.

What's with the blood, paleface? It's a pigment, anthocyanin, which crops up in other fruits, but not usually in the citrus variety.

Does it do anything apart from produce this rather fancy colour? Well, they have a distinctive, slightly musky flavour and tend to be less acidic than your average orange orange.

fields.headline: Samurai meets Inuit at Kenzo
fields.trailText: Kenzo, one of the most colourful and unconventional names in Paris fashion, has been given a new lease of life by an accomplished first collection from Gilles Rosier.
fields.body:
Kenzo, one of the most colourful and unconventional names in Paris fashion, has been given a new lease of life by an accomplished first collection from Gilles Rosier.

Kenzo was founded in 1970 by Kenzo Takada, one of the first of a wave of influential Japanese to come to Paris. His fascination with travel, folklore and cross-cultural dynamics led him to introduce the west to styles that today appear natural - wide-legged trousers, or jackets in heavy cotton - with a flamboyant use of colour and print.

Rosier, whom Kenzo made his successor, is one of a very few homegrown designers amongst the British and American talent dominating Paris. He has designed under his own name since 1982, but he admitted before yesterday's show that there was "a lot of pressure, of expectation" for his first Kenzo collection.

The nerves did not show. Taking an eclectic mix of global influences from Samurai to Inuit, Rosier produced a chic, luxurious collection: wrap coats and tunics in leather were fastened with sash belts, kimono style, while tweeds and tartans were livened with flashes of bright Japanese-style flower print between pleats and in linings.

Fur hats and leather gauntlets looked warm enough for a Cossack winter - a little sombre, but lightened by an abundance of red and flashes of turquoise, and glittered lilies at the waistband. The silhouette was full-skirted and cinched at the waist, with outfits built from perfectly-fitting layers.

 Fashion's worst-kept secret became official yesterday when Gucci, owner of Yves Saint Laurent, announced Alber Elbaz was to be relieved of his duties despite an acclaimed show this week. Gucci's Tom Ford will design the line himself.

fields.headline: Thomson plays £100m catch-up
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Thomson Travel, Britain's biggest package tour company, is to invest £100m in a "clicks and trips" operation which will allow holidaymakers to book its existing programme and newly designed web vacations on the internet.
fields.body:
Thomson Travel, Britain's biggest package tour company, is to invest £100m in a "clicks and trips" operation which will allow holidaymakers to book its existing programme and newly designed web vacations on the internet.

Under its new chief executive, Charles Gurassa, Thomson has been criticised as slow to embrace the net as a sales outlet but said yesterday that it would also develop a strategy for digital television and other media outlets.

"We intend to align all of our retail, telephone and multi-media distribution capabilities to provide customers with the widest possible choice of how to search, browse and book their holidays whilst providing them with much more information on resorts and accommodation," said Mr Gurassa.

His promise came as Thomson admitted that earnings fell by 38% to £77m last year. That was despite a rise of almost £400m in sales to £3bn.

The group - which sold 7.7m holidays last year - was hit by price competition, a disastrous millennium season, over capacity and internal management difficulties which saw the departure of all the senior executives involved in the 1998 flotation, when the share price reached nearly 200p.

Thomson has issued a series of profits warnings and its shares have slipped remorselessly ever since flotation.

Mr Garussa, who joined the group late last year from British Airways, yesterday appeared to admit that Thomson had been slow to climb on the internet bandwagon.

He admitted Thomson knows little about its customers and he said introducing databases would be crucial to a turnaround. "I have 25m customers that walk into my stores and I don't sell to them, let alone recognise the loyal customers."

Shares slipped by 5p to 95.75p on the day although analysts welcomed the internet initiative.

This was coupled with the promise of £50m in savings every year and a pledge that Thomson's pre-tax profit margins would be "best in class" within the next three years - a departure from the recent policy to remain the country's biggest tour operator regard less of the discounts it has to offer to maintain that ranking.

Vernon Sankey, the chairman who joined after being ousted by Reckitt and Colman where his tenure at the top was judged lacklustre, described the latest fall in profits as a "wake up call". He admitted earnings were inadequate and said: "The process of change required to deliver substantially improved shareholder returns has only just begun and there is still much to be done."

He added that despite the poor financial performance Thomson's brand name was immensely well known and customer satisfaction was at a record level.

The company, which is holding its dividend at 3p, said that, although bookings for the summer were below last year the decision to reduce capacity meant profit margins should not suffer.

Mr Sankey said: "Thomson has outstanding brands and strong market positions. We now have the opportunity to capitalise on these even further by capturing the benefits of e-commerce and new media channels and applying them to our existing business."

webTitle: Let's hear it for Postman Pat

fields.headline: Let's hear it for Postman Pat
fields.trailText: Heard about lastminute.com and Amazon.com? Of course you have. There is money - and lots of it - to be made at the cutting edge of the new economy, where entrepreneurial flair meets the revolution in technology.
fields.body:
Heard about lastminute.com and Amazon.com? Of course you have. There is money - and lots of it - to be made at the cutting edge of the new economy, where entrepreneurial flair meets the revolution in technology.

Which is why the government could be sitting on perhaps the biggest e-business of them all: the Post Office.

On the face of it the idea of the PO as a trendy organisation is a bit hard to accept. Its image is not so much old as prehistoric - a million miles away from the internet start-ups that have become the darling of the City during these past few months.

But it only takes a moment's thought to realise that it has the ingredients to exploit the expected boom in online shopping in the next 10 years.

So far, all the attention in e-commerce has been focused on software. The action has been in ideas that save consumers time, effort and money through online services. A great deal of attention has been paid to what happens when a consumer sits down at a computer keyboard but not a lot to what happens afterwards.

What does happen is that for physical goods, as opposed to services such as insurance, somebody has to make a delivery. A book from Amazon, for instance, has to be found in the company's warehouse, wrapped and dispatched. Consumers have to be certain that what they ordered will turn up on time, which is why Amazon's sales tailed off before Christmas.

When it comes down to it, e-commerce is no different to mail order. It is not all that glamorous, and so some pretty unglamorous businesses are going to do very well out of it.

Manufacturers of cardboard boxes, sticky tape, bubble wrap and padded envelopes could soon be rubbing their hands in glee as orders flood in. If the weekly shop is sent round by Tesco or Asda, then sales of small vans are likely to increase.

But it is the PO which has the most to gain, with the internet offering it a way to generate extra revenue over the coming years as its letter monopoly is scaled back. It is in a position where it could clean up, provided that it can offer a rapid and guaranteed service.

The first steps are being taken to exploit the potential opportunities. A post office is being set up inside Amazon.co.uk to handle the growing book sales over the net; a scheme is being piloted which would allow householders to choose any time of day for delivery.

At the moment, only a small fraction of the PO's business is generated by the net, but it is forecasting growth of up to 75% in five years.

This process needs to be accelerated and expanded, and the white paper proposal to turn the PO into a plc, wholly owned by the government, should enable this to happen. There are some ministers who would like to privatise the business but are prevented from doing so by fear of the sort of backbench rebellion over rural post offices that scuppered Michael Heseltine's plans in the 1990s.

The concern of ordinary voters for their local post office is genuine and justified. It should be remembered that most people in Britain do not shop online.

Even so, there are no doubt people in Whitehall who are thinking that this would be a wonderful time to float the PO, with the opportunity to make some serious money for the treasury before the internet bubble bursts.

Image would still be a problem - as it already is for those many other solid citizens of corporate Britain from brewers to banks who have suffered in recent months because they lack the cachet to appeal to investors in these e-fixated days.

But there is an obvious solution to that. Rename it postmanpat.com instead.

fields.headline: The Vienna opera ball
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the Austrian social event of the year on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the Austrian social event of the year on the net
fields.body:
1. Vienna's glitzy opera ball was thrown into chaos last night when an actor dressed as Adolf Hitler (pictured left) turned up to register his discontent at Austria's far right in power.

2. Outside the building, 10,000 demonstrators blew horns and whistles and banged pots and pans to protest at the ball, the city's most prestigious social event.

3. The opera ball started in 1869 when the Emperor Franz Josef decreed that the Vienna opera house "should be used for the performance of operas and ballets as well as for the celebration of opera balls".

4. Since then kings, statesmen, politicians, artists and industrialists have gathered to watch and dance the waltz.

5. Not this year though: The absence of Portuguese president Jorge Sampaio (whose country holds the EU presidency) suggests that Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party (even without Herr Haider) are not welcome in the European political mainstream.

6. But a snub from John Wayne Bobbitt, famous because his wife sliced off his pecker, confirmed the contempt many have for the party. Bobbitt said involving himself with Herr Haider could damage his career

7. In defence, Herr Haider says he shares "amazing similarities" with Tony Blair, whose policies on asylum seekers Haider says are more extreme than his own.

8. And in a further parallel, the prime minister has lost the support of former Blairite celebrities who were once quite partial to a Downing Street cocktail party.

9. But Haider, previously targeted by internet hoaxers and the Belgian government, appears to have found a new, tougher enemy.

10. Arnold Schwarzenegger, Hollywood hardman and former Terminator, reportedly put pressure on fellow stars to say balls to the ball.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Blair Witch producers let plot slip, Billy Wilder honoured in Germany, George Lucas tops breadwinners list, Stephen Spielbery goes footie-mad, and Sandra Bullock on the casting couch
fields.body:
 Screen International today reports that the Blair Witch producers, looking to entice investors in the planned sequel, are giving away some of the plot. The film opens with three teens surfing the notorious Blair Witch web site and becoming so hooked on it that they decide to visit the actual scene, where they discover that the story isn't fiction. The trade paper reports that the film will be shot in the style of early 80s horror flicks.

 93-year-old film director Billy Wilder is to be presented with one of Germany's top honours - the Knight Commander's Cross of the Order of Merit - for his contribution to film. German Ambassador Juergen Chrobog will present the award during a reception in Beverly Hills next Friday.

 Forbes magazine has placed George Lucas at the top of last year's US celebrity breadwinners. The Star Wars creator earned $400m in 1999, more than double Oprah Winfrey, whose talk show and other ventures earned $150m and second place.

 If you haven't visited the Lord of the Rings official movie site in a while, it's worth another look (www.lordoftherings.net). The site has been extensively overhauled, and you can now email questions to director Peter Jackson, see filming taking place straight from the set of the film via a live WebCam, and receive emailed news of site updates.

 Over on Ain't It Cool News, a spy reports that Stephen Spielberg will be in Brazil in May to produce a documentary about football.

Casting couch

 Donald Petrie (My Favorite Martian) is in negotiations to direct Sandra Bullock in the comedy Miss Congeniality, which is expected to begin production by the end of the month. Hugh Wilson (The First Wives Club) exited the Warner Bros project last week over creative differences. Bullock portrays an FBI agent who goes undercover as Miss New Jersey at a beauty pageant in order to thwart the efforts of a group that threatens to bomb the event.

 Two Australian actors have apparently been cast in the upcoming Lord of the Rings trilogy currently filming in New Zealand. E! Online reports that Miranda Otto is to take the role of Eowyn vacated by Uma Thurman a few weeks ago, and actor Hugo Weaving (The Matrix) has joined as Elrond, the elven leader.

fields.headline: Madonna gets serious with Ritchie
fields.trailText: Madonna has revealed to the Mirror in an exclusive interview how much she adores her British boyfriend, Lock, Stock director Guy Ritchie - and says she may marry him.
fields.body:
Madonna has revealed to the Mirror in an exclusive interview how much she adores her British boyfriend, Lock, Stock director Guy Ritchie - and says she may marry him.

"I'm very happy," she said. "It's a very serious relationship. He's excellent." The superstar has recently set up home in London with her three-year-old daughter Lourdes. "Everyone in England seems to be so well-read and cultured... I love the English sense of humour and their dry irony," she told Mirror readers.

One of the pop divas best friends is none other than British actor Rupert Everett, with whom she stars in The Next Best Thing, which opens in the US today. However, while her lovelife might be scorching, it looks like Madonna, yet again, has failed to set the movie world alight.. "About halfway through, the story takes a disastrous turn and heads away from comedy into the land of suds and sorrow" writes the New York Times, while for Salon magazine, "it takes so many wrong turns it's barely an also-ran."

fields.headline: Modern biographies
fields.standfirst: ...to save you the bother of reading them
fields.trailText: Biography is the new black. Or the new Jilly Cooper. Or something. The old way of writing biographies was to do loads of research into your subject, and then, decorously and respectfully, write an objective and footnoted account of the subject's life. The new way, it seems, is to do loads of research and then just make it up.
fields.body:
Biography is the new black. Or the new Jilly Cooper. Or something. The old way of writing biographies was to do loads of research into your subject, and then, decorously and respectfully, write an objective and footnoted account of the subject's life. The new way, it seems, is to do loads of research and then just make it up.

Andrew Motion has taken this to its extreme with Wainewright The Poisoner. In the introduction he explains how he borrows words, filling in the holes in the Wainewright saga by telling it in the first person, and using his imagination for the bits he couldn't find any data for. (Some of the key material was waiting on the shelves to be unearthed, according to research by Marc Vaubert de Chantilly, but no matter.) Motion has obviously taken enormous pleasure in reproducing the 19th-century voice and gives Wainewright all the room in the world to make excuses and to apologise for the three murders he is believed to have committed.
Buy it at BOL

The funny thing is that this idea seems to have occurred to several biographers at the same time. Ann Wroe became obsessed with the haunting figure of Pontius Pilate nearly five years ago, but painstaking research turned up little more than the fact that, really, we know few facts about him. Never mind, she must have thought bracingly, we'll do supposition instead. And suppose she has (for 400 pages) in Pilate, drawing together every different legend, play and picture of him and, basically, just guessing.
Buy it at BOL

Peter Robb got lucky with Caravaggio (slightly more material to work with), but even he admits to just making up his own mind on certain points in M (such as the minor matter of Caravaggio's death - or murder). And, as with Motion and Wroe, Robb has taken a firm attitude on the prose front: make it visceral, make it immediate. He even makes up a name for his subject - "M" - because Caravaggio went by so many others. How impertinent is that?
Buy it at BOL

David Wilbourne's fictionalised diary of the Virgin Mary, A Virgin's Diary, does all the irritating things that this type of writing is capable of (and which the three above, to their credit, mainly avoid). Can anything be more aggravating than Mary's description of her pregnant cravings: "I gorge myself on loaves and loaves of flat bread, with sardines sandwiched between every slice. I'm sure I've eaten enough to feed 5,000 by now"?
Buy it at BOL

By contrast, Edmund Wilson's Dutch (admittedly, of all five he had most material: 13 years by Ronald Reagan's side) is wonderful. Yes, he cannot be bothered to write a totally straightforward biography, either. He talks about himself a lot (but after 13 years of research, you would feel a bit involved), and tells parts of the story in the style of a film script, a documentary, and through conversations with friends. It seems if you want to make this bid for biographical autonomy (we tell those stories, we'll decide what happened) the main qualification is that you have to be an absolutely brilliant writer. How fortunate.

webTitle: Plot thickens over Lara Croft role

fields.headline: Plot thickens over Lara Croft role
fields.trailText: It's one of the movie world's favourite topics: who will play cyberbabe Lara Croft in Paramount Picture's forthcoming big screen adaptation of Tomb Raider?
fields.body:
It's one of the movie world's favourite topics: who will play cyberbabe Lara Croft in Paramount Picture's forthcoming big screen adaptation of Tomb Raider? Variety has reported that Oscar nominee Angelina Jolie is in final talks to play the improbably buxom archaeologist in a live-action feature based on the hugely popular video game.

However, director Simon West (Con Air, The General's Daughter) was tight-lipped over his future star in an interview earlier this week with Entertainment Weekly.

The director claims he is searching for an unknown actress who can start playing the "James Bond of archaeology" this June. "We don't want to ram a Hollywood star into this thing, because Lara is visually [known]."

West's heroine will be more Alien-bashing Sigourney Weaver than Barb Wired Pamela Lee. Aspiring Laras should leave their wonderbras and lipstick at home.

And a further word of warning from the director: "No movie made from a videogame has ever worked". Nonetheless, West is hoping his summer 2001 adaptation of the phenomenon will be to Paramount what Batman was to Warner Bros: a big-budget, billion-dollar box office franchise. Stars already confirmed to appear in Tomb Raider are Brian Blessed and Rene Russo in cameo as Lara's parents.

Meanwhile, the Daily Express yesterday reported that the film's opening sequence will feature Lara Croft actually scaling London's 200ft-tall Millennium Wheel. The giant ferris wheel opened recently along the River Thames and, despite early problems, seems to be in full working order now.

 Shooting is scheduled to begin in May at Pinewood
