"We don't want to ram a Hollywood star into this thing, because Lara is visually [known]." West's heroine will be more Alien-bashing Sigourney Weaver than Barb Wired Pamela Lee. Aspiring Laras should leave their wonderbras and lipstick at home. And a further word of warning from the director: "No movie made from a videogame has ever worked". Nonetheless, West is hoping his summer 2001 adaptation of the phenomenon will be to Paramount what Batman was to Warner Bros: a big-budget, billion-dollar box office franchise. Stars already confirmed to appear in Tomb Raider are Brian Blessed and Rene Russo in cameo as Lara's parents. Meanwhile, the Daily Express yesterday reported that the film's opening sequence will feature Lara Croft actually scaling London's 200ft-tall Millennium Wheel. The giant ferris wheel opened recently along the River Thames and, despite early problems, seems to be in full working order now.  Shooting is scheduled to begin in May at Pinewood

fields.headline: 'Mockery' of Nazi victims by Irving
fields.standfirst: The David Irving libel trial: special report
fields.trailText: The historian David Irving was accused in the high court yesterday of "mocking the survivors and dead" of the Holocaust.
fields.body:
The historian David Irving was accused in the high court yesterday of "mocking the survivors and dead" of the Holocaust.

The allegation was made by the QC representing the academic Deborah Lipstadt and Penguin Books in their defence to Mr Irving's libel action against them over claims that he is a "Holocaust denier".

Richard Rampton put it to Mr Irving that by "mocking" eyewitness accounts during public speaking engagements, he was "appealing to, feeding, encouraging the most cynical radical anti-Semitism in your audience."

Mr Irving said that he was "mocking the liars" who had told untrue stories about what had happened to them.

Mr Rampton replied: "Oh, yes, but why the applause?"

Mr Irving, who is representing himself during his action before Mr Justice Gray, replied: "I am a good speaker."

Mr Irving, of Mayfair, central London, is seeking damages over Professor Lipstadt's 1994 book, Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory, which he says has generated waves of hatred against him.

The defence alleges that Mr Irving's audiences often consisted of radical rightwing, neo-Nazi groups. Mr Rampton reminded the court of what Mr Irving had said to an audience in Canada in 1991. Mr Irving then stated: "I don't see any reason to be tasteful about Auschwitz. It's baloney, it's a legend. Once we admit the fact that it was a brutal slave labour camp and large numbers of people did die, as large numbers of innocent people died elsewhere in the war, why believe the rest of the baloney?

"I say quite tastelessly, in fact, that more women died on the back seat of Edward Kennedy's car at Chappaquiddick than ever died in a gas chamber in Auschwitz.

"Oh, you think that's tasteless, how about this? There are so many Auschwitz survivors going around, in fact the number increases as the years go past, which is biologically very odd to say the least. Because I'm going to form an association of Auschwitz survivors, survivors of the Holocaust and other liars, or the ASSHOLS."

Mr Irving said there were no "skinheads or extremists" in the audience, who looked like a "perfectly ordinary bunch of middle class Canadians".

Mr Irving rejects the accusation that he is a Holocaust denier, although he does question the number of Jewish dead and denies the systematic extermination of the Jews in concentration camps.

The hearing was adjourned until March 13.

webTitle: Condemned Owls to shock flying Toffees

fields.headline: Condemned Owls to shock flying Toffees
fields.standfirst: Our man in the members enclosure at Newbury, Mike Hodgkinson, runs the rule over the weekend's big games
fields.trailText: Our man in the members enclosure at Newbury, Mike Hodgkinson, runs the rule over the weekend's big games.
fields.body:
There's hardly a punter in the land who'd wager against Everton beating Sheffield Wednesday on Saturday. By stuffing West Ham away last week, they confirmed that they've discovered a handy seam of form. American hit man Joe Max Moore continued his scoring run and Nick Barmby pitched in with a hat-trick. Everton must surely be banker material against a side that's pretty much dead in the water. Or perhaps not.

Sheffield Wednesday have an outstanding recent record at Goodison Park. It's a home from home for the Yorkshire side, who should be backed at 6-1 with Coral to cause Saturday's biggest priced Saturday upset. They've only lost one from their last eight on the Toffees' turf. And in the Premiership alone, they have won by two or more clear goals in four of their last six Goodison outings.

The home side's loss of Don Hutchison, now training alone after his highly public money wrangle, is sure to produce an adverse knock-on effect before long. Anything like a determined performance from Danny Wilson's men can earn them a win, even if relegation is now as good as certain.

Wimbledon are unbeaten in five trips to Derby and, on the strength of their point against Manchester United last week, are well placed to nick the victory on Saturday. The Dons' away form hasn't been up to much this season but Derby's home form has been atrocious. If lardy Georgian tearaway Georgi Kinkladze is as fit as he says he is, then Jim Smith may have reason to smile come quarter to five. But for our money, his relegation crisis look sure to worsen. The best price available for a Rams' defeat is the 13-5 at Stanley.

The weekend's glamour tie kicks off at 11.30am on Saturday morning, when Gerard Houllier's Liverpool travel to Old Trafford for what could well turn out to be the Premiership clincher. The visitors' best hope of beating Manchester United lies in the fact that Ferguson's defenders have been shipping goals recently - against the likes of Newcastle, Coventry and Wimbledon.

The resting of Mark Bosnich on Wednesday against Bordeaux may be more serious than the boss-man made it sound - basically, Boz from Oz cannot cleanly hit a deadball or backpass to save his life, regardless of how impressive the other facets of his game. The ex-Villa keeper has kept just seven clean sheets in 23 Premiership and European starts since he arrived in the summer and the rumour mill says that sturdy Dutchman Raimond van der Gouw is set to start after his faultless midweek European display.

Having said all that, the Merseysiders will be up against 'flying' Ryan Giggs, who has rarely looked more impressive than he has over the last few weeks. And the history book reveals that Manchester United have lost only one of their last 19 at home to Liverpool. Back the home side on this occasion, regardless of whether Michael Owen starts or not. And if you took our advice to back Liverpool for the Premiership from the start you'll be laughing whatever the result.

Recommended treble

Everton v Sheffield Wednesday - away win

Derby v Wimbledon - away win

Manchester United v Liverpool - home win

webTitle: MPs attack Smith's ban on Wembley athletics

fields.headline: MPs attack Smith's ban on Wembley athletics
fields.trailText: The culture secretary, Chris Smith, came under fierce criticism last night from MPs over his decision to remove athletics from the revamped Wembley stadium.
fields.body:
The culture secretary, Chris Smith, came under fierce criticism last night from MPs over his decision to remove athletics from the revamped Wembley stadium.

Mr Smith had taken "disproportionate" account of the views of the British Olympic Association in ruling that a removable running track envisaged for the new Wembley would be inadequate, the culture, media and sport select committee said.

But Mr Smith last night refused to reconsider his decision to turn down a £475m redevelopment scheme, drawn up by the Football Association subsidiary Wembley National Stadium Ltd, after the BOA complained the track would not be suitable for the Olympics. WNSL was told to return £20m of a £120m lottery grant, and athletics was removed from the Wembley redevelopment scheme, now concentrated on football and rugby league.

Problems stemmed from the "fundamental failure" to involve athletics officials in monitoring the planning of the new stadium, the committee said. But the removable platform plan was "commendable and innovative" and would be suitable for Olympic events.

MPs criticised Mr Smith for failing to properly consult other interested parties after hearing the BOA's concerns. The £20m was "an arbitrary figure plucked out of thin air," they claimed - although culture department sources said last night it had been agreed by the Football Association and offered to the government.

MPs also recommended the appointment of a minister for events, based in the cabinet office, to direct government strategy on events of international importance.

Gerald Kaufman, the Labour chairman of the committee, said Wembley was the best option for bids for not only the 2006 World Cup but also the 2005 Athletics Championships and a future Olympic Games.

The shadow culture secretary, Peter Ainsworth, said Mr Smith's position was now "wholly untenable". WNSL said the report "vindicated" its position.

But Mr Smith responded: "It would have been easy - and foolish - to proceed with athletics at Wembley." Problems with the platform might not have emerged for another five years, he said. Taking athletics away from Wembley saved £60m for another, better athletics stadium.

The committee itself had warned last May of the potential dangers of combining football and athletics in the same stadium, Mr Smith said. "As well as being both temporary and expensive, the Wembley option would have scuppered any plans to bid for a London Olympics. The government's decision not to proceed with the extremely expensive and temporary Wembley athletics option will make funding available to create a lasting legacy for UK athletics."

webTitle: Heseltine scorns Tory leader's euro policy as 'barking mad'

fields.headline: Heseltine scorns Tory leader's euro policy as 'barking mad'
fields.standfirst: Economic and Monetary Union: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Heseltine yesterday turned his formidable firepower on both William Hague and Tony Blair as he mocked the Tory leader for his "barking mad" European policy and rounded on the prime minister for his timidity over the European single currency.
fields.body:
Michael Heseltine yesterday turned his formidable firepower on both William Hague and Tony Blair as he mocked the Tory leader for his "barking mad" European policy and rounded on the prime minister for his timidity over the European single currency.

The former deputy prime minister warned that Britain would be severely damaged unless pro-Europeans challenged the "innate xenophobia" of the Tory frontbench and the government stepped up its efforts to join the euro.

Mr Heseltine's criticism of the Tory leadership, at a conference organised by Britain in Europe, the cross-party pro-European group, will come as little surprise to Mr Hague who took his Keep the Pound campaign to Wales yesterday.

However, his criticism of the government underlines the growing frustration of the Tory pro-European heavyweights who joined the Britain in Europe campaign last year only to find that the prime minister can barely bring himself to mention the single currency. With less than two years to go until the introduction of euro notes and coins in 11 EU countries, Downing Street is still sticking to its formula that it will consider holding a referendum after the next election if the economic conditions are right.

Mr Heseltine yesterday made his irritation with the government abundantly clear with a strong warning of the dangers of remaining outside the eurozone.

"We see [the dangers] today in the exchange rates where our own non-membership of the eurozone is threatening great swathes of British manufacturing industry," he said. "The effect of [the introduction of euro notes and coins] will unleash a range of competitiveness which is simply not understood."

Mr Heseltine then turned to Mr Hague, condemning his opposition to the government's national changeover plan which is designed to help British businesses prepare for the eurozone.

"You see the most extraordinary things said about the plans to encourage British industry to change its capacity to trade in euros, as though changing over your tills and cash registers is somehow a contribution to the sacrifice of your sovereignty," he said. "If you have 300m people who have nothing but euros to spend you have to be barking mad not to be able to take the euros."

Mr Heseltine said that dire warnings about the euro were fostering a dangerous psychology among business leaders who were "deluding" themselves that they could cut themselves off from the single currency. "I shudder at the dangers of this sort of innate xenophobic prejudice linked to the war over 50 years ago," he said.

He was withering about the Tory leadership's warnings that the euro would undermine British sovereignty. He reminded his audience that western Europe had guaranteed its post-war security by pooling sovereignty in Nato.

"The man in the desert is free," he said. "He has sovereignty, but he has no power. So the whole issue is about exercising real power in a context that is relevant."

fields.headline: Dobson 'make my day' jibe
fields.standfirst:
'Dirty Harry' challenge to Livingstone in TV debate
The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Labour's battle over the London mayor descended into farce last night when Frank Dobson tried - unsuccessfully - to force Ken Livingstone into declaring his hand by invoking Dirty Harry's "make my day" catchphrase.
fields.body:
Labour's battle over the London mayor descended into farce last night when Frank Dobson tried - unsuccessfully - to force Ken Livingstone into declaring his hand by invoking Dirty Harry's "make my day" catchphrase.

In the first public encounter between the two men since Mr Dobson won the Labour nomination, the former health secretary eyeballed his rival on BBC1's Question Time and asked: "Are you going to support me or are you going to stand separately? Go on - make my day."

Sadly for Millbank, which was nervously watching the encounter, Mr Dobson failed to have the same chilling effect on Mr Livingstone as Clint Eastwood had on his quarry.

Lacking Dirty Harry's gun and confident poise, Mr Dobson failed to rattle Mr Livingstone, who remained unmoved by the challenge. In an elliptical response, the former GLC leader said he would give Labour time to "sort out the mess" and embrace him as the party's official candidate.

The Labour party's unlikely incarnation of Dirty Harry made an 11th-hour decision to appear alongside Mr Livingstone in an attempt to quash rumours that he would stand down as Labour's candidate and to force his rival into stating whether he would stand as an independent.

Angered by rumours circulating at Westminster all week that he is planning to stand down, Mr Dobson insisted that he was determined to remain in the fray.

"Let me make it clear Ken, I have made up my mind," he said. "I will say it to your face. I am the official Labour candidate. I am not going to stand down. No matter how much you and your friends organise within the Labour party in London to try and have a go at me I will not change my mind."

Mr Livingstone, who won the overwhelming support of London Labour members in the party's mayoral ballot, made clear on Question Time last night that he was still determined to oust Mr Dobson as the Labour candidate.

In heated exchanges, he said: "It's no good Frank, simply saying, 'I'm not going to change my mind, I'm not going to listen.' Londoners expect you to listen. Londoners would rather you stood down, so the Labour party members get the candidate they voted for, which is me."

However, the normally confident Mr Livingstone also betrayed nerves as he refused to make clear whether he would stand as an independent after his earlier insistence that he would support Labour's official candidate. His voice almost breaking, he said: "This is the most difficult decision in my life. I don't want to break my word, but at the same time I am being deluged by ordinary people in London who want me to stand."

The television spat between Mr Dobson and Mr Livingstone came after the government finally backed down over the issue of freepost mailshots for the election, agreeing a compromise that will see every voter sent a booklet with addresses from each candidate.

fields.headline: Protests over cemetery monument
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Democratic Unionists yesterday demanded that a 10ft statue of an armed terrorist be removed immediately from a cemetery in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Democratic Unionists yesterday demanded that a 10ft statue of an armed terrorist be removed immediately from a cemetery in Northern Ireland.

The granite sculpture, commissioned by the Irish Republican Socialist party, the political wing of the Irish National Liberation Army, has been erected in Londonderry city cemetery and is to be formally unveiled by hardline republicans this weekend.

It depicts a man standing guard with a rifle, dressed in combat clothing, a scarf, beret and dark glasses, and commemorates the 10 Provisional IRA and INLA men who died on hunger strike in 1981.

The Democratic Unionist MLA Gregory Campbell said the monument was "enormously offensive" for a cemetery in which people from both political traditions were buried.

"One of the worst terrorist atrocities in the entire history of the troubles was by the INLA, 12 miles from the city cemetery, in Ballykelly," he said. "Seventeen people were murdered by an INLA bomb in the Droppin' Well bar in 1982."

A spokeswoman for Londonderry city council said permission had been granted for the memorial, but in light of the row the city engineer was compiling a report to be presented to the council this month.

fields.headline: West exposed by disaster
fields.standfirst: A month after the first warnings, there is still no strategy to stem the sufferingMozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: A month after the first warnings, there is still no strategy to stem the suffering.
fields.byline: Owen Bowcott, Chris McGreal  in Chokwe  and Richard Norton-Taylor
fields.body:
A gigantic Antonov 124 transporter flew south ferrying an emergency airlift of RAF helicopters last night as the government was reinforcing its multimillion-pound efforts to rescue thousands trapped by rising floodwater in Mozambique.

The launch of a celebrity-led appeal yesterday by the Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC), representing 11 major charities, may mobilise further public support and raise millions more. Behind the popular enthusiasm, however, an inter-departmental political storm is brewing over delays in despatching helicopters to the flooded region.

Last night it became clear that the ministry of defence (MoD), which initially told the department for international development (DfID) that it should bear the cost of transporting helicopters to the disaster region, had offered to share the bill.

The MoD at first asked DfID for £2.2m for the package of 100 RAF pilots, support staff, four Puma helicopters and the freight transporter fare to Mozambique. By last night the cost had been halved to £1.15m. In a change of approach, military sources were agreeing to "defray some of the costs". Having already spent £6m on aid to Mozambique, Britain is now one of the largest international donors.

For those in southern Africa who have watched since the rains came a month ago, a more fundamental flaw has been lack of planning: only television pictures of refugees clinging to the treetops panicked the international aid community into the necessary response.

All along, local observers have argued, the UN and foreign governments have responded to each twist of the crisis belatedly and with little forethought to what might happen next. There have been more than a few warnings that Mozambique's misery was only going to worsen.

The downpour which struck at the end of January dumped a year's rainfall on the country in the space of four days. They were the heaviest for half a century. After the first floods, Britain and other governments funded the usual emergency medical supplies and tenting and food. South Africa sent five helicopters to lift food and other aid to the homeless.

One puzzle is how, with so many experienced aid agencies present, it could take so long to recognise the urgent need for helicopters and boats.

Two weeks ago, Cyclone Eline began tearing through Madagascar, where it left seven people dead. Then it turned toward Mozambique. By then, the UN had a contingent from its office for the coordination of humanitarian affairs in Maputo planning how to deal with the existing floods. Britain's DfID sent a team on February 11.

Eline did not prove to be as devastating as feared, although it drove tens of thousands from their homes. Aid donors took it as a sign that the worst was past. But it was a false dawn.

It went unnoticed that Cyclone Eline was pouring huge amounts of waters into the already swollen Limpopo and Save rivers in South Africa and Zimbabwe. No one planned for what would happen when that water came back down the rivers and into Mozambique.

They discovered in the middle of last Saturday night. There was no preparation by foreign donors. It was already evident that helicopters would be crucial, but as the flooding consumed entire towns, no one had resolved the question of who was going to pay for the existing five South African helicopters let alone additional aircraft.

Aid agencies have admitted they were caught unawares by the opening of overwhelmed dams upstream in Zimbabwe and South Africa. They were also not prepared to help with rescue efforts. "We would be looking to governments and armed forces for that," said Nicola Pazdzierska of the DEC. "It's not what humanitarian agencies are all about."

The Red Cross took a similar view. "Helicopters are very expensive," said a spokeswoman. "We don't see ourselves as a rescue service. We are more of a service to help people once they have been rescued." At one stage, she added, they had inquired about hiring an aircraft and be told it was $80,000 a day.

The Mozambique disaster has exposed an embarrassing weakness in Britain's military ability to mount operations involving the movement of heavy equipment, such as helicopters and boats. This gap in the MoD's capability was singled out in the 1988 strategic defence review: RAF Hercules transporters are too small to carry large helicopters.

DfID's first instinct was to charter local South African helicopters; they were nearer. But on Monday (according to DfID) or Tuesday (according to the MoD), Clare Short's department asked the MoD if it could spare some helicopters.

"There were none within 3,000 miles," was the reply. It would take nine days sailing from the Persian Gulf to reach Mozambique said defence officials.

In the meantime, DfID officials located another five helicopters in Mozambique and South Africa and hired them immediately. Not until late on Wednesday, after two days of wrangling, was the green light given to despatch the RAF Pumas by a chartered Antonov.

The Mozambique floods underline the need for improved international early warning centres and coordination of rapid response forces.

At the beginning of the week there were just seven helicopters dedicated to rescue missions. Now there are at least 17. No one knows the death toll, or how many died for want of rescuing in the first days. Even now, priorities are not what they should be. Yesterday, one commercial helicopter which had been plucking people from the waters was taken off its rescue mission to fly a Danish EU commissioner, Poul Nielson, to view the devastation.

Always too little and too late?

Venezuelan floods, December 1999

20,000-30,000 dead

400,000 homeless

$2bn damage

Torrential storms caused flooding and landslides in and around Caracas on December 16. It took five days for the International Red Cross to launch an appeal for $2.8m (£1.75m) to fly in medical supplies. On December 20, the country's foreign minister, Jose Vicente Rangel, was quoted as saying that more foreign aid was needed. "It's never enough, given the magnitude of the tragedy, solidarity is never enough."

Orissa, India, cyclone October 1999

10,000 dead

2m homes destroyed, 12m families affected

$3.5bn damage

Gales of up to 170mph hit the east coast of India in Orissa on October 29. It took three days for a relief effort to begin, when India's prime minister announced a £42m rescue package. Five days after the storm, the coordination centre consisted of six workers, two telephones and a fax machine. The Red Cross launched a preliminary appeal for $2.5m, and Britain's emergency committee launched an appeal for the victims.

Izmit, Turkey, earthquake, August 1999

18,000 dead

100,000 affected

An earthquake of 7.8 on the Richter scale struck north-west Turkey on August 17. The government of Turkey was criticised for failing to have prepared emergency plan for a big earthquake. The Turkish army was active immediately, but was accused of focusing much of its early efforts on searching for survivors of a destroyed naval base in Golcuk. It took three days for national emergency teams to reach the worst-hit areas.

Honduras, Nicaragua and El Salvador, Hurricane Mitch, October 1998

11,000 dead, 1m refugees

$5bn damage

Forecasters predicted the hurricane, which struck on October 27. But the west only responded after the event. The US initially pledged just $2m, later increased to $30m. In Britain, Clare Short was criticised for initially refusing to write off the region's debt. Britain first pledged £51,000, raising it £750,000 in direct aid. It took almost a week for large-scale food and emergency equipment to reach the region.

Those wishing to contribute to the DEC's appeal can ring 0870-6060900.

webTitle: Prevention is better - and cheaper - than cure

fields.headline: Prevention is better - and cheaper - than cure
fields.standfirst:
Mozambique flood disaster

Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: Natural disasters used to be called acts of God because human beings admitted no responsibility for such events, and made only limited efforts to alleviate their consequences. But there has been a slow revolution in the understanding of how men and women are complicit with nature in ways that can magnify or minimise climatic and geological catastrophes.
fields.body:
Natural disasters used to be called acts of God because human beings admitted no responsibility for such events, and made only limited efforts to alleviate their consequences. But there has been a slow revolution in the understanding of how men and women are complicit with nature in ways that can magnify or minimise climatic and geological catastrophes. What the study of disasters reveals is that habits of solidarity are more important than wealth and technical resources.

The reporting of the Mozambique floods, with its concentration on the visual drama of the helicopter rescue operation, gives the impression that those affected are passive victims. But it is difficult to believe that this society, which endured years of war and which experienced those same years as a time of local self-government under extreme stress, has not been helping itself. True, the challenges with which people in Mozambique were used to coping - survival in the wake of military operations, war casualties, and damage to crops - have been cruelly replaced by a different kind of emergency. This is particularly harsh because, before the waters rose, the country may well have been on the brink of a period of economic growth that some thought would make it an unusual African success story. The floods will set that prospect back. But, again, where people have habits of self reliance and where local leaders accept their responsibilities, recovery can be swift.

It is right to be critical of those countries who could have helped, but have not so far done so, or those who could have helped more quickly. Britain, in particular, should have responded earlier to an emergency in a country which joined the Commonwealth precisely because it wanted to be part of a larger, English-speaking community; one which, among other things, could help it out in times of trouble. There seems, for instance, no reason why the British commando carrier could not have been diverted to Mozambique a week ago. Had that been done, its helicopters and marines would have been in action now.

Yet Britain has still reacted more effectively than other countries, apart from South Africa. The United States is only just beginning to notice the situation, and France, Germany and even Portugal, for all the old connections, are also laggard. Other African countries have done little.

What Kenneth Westgate, director of Cranfield University's centre for the study of disaster management, calls the "US cavalry" model of disaster relief has led some to call for a permanent international rescue force. The Israeli radical, Uri Avnery, writing after last year's Turkish earthquake, called for "a world organisation . . . with a regular international command structure and an international general staff, similar to a military outfit. The commander should have authority to declare a world emergency within minutes after a disaster," and to mobilise "national units of trained and equipped rescue experts."

Those who oppose such ideas say not only that the practical obstacles are huge, but that even if they were overcome the resulting organisation would be costly and unwieldy. Better, they suggest, to stay with the existing informal system, in which there is already international coordination of specialised national teams. It does not work too badly unless nature outwits it, as was the case in Mozambique when a second bout of rainfall compounded the effects of the first.

But, although there should have been a swifter international response, that is not the main lesson to be drawn from this and other disasters. Kenneth Westgate points to the immense disparity between the international money spent on rescue and rehabilitation and that available for preventive measures. Some of these are matters of relatively simple and cheap equipment, where foreign money can be easily applied.

Other goals are both more elusive and more important. They concern a society's collective perception of risk, its treatment of its poorest classes, and its standards of behaviour. A society which scores high in these categories, even if it is not a wealthy society, prepares more intelligently for disasters, gets through them with fewer lives lost, uses international aid more efficiently, and recovers more quickly. At its broadest, disaster management shades into the general offensive on poverty and ignorance and into efforts to make societies more participatory, democratic, and comradely. The World Bank's new disaster management facility, for instance, operates on the basis that reducing poverty is the key to diminishing the impact of disasters.

The scale of the problem when conceived of in this holistic way is daunting to many governments in wealthy countries. That is no doubt why they seem to prefer paying for rescue efforts to paying for prevention. The former involves a limited and episodic responsibility, the latter a more universal duty. There is obviously a connection between the recognition by wealthy nations that they have this duty and the recognition by nations particularly vulnerable to disasters that they also have duties.

One modest idea to link the two in concrete ways is represented by a newly formed group called the ProVention Consortium, which includes two leading insurance companies. The plan is to tie aid and insurance to measures to prevent and mitigate disasters, in this way reinforcing good habits.

The problem is not at all confined to the poorer countries. Studies show that long-term planning for disaster in developed countries is also defective, partly because of the reduction of risk in the past. Flood control measures, for example, can prevent lesser flooding but make the impact of a really serious flood worse. Reducing risk is thus a complicated business, but the most critical aspect is that people should have a day to day awareness of the relationship between their behaviour and future disasters. As long as this information is compartmentalised, disaster prevention will suffer in wealthy and poor countries alike.

The idea that war is the most serious problem requiring international attention is perhaps natural in a Europe which has been dominated by the conflicts in former Yugoslavia during the past decade. But natural disasters kill more people than wars in most years. They killed 60,000 in 1999. It is true that wars can make natural disasters worse, and natural disasters can lead to wars.

At bottom, human security is indivisible. Yet a fraction of the funds western countries have been forced to expend in the Balkans might have made a large difference to such figures, particularly if it had been spent before rather than after disasters. Mozambique should make us think hard about such arguments.

webTitle: Spice Girls win lifetime achievement award

fields.headline: Spice Girls win lifetime achievement award
fields.trailText: All five original Spice Girls will be performing at the Brit Awards tonight - but not together.
fields.body:
All five original Spice Girls will be performing at the Brit Awards tonight - but not together.

The Spice Girls, who were once hailed as the biggest British pop band since the Beatles, but who are now better known for their celebrity babies and partners than for their singing, are due to receive a lifetime achievement award tonight.

This prompted rumours that the band would get together for the first time since Geri Halliwell left two years ago. It was also rumoured that Ms Halliwell would boycott the ceremony.

A spokesman for the British pop industry's equivalent of the Oscars said that all the girls would be there, but separately.

"The Spice Girls set is amazing, they come on out of a big yellow space ship", he said.

"But I've just seen Geri's set and it's totally outrageous. There are these huge pink inflated legs with high heels, and a glimpse of Union Jack, and between the legs there's a staircase and that's where she comes on," he added.

There is a chance that the five may meet briefly on stage for a bit of smiling and waving but the spokesman said: "That's very much under negotiation at the moment".

The awards ceremony takes place at Earl's Court in London and will be broadcast on television tomorrow night.

webTitle: Farm squatters are promised white land

fields.headline: Farm squatters are promised white land
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe special report
fields.trailText: The Zimbabwean government yesterday ordered thousands of black squatters to leave the 70 white-owned farms they invaded this week, promising them that it would soon have the constitutional power to seize the land for them.
fields.body:
The Zimbabwean government yesterday ordered thousands of black squatters to leave the 70 white-owned farms they invaded this week, promising them that it would soon have the constitutional power to seize the land for them.

The minister of home affairs, Dumiso Dabengwa, said he was giving the invaders 24 hours to leave, because the government would confiscate white-owned land without paying compensation. He said it would redistribute the land to the squatters and other poor black people.

The wave of farm takeovers across the country this week followed a referendum last month in which voters rejected a draft constitution including a clause authorising the government to seize the white farms.

The well-organised incursions were clearly carried out with support from the government and the ruling Zanu-PF party. Police refused to act against the trespassers.

Far from being desperately poor peasants, the squatters were clearly city dwellers. They were bussed to the farms in vehicles registered to the government and the Zanu-PF party. Food was distributed to them from those vehicles. In one case, they took over a farm by day and were ferried back to their homes in Harare for the night. Many wore new T-shirts saying "Vote yes for the constitution".

Despite the failure of the draft constitution two weeks ago, President Robert Mugabe yesterday unveiled an amendment to the existing constitution that will authorise the government to take over the farms without compensating their white owners. Opposition parties have expressed outrage at his flouting of the referendum vote.

On Wednesday, the former Rhodesian prime minister, Ian Smith, launching a new opposition group, called Mr Mugabe " dangerously incompetent" and "clearly senile". Mr Smith, 80, said: "Our country is in a serious crisis and it's going down the drain."

The government's amendment is taken word for word from the draft constitution that was rejected by voters. It states that if Britain does not pay for the land its white colonists seized from Africans, the Zimbabwean government is empowered to seize the land without paying compensation.

Mr Mugabe personally wrote in the reference to Britain. He said on television yesterday that the land had been stolen from Africans, and that he would not act against the squatters.

But a few hours later Mr Dabengwa, who is in charge of the national police, told the squatters to be off the farms by tomorrow morning or face police action. He said they would soon be able to get the land legally through the constitutional amendment. The wave of farm invasions was "a difficult political issue and we had to find a political solution", he said.

David Hasluck, head of the farmers' union, said farming districts were facing anarchy as police refused to act.

It will take 30 days for the amendment to become law. It has been published in the government gazette and must now have three readings in parliament. It is virtually guaranteed the two-thirds parliamentary support it needs to become law, because Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF party controls 147 of the 150 seats.

The government's move is widely viewed by ordinary Zimbabweans as well as political analysts as a desperate attempt to use the land issue to regain popularity before the parliamentary elections, which are due in mid-April.

"Everybody knows these squatters were sent in by the government to create a big stink so that Mugabe can say he is solving the problem with the amendment," said Mabel Munondo, an office worker in the capital, Harare.

"We did not want Mugabe's land clause in the draft constitution and we do not want it now. What Zimbabwe needs is fair redistribution of land, but Mugabe and his crooks will keep the land for themselves."

"These farm invasions are a cheap political ploy," said Brian Kagoro, spokesman for the national constitutional assembly which campaigned against Mr Mugabe's draft constitution.

"The invasions are clearly illegal. It is very worrying that the police failed to maintain the law. When civic societies want to demonstrate peacefully the police are quick to prevent us, with tear gas and truncheons, but when government supporters invade farms, it is OK."

Mr Kagoro said he was "certain the government took a deliberate decision to amend the constitution and felt it needed an international incident like the farm invasions to justify their actions."

The authorities were now trying to make it appear as if they were "responding to pressure rising from the people", Mr Kagoro said.

webTitle: Survivors flee as Mozambique's rivers rise again

fields.headline: Survivors flee as Mozambique's rivers rise again
fields.standfirst: Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: The Limpopo and Save rivers were again on the rise yesterday, threatening flood-stricken areas of Mozambique where tens of thousands of people are still trapped.
fields.body:
The Limpopo and Save rivers were again on the rise yesterday, threatening flood-stricken areas of Mozambique where tens of thousands of people are still trapped.

Rescue efforts were given added urgency by warnings that another cyclone could hit the coast next week.

A brief drop in the flood waters overnight around the devastated town of Chokwe brought thousands of people down from trees and roofs to try to escape before renewed floods. They were also fleeing armed looters, using boats that could have rescue people. Some were looking for food in shops but found little except tins. Others plundered homes.

Antonio Nhampossa, 40, a teacher, spent four days on his roof as his young daughter contracted malaria and thieves robbed his house. "They came by boat right up to the house and stole what they wanted. We were on the roof but we could not stop them. They were armed. They took my television," he said.

The anarchy in Chokwe may not last long. The rivers are rising in the aftermath of last week's cyclone Eline, which dumped huge amounts of water on Zimbabwe and South Africa. That water is now flowing back down the two rivers.

Another cyclone, Gloria, is heading for the Mozambique coast. If it hits areas where hundreds of thousands are homeless, it could claim yet more lives, spread disease and hinder relief efforts.

But meteorologists said Gloria was still a week away and that cyclones can fizzle out or veer away.

Many in Chokwe watched rescue helicopters fly overhead without stopping. There were too many for the South African crews to pick up, and those in the water had priority.

Mr Nhampossa and his wife risked their lives to find food for their four children. "We survived by catching driftwood and laying it on the roof to dry out. Then we used it to cook. We dived under the water to cut the corn in the fields. Sometimes we found an animal and cooked it. It was not easy," he said.

Lazaro Salamao wheeled his bicycle through flood waters up to his neck. He was sodden but relieved to have retrieved two ducks, a couple of chickens and a video recorder. "I'm not going back. They say more water is coming," he said.

Most head to a refugee camp about 30 miles away. Belated aid deliveries of food, blankets and tents have brought relief to some.

Emergency workers put faith in the arrival of 900 US troops. "If anybody has the ability to turn this crisis around it is the Americans," said Michele Quintaglie of the World Food Programme.

The UN special humanitarian envoy, Ross Mountain, said at least 70 people had been spotted dead in recent days.

fields.headline: To the slaughter
fields.standfirst: In the good old days, Farmer Burton's 350 sows would earn him £40,000 a year. Now he loses £8 on each animal. Battered by food scares and under threat from giant hog farms the size of cities, our pig industry faces extinction. How was this allowed to happen? John Vidal reportsCountryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: In the good old days, Farmer Burton's 350 sows would earn him £40,000 a year. Now he loses £8 on each animal. Battered by food scares and under threat from giant hog farms the size of cities, our pig industry faces extinction. How was this allowed to happen?
fields.body:
Pig 140 looks swell. Almost one third of a ton swell: two rows of six swollen pink teats flapping like pelmets beneath her, a wicked piggy grin, snout high in the early morning Yorkshire air, she trots across Farmer Grant Burton's field for breakfast, a scratch and a sniff.

Congratulations, Pig 140. Last night she gave birth to 10 piglets. The plump little 2lb pork barrels are curled up and kicking and squealing on a bed of fresh straw in their 12ft by 5ft insulated, corrugated farrowing house in the middle of a field.

Pig 140 gets her nuts and a scratch. Grant, an immense man, approves. "Intelligent animals are pigs," he says. "Sociable, too. Individual. Playful. They've got ideas of their own, go their own way. Dogs look up to you, they say, cats look down, but pigs are your equal." He tells of a vicar who used to use them as dogs on the hunt: "Pigs' sense of smell is 50 times better than dogs. They're much cleaner than cows, too. And they look you in the eye, you know."

On cue, Pig 140 fixes Grant with a bright, olive eye from under long blonde lashes, grunts and returns slowly to her family. It's a small miracle that none of the Yorkshire 10 are crushed as she lies down. They attach themselves to her in the time-honoured order: strongest take the front teats, weakest the rear.

Pigsville is stirring. In the same field, 25 other great sows and three grizzled boars are being fed. Another group of 30 is waiting, spreadeagled, head down, snout to snout, some snoring in the hay. Further on, by a wallow pool, a young boar is servicing 30 gilts, the young females. The object of his thrusts looks serenely bored, continuing to root around in the mud for food handouts. Gestation, should it happen, will take three months, three weeks and three days. It is the age-old pig cycle.

It all looks normal enough. Happy, healthy, well-looked-after, free-range pigs. None of your tethered or stalled beasts. Big-hearted, cricket-loving farmers. Beautiful situation in the rolling North Riding. Rooks flapping lazily in the mists. Young Mark and Matthew, local lads, dealing out the food. Grant's mum cooking sausages and bacon in the farmhouse. Brother Mark on the computer checking out pig prices. Spring busting out everywhere. What could be wrong?

Everything. This is a social, financial and agricultural nightmare. The British pig industry, like the hill farmers and others, is bumping along the bottom of the longest, deepest crisis it has ever known. Every pig reared in Britain is losing the farmers between £5 and £10. Prices collapsed in 1996 and have not recovered, except for a brief spell when the Dutch had to slaughter millions when swine fever erupted.

Almost 4,000 pig farms, one in three in Britain, have gone out of business since 1994. Mostly it's been the small and medium-sized farms, but now the big ones are suffering and two of three of Britain's best-known have recently gone under. The pigs have their natural cycle and the industry has its cycles of regular ups and downs, too. But this time there are no ups.

It's been catastrophic for the Burtons and their average-sized family farm near Pocklington. In a really good year, their 350 sows might make £40,000 profit. But those days are faint memories. Last year, they lost more than £100,000 and this year is as bad. They are living on just £70 a week. For the past year they have been downsizing, from more than 350 sows to fewer than 250 now. The family "silver" is being sold off. Last week, they decided to sell the farm cottage. It hurts. The long-term tenant must go.

Every week the brothers send another load of pigs to the slaughterhouse and see their overdraft rise. They lose about £8 on every pig they rear. There are no subsidies and no sign that the crisis will be over in the foreseeable future. The harsh reality, says a new Lloyds Bank analysis of the industry, is that thousands more farms must go out of business before there is an upturn. By the end of this month, Grant and Philip may only be able to survive another few weeks. Many others in the region are taking stock, too. They all know it could be the end.

"We're in the bottom of the trough," says Grant. "It's a case of gritting your teeth and tightening the belt. People have put their pensions into pig farming, they have lost everything. This isn't a normal cycle. If something doesn't happen soon, we'll have to get rid of the men. It's not possible to over-emphasise the seriousness of what is happening."

The battered farmers have tried everything from demonstrating to persuading the supermarkets and the army to buy British. They blame the very high pound that means European importers can flood the British market with cheap meat, and leaves them unable to export; they blame the supermarkets who are profiting hugely from their crisis.

The anger is turning to resignation. They know that there has been over-production but they say that's just half the story. It's unfair that they should have to meet higher animal welfare standards when the rest of Europe can avoid them and so undercut them; they claim BSE, which had nothing to do with pigs, costs them an extra £5 on every animal; they despise a system that allows pigs reared anywhere in the world to be imported whole and then be processed here and sold as "British". They say that the government has only offered to help them with marketing. They don't want sympathy or subsidies, but they do want a fair share.

Five hundred yards away, Matthew and Mark have moved on from feeding Pig 140 and her colleagues to herding 140 youngsters into haulier Malcolm Smith's big blue lorry to send them to the giant Malton slaughterhouse 15 miles away. With lots of "Go on, lads", and "Come on, girls", the pigs go up the ramp willingly enough. A few start fighting. Their bright, white saliva stains the black mud.

Malcolm has been carting pigs and farm animals around Britain for 30 years, and knows every pig farmer in Yorkshire and most markets and slaughterhouses in Britain. "Glad I'm not a farmer now," he says. "Dad had a black and white pig. It followed us around everywhere. Every small holding had a pig. We killed our own."

He's not morose by nature but what he sees, as he does his rounds, shocks him. "This is as bad as anything I've seen in 28 years. Pretty grim, is the mood of the farmers. How long can they keep going? They're on the bank's doors. Nobody's doing well. A lot of them are on the tender edge," he says.

He's talking suicides. In the past few months, at least half a dozen farmers in the region have killed themselves. Many others, as confirmed by a NUJ report into tenant farmers this week, are desperate, with one in four saying they are having marital problems because of the crisis; 70% are unable to sleep and 60% fear they will lose every thing. One in 10 are being prescribed anti-depressants.

The land looks neat and tended, but the view from Malcolm's cab is bleak, with sign after sign of a divided and depressed economy. There are union jacks in the fields and signs asking: "Is it British?" Farm buildings are being converted into flats. Where communities had five farms only a few years ago, now they have one or two. There are self-service signs at the farm gates. The abattoirs are cutting back, says Malcolm; there's less work for the hauliers, the feed merchants, the carpenters and builders, the processors, and all the way down the food chain. Farms are practically giving away produce.

We truck through deserted commuter villages. As the small farmers go bankrupt or leave, so the land is being gobbled up by the large estates who in turn are moving towards "contract" farming, where fewer local people are employed and the contact between the brought-in labour and the community is even less. "It's like we're going backwards," says Malcolm. "The traditional communities are fracturing; the shops going."

The farmers' markets, where farmers can sell directly to the public, may be one bright spot. But the odds are that the British industry will shed another quarter or more of its pig farms in the next year, and in the long-term things may be worse. The Lloyd's Bank analysis suggests that even a more efficient, smaller industry will never be able to compete on the world market in which farming is now thrust. Global and European corporations, working on an unimaginable scale, are already targeting Britain and the big new threat is likely to come from the US.

Hog farms in North Carolina are now the size of British cities, with up to 1m breeding sows - more than 100 times the size of the biggest British operations. The smallest viable units are now bigger than even the largest British ones, and are unable to compete. Communities near the giant farms are up in arms over the pollution and it's only a matter of time before Britain is flooded with the cheapest pigs in the world. The social, environmental and economic price of cheap food will be paid by the rural communities.

But the British supermarkets, who traditionally have little loyalty to their producers, may get there first in their search for the cheapest cuts. There is talk of Asda, owned by giant US retailer Wal-Mart, setting up a pig farm in Poland 10 times the size of Britain's largest to provide all the chain's meat. It would be another nail in the coffin of British farming.

The reality is that four or five giant US-sized pig farms could produce most of the 1m tons of pig meat that we eat every year. Never mind the welfare standards or how the pigs are reared - under world trade rules, which prevent protectionism, there is little or nothing that British ministers can do except preside over the virtual end of an industry. And for pigs, read cows, fruit and vegetables, too.

Malcolm, Grant and Mark understand this perfectly. "Britain is becoming just a dumping ground now. It's going to be left to one or two producers," says Grant. He's a natural Tory, but he blames Margaret Thatcher and the rush to the free global market. "A whole new atmosphere came in then," he says. "The old relationships between people broke down. Nothing mattered except the profit motive. It became the devil-take-the-hindmost society. This is a fundamental breakdown of everything that we know. We don't want to make a fortune, just a living. Yes, in one sense we're like the third world here."

Malcolm's wagon arrives at the Malton slaughterhouse. It's a huge, grim-looking factory on an industrial estate with chimneys belching, tall tanks of blood, black gut, sludge and effluent, and that lingering smell of fresh death. We queue up on the concrete yard with wagons from Lincolnshire, Norfolk and Northumberland, each with 150 or more pigs. Malton used to kill 8,000 pigs a day, now it's 6,000.

They are signed in by a Mr McCarthy and Malcolm helps unload them. Within the hour, they will be gassed and on their way to being a traditional British breakfast or pie. Tomorrow, he'll bring more in from elsewhere; next week Grant and Mark will get a cheque for more than £7,000 but will be £1,120 poorer and the whole pig cycle will go on. Except that in a few weeks he and his family will decide whether or not to chuck the whole lot in.

fields.headline: Kohl's fundraising talents still sharp
fields.trailText: Germany's former chancellor, Helmut Kohl, whose party is expected to be fined £2m for accepting secret donations, yesterday confirmed that he was fundraising again - this time, to pay the fine.
fields.body:
Germany's former chancellor, Helmut Kohl, whose party is expected to be fined £2m for accepting secret donations, yesterday confirmed that he was fundraising again - this time, to pay the fine.

He told reporters that his latest enterprise was "in a good cause".

Mr Kohl is under criminal investigation for failing to disclose the source of cash he accepted while leader of the Christian Democrats until 1998. He has insisted on keeping the names of his earlier donors secret, even though German law requires that they be made public.

Officials of the Christian Democrat Union (CDU) said that, this time, they expected Mr Kohl to name his benefactors.

While he continues to refuse to identify the original donors, it will be impossible to allay the suspicion that he went back to the same sources to collect the money for the fine.

The CDU's opponents yesterday reacted with stupefaction to this latest twist to Germany's most serious political scandal since 1945.

"It is hard to credit at this point what is actually happening here," said Franz Müntefering, the general secretary of the ruling Social Democrats. "It's a return of the same old Kohl, thinking he can repair all the damage caused with money."

Christian Democrat leaders welcomed the news. The CDU general secretary, Angela Merkel, said: "This helps us".

The party's new parliamentary leader, Friedrich Merz, said any move by Mr Kohl to make good the financial damage he had done was positive. But he added: "The loss of confidence in the Christian Democrats won't be erased by this alone".

The problem for Germany's conservatives is that Mr Kohl has again thrown his giant shadow - and the impression of cronyism - across their party at a time when they are trying desperately to move on.

But the former chancellor and his sympathisers will have taken heart from last weekend's regional election in Schleswig-Holstein where, despite the scandal, the Christian Democrats lost less than 2 percentage points in support.

"It's a return of the same old Kohl, thinking he can repair all the damage caused with money." Christian Democrat leaders welcomed the news. The CDU general secretary, Angela Merkel, said: "This helps us". The party's new parliamentary leader, Friedrich Merz, said any move by Mr Kohl to make good the financial damage he had done was positive. But he added: "The loss of confidence in the Christian Democrats won't be erased by this alone". The problem for Germany's conservatives is that Mr Kohl has again thrown his giant shadow - and the impression of cronyism - across their party at a time when they are trying desperately to move on. But the former chancellor and his sympathisers will have taken heart from last weekend's regional election in Schleswig-Holstein where, despite the scandal, the Christian Democrats lost less than 2 percentage points in support.

fields.headline: Glitterati boycott Vienna's opera ball
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Leading glitterati, from presidents to porn stars, snubbed Vienna's prestigious opera ball last night in protest at the presence in Austria's government of the far right.
fields.body:
Leading glitterati, from presidents to porn stars, snubbed Vienna's prestigious opera ball last night in protest at the presence in Austria's government of the far right.

Organisers were left to search for replacement guests of honour after the Portuguese president, Jorge Sampaio, and the porn diva Dolly Buster turned their backs on the event. Even John Wayne Bobbit, who leaped to fame when his wife cut off his penis, withdrew, saying that involvement could damage his career.

Female personalities were reportedly offered large payments to attend. Some who agreed to go insisted on bodyguards to protect them from being photographed alongside Jörg Haider, the far-right Freedom party's de facto leader.

The British film star Jacqueline Bisset received a late invitation after the French actress Catherine Deneuve and the Italian star Claudia Cardinale rejected pleas to attend.

Bisset accepted and was on the way to the airport when she received a call from Arnold Schwarzenegger. The Austrian-born Schwarzenegger, a critic of Mr Haider, warned her that she could not afford to be seen rubbing shoulders with the far-right populist. She quickly returned home.

Instead of Mr Sampaio, the Austrian president, Thomas Klestil, entertained Nursultan Nazarbayev, the president of Kazakhstan, as the 4,100 guests - who paid £120 a ticket or £10,000 for a box - waltzed the night away.

Outside, at least 10,000 demonstrators - many in fancy dress - gathered. An anti-fascist street dance was also planned in the city centre.

The ball was the first major social event for the new ministers. Mr Haider was not expected to attend.

webTitle: Libertysurf float will add £1bn to Kingfisher value

fields.headline: Libertysurf float will add £1bn to Kingfisher value
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: More than a billion pounds is likely to be added to the stock market valuation of retailer Kingfisher with the flotation of the first French internet service provider on the Paris Bourse later this month.
fields.body:
More than a billion pounds is likely to be added to the stock market valuation of retailer Kingfisher with the flotation of the first French internet service provider on the Paris Bourse later this month.

The Libertysurf ISP - modelled on the UK's Freeserve, which was developed by Dixons - was backed by Kingfisher and French tycoon Bernard Arnault's private investment company when it was created last year. The two backers each poured 50m euros (£30m) into the venture, taking 45% stakes. Less than 12 months later they are sitting on stakes valued at only a little less than £1bn each.

France's bourse regulator confirmed yesterday that shares in Libertysurf would be priced at 35.5 to 41 euros each, valuing the ISP at 3.05bn to 3.52bn euros.

Libertysurf is raising 518m euros by selling 12.6m new shares but the two main backers are not reducing their holdings. They will be left with 40% stakes.

Shares in Kingfisher, which owns the Woolworth, B&Q, Comet and Superdrug chains plus a network of European retailers, climbed 35p or 6.9% to 545p as details of the float were disclosed.

Analysts say the flotation is bound to be oversubscribed and believe Libertysurf will increase the scale of the offer. "It is the first offering to give a pure French internet play," said an official from Deutsche Bank France, the issue's lead manager.

fields.headline: Autonomy calls off the search
fields.standfirst:
Autonomy

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Autonomy, the firm from Cambridgeshire which has developed software that "understands" text, is preparing to launch a free service which it claims will remove the need to use search engines while surfing the internet.
fields.body:
Autonomy, the firm from Cambridgeshire which has developed software that "understands" text, is preparing to launch a free service which it claims will remove the need to use search engines while surfing the internet.

Called Kenjin and using Autonomy's technical ability to understand written concepts rather than keywords in web pages or word processing documents, the Kenjin software will automatically recommend links to relevant information on the web.

The news emerged as Autonomy, which is listed on the Easdaq high technology exchange in Belgium, released year-end figures showing what chief executive Mike Lynch described as "exponential" growth.

Turnover was up 212% to £16.5m during 1999, with the US accounting for more than half of sales. Pre-tax losses narrowed to £680,000 from £1.74m and Mr Lynch said the company was effectively running at break-even as Autonomy rolled out a string of new partnerships and product.

These include the recently announced i-WAP - software that will search the internet for specific information, filtering out irrelevant data and deliver the rest to a mobile phone or other wireless device.

Recent partnerships include one with software developer Razorfish to work on delivering personalised news and other information to users in Britain.

The company also pointed out that it had won a multi-million dollar contract with General Motors in the fourth quarter - representing the company's largest deal to date - whose revenue would be recognised in the quarters ahead.

The news was greeted with euphoria on Easdaq, where Autonomy's shares jumped $34 to $115.

The company, which floated in June 1998 at $4 a share, is now worth around £6.5bn and Mr Lynch continues to hold just over 20%.

Mr Lynch declined to say when the company would move into profit.

"As you can see, the company is generating cash and most of the spending in marketing is discretionary. We are running break-even at the moment and if you want to see this kind of growth you would expect that to be the case," he said.

webTitle: BT threat to delay mobile licence sale

fields.headline: BT threat to delay mobile licence sale
fields.standfirst:
BT
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The government yesterday warned British Telecom not to interfere with next week's auction of licences for the third generation of mobile phones.
fields.body:
The government yesterday warned British Telecom not to interfere with next week's auction of licences for the third generation of mobile phones.

BT has written to the department of trade and industry reportedly threatening legal action to halt the auction because the rules have been changed.

The Radiocommunications Agency, which is conducting the auction, originally ruled that there could only be one bid per group.

But it has decided to allow Vodafone and Orange to make separate bids following Vodafone's £103bn takeover of Orange's parent, Mannesmann.

A DTI spokesman said: "We have received a letter from BT and it is up to BT to decide what to do. But it would not be in the interest of BT, or anyone else, to delay the auction."

He said the auction, which starts on Monday, would be the world's first for a third generation mobile network, and would put Britain "at the forefront of the world's telecom market".

He said that if Vodafone and Orange succeeded in the bidding they would not be granted licences until Orange had been sold off.

A BT spokesman said: "We have written to the DTI about the unfairness of the current arrangements whereby both Vodafone and Orange will be allowed to bid.

"We now know that the auction will start on Monday and that our representations have not been accepted."

He refused to confirm that the group was considering legal action, though he admitted it was an option.

The government is auctioning five licences, at least one of which will go to a new entrant to the market. It is expected to raise well over its £500m reserve price. Thirteen companies have applied to take part.

The third generation phones will be able to receive email, music, high quality pictures, video and video conferencing. Most handsets will include a screen and a keyboard.

Licence winners will have to spend several billion pounds building new networks, which are not expected to come into operation until at least 2002.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • As the Health and Safety Executive takes on responsibility for train safety, it might ponder the 6.34am from Penzance to Paddington on February 23, which a reader reports was grossly overcrowded "like a tube train in rush hour". Some 40 people, children on half-term among them, stood or sat by the doors all the way from Cornwall, and after lots of livid comparing of reservation cards it became obvious that train operator First Great Western had double-booked seats.
fields.body:
 As the Health and Safety Executive takes on responsibility for train safety, it might ponder the 6.34am from Penzance to Paddington on February 23, which a reader reports was grossly overcrowded "like a tube train in rush hour". Some 40 people, children on half-term among them, stood or sat by the doors all the way from Cornwall, and after lots of livid comparing of reservation cards it became obvious that train operator First Great Western had double-booked seats.

"It's not good enough, especially after the Paddington crash," said a ticket collector as he declassified a first-class carriage. "It's not safe to stand up. If we make an emergency stop, they'll hit the front of the carriage." Denying any knowledge of double-booking, press officer Elaine Wilde has nothing to say about the safety angle. "If it was overcrowded, the train wouldn't stop at the next station," she says bafflingly, adding that those who wanted to get off would have had to get a taxi back from the next station. Mmm. The HSE has much to do.

 So farewell Augusto Pinochet. It was on October 14 1998, you may recall, that the Diary carried one of the first British newspaper references to his visit. Hoping to locate him and make a citizen's arrest, my then colleague Simon Bowers rang hospitals pretending to be from the Chilean embassy, but his Spanish accent was so pitiful that the receptionist at the London Clinic, where Pinochet was staying, giggled and put the phone down.

But for this failure, we may have found him before Jack Straw - and the old swine would be banged up in Madrid rather than a free man in Santiago. On such tiny corners does the course of history turn!

 At the Mirror, Paul Routledge backtracks after giving Piers Morgan a lecture on share-dealing, while in his cups. Routers woke the next morning regretting his Kilfoylian threat to resign, but we know that he stands by his declaration that all share-dealing, honest or not, is wicked. Who better than Routers, landlord of six properties in Yorkshire, who once flashed his Skipton bank book (credit of £204,000) at Oofy Wegg-Prosser, to carry the torch of working class heroism?

 My post bag bulges with letters concerning Stephen Glover. The man who recently accused this paper of being run by an IRA cell hasn't been so well lately (one of his artificial kneecaps rejected him), so the letter from a Mr P Stothard is especially untimely. "Why is this chap paid to opine about successful editors," he asks, "when he was so famously useless at it himself?" Well, Mr Stothard, if you listen to Radio 5 Live football commentary, you often hear Bobby Gould giving advice to Alex Ferguson, and no one in the studio laughs. It's the same with Steve. An army must carry its wounded, and if that means affecting polite interest in their opinions, so be it. In future, Mr Stothard, do show a little Christian charity.

 Speaking of which, there is sad news of another wounded Steve. Diary Vicar the Rev Steve Chalke (or "TV Steve" as the Caterham Advertiser has it) is on crutches after "he caught a kerb with his foot while running and broke an ankle" just before Christmas. What a trouper he is, not only making his scheduled trip to No 10 that day (Steve is friendly with Cherie) but being up the next day "at 4am for a GMTV Show". We hope to speak with the Reverend next week for a sermon on pain and healing.

 By popular demand here is the second verse of Millbank Believer, Nick Drew's celebration of Frank Dobson to the tune of the Monkees' hit I'm A Believer:

I thought I was just a Millbank victim,
Seems the more they spun, the less I got.
What's the use of fixing?
All you get is scorn.
I was just a poodle - hope was gone.
Then they fixed Red Ken....
(repeat chorus)

webTitle: Psion boost is just what the doctor ordered

fields.headline: Psion boost is just what the doctor ordered
fields.standfirst:
Psion
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Portable computer specialist Psion took advantage of its soaraway share price yesterday to bolster its acquisition war chest by £100m and allow founder and chairman David Potter to turn £100m of his £900m paper fortune into hard cash.
fields.body:
Portable computer specialist Psion took advantage of its soaraway share price yesterday to bolster its acquisition war chest by £100m and allow founder and chairman David Potter to turn £100m of his £900m paper fortune into hard cash.

Announcing year-end figures which were once again scarred by the company's heavy investment in its Symbian joint venture with the world's leading mobile phone makers, Psion also gave further details of the new pocket-size wireless devices that will allow access to the internet on the move later this year.

While the company reported a recovery in sales of its electronic organisers, led by its new Revo model, it warned that rising development costs at Symbian will continue to erode Psion's profits, which slumped from £23.3m to £4.55m in the year to December. Turnover slipped £9.5m to £150m but shareholders will still get a 3.1p total dividend, up from 2.8p.

With Symbian - formed 20 months ago with Nokia, Motorola and other mobile industry leaders to develop Psion's Epoc operating system for use on a new generation of mobiles - Dr Potter fleshed out his vision of putting wireless access to the internet at the core of the firm's strategy.

"Psion is positioned at the centre of developments in mobile data, mobile internet and software systems for cellular wireless networks," he said. "These are highly competitive and rapidly changing markets to which significant risks are attached. However, the company has an outstanding range of investment opportunities in these industries."

Investment bank Credit Suisse First Boston has been given the job of placing £100m of new stock with institutions, while 1.6m shares belonging to directors, most of them Dr Potter's, are being sold at the same time.

Having jumped seven-fold in five months, shares in Psion surged again yesterday to close at £72.70, up almost £8, as the company also announced a four-for-one stock split. Interest in Psion has also been fuelled in recent days by demand for shares in freshly floated American rival Palm, which has been spun off by 3Com in New York.

fields.headline: All the world's a stage
fields.standfirst: Jeffrey Archer may have his faults, but there's no doubting his talent for reinvention. Four months after the scandal that led to his ousting as a mayoral candidate, he has announced his debut on the West End stage. Stephen Moss on another astonishing comebackThe fall of Archer: special report
fields.trailText: Jeffrey Archer may have his faults, but there's no doubting his talent for reinvention. Four months after the scandal that led to his ousting as a mayoral candidate, he has announced his debut on the West End stage.
fields.body:
When a catastrophe befalls you, when the whole world discovers you are a liar, what do you do? Change your name? Run away? Emigrate to Patagonia? If you are Jeffrey Archer - or as we must still call him, Baron Archer of Weston-super-Mare - you agree to be interviewed by Martin Bashir and make your debut on the West End stage. Whatever you say about Lord Archer, he does not lack chutzpah.

The choice of play, too, is wonderfully apposite: The Accused, in which Archer will star as a doctor charged with murder, and the audience will be invited to decide whether he is guilty or innocent. It is as if Archer is asking all of us to determine what kind of man he is, perhaps because he no longer knows himself.

Michael Crick subtitled his revelatory biography of Archer "Stranger than fiction"; as so often with clichés, it is spot on. Archer once asked his publisher whether, if he worked really hard, he might win the Nobel Prize for Literature. Er, no, Jeffrey, unless they take a leaf out of your book and treat your rollercoaster life as the most glorious piece of fiction.

Archer told Bashir, in last night's interview on ITV's Tonight programme, that he began writing the play as a cure for the depression he felt after the revelations of his concocted alibi led to his withdrawal from the London mayoral race and his suspension for five years from the Conservative Party. "I was desperately fed up, broken - and the catharsis was getting up in the morning, and trying to do something, trying to get one's mind off everything and put something down on paper."

That fed-up feeling sounds rather less serious than the near-suicidal despair the press was told that Archer was suffering in the immediate aftermath of last November's scandal. Archer is a brilliant self-publicist and apparently indomitable; only he could believe that it was possible to turn back the tide of condemnation that followed the revelations that he paid one associate to lie on his behalf, and another to leave the country to avoid giving evidence.

The apologies he issued through his aide, Stephan Shakespeare, the posed photographs with fragrant wife Mary and tabby cat Stan in the Archers' lovely kitchen in Grantchester, the confessional with the Rev Bashir (lots of Hail Marys, Jeffrey) and the you-the-jury play are all part of a strategy aimed at re-establishing Archer. As comeback kids go, Archer believes he is world champion.

Archer's life has been a succession of extraordinary escapades and unlikely escapes. That cliffhanging capacity to survive the trickiest situations appeals to many who accept that he is a rogue but demur from following Crick and Paul Foot, who has exposed many of his fabrications, in declaring him a villain. What his supporters forget is that the crises are usually of his own making: like Houdini, he knowingly ties the knots and locks the chains that bind him.

Wily politicians like Lord Whitelaw, who warned Margaret Thatcher he was "an accident waiting to happen", and Steven Norris, who believed from the beginning that he would have to withdraw from the mayoral race, recognised that he was a political liability. But friends always seemed to outnumber foes. It was ridiculous that, after the exposure of his deceptions and the Anglia share scandal in 1994, he became Tory candidate for mayor, but his sheer desire to do the job and the party's post-meltdown lack of direction allowed him to win the nomination.

Archer is like a pint-sized Citizen Kane: he believes in himself so utterly and has mythologised his life so completely that he is able to get away with anything. Just as he is nailed, he wriggles free and begins again. His first great disaster saw him resign as a Conservative MP in 1974 after investing in a fraudu lent Canadian company: he fought back to become a bestselling novelist and, as he likes to boast, to repay all his debts within seven years. "I can't expect people to have trust and respect for a man who has behaved so stupidly," he said at the time of his resignation. "But that doesn't mean I'm now going to crawl away and hide. I will be fighting back."

He fought back again in 1986, when the News of the World exposed his willingness to pay £2,000 to Monica Coghlan, a prostitute he insisted he had never met. Archer had spent the early 80s restoring his fortunes in the Conservative Party and had risen to be its deputy chair man; now his "foolishness" forced him to resign. But again he came back, winning £500,000 in damages in his celebrated libel action against the Daily Star. The Daily Star is now promising a re-run.

He won, but it was a tainted victory and, although he continued to have Thatcher's admiration, he did not return to party office immediately. Instead, he toured the constituencies relentlessly, enhanced his fortunes as a novelist (in 1990, he signed a $30m deal with HarperCollins for three books) and raised money to help the Kurds (he claimed to have raised £57m; others put the figure at £3.8m). His rehabilitation plan worked perfectly: the trial was forgotten (except by tormentors like Crick and Foot), the bogus CV was forgiven, he was given a peerage in 1992 and he was tipped for the Tory party chairmanship.

It was the high point of his career, but once again disaster struck: he was involved, with a friend, in the purchase of shares in Anglia TV, which rose in the midst of takeover fever. The problem was that Mary was a director of the TV company, leaving him open to accusations of insider trading. He strenuously denied them, apologised to his wife (a familiar refrain), and was investigated by the DTI. The latter found him innocent of insider dealing, but the damage was done.

"I'm never sure of what my 10-year-old will be up to next," Jeffrey Archer's mother, Lola, wrote in her weekly column in the Weston Mercury in 1951. It could still be said of Archer, who will be 60 next month. He has been running ever since, though nobody knows quite why. He never appears to have any interest in ideology or policy, only in the Trollopian great game of politics.
