webTitle: The Sun says: Dutch love our currant bun

fields.headline: The Sun says: Dutch love our currant bun
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: News International reined in its web presence in the UK yesterday by selling bun.com, the website of the Sun newspaper, to internet service provider World Online for an undisclosed sum.
fields.body:
News International reined in its web presence in the UK yesterday by selling bun.com, the website of the Sun newspaper, to internet service provider World Online for an undisclosed sum.

Rotterdam-based World Online is moving to build its subscriber base in the UK before a flotation expected later this month on the Amsterdam stock exchange. It is expected to be capitalised at almost €10bn (£6bn).

Bun.com delivers World Online 450,000 direct subscribers, making it the seventh largest ISP in the country, according to Fletcher Research.

Despite its recent success, the birth was painful. News International launched Currantbun.com last April amid difficulties as visitors to the site were greeted with a message that "the Currant Bun is still in the oven".

News International decided to relaunch the site as bun.com, targeting a more affluent market.

Until now, World Online which is in 15 European countries, had no direct subscribers in the UK.

World Online's UK chief executive, Simon Preston, said: "Bun.com was attractive because we want to develop further joint marketing arrangements with News International."

He declined to disclose the terms of the sale and whether News International would receive shares in World Online's flotation.

"I'm sure they are attracted to the fact that we are floating," Mr Preston said. "We intend to become a major international ISP and we will be extremely well funded."

No staff will be included in the sale of Bun.com to World Online. The UK's biggest ISP by subscribers is Freeserve, followed by LineOne, Virgin Net, AOL, BT Clickfree and X-Stream.

News International said its News Networks team would continue to focus on "internet efforts on areas ... for creating long term value".

"We are still negotiating with News International over the content for bun.com but there are discussions about lots of things on the table," added Laurence Alexander, World Online UK managing director.

fields.headline: Kidney error team faces action
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Hospital officials are to begin formal disciplinary proceedings against two surgeons after the death of a man who had the wrong kidney removed.
fields.body:
Hospital officials are to begin formal disciplinary proceedings against two surgeons after the death of a man who had the wrong kidney removed.

Graham Reeves, 70, died on Wednesday, five weeks after what should have been a routine operation at the Prince Philip hospital in Llanelli, west Wales. Investigations have found that the surgical team removed Mr Reeves's healthy kidney instead of the diseased organ because of an alleged failure "to comply strictly with established procedures".

Mike Jones, chief executive of Carmarthenshire NHS trust, which runs the Prince Philip, said that for legal reasons the findings of two inquiries, one by the Royal College of Surgeons, could not be made public.

Dyfed Powys police is investigating the cause of Mr Reeves's death on behalf of the Swansea coroner; a home office pathologist will today carry out a postmortem.

Three members of the team which carried out the operation, including John Roberts, a consultant urologist, were suspended when the mistake came to light. Others in the team could face disciplinary action.

webTitle: Doctors say 'vague' GMC is failing them

fields.headline: Doctors say 'vague' GMC is failing them
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: Doctors' leaders yesterday turned on their regulatory body for failing to grasp the depth of the crisis of confidence in the profession's ability to keep its own house in order.
fields.body:
Doctors' leaders yesterday turned on their regulatory body for failing to grasp the depth of the crisis of confidence in the profession's ability to keep its own house in order.

In unprecedented criticism, the British Medical Association accused the General Medical Council of making only "vague" proposals for reform in the wake of the case of Harold Shipman, the GP jailed for murdering patients.

The association, which is hastily producing its own proposals, said that time was running out for the profession to head off punitive government action in response to the Shipman affair, even though no reform would of itself have prevented his crimes.

Ian Bogle, who chairs the association's ruling council, said: "We need to do something pretty fast because I think it's possible that Alan Milburn [the health secretary] might be more influenced by work we do than by the vision that the GMC seems to be working to."

His comments came after the BMA council met in private on Wednesday to discuss the crisis. It resolved that there was a need for a "frank and open debate on the regulation of the medical profession in a modern society".

Mac Armstrong, the association's secretary, said the reality was that the regulatory system was under attack from the government, had lost the confidence of the profession and was feared by doctors no longer to have the confidence of patients.

"A lot of people in council said they thought that at the moment we had the worst of all worlds."

The GMC, which has the power to strike off doctors, issued Shipman with a warning letter in 1976 when he was convicted of falsifying precriptions to obtain morphine for his own drug habit. When he was later under investigation for murder, lawyers advised that the body had no power to suspend him.

Last month the GMC announced it was accelerating a programme of reform - through two separate reviews - in recognition of what Sir Donald Irvine, its president, conceded was seen as its "cosy club atmosphere".

Dr Bogle said this was an inadequate response to problems identified by BMA council members, particularly the slow pace of the GMC machine. "Their personal experience is of totally unacceptable delays, allowing doctors who should not be treating patients to carry on treating patients - and that must be addressed very, very quickly."

So concerned had been the council that about 20% of those present had appeared unwilling to endorse the continued principle of self-regulation, although only two or three had been opposed to it outright.

"The GMC [proposals] are vague, let's be frank about it," said Dr Bogle, admitting he could not follow some of them. "What we need are clear answers to the questions being asked, expressed in terms I can understand."

The government is unlikely to scrap self-regulation, but is thought to want changes including regular scrutiny of the GMC by the Commons health select committee and majority lay representation on all disciplinary committees.

Dr Bogle said that while he believed self-regulation must mean a majority, however small, of doctors on the GMC's governing body, he would be willing to contemplate lay majorities on its committees "if that's going to give greater public confidence".

He had, he reported, already given a no-punches-pulled report of the BMA council's discussion to Sir Donald, who is attending a conference in South Africa.

"He seemed to think that he had it all under control."

 Results of a Mori survey for the BMA suggest that public trust in the way doctors do their jobs has been little affected by the Shipman case.

Thirty-six per cent of people said they were very satisfied and 54% fairly satisfied, compared with 41% and 50% respectively last year.

fields.headline: Rail regulator ups fees by £5m
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, is seeking a "very substantial" rise of up to 50% in licence fees from the rail industry to pay for his expanding office.
fields.body:
The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, is seeking a "very substantial" rise of up to 50% in licence fees from the rail industry to pay for his expanding office.

If the railway companies agree, it will mean a rise in fees from £9m to around £14m next year. Mr Winsor argues that the demand is justified because his office "has been fundamentally under resourced for the task of effectively regulating the railway."

In a letter to Gerald Corbett, chief executive of Railtrack, Mr Winsor says: "I have always made it clear that I intended to adopt a more proactive and ambitious approach to regulation than did my predecessors.'

His letter goes on: "This does not mean more intrusive regulation, or seeking to regulate activities which should properly be regarded as commercial. But it does mean using proportionately and fairly the powers with which I have been provided."

Mr Winsor says that he must have sufficient staff in place with proper skills, "and I must have the resources available to secure first-class external advice on engineering, economic and legal matters."

The letter, seen by the Guardian, will increase the friction which exists between Mr Winsor and some sections in the industry, who believe that the regulator has adopted far too high a public profile.

One critic suggested that it was wrong for the regulator to have a chauffeur driven car. But unlike his predecessor who spent £60,000 a year on the service and was driven from home three miles away to his office, Mr Winsor journeys to work each day by train from his home 40 miles away.

Since taking over the job last year, Mr Winsor has largely concentrated on improving Railtrack's performance to such an extent that the company may now be able to escape most of the £40m fine imposed by Mr Winsor for falling behind targets it set itself.

The regulator's office said last night: "The cost of regulating the industry is made by the railway companies and not the taxpayer. Having a new regulator has meant a considerable increase in activity and scrutiny."

webTitle: Train bounced back after leaving track

fields.headline: Train bounced back after leaving track
fields.standfirst: Transport in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Rail commuters had a lucky escape when part of their train travelling at 90mph left the track and careered along for more than 400 yards before "jumping" back on to the line again, it emerged yesterday.
fields.body:
Rail commuters had a lucky escape when part of their train travelling at 90mph left the track and careered along for more than 400 yards before "jumping" back on to the line again, it emerged yesterday.

The rear section of the six carriage Salisbury to Waterloo service with several hundred people on board remained upright. Passengers were "very shaken" although no one was hurt. The incident happened at the end of January.

An official inquiry into the accident, which started yesterday, was told how the rear two tonne diesel engine of the 5.28am train broke free and tore up a mile and a half of track as it was dragged under the carriages.

The force was so great that it knocked the rear section of the train from the track, but it then bounced back on further along the line.

On this type of train the diesel engines are mounted under the carriage rather than as a separate unit. A broken bolt which led to the incident is undergoing laboratory tests. The train operator, South West Trains, inspected its entire fleet, stripping down engines to ensure that flywheel bolts were secure. A source said: "If the front engine had come off we could have been investigating another major train disaster."

The train was travelling on the fast line between Winchfield and Hook in Hampshire. One of the bolts securing the flywheel to the engine's crankshaft sheared. This put the engine out of balance, and other bolts then broke, sending the flywheel smashing through the casing, which caused the engine to break free.

It was then dragged along the track, damaging sleepers and other equipment.

webTitle: Chechen rebels warn 'vodka army' of revenge

fields.headline: Chechen rebels warn 'vodka army' of revenge
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: As the Russian military declared that its battle for Chechnya was nearly complete, the president of the breakaway region, Aslan Maskhadov, vowed yesterday that the rebel army still had the power to mount a savage counter-offensive.
fields.body:
As the Russian military declared that its battle for Chechnya was nearly complete, the president of the breakaway region, Aslan Maskhadov, vowed yesterday that the rebel army still had the power to mount a savage counter-offensive.

Mr Maskhadov's threat came in response to the significant advances made by Russian forces into the mountainous region in the south of the state, a traditional rebel stronghold.

The last major Chechen-held town, Shatoi, fell to the Russians earlier this week and soldiers were yesterday sweeping through the cave-ridden terrain around the town, searching for rebel bases.

Fighters fleeing the area were said to be making their way back to the plains of northern Chechnya.

That raised suspicions among the Russian military that scattered bands of rebels were planning to launch new raids on Russian-occupied regions - a tactic used with devastating success by Chechen fighters during the last war.

But with the propaganda war raging in Moscow, it was hard to establish the strength of the beleaguered guerrilla forces or to determine how much control the Chechen army retained in the southern mountains.

In a rare interview, Mr Maskhadov told a Moscow-based radio station that militants still held the Argun gorge, a strategically important canyon cutting through the mountains to the Georgian border. Conceding that Shatoi had been seized by the Russian army, he argued that rebels had never aimed to control villages but preferred to fight for the territory in between.

But Russian army officials insisted that rebels held only four villages in the area and controlled just a few square miles in the entire region.

The Chechen president also claimed still to have ample fighters. "Out of 25,000 volunteers who took up arms, 23,000 remain. The fighting will go on for a long time," he said.

Russian military officials claim that there are no more than 2,000 rebels still at large and said that about 500 of those were yesterday hemmed in by Russian troops as bitter fighting continued in nearby villages.

An official Chechen rebel website also announced that fighters planned to push back the Russian advance into the mountains.

"Like eagles in the sky and like lions in the brush, the mojahedin are watching every move the Russians make," it said. "They will soon pounce on the vodka army and will teach them once again why the mountains of Shatoi are described as the 'lion's den'."

The same site, Jihad in Chechnya, listed the names and ranks of 96 Russian soldiers killed - according to Chechen officials - during the battle for Shatoi.

But Sergei Yastrzhemsky, the spin doctor appointed to coordinate news on Russia's campaign, declared that he had evidence that the Chechen warlord Khattab was planning a new wave of terrorist attacks in major Russian towns.

It was Russia's insistence that Chechen rebels were behind last September's bomb attacks that provided the government with crucial justification for its offensive.

President Maskhadov also reiterated his willingness to negotiate to bring the conflict in Chechnya to a close.

But the acting president, Vladimir Putin, responded that the only talks Russia was prepared to hold with him would be carried out by state prosecutors investigating criminal charges against him.

Vadim Timchenko, the deputy commander of Russia's forces in the region, was even more blunt, commenting that Mr Maskhadov and other leading rebel commanders were being actively hunted down by the military. "We are undertaking all means ... to destroy them," he said.

International concern over allegations of severe human rights abuses by Russian troops in the region was discussed in Portugal yesterday.

After meeting the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, in Lisbon, European Union officials said they would demand an independent investigation into alleged human rights abuses in Chechnya.

Mr Ivanov later said he had granted permission for Mary Robinson, the UN high commissioner for human rights, to visit Moscow and the north Caucasus early next month.

Moscow had previously refused Mrs Robinson's demand for access to the region, attacking what it described as her "non-objective, biased and one-sided" criticism of the brutality of Russia's campaign.
fields.bodyText: As the Russian military declared that its battle for Chechnya was nearly complete, the president of the breakaway region, Aslan Maskhadov, vowed yesterday that the rebel army still had the power to mount a savage counter-offensive. Mr Maskhadov's threat came in response to the significant advances made by Russian forces into the mountainous region in the south of the state, a traditional rebel stronghold. The last major Chechen-held town, Shatoi, fell to the Russians earlier this week and soldiers were yesterday sweeping through the cave-ridden terrain around the town, searching for rebel bases. Fighters fleeing the area were said to be making their way back to the plains of northern Chechnya. That raised suspicions among the Russian military that scattered bands of rebels were planning to launch new raids on Russian-occupied regions - a tactic used with devastating success by Chechen fighters during the last war. But with the propaganda war raging in Moscow, it was hard to establish the strength of the beleaguered guerrilla forces or to determine how much control the Chechen army retained in the southern mountains. In a rare interview, Mr Maskhadov told a Moscow-based radio station that militants still held the Argun gorge, a strategically important canyon cutting through the mountains to the Georgian border. Conceding that Shatoi had been seized by the Russian army, he argued that rebels had never aimed to control villages but preferred to fight for the territory in between. But Russian army officials insisted that rebels held only four villages in the area and controlled just a few square miles in the entire region. The Chechen president also claimed still to have ample fighters. "Out of 25,000 volunteers who took up arms, 23,000 remain. The fighting will go on for a long time," he said. Russian military officials claim that there are no more than 2,000 rebels still at large and said that about 500 of those were yesterday hemmed in by Russian troops as bitter fighting continued in nearby villages. An official Chechen rebel website also announced that fighters planned to push back the Russian advance into the mountains. "Like eagles in the sky and like lions in the brush, the mojahedin are watching every move the Russians make," it said. "They will soon pounce on the vodka army and will teach them once again why the mountains of Shatoi are described as the 'lion's den'." The same site, Jihad in Chechnya, listed the names and ranks of 96 Russian soldiers killed - according to Chechen officials - during the battle for Shatoi. But Sergei Yastrzhemsky, the spin doctor appointed to coordinate news on Russia's campaign, declared that he had evidence that the Chechen warlord Khattab was planning a new wave of terrorist attacks in major Russian towns. It was Russia's insistence that Chechen rebels were behind last September's bomb attacks that provided the government with crucial justification for its offensive. President Maskhadov also reiterated his willingness to negotiate to bring the conflict in Chechnya to a close. But the acting president, Vladimir Putin, responded that the only talks Russia was prepared to hold with him would be carried out by state prosecutors investigating criminal charges against him. Vadim Timchenko, the deputy commander of Russia's forces in the region, was even more blunt, commenting that Mr Maskhadov and other leading rebel commanders were being actively hunted down by the military. "We are undertaking all means ... to destroy them," he said. International concern over allegations of severe human rights abuses by Russian troops in the region was discussed in Portugal yesterday. After meeting the Russian foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, in Lisbon, European Union officials said they would demand an independent investigation into alleged human rights abuses in Chechnya. Mr Ivanov later said he had granted permission for Mary Robinson, the UN high commissioner for human rights, to visit Moscow and the north Caucasus early next month. Moscow had previously refused Mrs Robinson's demand for access to the region, attacking what it described as her "non-objective, biased and one-sided" criticism of the brutality of Russia's campaign.

fields.headline: Appeasing the mob
fields.standfirst: The state plays a disreputable role in keeping out foreigners, for the voters believe they are being 'swamped'
fields.trailText: The state plays a disreputable role in keeping out foreigners, for the voters believe they are being 'swamped'
fields.body:
A good week for Jack Straw. Waving goodbye to General Pinochet, one troublesome foreigner less "swamps" his in-tray. But another 104,000 remain to be dealt with - that mountainous backlog of asylum-seekers. W

hile they all wait for years for an adjudication, the Afghans have been judged in no time at all and are now deftly removed from tabloid front pages with the stern announcement that only two (plus dependants) can stay. At the same time the Times carries a very satisfying front page story that "Jack Straw is demanding a complete overhaul of the United Nations convention on refugees in an attempt to stem the tide of asylum seekers entering Britain". Yes, all in all, a good week for the home secretary.

Bogus asylum seekers are the problem. But everything connected with policy on asylum seekers is bogus. Most of what the government says is bogus: it relates neither to what it does nor to what it thinks. Much newspaper reporting is bogus, with any stray bad-hat case tarring all refugees. Tory politicians' exploitation of this is bogus opportunism. And liberal hand-wringing about asylum policy is sometimes bogus: an open immigration policy, desirable or not, is impossible politics yet they would reject any actual immigration policy.

There is no honourable policy available on immigration. Keeping foreigners out will always be a disreputable business likely to make decent people recoil. Romanians, Albanians or citizens of the former USSR, we turn away people from pretty nasty countries, if not quite nasty enough, or from very poor countries and poverty is not a crime.

There are only better and worse ways of handling what will always be a bad business. But we have not done well, even by that relativist standard. Our home secretary's remarks about the Afghans shocked even the Wall Street Journal into writing an angry editorial - hardly a liberal newspaper.

Now the Afghans have been dealt with - sort of. Day after day these "bogus" hijack victims in their £200-a-day Hilton hotel rooms were splashed across the tabloids.

The Mail's leader said: "We'll wager that most 'victims' of the Stanstead hijack are still enjoying life on benefits in Britain, five years hence," and Straw had to prove them wrong fast, as well needing to deter future hijacks. So the remaining planeload may be auctioned off to other countries. This could start a whole lucrative new world trade with the poor world selling entry permits to the rich world yearning to breathe free of its refugees.

Straw barked loud enough to drive the Afghans off the Mail's front page, but the story they were running instead was a cracker.

The Nistor family arrived hidden in a lorry from Romania in 1998, applied for asylum as persecuted gypsies and while awaiting adjudication have a council house in Hillingdon. Cheating on social security, the men in the family work on construction sites and this week one mother was arrested yet again begging with her improbably named son, Lucifer, in the London tube.

A gem, bang to rights - that shows the kind of people scrounging off our soft asylum laws, a story to stick in the public mind for a decade. Against that tide of opinion Jack Straw has to swim hard and Labour's polling shows they are losing. "Swamped" is what people believe.

How should they regain public trust in the asylum system? Not by throwing petrol on the flames. Every time they appease the mob it stokes up demand for ever more draconian measures.

When Jack Straw called for a complete overhaul of the UN convention and a new EU directive on immigration it sounded the right kind of tough stuff. "We shall be raising our concerns with like-minded countries," Straw says. Who? Austria, perhaps. That's how it came across.

In fact he means overturning some rather bizarre recent interpretations of the UN convention by our own appeal court, far looser than any other in Europe: in one case asylum seekers entering through Europe were allowed to stay because our court declared France and Germany unsafe. These are our own domestic legal problems. The government does want the UN to introduce the system used over Kosovo whereby all countries take agreed quotas of refugees from trouble spots, a reasonable proposal. But as he keeps declaring the UN convention outdated it sounds, perhaps conveniently, like a headlong repudiation of the UN refugee principles. When challenged, it's denied. But where are the rousing speeches in favour of human rights and saving the genuinely persecuted?

Some facts: Britain takes just under the European average of refugees (measured per capita of population: Luxembourg can't take as many as Germany).

In the 10 years 1988-98 a total of 58,350 were allowed to settle here - hardly a "swamp", though it is rising. Under Michael Howard, 80% of applications were rejected. Dealing with fresh cases, the government estimates the underlying rate at about 30%. It is the monster backlog that causes the problem and offers such delectable pickings to the Mail. The maladministration of the whole asylum system is the problem - Straw's fault, not the law's.

For two years Straw wasted time and millions of pounds trying (but failing) to impress the mob with draconian measures to disperse asylum seekers around the country to camps, hulks or anything that can be made to sound horrible.

Tough new rules start in April. But tinkering with punitive vouchers for food to send out deterrent messages, they took their eye off the ball. What matters is a system that deals with new arrivals fast and expels those refused entry promptly. (Look at the speed with which the Afghans were adjudicated.)

The refugee council is broadly satisfied with the adjudication system itself, but says the injustice is in delays. Too late, the government has put a lot more money into adjudication and for the first time last month the number of cases dealt with exceeded the number of new arrivals. But it still needs more money and more officials.

Only after nearly three years is Straw finally drawing up new plans to remove those who lose their case. Until now (and under Howard), sheer bungling meant few people refused entry were ever actually deported. It is not new policy that Straw needs but simple good administration inside his own hopeless home office.

Unless the government holds the line and explains loudly why taking in refugees is a good thing, the refugee council fears that public anger at a few cases like the Nistors will get out of hand.

Open aggression towards refugees is on the rise and appeasement only encourages yet more xenophobia. Why not praise the wealth of cultural riches refugees have brought with them? International conventions may need technical reform, but Labour should be persuading the beastly British of the noble principle of the UN convention, not undermining it.

fields.headline: Greg and his big assets
fields.trailText: Accessibility is my watchword. As I can't say too often to my clients in the media, you might have created the greatest work of art of all time in the world ever, but if less than two million poor sods get to see it, what's the bloody point, then, love?
fields.body:
Accessibility is my watchword. As I can't say too often to my clients in the media, you might have created the greatest work of art of all time in the world ever, but if less than two million poor sods get to see it, what's the bloody point, then, love?

I have a helluva lot of time for one of our most valued clients, the lovely Michael Jackson of Channel 4. His old boss at the Beeb, Sir John Birt, taught him to keep the following flow-chart in his head at all times - C + A = B, or, in laymen's terms, Credibility Plus Accessibility Equals Buzz.

Credibility is a word that needs no explanation from me. It's the bedrock of broadcasting, and let's hope it remains that way. Broadly speaking, it means "what you can get away with". But Accessibility is a more complicated animal, incorporating a lot of highly innovative, diverse and relevant concepts in an overall structure of programming values.

Pulled out of the air, words Michael and I associate with Accessibility include "partnership with the audience", "strong language", "clitoris", "prostitution", "widespread concern", "Thailand", "responsibility", "Courtney Love", "dildo", "penis", "cunnilingus" and "talking frankly". After all, we're all grown-ups.

With major new Channel 4 series on church architecture (Women Who Make Love In The Confessional: An Investigation), zoology (I Fell In Love with A Chicken) and birdwatching (As Nature Intended. Twitching in the Nude with Bill Oddie), we have a highly innovative and accessible spring season of documentaries upcoming.

Meanwhile, our drama schedules have never looked stronger, never more relevant. For instance, our keynote drama series, Brookside, will continue to hold a mirror up to society, with hard-hitting storylines exploring the changing role of women in society (Beverley enters the twilight world of prostitution), personal fulfilment (Linda explores her sexuality in the shower with Charmain), psychological challenges (Darren's D-I-Y sex-change ends in tears) and man's relationship with nature (things take a turn for the worse when Frank is caught by Louise with a distraught hamster concealed in his underwear).

Major new drama on 4 includes the six-part series, Scrubbers. Set in a Tyneside strip-club, it is a no-holds-barred indictment of a male- dominated world, with full-frontal nudity, lengthy hand-held close-ups of naked breasts, strong language and a number of disturbing shots of all-over body massage that may offend some viewers. Fulfilling our commitment to quality broadcasting, we will also premiere a striking new production of Ibsen's A Doll's House, with Samantha Janus as the doll.

Small wonder, then, that with the reinvigoration of Channel 4 behind us, my company, Bel and Frendz, has been approached by the lovely Greg Dyke to work our magic on the BBC schedules.

"You've got a massive 98% brand recognition, Greg," 1 told him, straight up, when he checked into our intensive two-day Media Workshop last weekend, "and that's something to build on.

On the other hand, we have a downside: viewers have told us that the BBC is still 'authoritative', 'intelligent', 'principled' and - I hate to say it, Greg, - 'decent'. And that translates as stuffy, old- fashioned, irrelevant and inaccessible." Yes Greg, we have a problem on our hands.

But Greg's a quick learner, and it didn't take him long to work out that the best way forward is to build on our assets. This means directing additional resources to re-branding some of our existing programmes.

The autumn schedules are still in a process of formulation, but I'm delighted to say we have already approached Graham Norton to replace Joan Bakewell as the presenter of our prestige religious documentary series, The Heart of the Matter. Filming on the first two programmes (The Church of England - Should Female Vicars Go Topless? and A Spiritual Buzz: The Role of the Vibrator in Christianity, will begin in late June.

Other progs to get a makeover include Delia Smith's How to Slag Out, in which Delia lets her hair down on a Club 18-30 holiday with half-a-bottle of rum and a whole range of fun recipes involving bananas and pineapple rings; also old favourites like Blue Peter, in which, for the first time ever Peter himself will appear - and viewers will be able to find out exactly why they call him "Blue"!!! Meanwhile, the cut and thrust of contemporary politics will continue to be covered in full by much-loved series such as Question Time, jointly chaired by David Dimbleby and Ulrika Jonsson, with the introduction of the one-item-of clothing forfeit for every hesitation, repetition or deviation. Stuffy? No. Accessible? Yes. And that's the way - uh-huh, uh-huh - I like it!

webTitle: Laying down the law on oppression

fields.headline: Laying down the law on oppression
fields.trailText: Catherine Bertini is right that humanitarian workers are exposed to considerable danger in wars and natural disasters (Don't shoot the helpers, February 29).
fields.body:
Catherine Bertini is right that humanitarian workers are exposed to considerable danger in wars and natural disasters (Don't shoot the helpers, February 29).

However, it is astonishing that, as executive director of the UN's world food programme, she devotes an article to proposing "an inviolable recognition that the safety and well-being of humanitarian workers in the field are to be respected at all times" without once mentioning a recent treaty which was intended to ensure exactly that with respect to personnel (including humanitarian workers) on UN operations.

The 1994 convention on the safety of UN and associated personnel, which entered into force on January 15 last year, has certain limitations: it does not cover all types of humanitarian worker, nor all types of situation, and by the end of 1999 only 29 states (including the UK) were parties to it. H

owever, this treaty does represent an attempt to do many of the things that Ms Bertini proposes, such as punishing those responsible for crimes against humanitarian workers. The deeper problem may be not the absence of a legal framework, but the absence of respect for it.

Prof Adam Roberts
Balliol College, Oxford

 So much for the change in thinking that the election of over a hundred women Labour MPs was supposed to herald.

Not one of them has spoken in support of the asylum applications made by the Afghan women on that flight despite the gross abuses of human rights of women by the Taliban regime (Straw lets eight Afghans stay in UK, March 2). Abuses which even this "ethical" government recognised in its much vaunted human rights report.

The denial of access to education and employment, the requirement that women must only be allowed out of the home when accompanied by a close male relative and other policies demonstrate that women in Afghanistan are being denied core human rights.

These women are persecuted because of these policies and because they cannot challenge them without marking themselves out as religious opponents of a regime which will not allow any form of religious dissent.

If these women cannot be accepted as refugees then, I wonder, who can?

Vanessa Beck
Birmingham University

fields.headline: A flood of suggestions
fields.trailText: The staggering failure of the international community to respond adequately to the Mozambique tragedy (Flood aid 'not enough' - UN, March 2) served only to remind us of the critical need for an international logistical force.
fields.body:
The staggering failure of the international community to respond adequately to the Mozambique tragedy (Flood aid 'not enough' - UN, March 2) served only to remind us of the critical need for an international logistical force. Proof was provided yet again over the past three weeks of the utter indifference of the world's governments to the plight of the vulnerable and needy.

The task in Mozambique was a relatively simple one - provide helicopters and boats to effect a rescue. Sadly and inexplicably this was not done. Not done because the international community simply does not care enough about the lives of hapless Mozambicans. Indeed we now know the international community does not really care about the lives of the poorest of the poor, wherever they may be.

Hopefully public opinion will now prompt the UN or some such body to form an international force. Had this force been in place last month, several thousand Mozambicans would not have perished in the floods. Meanwhile GOAL, which has worked in Mozambique since 1994, continues to need support from the public, to reach some of the victims.

John O'Shea
GOAL
aspearman@goal.ie

 You report that six helicopters have so far saved 8,000 Mozambique flood victims. This means roughly 75 more of them are needed to save the remaining 100,000 stranded survivors. So why, at this late date, is Clare Short sending just six more helicopters as part of a package worth a paltry £5.8m? If that's it, even alongside the pathetic donations of other states, then my sums tell me they are planning to send many thousands to a watery grave.

Aidan Hartley
London
Mashur@cs.com

 Strange, isn't it, when there's a war plenty of helicopters are instantly available? When floods in poor Mozambique are submerging people, after three weeks there are still only five. You would think wealthy countries would already have rushed helicopters, boats and crews to this devastated country; you might also think that millionaires could have offered some of their helicopters and boats. But there, they need these conveyances for really important things like board meetings and getting off to tropical paradises for holidays (not Mozambique at the moment).

AC Evans
Cheadle Hulme, Cheshire

 An international disaster force could be funded by a tax on aviation fuel. At the moment no nation will tax this fuel, which is massively polluting, because they all have competitive airlines.

The tax should fall on all polluting nations to pay for environmental protection measures such as reforestation.

Anthea Hardy
High Wycombe, Bucks

 Almost £70m of national lottery prizes have gone unclaimed in one year. Why not send this to relieve the suffering in Mozambique?

Nuala Stroud
Belfast
ballofstring@hotmail.com

fields.bodyText: The staggering failure of the international community to respond adequately to the Mozambique tragedy (Flood aid 'not enough' - UN, March 2) served only to remind us of the critical need for an international logistical force. Proof was provided yet again over the past three weeks of the utter indifference of the world's governments to the plight of the vulnerable and needy. The task in Mozambique was a relatively simple one - provide helicopters and boats to effect a rescue. Sadly and inexplicably this was not done. Not done because the international community simply does not care enough about the lives of hapless Mozambicans. Indeed we now know the international community does not really care about the lives of the poorest of the poor, wherever they may be. Hopefully public opinion will now prompt the UN or some such body to form an international force. Had this force been in place last month, several thousand Mozambicans would not have perished in the floods. Meanwhile GOAL, which has worked in Mozambique since 1994, continues to need support from the public, to reach some of the victims. fields.headline: Don't come as a victim
fields.trailText: We can all learn from Jack Straw's decision. If you are persecuted you will face a camp whilst your application for asylum is considered. Conversely, if you have persecuted, raped and murdered you have nothing to worry about (Pinochet prepares to fly home, March 2).
fields.body:
We can all learn from Jack Straw's decision. If you are persecuted you will face a camp whilst your application for asylum is considered. You will endure constant questioning about your validity to be here and suffer hostility from press and politicians whilst they whip up further hatred. Conversely, if you have persecuted, raped and murdered you have nothing to worry about (Pinochet prepares to fly home, March 2).

Uncle Jack will, of course, have to put up a pretence whilst the human rights do-gooding activists try to have you put on trial, but no problem. You will, during this inconvenience, be accommodated to the best standards: a nice country home with 24-hour security.

Gary Daniels
Manchester
gaz36f@aol.com

 The debate on Pinochet's health has centred on the wrong issue. The home secretary needed only know that Pinochet was fit enough to step on to a plane to fulfil his obligation to extradite him. (And if he can fly to Chile, he can fly to Spain.) After which it was up to Spain to determine whether he is fit to stand trial.

Luke Sorba
London
Lukeso@aol.com

 Pinochet and his supporters might not understand the concept of justice and a fair trial, but he has encountered some of these ideas. More importantly, he has met an ideal of which his regime was totally ignorant: mercy. We can be happy that we are capable of such, even for the most undeserving. Let it always be so.

Brian Robinson
Brentwood, Essex
brirobinson@lineone.net

 In view of the incontinence and other unpleasant symptoms now affecting Pinochet, I am sure all readers will want to join me in wishing him a very long retirement.

CJR Abbott
Harlow, Essex
cabbott@netcomuk.co.uk

fields.headline: No excuse for Blunkett
fields.trailText: One of the obligations secondary schools have to their pupils is to ensure that they achieve examination grades at the highest possible level. I loathe underachievement and the wasted potential it involves as much as the secretary of state (Poverty no excuse for failure, says Blunkett, March 2).
fields.body:
One of the obligations secondary schools have to their pupils is to ensure that they achieve examination grades at the highest possible level. I loathe underachievement and the wasted potential it involves as much as the secretary of state (Poverty no excuse for failure, says Blunkett, March 2).

But setting as a target the requirement that all secondary schools - including those whose pupils must overcome disadvantage, deprivation and poverty in order to realise their academic potential - should ensure that one quarter of their pupils gain five GCSEs at C or better is likely to prove counterproductive.

Schools need challenging targets, but targets for all their pupils. In effect, those schools which are below the secretary of state's threshold have been told they will be judged on their achievements wth just a quarter of their pupils.

Prof Chris Husbands
University of Warwick
edsbc@snow.csv.warwick.ac.uk

 As a former inner-city comprehensive head for two decades, I am appalled by Blunkett's proposals for "failing schools". A good head and competent teachers are only some of the factors that lead to good exam performance.

Other factors are poverty, housing, employment, family size, housing, health, language skills, prior learning experiences - and they're outside the control of the school. Mr Blunkett has become one of the factors driving down standards in the inner city.

Jack Schofield
Oldham

fields.headline: Bond issues
fields.trailText: May the real debate on funding of the tube begin (Letters, February 29). The government's problem with guaranteeing bonds for the tube is that the debt would be placed on the public sector borrowing requirement.
fields.body:
May the real debate on funding of the tube begin (Letters, February 29). The government's problem with guaranteeing bonds for the tube is that the debt would be placed on the public sector borrowing requirement.

While Railtrack did pressure the government into guaranteeing the £2.65bn channel tunnel rail link bond last year, the government ducked the PSBR issue by saying that the guarantee was unlikely to be used. Such behaviour alarms the markets. The public sector should be encouraged to raise their own finance and use the eurobond markets. Our European counterparts have shown it to be a cheap and effective method of raising finance.

Tom Freke
Reporter, International Insider

fields.headline: Leave the Lebanon now
fields.standfirst:
Mr Barak needs to restore momentum

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: The attempt by Ehud Barak to achieve a comprehensive peace settlement with Syria and the Palestinians, and by extension with Lebanon and the Arab world at large, is faltering badly.
fields.body:
The attempt by Ehud Barak to achieve a comprehensive peace settlement with Syria and the Palestinians, and by extension with Lebanon and the Arab world at large, is faltering badly. The hopes engendered by the Israeli prime minister's election last spring wear thin. In the absence of substantive progress, goodwill is dissipated; distrust resurfaces; hardliners on all sides move to fill the vacuum. A familiar pattern of violence, verbal and physical, reasserts itself. The task of peace, always hard, grows harder by the day. The process badly needs a shot in the arm. But who is to provide it?

Not Syria, it seems. President Hafez Assad's overriding goal is the return of the Golan Heights and a full Israeli withdrawal to the June 4 1967 border. Ostensibly outraged by Mr Barak's refusal immediately to make such a pledge at the US-sponsored Shepherdstown talks, and perhaps because he is unused to the concept of gradualist negotiations, Mr Assad resorted to extra-mural means. In January, he unleashed his Hizbullah proxies in Lebanon, armed and encouraged by elements of the Iranian regime opposed to any accommodation with "Zionism". By the first half of last month, seven Israeli soldiers were among the dead, Israeli citizens were again cowering in bomb shelters and Mr Barak was under heavy political fire in Jerusalem.

Seasoned analysts smiled grimly; the Damascus fox had made his point, as so often in the past, by inflicting pain. What they seemed to forget was that in the process, Mr Assad had needlessly inflamed opinion on both sides; delayed a resumption of talks; and made it more difficult for Mr Barak to honour Yitzhak Rabin's secret promise of a full Golan withdrawal which, given negotiated security guarantees and demilitarisation, he seems to be ultimately prepared to do. The government's Knesset defeat over the conduct of a future Syrian peace referendum was primarily the result of coalition politicking. But it also reflects sharpened hostility within Israel to a Golan deal which is the direct result of Mr Assad's crude arm-twisting.

Mr Barak, too, has made mistakes. He over-reacted to Syria's provocations in Lebanon. Israel's air strikes on non-military targets last month put it in the wrong in the eyes of the world. The prime minister has let talks with the Palestinians drift into a dangerous stalemate. He has perhaps relied too much on US intercession. Mr Barak has also given his political allies too much latitude. A firmer hand could have avoided Wednesday's coalition split. And he should tell David Levy, his foreign minister, that whatever anti-semitic ranting passes for fair comment in the Arab world, incendiary, retaliatory threats to kill "a child for a child" are equally repulsive.

But how to move forward? Who can create new momentum? Like his mentor, Mr Rabin, before him, it falls to Mr Barak to show the leadership which others in the region lack. To reduce Mr Assad's leverage, to gain moral advantage, to right an historic wrong, and to satisfy majority domestic opinion, Mr Barak should bring forward Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon. The date he has already set is July 7. But why wait? An early pullout would win international approbation, would spike hardliners' guns, and would not, in any real sense, compromise Israel's security. It would boost confidence in a process foundering for lack of results. Crucially, it would help break the old cycle of disillusion and violence upon which the enemies of peace thrive. And who knows? Denied his Lebanon card, Mr Assad might finally be induced to shuffle the pack and cut a deal.

fields.headline: Pseudo Scots
fields.trailText: Dr Iain Stevenson (Letters, March 2) suggests some test questions for sniffing out spurious Scots. I had an uncle in Canada who only hired Scottish immigrants as labourers in his mill.   When interviewing applicants he would weed out the ringers by asking them how they had arrived at his office.
fields.body:
Dr Iain Stevenson (Letters, March 2) suggests some test questions for sniffing out spurious Scots. I had an uncle in Canada who only hired Scottish immigrants as labourers in his mill. When interviewing applicants he would weed out the ringers by asking them how they had arrived at his office. If they said they'd used the elevator, they were American: and if they'd used the lift they were English. But, if they said they'd used the hoist, they were indisputably Scottish and were hired.

David Kemp
Glasgow

fields.headline: Fly away home
fields.standfirst:
A shamed old man goes back to Chile

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: The sneaky departure of ex-dictator Pinochet neither looked nor felt good. But what was the alternative?
fields.body:
The sneaky departure of ex-dictator Pinochet neither looked nor felt good. But what was the alternative? In theory he might have been bundled aboard another Boeing 707 bound for Madrid. But Spanish doctors would have been no less likely than the four British experts (two of them fluent Spanish speakers) to find a doddering old man unfit to be tried.

And Spanish courts, mindful of their obligations under the European convention on human rights, would have had to pay attention. Jack Straw's voluminous apologia for his decision, issued yesterday, returns time and again to the medical case. He was obliged to consider Pinochet's fitness and from then on everything hinged on the neuropsychologists' opinion. It is hard to challenge the home secretary's procedural piety. At every turn he double-checked with lawyers and that should not be held against him. If, on asylum seekers and penal matters in general, he behaved with as much decorum, his ultimate decisions might command a lot more assent.

Pinochet's departure is not the end of the affair. Its very tawdriness was appropriate. Even if the bands and gold braid come out for him in Santiago, recent months have made a spectacle of what former caudillos come to - shambling shadows lurking behind the curtains, fearful of legal process. And for that we need to reserve a mote of thanks for the Iron Lady, on whose watch torture outside the UK first became punishable in domestic courts.

There are those who fear, back in Chile, a medical miracle will take place. But so what? Even Norman Lamont would find it hard to applaud a petty fraudster, one moreover who can never again leave Chile - the Spanish dossier remains open. The international enforcement of the claims of justice against human rights' abusers is a work in progress. Pinochet's arrest here 17 months ago remains a grand, precedent-setting event.

fields.headline: Blue tinged with green
fields.standfirst: But the Tories are still not convincing
fields.trailText: Stemming the destruction of British biodiversity was a central plank of Labour's manifesto commitment on the environment, yet it has taken nearly three years for them to deliver: today they finally publish their wildlife and access bill.
fields.body:
Today is a big day in the precarious lives of the high brown fritillary butterfly, the grey partridge, turtle dove and song thrush. These species have declined catastrophically in recent decades - by 94%, 82%, 77% and 55 % respectively. Equally spectacular is the threat to our sites of special scientific interest (SSSIs) of which half are in "unfavourable condition" and 5% are lost or damaged every year.

Stemming the destruction of British biodiversity was a central plank of Labour's manifesto commitment on the environment, yet it has taken nearly three years for them to deliver: today they finally publish their wildlife and access bill. Next week, they are due to publish their strategy on meeting the targets agreed in Kyoto on climate change. It is crunch time on the environment: can Labour justify their claim to be the first truly green government?

Already, there are worrying signs of serious slippage, particularly on climate change, where the manifesto commitment for more ambitious targets has completely disappeared from view. Here is an opportunity for Her Majesty's opposition to hit New Labour hard. So what does the Conservative party have to say? In a bid to lay out its stall ahead of the wildlife bill, central office has been churning out press releases on a blue-green theme all week.

Archie Norman, the new shadow environment, transport and regions secretary, claims the environment as natural Conservative territory - which is not as ludicrous as recent experience might suggest, given the illustrious past roles of Chris Patten (1990 white paper) and of course, John Gummer. But Mr Norman's opening gambit misfired. Setting up a green energy commission to investigate renewable energy (an excellent notion: government action has been lamentable here) yesterday, Mr Norman made two factual errors when referring to the Kyoto agreement - he got the wrong target date and misunderstood what gases were to be cut. And he failed to nail a bigger omission still - Labour's abandonment of its manifesto pledge of a 20% cut in carbon dioxide.

This debacle was the culmination of a week devoted to such pressing issues as Leylandii hedges and mobile phone masts. Mr Norman has to get the big picture fast; Labour is vulnerable on its environmental record and a vigorous effective opposition is badly needed for the sake of the high brown fritillary and, in the end, of all of us.

fields.headline: Three dead as Israel foils bomb plot
fields.standfirst:
Palestinian guerrillas killed by explosion after shootout at house

Israel and the Middle East: special report
fields.trailText: Israeli security forces yesterday bulldozed a ramshackle house in an Arab town at the end of a day of drama that began with a shoot-out and explosion which killed two suspected Hamas guerrillas, and extended into a lengthy police siege of their hideout.
fields.body:
Israeli security forces yesterday bulldozed a ramshackle house in an Arab town at the end of a day of drama that began with a shoot-out and explosion which killed two suspected Hamas guerrillas, and extended into a lengthy police siege of their hideout.

Police later confirmed that another body was found inside the house.

Israel Radio said the men belonged to a cell that was using Taibeh in central Israel as a base for a bomb attack within the next few days. The prime minister, Ehud Barak, praised the police and intelligence services for thwarting "a severe incident whose aim was to attack Israeli citizens and sabotage the peace process".

Although yesterday's events unfolded without greater bloodshed - apart from an Israeli policemen who was wounded in the shoot-out and had a foot amputated - their timing was significant. In recent weeks, there has been growing anticipation of a terror attack, along with predictions that Palestinian frustration with the blocked peace process could end in violence.

Security officials have issued repeated warnings of plans by Izzadin Qassam, the military wing of Hamas, to set off bombs or to kidnap soldiers. They also expect a big increase in violent protests, stone throwing and petrol bomb attacks after a visit by the Pope at the end of the month.

The warnings have prompt ed tightened security in Jerusalem and other cities, with soldiers posted outside shopping centres, bus stations, and fast food restaurants.

So far, none of the perceived threats has caused loss of Israeli life. But last week security officials announced the arrest of some 60 Hamas activists in connection with a plot to blow up a building in Jerusalem.

Israel's deputy defence minister, Ephraim Sneh, said the men killed yesterday also belonged to Hamas.

"They intended to lay explosives in the centre of one of the Israeli towns and to inflict very heavy casualties," he said. However, the Hamas spiritual leader, Sheikh Ahmed Yassin, denied any knowledge of the plan.

According to Taibeh's mayor, Issam Masarwa, the Hamas cell had rented the ground floor of the white two-storey house on Wednesday. Within hours, Israeli intelligence agents were on their trail, and commandos surrounded the building. Mr Sneh said the forces were acting on information from their counterparts in the Palestinian Authority.

At 4.30am, the security forces used a megaphone to order the men to leave the house, according to a police spokeswoman, Sivan Kedmi. One man surrendered, but one of his comrades opened fire. A suitcase packed with explosives was detonated in the shootout that followed, killing two men.

Commandos then sent a sniffer dog into the house to test for further explosives. After the dog died in an explosion, they sent in a robot to search for bombs.

For several tense hours, the security forces encircled the building. Commandos stood on the roofs of homes in the tightly-packed area around the house, and a helicopter hov ered above. Schools were closed, and residents were ordered to stay inside.

In the late afternoon, when the bulldozers moved in to tear down the walls of the house, and uncover any more explosives, a third body was found in the ruins. Police could not confirm reports that yet another body was still in the house.

According to security officials, Hamas had been planning a spectacular attack to demonstrate that it was still active after the arrests last month, which were believed to be connected to a plot to blow up a 12-storey building in Jerusalem and two buses in the resort of Netanya. Some of those arrested reportedly confessed to a spate of bomb attacks last year.

As was the case in Taibeh yesterday, the crackdown was the result of cooperation with Palestinian intelligence services. Such joint efforts are widely believed to have blunted the force of Hamas attacks in recent months.

But in a recent interview, Sheikh Yassin denied that the organisation was a spent force.

"We never stopped armed resistance. It is always there, and will remain the strategy of the movement," he said. "The security coordination between the Americans, the Palestinians and the Israelis makes it more difficult for armed resistance. But when people are frustrated, when people have lost everything, anything can happen."

webTitle: Hollywood casts around for leading man

fields.headline: Hollywood casts around for leading man
fields.standfirst:
US movie industry split as White House candidates fail to excite

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: US movie industry split as White House candidates fail to excite
fields.body:
Hollywood has had its fair share of presidents over the last two decades. There has been a real one, Ronald Reagan, and a bunch of fictional ones, from Jack Nicholson in Mars Attacks to Michael Douglas in The American President and Martin Sheen in The West Wing, a popular US television series.

Now the four leading candidates for the real thing are seeking endorsements from the film industry. But, for once, there is no obvious Hollywood favourite.

As long ago as last July, George W Bush made a trip to Los Angeles and met some of the Hollywood establishment at an event laid on for him by the former chairman of Warner Bros Terry Semel. The Republican frontrunner has also picked up the support of a number of actors.

However, his ill-advised visit to Bob Jones university in South Carolina, the college where inter-racial dating is banned and Catholics are officially reviled, may have done some damage to his Hollywood rating.

John McCain's autobiography, Faith of My Fathers, has already been optioned by USA Films and he has been fund-raising in LA as part of his "Straight Talk Express", with $1,000 (£600)-a-head private receptions and $250-a-head lunches at the Beverly Hills Hilton hotel with the assistance of actors such as Morgan Fairchild.

Harrison Ford may well be the biggest name in the McCain camp, but the Vietnam veteran has also picked up support from the music mogul and Dreamworks studios partner Dave Geffen - who has also donated to Al Gore.

Mr McCain is often referred to as a "Bulworth" Republican, a reference to Warren Beatty's 1998 film in which a politician who has arranged for his own murder starts to talk the truth for a change and finds his popularity soaring.

Mr McCain is seen as closest to this image because he is someone who cannot be bothered to tiptoe round special interest groups.

Mr Gore is benefiting from Hollywood's traditional association with the Democrats, although neither he nor Bill Bradley has aroused the affection or excitement that greeted George McGovern in his unsuccessful attempt in 1972.

Bill Clinton was popular in the film business and made a point of returning the compliment. Mr Gore seems less at ease with that world but has still picked up support from Tom Cruise, among others. Tom Selleck has donated to Mr Gore and Mr Bradley - as well as Mr McCain.

It will do Mr Gore no harm that he also has the backing of Leonardo DiCaprio, who tries, usually in vain, to talk seriously about ecology to interviewers who only want to know who his girlfriend is.

But Mr Gore may not be the first choice for everyone in the film business. He has been mainly responsible for equipping televisions with a v-chip so that parents can monitor what their children watch and is regarded as something of a puritan. Writing in the film industry paper Variety, Christopher Stern wondered if the Gores in the White House would be the "first to declare it a sex and violence free zone" in the same way that the Clintons banned smoking.

"Clinton embraced pop culture," wrote Stern, "and Gore criticises it, but it's not clear if Bradley is even aware it exists."

Which may not be quite fair. Mr Bradley's best-known backer remains the basketball legend Michael Jordan, but he also has support from actors and directors of the calibre of Samuel L Jackson and Sydney Pollack.

But none of the four pressing to run in November's presidential election has emerged as the dream candidate.

"Hollywood, which loves to be smitten, hasn't fallen in love yet this election year," writes Scott Kaufer in the Los Angeles magazine. "There is no candidate with the perceived ideological purity - or urgent message - of a Gene McCarthy, no Democrat with the magnetism of a Jack or Bobby Kennedy, no Republican with the chops of Ronald Reagan."

The backing of the film industry is valued by candidates for two reasons: first, it can generate big funding at functions where wealthy people rub shoulders with the famous; second, it can raise a candidate's profile. But there can be disadvantages.

"Celebrities are a tricky business because they have a tendency to swamp the message," said Jack Feuer, the national media editor of Adweek, the advertising industry trade paper. The problem could be that people remember seeing the celebrity but forget with whom they are associated. "They can be a bigger brand than the brand they're promoting. I think celebrity endorsement might even hurt in the long run," Mr Feuer said.

The Campaign Study Group, which analyses political donations, showed Mr Gore topping the list of entertainment industry backing with $498,000, ahead of Mr Bradley ($320,000), Mr Bush ($202,000) and Mr McCain ($136,000). But this was before Mr McCain's late populist surge in California and his critical comments about the religious right, which will play well in LA.

Meanwhile, the cable channel HBO, with wicked timing, has just screened Bulworth. It is unlikely that any of the real-life candidates will echo these words of Bulworth's: "The rich are getting richer ... and rich people have always stayed on top by dividing white people from black people."

Nor will the real-life contenders be addressing the television journalists quite as bluntly as Bulworth does: "Our campaign is financed by the same guys who are paying you."

Unless, of course, Mr McCain decides to go for broke and see if what worked in the film can work for him in real life.

fields.headline: Legal 'safeguard' risks injustice
fields.trailText: Rules passed by parliament to prevent miscarriages of justice are not working, the watchdog on the crown prosecution service reports today.
fields.body:
Rules passed by parliament to prevent miscarriages of justice are not working, the watchdog on the crown prosecution service reports today.

The 1996 criminal procedure and investigations act, introduced after a series of wrongful convictions which dented public confidence in the justice system, is not living up to parliament's intention, says the CPS inspectorate.

Under the act, the prosecution must disclose to the defence any material which could undermine the prosecution case or be helpful to the defence. In a significant proportion of cases, CPS compliance is "defective in one or more respects".

The findings support claims by criminal lawyers that the system risks creating new miscarriages of justice. The chief inspector, Stephen Wooler, said: "The degree of non-compliance is unacceptable. Our findings do not come as a surprise. They confirm what the director of public prosecutions and criminal practitioners have suspected for some time."

Lawyers claim the system breaches the European convention on human rights because it denies defendants a fair trial, and say challenges could be mounted in the English courts once the human rights act comes into force next October.

David Calvert-Smith, director of public prosecutions, who heads the CPS, said: "I have never made any secret of my concern that the disclosure regime is not working as it should."

He said the report would provide "a further helpful stimulus" to ensure that by October the disclosure regime conformed with article 6 of the European convention on human rights. "We now need a concerted effort by the police, the CPS and the bar to make sure disclosure works properly."

The inspectorate recommends that crown prosecutors should be much more involved in deciding what should be disclosed. At present, police "disclosure officers" draw up lists of information for possible disclosure, and much information never gets to crown prosecutors or prosecuting counsel.

Criminal lawyers argue that the police, who are not legally trained, are not in the best position to decide what material would help the defence case or adversely affect the prosecution's. In several aspects, the regime places responsibilities "on individuals who appear ill-equipped to discharge them", the report concludes.

The inspectorate calls for crown prosecutors to look at much more material themselves, rather than rely on lists compiled by police disclosure officers, and for a bigger role for prosecuting counsel. It recognises that this would mean substantial extra resources for the CPS, and also for the police, who would have to copy far more material for prosecutors.

fields.headline: Composer awarded £8,000 for paper's 'heckle' libel
fields.trailText: A composer who was accused by the Times diary of organising hecklers to wreck performances of modernist, atonal music yesterday won £8,000 in libel damages in the high court in London.
fields.body:
A composer who was accused by the Times diary of organising hecklers to wreck performances of modernist, atonal music yesterday won £8,000 in libel damages in the high court in London.

However, Keith Burstein, 37, who says he lives a frugal lifestyle in order to compose, has to wait to learn whether he will have to pay his costs in bringing the action.

The composer, who changed his style from modernist to "romantic futurist", had sued the newspaper after its diary column ran an item which he said was a "straightforward lie". He had feared the article would cause others in the music world to shun him, putting him out of work.

Last night Mr Burstein, of London, said: "I feel fully vindicated. The case has been won in gradual stages. The Times told a lie, and that has been clearly established in court. I have never heckled at a concert. I have never interrupted any concert or performance of any sort. It would have been inconceivable to interrupt anybody's performance."

The diary item, in June 1997, referred to a forthcoming concert of Mr Burstein's music in a memorial to the late Labour leader John Smith.

It said: "The music is by Keith Burstein, an aggressively self-righteous, rather slushy composer who used to organise bands of hecklers to go about wrecking performances of modern atonal music, particularly anything by Sir Harrison Birtwistle."

Mr Burstein sued over the allegation that he wrecked concerts.

The jury settled on damages of £8,000 after deliberating for three hours. Judge Richard Walker had already ruled that the article was libellous.

The jury had not been allowed to hear, however, that Mr Burstein had been a member and co-founder of a group called the Hecklers, who had booed after a performance of Birtwistle's Gawain at Covent Garden. The judge struck out the Times's only line of defence - fair comment - in the absence of the jury.

He said this evidence might have been relevant to a defence plea of justification, but no such defence had been pleaded, and he could not allow the Times to introduce it by the back door in an attempt to restrict the amount of damages it was liable to pay.

Justin Rushbrooke, for the Times, submitted to the judge that because Mr Burstein had waited until the action started to claim that there was no defence of fair comment, the newspaper had wasted money gathering evidence, and he should make no order for costs.

Summing up to the jury, the judge had said: "You may feel that this was really quite a nasty allegation to make about someone who is a serious composer of classical music. You may think that the Times has not responded well to Mr Burstein's protests [about the article], but on the other hand you may feel that this is not an allegation of serious criminal conduct that would justify really large damages."

He added: "Bear in mind there's no evidence to suggest that the article had long-term damaging effects. You might feel that anything less than £5,000 would be mean and anything more than £25,000 to £30,000 would be extravagant.

"If the Times had chosen to prove any of this it was open to them to do so."

The newspaper had refused to publish a letter from Mr Burstein regarding the article and had not offered an apology or clarification. An offer of an ex gratia payment of £500 may have aggrieved him further.

The hearing resumes today for the judge's decision on costs.

fields.headline: Blunkett facing more fees pressure
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: English universities could have huge difficulties in recruiting and retaining good staff as they face a 1% cut in budgets in real terms for the coming year, the head of the funding council said yesterday.
fields.body:
English universities could have huge difficulties in recruiting and retaining good staff as they face a 1% cut in budgets in real terms for the coming year, the head of the funding council said yesterday.

Sir Brian Fender, chief executive of the higher education funding council for England, added to pressure on the government to consider charging students higher fees as he said that the basic funding position was unsatisfactory, even though the total grant to universities of £4.38bn would create an extra 37,000 student places.

"An average cash increase of only 1.5% in the unit of resource, following on cuts earlier in the nineties, will pose difficulties for institutions, particularly in recruiting and rewarding staff."

Lecturers said more than half of institutions would suffer a cut in real terms this year, compared with a third last year, despite a £100m increase in student fee payments.

David Blunkett, education secretary, has set his face against allowing universities to charge more than the current £1,025 a year tuition fee but acknowledged last month that a "debate" on top-up fees was inevitable after the next general election.

The Russell Group of top universities, including Oxford and Cambridge, has commissioned economists to draw up plans for differential fees which would not penalise the least well off. These are due to be published in the summer.

The funding council itself warned last month that all universities faced a "brain drain" as a generation of academics moved towards retirement while bright young graduates chose better paid careers in the private sector or abroad.

Worst hit is Thames Valley university, which sees its grant cut by 11% after being disciplined by the standards watchdog. More than £1m has been held back by the funding council because Thames Valley failed to recruit as many students as promised. But leading institutions such as the London School of Economics and School of Oriental and African Studies have also fared badly, with cuts in real terms.

David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers, said: "The prime minister wants to market our universities worldwide, yet half of them are being pushed through serious cuts toward penury. From leading edge to laughing stock - that's how we will be seen worldwide."

The department for education and employment said higher education funding had been increased by 11% since the election and Conservative cuts scaled down to 1% a year. Fees were enabling universities to expand.

Sir Brian said the position on capital spending was healthier than for a long time, with extra money for research equipment. "But we are drawing attention to the fact the recurrent income is significantly below the cost demands of the universities."

David Triesman, general secretary of the Association of University Teachers, said: "The prime minister wants to market our universities worldwide, yet half of them are being pushed through serious cuts toward penury. From leading edge to laughing stock - that's how we will be seen worldwide." The department for education and employment said higher education funding had been increased by 11% since the election and Conservative cuts scaled down to 1% a year. Fees were enabling universities to expand. Sir Brian said the position on capital spending was healthier than for a long time, with extra money for research equipment. "But we are drawing attention to the fact the recurrent income is significantly below the cost demands of the universities."

webTitle: Britain scorned as easy haven for criminals

fields.headline: Britain scorned as easy haven for criminals
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Belgium, the most militant of the four EU countries seeking General Pinochet's extradition, pledged yesterday to pursue the former dictator through the courts in Chile.
fields.byline: Ian Black  in Brussels,  Adela Gooch  in Madrid and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Belgium, the most militant of the four EU countries seeking General Pinochet's extradition, pledged yesterday to pursue the former dictator through the courts in Chile.

But it had decided against lodging an eleventh-hour appeal against the decision of the home secretary, Jack Straw, to allow him to return home.

Mr Straw's decision was met with similar resignation by the other three countries seeking extradition: Spain, France and Switzerland.

The Belgian foreign minister, Louis Michel, said: "We haven't reached the ultimate stage yet, namely making Pinochet accountable for his atrocious crimes. But we were able to demonstrate that a dictator is no longer out of the reach of justice."

He said the Chilean foreign minister, Juan Valdes, had asked him to pursue the case under Chilean law.

In Switzerland the public prosecutor, Bernard Bertossa, said there was no scope to appeal, but he condemned Mr Straw's decision and castigated Britain as "a comfortable haven for criminals". France, too, opted against an appeal.

Battling to the end, the Spanish magistrate who first ordered Gen Pinochet's arrest, made a last-ditch attempt to stop him leaving Britain.

Within minutes of Mr Straw's announcement, Judge Baltasar Garzon sent a nine-page fax to the crown prosecution service declaring his intention to appeal against the ruling. But Spain's foreign minister, Abel Matutes, reiterated as swiftly that he would not authorise the appeal.

"I am not angry but I do feel pain and sadness for Pinochet's victims," said Judge Garzon as he promised to maintain his international arrest warrant against Gen Pinochet and to continue his investigation of human rights violations during his 1973-90 rule.

"This has left a bitter taste in the mouth," said Mr Matutes. "We would all have wished to see the judicial process through to the very end."

His words were condemned as "arch hypocrisy" by the Socialist opposition, which has accused the government of going through the legal motions required by Judge Garzon's case while making every effort behind the scenes to prevent extradition.

"The government could have stopped this decision if it had backed Garzon's request for fresh medical tests to be carried out," said the Socialist party leader, Joaquin Almunia.

Carlos Seploy, a lawyer representing Gen Pinochet's victims, was equally damning of Mr Straw's decision.

"The UK has seriously violated its international obligations to cooperate in the arrest, extradition and punishment of criminals," he said.

Many expressed scepticism that justice could be done in Chile. "No Chilean judge has dared bring charges against him, so there is no hope that he can be judged there," said Mr Garzon.

In the European parliament, the Green group called Mr Straw's decision "an historical error". The Socialist group said: "When we see Pinochet being shuttled back home, we see a loser not a winner."

The British Green MEP Jean Lambert said: "The UK is worried about the increasing number of asylum seekers fleeing human rights violations, yet the government appears to be protecting the perpetrators of such abuse.

"There can be no double standards. There is no mercy or compassion in this decision for the victims or their families. Those of us who believe that human rights should be upheld can only condemn the home secretary."
