fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Fury over 10ft terrorist statue
fields.body:
Fury over 10ft terrorist statue

Democratic Unionists yesterday demanded the immediate removal of a 10ft statue of a terrorist from a cemetery in Londonderry. Assembly member Gregory Campbell said it was "enormously offensive".

The granite man standing guard with a rifle in combat clothing, scarf, beret and dark glasses, is to be unveiled by the Irish Republican Socialist party, aligned to the INLA, at the weekend.

Derry city council said permission had been granted, but the city engineer would report to the council later this month. "We don't screen memorials," it said. "This is the first time there has been a problem and the situation has to be assessed fully."

Shops withdraw goats' milk

A batch of St Helens Farm goats' milk contains traces of antibiotics and has been removed from sale.

The skimmed and semi-skimmed batch at Sainsbury's, Waitrose, Tesco and Safeway was "best before" March 6. It might cause severe reactions among those allergic to penicillin. All batches were routinely tested, and this had been the only one affected, the health department said

Rock star's dive injures fan

A teenage fan was injured when a member of Slipknot, an American rock band, performed a back flip from the balcony 30ft up and landed on top of her at a concert in Wolverhampton in the West Midlands.

She is in hospital with suspected head and spinal injuries. The town's civic hall said it had a ban on the audience doing "what we call stage diving", though it was unusual for a band to cause injuries this way.

It's the end for the Di Marcos

All the Di Marcos except Beppe are to be written out of EastEnders by John Yorke, who took over as producer two months ago. Marc Bannerman (Gianni), Louise Jameson (Rosa), Leila Birch (Teresa), Carly Hillman (Nicky), and also Leslie Schofield, who plays Jeff Healy, are not having their contracts renewed. A spokeswoman would not say how they would go.

webTitle: Straw tells why charges were not possible

fields.headline: Straw tells why charges were not possible
fields.standfirst:
Commons debate: 'I am aware that the consequence of refusing to extradite Senator Pinochet is that he will probably not be tried anywhere'

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Edited text of Jack Straw's statement to MPs
fields.body:
Edited text of Jack Straw's statement to MPs

My role under the extradition act 1989 is a quasi-judicial one. Although neither are generally incorporated into our domestic law, both the European extradition convention and the United Nations torture convention place important obligations on the UK, but I have to discharge those obligations within the powers and responsibilities placed on me by UK law.

All the decisions which I have taken have been mine alone, and have not been decisions of her majesty's government. Throughout, I have been keenly aware of the gravity of the crimes allegedly committed by Senator Pinochet, and of the desire for justice by those who suffered at the hands of the former Chilean regime.

This has been an unprecedented case. Both I and the courts have had to navigate in uncharted territory. Two judicial committees of the House of Lords took different views about what offences constituted extradition crimes. More recently, Mr Justice Kay ruled that my refusal of Belgium's request for disclosure of the medical report which I had commissioned was correct: shortly afterwards a full divisional court, while acknowledging strong arguments on both sides, came to the opposite view.

Senator Pinochet landed at Heathrow airport on 22 September 1998, for a private visit to the United Kingdom.

On 16 October the Metropolitan police received an extradition request from a Madrid court for the provisional arrest of Senator Pinochet for serious offences including the murder of Spanish citizens. The police were advised by FCO officials that Senator Pinochet did not enjoy diplomatic immunity from arrest.

The Bow Street magistrates court then issued a provisional arrest warrant and Senator Pinochet was arrested that evening.

Senator Pinochet's solicitors made representations to me on 21 October 1998, asking me to cancel this provisional arrest warrant. I declined to do so on the basis that the issues raised at this stage were a matter for the court. They challenged my decision.

A divisional court, headed by the lord chief justice, rejected that challenge and awarded me my costs. The court nevertheless quashed the warrant on the grounds that Senator Pinochet had sovereign immunity as a former head of state and that the warrant did not disclose an extradition crime.

The crown prosecution service, acting on behalf of Spain, then entered an appeal to the House of Lords. In a unique feature of this case, the issue was considered twice by the House of Lords, first in November 1998 and then, after the first judgment was vacated, in March 1999. The key majority finding of the second court was that torture was an international crime over which the parties to the torture convention had universal jurisdiction and that a former head of state did not have immunity from such crimes.

This ruling was a landmark judgment in human rights law, whose impact has been felt far beyond our shores. It will be a permanent legacy of the Pinochet case.

I issued a second authority to proceed on 14 April 1999. A second judicial challenge by Senator Pinochet's representatives was again rejected by the divisional court.

On 8 October 1999 Senator Pinochet was committed by the Bow Street magistrate to await my decision whether or not to extradite him to Spain. Senator Pinochet's solicitors applied for habeas corpus and a hearing date was set for 20 March this year.

On 14 October, I received representations from the Chilean embassy, supported by medical reports, which suggested that there had been a recent and significant deterioration in Senator Pinochet's health. I commissioned a medical examination of Senator Pinochet. The report indicated that Senator Pinochet was unfit to stand trial and that no significant improvement could be expected.

I informed the interested parties on 11 January that in the light of this medical evidence and subject to any representations received by 18 January, I was minded to conclude that no purpose would be served by continuing the Spanish extradition request. On 25 January a judicial review application was made by Belgium and Amnesty International for disclosure of the medical report.

A judgment of 15 February said that I should disclose the report to Spain, Belgium, France and Switzerland only in terms of strict confidence. Requesting states were invited to make any representation on the medical report by Tuesday 22 February 2000.

I considered the matter afresh in the light of all this material. Having done so, I was satisfied that the conclusion of the original report was correct.

The principle that an accused person should be mentally capable of following the proceedings, instructing lawyers and giving coherent evidence is fundamental to the idea of a fair trial. The trial of an accused in the condition diagnosed in Senator Pinochet, on the charges which have been made against him in this case, could not be fair in any country, and would violate article 6 of the European convention on human rights.

A number of representations which I received argued that even if there were questions about Senator Pinochet's fitness for trial, these should be determined in Spain and not here. I looked at this question with great care. However, I was advised and I concluded that on the basis of English law I was bound to form a view of my own on Senator Pinochet's fitness to stand trial and that I could not refrain from reaching such a view on the basis that the question could be determined in Spain.

In any event, I established with the assistance of the Spanish authorities that their principles for determining the fitness of an accused to stand trial were similar to ours. I therefore concluded that given the advice that no improvement in Senator Pinochet's condition could be expected, no judicial purpose would have been served by the continuation of extradition proceedings for the objective of a trial in Spain which could not result in any verdict on the charges against him.

Of the 70,000 letters and emails from the public which I have received from all over the world, and many letters from members of parliament and organisations, almost all have urged me to allow the extradition proceedings to take their course, so that the allegations made against Senator Pinochet could be tried. I attach great importance to the principle that universal jurisdiction against persons charged with international crimes should be effective.

I am all too aware that the practical consequence of refusing to extradite Senator Pinochet to Spain is that he will probably not be tried anywhere. I am very conscious of the sense of injury which will be felt by those who suffered from breaches of human rights in Chile in the past, as well as their relatives. All of these are matters of great concern, and I had them very much in mind when considering the evidence about Senator Pinochet's state of health.

They are among the reasons why I required the evidence of Senator Pinochet's condition to satisfy a high standard of expertise, thoroughness, objectivity and cogency before I was prepared to act on it.

Ultimately, however, I was driven to the conclusion that a trial of the charges against Senator Pinochet, however desirable, was simply no longer possible.

fields.headline: Victims of a brutal regime
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: • A total of 3,197 people were tortured, murdered and then disappeared under Pinochet's brutal 17-year regime
fields.body:
 A total of 3,197 people were tortured, murdered and then disappeared under Pinochet's brutal 17-year regime

 Inside the infamous torture centres, victims were subjected to violent and continuous beatings, often to the point of death, before doctors revived them to prolong their suffering

 Prisoners were tied up and "walled in" tiny cubicles where they were denied food, water and clothing; others were tied to a metal rack known as "the grill" where they were subjected to electric shocks to all parts of the body, including their genitals and their mouths

 Many were subjected to systematic rape and sodomy

 Age and gender was no defence; pregnant women and young children were also killed

 Pinochet was also involved in Operation Condor, a South America-wide operation to kidnap and kill dissidents opposed to the continent's rightwing military regimes

fields.headline: Rivals build homecoming tension
fields.standfirst:
Future uncertain as emotions erupt on the streets
Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Military helicopters buzzed over Santiago yesterday in practice runs for the high security operation that will transfer General Pinochet from an airport on the outskirts of the capital to a heavily guarded military hospital in the city centre.
fields.body:
Military helicopters buzzed over Santiago yesterday in practice runs for the high security operation that will transfer General Pinochet from an airport on the outskirts of the capital to a heavily guarded military hospital in the city centre.

By 7am, preparations for the imminent return of Gen Pinochet were visible throughout Santiago. Many street corners were bedecked in Chilean flags in a show of patriotic support for the former commander in chief.

His supporters drove in convoys around the city, honking their horns and screaming "grandpa is coming home".

Chileans of all political views were glued to television sets or crowded around newspaper kiosks as the country prepared for what is expected to be a chaotic return.

After 16 months' detention in London, the self-designated "senator for life" is expected to arrive in Santiago early this morning.

But the Gen Pinochet who returns is very different from the confident and proud soldier who left 16 months ago. He has been widely humiliated in the international press and made a symbol by international human rights groups keen to pursue notorious dictators.

Human rights groups in Chile, while saddened by the imminent return, were yesterday quick to define the episode as a positive advance for human rights.

"We don't have to be sad; quite the contrary, we have to feel that we have made an important step," said Viviana Diaz, president of Family Members of the Detained and Disappeared.

"We all know that Pinochet thought he was the untouchable, the invincible, one and that justice would never reach him."

The president-elect, Ricardo Lagos, a Socialist who will take over the government on March 11, has repeatedly stressed that the Chilean courts must decide the future of Gen Pinochet.

While many political analysts argue that the general's power and supporters are strong enough to block a trial in Chile, Mr Lagos this week insisted he could be tried in Chile. "If that were not the case, it would mean that our democracy is castrated," he said.

For Gen Pinochet to be tried in Chile, he must first be stripped of his senatorial privilege. A petition to that end is expected to be filed in the next 24 hours.

Hugo Guttierez, a leading human rights lawyer in Chile, was poised to coordinate a legal attack the minute the former commander in chief landed in Chile. Mr Guttierez said yesterday that the investigating judge Juan Guzman is handling 59 separate criminal investigations of Gen Pinochet and that Chilean law makes no exception for the poor health of a defendant.

Mr Guttierez also emphasised that he believed Gen Pinochet to be in far better health than was publicly admitted. "This [decision by Straw] is nothing more than a cover for a political decision. The mental health problems don't exist. When Pinochet arrives in Chile, the public is going to see how he quickly recovers."

Judge Guzman, who heads the Chilean investigation, will soon decide when Gen Pinochet will be forced to undergo fresh medical tests. Chilean law allows for exemption from prosecution only in cases of senility or dementia.

Tension rose throughout the country yesterday in anticipation of the general's return. A BBC reporter was attacked by his supporters at the non-profit Pinochet Foundation, who shouted, "colonialist", "imperialists" and "stupid gringo, go home".

Luis Cortes Villa, the director of the foundation, quickly broke up fights among supporters but expressed enthusiasm at the general's return. "Justice has been done," he said. "We are all very proud of General Pinochet for his strength. Thank God he could survive this whole process in London."

It is still unclear whether Gen Pinochet will immediately be transferred to a military hospital in Santiago or hustled away to a military post in the desert to the north. But his presence in the country is sure to uncork street celebrations - billed by supporters as a carnival - as well as mournful protests and another round of national soul searching.

Despite efforts by rightwing political parties to define the Pinochet arrest as an affront to national sovereignty, opinion polls in Chile indicate that 60% of the public want him put on trial here.

Jack Straw's decision was widely interpreted as a victory for the outgoing Chilean president, Eduardo Frei, who had long promised to bring Gen Pinochet home before March 10 - the end of his six-year term.

After frustrated attempts to convince the British judicial system that the general, as a special ambassador or a former head of state, was immune from prosecution, the administration switched strategies.

Led by the foreign minister, Juan Gabriel Valdes, the Chileans began to argue last December that Gen Pinochet's deteriorating health made him unfit for trial in Spain. That argument eventually prevailed, although the political capital spent in defending the former dictator has cost the ruling Christian Democrat government heavily.

After Mr Straw's announcement that Gen Pinochet had been freed, Mr Valdes described the entire Pinochet affair as a "disgusting" episode in the country's history.

He added: "The primary person responsible for this event is the person who maintained a lack of respect for international politics - Augusto Pinochet."

Judge Guzman, who heads the Chilean investigation, will soon decide when Gen Pinochet will be forced to undergo fresh medical tests. Chilean law allows for exemption from prosecution only in cases of senility or dementia. Tension rose throughout the country yesterday in anticipation of the general's return. A BBC reporter was attacked by his supporters at the non-profit Pinochet Foundation, who shouted, "colonialist", "imperialists" and "stupid gringo, go home". Luis Cortes Villa, the director of the foundation, quickly broke up fights among supporters but expressed enthusiasm at the general's return. "Justice has been done," he said. But his presence in the country is sure to uncork street celebrations - billed by supporters as a carnival - as well as mournful protests and another round of national soul searching. He added: "The primary person responsible for this event is the person who maintained a lack of respect for international politics - Augusto Pinochet."

fields.headline: No hiding place for tyrants
fields.standfirst:
The legacy: Key precedent established for human rights

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Augusto Pinochet has escaped trial, but there is one substantial and lasting legacy from his 17 months as an unwilling exile: international law will never be the same again.
fields.body:
Augusto Pinochet has escaped trial, but there is one substantial and lasting legacy from his 17 months as an unwilling exile: international law will never be the same again.

The battle to bring the former Chilean dictator to justice, culminating in the law lords' ruling a year ago opening the way for his prosecution, has put the entire international regime of human rights law on an established footing.

The old doctrines of sovereign immunity, under which former heads of state were immune from criminal action at the behest of authorities in foreign states, and "act of state" - which means that the courts of one state will not question the legality of official acts by another - have given way to the emerging international law principle of individual responsibility for crimes against humanity.

When Gen Pinochet first went to the high court to challenge the arrest warrant issued against him at Spain's request, the answer seemed simple. Three judges held that the doctrines of sovereign immunity and act of state gave the former Chilean dictator complete immunity from prosecution.

The House of Lords ruled that he could stand trial, by the narrow margin of three to two. But the lords overturned their own ruling when it emerged that Lord Hoffmann, one of the majority, had links with Amnesty International. The final judgment by a rarely convened panel of seven law lords gave the go-ahead for prosecution by six to one.

The law lords held that the general could be prosecuted in Britain or extradited to stand trial under British acts of parliament that gave effect to our obligations under international treaties.

The judgment, probably the most momentous Britain's highest court has ever delivered, now stands as a key precedent in international law throughout the world. It confirms that the whole edifice of international treaties and national laws set up to ensure that those, even at the highest level, who commit crimes against humanity have no hiding place is not just a well-meaning gesture.

Former dictators will have to think twice before setting foot in any of the many countries that have signed up to international treaties on torture and hostage-taking, and the case stands as a warning to those tempted to commit such crimes in future.

The debacle over Lord Hoffmann damaged the standing of the House of Lords as a court. The saga has strengthened the case for the transformation of the law lords into a true supreme court.

fields.headline: National Roundup
fields.trailText:
Art theft unnoticed for 20 years
The National Maritime Museum yesterday admitted it had failed to notice that 13 paintings with a total value of around £90,000 had been missing from its collection for 20 years.
fields.body:
Art theft unnoticed for 20 years
The National Maritime Museum yesterday admitted it had failed to notice that 13 paintings with a total value of around £90,000 had been missing from its collection for 20 years.

The paintings disappeared from a museum store, and management has concluded that theft by a member of staff is the most likely explanation.

The pictures are 17th, 18th and 19th century seascapes, and one 20th century oil sketch of an aircraft carrier. Their banality would have made them easy to dispose of, as they were not valuable enough to arouse suspicion.

The alarm was raised last year by a dealer in Amsterdam. He had bought an early 17th century Dutch oil painting, found it had been sold under the wrong name, and traced it back to Greenwich.

The museum's director, Richard Ormand, then ordered his first audit in 14 years. Past inventory errors were discovered including pictures logged twice or under different numbers and pictures recorded as out on loan when they had been returned. [Maev Kennedy]

Marijuana 'is heart attack risk'
Smoking marijuana may increase fivefold the risk of a heart attack in the hour after inhaling, according to research.

Murray Mittleman from the Beth Israel Deaconess medical centre in Boston told a conference of cardiovascular scientists in San Diego yesterday that 124 out of 3,882 patients who survived heart attacks reported using marijuana regularly. Of these, 37 had used the drug within 24 hours of their heart attack, and nine had smoked marijuana up to an hour before.

In the first hour after smoking marijuana the risk of a heart attack was 4.8 times higher, falling to 1.7 times in the second hour.

Earlier this week marijuana was found to kill brain tumours in rats and alleviate symptoms of multiple sclerosis in mice. But these medical benefits were based on direct treatment with either THC, the active ingredient of cannabis, or cannabinoid compounds that mimic its effect, not the plant material itself.

Dr Mittleman's research was concerned with people who smoked. He said he could not be sure whether the heart attack was triggered by smoke from the plant, or by the active ingredient of the drug.

He said: "Smoked marijuana or oral THC increases the heart rate by 40 beats per minute. It causes the blood pressure to increase when the person is lying down and then abruptly fall when the person stands up. This could precipitate a heart attack."

There is pressure in Britain and the US for more liberal medicinal use of cannabis. But Dr Mittleman said that it might be no help to people with coronary diseases. [Tim Radford]

Hitler's notes fetch £11,700
Notes written by Adolf Hitler for a 1939 speech to the Reichstag yesterday fetched more than £11,700 in an auction of Third Reich items in Swindon, Wiltshire.

The speech, written on cards, was said to be one of Hitler's most notorious, because of its anti-Jewish nature. The cards had been swapped in 1954 for a packet of cigarettes by Wing Commander Ronald Mason, 79, from Swindon.

The cards were bought by a dealer, John Wilson, on behalf of an American collector. Mr Wilson said: "Something like this comes on the market once every 10 or 15 years."

The highest price, £14,000, was for a pair of binoculars from Hitler's yacht, Grille. The manuscript of a letter from Hitler to Emperor Hirohito of Japan fetched more than £6,000.

Other items included depositions made by Jewish survivors of the Belsen concentration camp as evidence in trials of the guards, and a collection of 39 Jewish prisoners' letters including a secret diary.

Lord Janner, chairman of the Holocaust Educational Trust, described the sale of Nazi memorabilia as "revolting". Richard Westwood-Brookes, a documents specialist at the auctioneer, Dominic Winter, said: "You can't deny that periods of history existed no matter how terrible they might be. The only people who have shown interest in this are genuine collectors and dealers."

TV brings families closer
Watching television brings families closer together, according to a survey published yesterday.

Parents across England and Wales say they value spending time with their children in what is called "the snuggle factor".

Many believe watching television as a family unit leaves their children feeling more secure.

The survey, produced for the Disney Channel UK, questioned 1,000 parents of children aged between four and 14. 47% said what they enjoyed most about television was being able to sit with their children on the sofa.

A third said that because of television they spent more time with their children. More than half said television was the family's preferred way to spend time together, beating traditional pastimes such as board games.

Psychologist David Lewis, who analysed the findings, said: "Television provides adults with the perfect opportunity for snuggling up with their children, becoming physically and emotionally closer as a result."

The survey showed differences between the south, where 57% said television brought them closer to their children, and the north, where the figure was 43%.

Lessons of malaria death
The department of health yesterday pledged that "lessons will be learned" from the death of a man aged 22 who caught malaria in hospital.

Gavin Sebborn was admitted to the infectious diseases ward of a Nottingham hospital in March last year suffering from pneumonia but died 12 days after he was discharged.

An investigation concluded that Mr Sebborn, from New Basford, Nottingham, and two others on the ward had most likely contracted malaria through a bottle of saline contaminated by another patient who had the disease.

Nottingham city hospital NHS trust was last month fined £15,000 after a prosecution brought by the health and safety executive.

The court heard a bottle had been left on a trolley in the ward and reused, spreading the infection. The two others recovered.

An NHS report published yesterday criticised the use of bottles with contents that can be used for more than one patient. A similar spread of infection could happen in many other hospitals unless proper precautions were taken.

The hospital has admitted liability and paid Mr Sebborn's family undisclosed compensation.

The NHS executive said: "The department of health's chief medical officer is determined that lessons are learned from Mr Sebborn's tragic death."

webTitle: The long road from Surrey to Santiago

fields.headline: The long road from Surrey to Santiago
fields.standfirst:
How secret talks around the world found a 'solution' to the diplomatic crisis and Straw's dilemma

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Sighs of relief could be heard echoing down the corridors of power in London, Santiago and Madrid yesterday as Augusto Pinochet took his final, faltering steps on British soil and boarded a Chilean airforce jet at RAF Waddington.
fields.body:
Sighs of relief could be heard echoing down the corridors of power in London, Santiago and Madrid yesterday as Augusto Pinochet took his final, faltering steps on British soil and boarded a Chilean airforce jet at RAF Waddington.

His departure signals the end of a 17-month diplomatic and legal nightmare for the governments of Britain, Chile and Spain, during which the general, once an almost forgotten pariah reviled by the left and loved by the right, has been cast centre stage in the debate on how the international community should deal with leaders who break the norms of civilised behaviour.

The victims and families of Pinochet's torture squads will have found yesterday's events hard to bear, but no doubt the civil servants, pragmatic to the last, will have raised a glass to the general, wishing him godspeed on his final journey home. Nowhere more so than in Madrid, where the government has found itself caught up in a spiralling diplomatic disaster that began when Baltasar Garzon - a crusading prosecutor with little regard for the diplomatic niceties that usually govern international relations - issued a warrant for Pinochet's arrest in October 1998.

Pinochet's lawyers fought the case all the way to the House of Lords, claiming, without success, that the general was entitled to immunity as a former head of state. But where the law could not save him from the dock of a Spanish court, his health, perhaps perversely, could.

While there is no reason to doubt that the final decision to end the extradition proceedings against Pinochet on medical grounds was taken in isolation by Jack Straw, acting in his quasi judicial role, it is also the case that the home secretary is not impervious to pressures from other departments. The foreign office in particular has been exercised by the possible ramifications of the case.

Diplomatic relations with Chile have been stretched, almost to breaking point, by the general's detention, while the affair produced a warning blip on the radar screens in the foreign office which suggested it could blow up to affect Britain's relations with much of South America.

Colonialism

Britain's trade links with Chile are negligible in real terms, but Pinochet's detention offended many governments in the region, who saw his arrest as Spain, and by default Britain, imposing a form of moral colonialism on Chile. Santiago's insistence that the general should only be tried in Chile was met with sympathy and support in other South American capitals. Argentina, whose General Galtieri is also on the list of former dictators Judge Garzon wants to see in the dock, vociferously supported the Chilean government.

The beginning of the end of the saga came last June when Robin Cook met Abel Matutes, the Spanish foreign minister, in secret during a summit in Rio of European and South American countries. Amid rumours of the ageing general's ailing health the two men reached an agreement. "I will not let him die in Britain," the foreign secretary reportedly told his Spanish counterpart. "I will not let him come to Spain," Mr Matutes responded.

But it was not until September that a solution to the affair presented itself. Over a cup of tea in a tiny room of the UN building in New York, Mr Cook met the Chilean foreign minister, Juan Gabriel Valdes. Mr Valdes surprised the foreign secretary by turning around the well-rehearsed argument that the Pinochet case was having a detrimental effect on the two countries' relations, instead concentrating on the general's health. The die was cast. It was now just a matter of time.

The home office was briefed by the foreign office, which later passed on representations from the Chilean embassy supported by medical reports suggesting there had been a recent and significant deterioration in Pinochet's condition and that he might be unfit to stand trial.

The request to send him home on humanitarian grounds came less than a month after a new Chilean ambassador, Pablo Cabrera, arrived in London. He was sent by the president, Eduardo Frei, with one instruction: "Bring Pinochet home."

Mr Cabrera's predecessor, Mario Artaza, who in private was reduced almost to tears by having to defend a man he despised, steadfastly refused to go anywhere near Pinochet's rented mansion on the Wentworth estate in Surrey. But Mr Cabrera brought a more pragmatic approach to the affair. His first task was to visit the general to outline the new approach.

Despite being surrounded by sycophantic supporters, loneliness was said to be making Pinochet severely depressed. That and suddenly being forced to spend long hours with his wife, something he had studiously avoided for much of his married life. His only real contact with the outside world came through the three special branch officers who spent every waking hour either in the next room or accompanying Pinochet during his brief sojourns in the mansion's garden.

According to the new Chilean ambassador, the man he found at Wentworth in September was a shadow of the general who had ruled Chile for 17 years with an iron fist. Unable to concentrate for more than a few minutes, Pinochet seemed to have no idea why he was under arrest.

Last rites

There was some hostility among the general's close advisers to the "health" option. Their interests conflicted with those of the Chilean government. For Mr Frei and his centre-left coalition the doomsday scenario was Pinochet dying in Britain: the old general returning to Santiago in a coffin would immediately grant Pinochet martyr status. But if Mr Cabrera could get him home he would return to Chile a disgraced and discredited man.

The first public sign that Pinochet's health may have deteriorated came in October at his committal hearing at Bow Street magistrates court in central London. Michael Loxton, the general's Surrey GP, told the court he had recently suffered two minor strokes to add to the plethora of other ailments - diabetes, kidney problems and incontinence - and that to put him in the witness box "would run the risk of him being very ill". At one point, the court was told, Pinochet's advisers had even called a priest to administer the last rites.

By the end of November the home office, helped behind the scenes by the Chilean embassy, had managed to get Pinochet, or at least his advisers, to agree that he would undergo independent medical tests. But it was more than a month, on January 5, before six hours of tests were carried out by four eminent doctors at Northwick Park hospital in west London.

The home office received the report the following day. Sitting at the kitchen table of his town house in south London, Mr Straw opened his red ministerial box and read the reports. They made grim reading. Pinochet was apparently brain-damaged and his condition was deteriorating.

After consulting the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, Mr Straw was convinced enough by the evidence to announce on January 11 - six days before the Chilean election - that he was "minded" to halt extradition proceedings against the general. While it would be hard to argue that Pinochet's health did not warrant his release, it was prudent to announce the decision a week before the Chilean election, rather than appearing to kowtow to the demands of a newly installed rightwing government afterwards. In the event Ricardo Lagos, Chile's first socialist president since Salvador Allende was killed during Pinochet's coup in 1973, won by a small majority.

Human rights groups were up in arms at Mr Straw's decision. In March Pinochet had been looking sprightly, taking tea with Lady Thatcher, while in July he had given an apparently lucid interview with Dominic Lawson, the editor of the Sunday Telegraph. How could he suddenly be too ill to stand trial?

For all the apoplexy of Amnesty International and others, Mr Straw's announcement should have left the way open for a quick and easy exit for the general. The Spanish foreign minister had been true to his word, and in a move that infuriated Judge Garzon the Spanish government refused to pass on a request for judicial review of Mr Straw's decision.

But just as the general appeared to be heading for the airport the Belgian government, in a move that enraged the foreign office and Mr Straw, entered the legal fray. Egged on by Judge Garzon, the Belgian government launched judicial review proceedings against Mr Straw's decision not to release the medical reports.

The home office had made what could have been a potentially disastrous mistake in its dealings with the general's lawyers. Officials had offered to keep the report completely confidential, even going so far as to refuse to disclose them to the countries wanting to extradite the former dictator. It was not much, but for the groups hoping to reverse Mr Straw's decision it was a legal chink of light that could be exploited in the courts.

After two high court hearings a panel of three judges ruled that the medical report should be released in confidence to the extraditing states. Within hours of the report arriving in Madrid it appeared in full in three Spanish newspapers. The finger of suspicion pointed at the Spanish government, although it denied any involvement. But by releasing the report the government was able to get through to the Spanish public what it had been saying all along: Pinochet should be allowed to go home.

While the legal manoeuvring and posturing continued in London the Chilean military swung into action to plan "Operation Return". After so many months of inaction, now was the Chilean military's chance to shine. Pinochet would have been proud of the planning of the operation. A Boeing 707 equipped with a mobile hospital was dispatched to Bermuda, where it waited on the tarmac for a week before finally arriving in the UK.

What happens to Pinochet now is a matter of conjecture. Mr Lagos has promised to allow the Chilean judiciary to do what it will with him, but the consensus among most observers is that as long as he does not try to re-enter public life by taking his seat in the senate he will be allowed to live out his days in peace, in marked contrast to the hullabaloo that surrounded his 16- month enforced stay in Britain.

One thing, however, is for sure: he will never leave Chile again. And that, perhaps, will be the former dictator's final and lasting legacy. The man who ordered the murder of more than 3,000 people has ensured that former heads of state cannot hide behind state immunity to avoid prosecution for crimes committed in office.

The first public sign that Pinochet's health may have deteriorated came in October at his committal hearing at Bow Street magistrates court in central London. Michael Loxton, the general's Surrey GP, told the court he had recently suffered two minor strokes to add to the plethora of other ailments - diabetes, kidney problems and incontinence - and that to put him in the witness box "would run the risk of him being very ill". At one point, the court was told, Pinochet's advisers had even called a priest to administer the last rites. By the end of November the home office, helped behind the scenes by the Chilean embassy, had managed to get Pinochet, or at least his advisers, to agree that he would undergo independent medical tests. But it was more than a month, on January 5, before six hours of tests were carried out by four eminent doctors at Northwick Park hospital in west London. The home office received the report the following day. Sitting at the kitchen table of his town house in south London, Mr Straw opened his red ministerial box and read the reports. They made grim reading. Pinochet was apparently brain-damaged and his condition was deteriorating. After consulting the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, Mr Straw was convinced enough by the evidence to announce on January 11 - six days before the Chilean election - that he was "minded" to halt extradition proceedings against the general. While it would be hard to argue that Pinochet's health did not warrant his release, it was prudent to announce the decision a week before the Chilean election, rather than appearing to kowtow to the demands of a newly installed rightwing government afterwards. In the event Ricardo Lagos, Chile's first socialist president since Salvador Allende was killed during Pinochet's coup in 1973, won by a small majority. Human rights groups were up in arms at Mr Straw's decision. In March Pinochet had been looking sprightly, taking tea with Lady Thatcher, while in July he had given an apparently lucid interview with Dominic Lawson, the editor of the Sunday Telegraph. How could he suddenly be too ill to stand trial? For all the apoplexy of Amnesty International and others, Mr Straw's announcement should have left the way open for a quick and easy exit for the general. The Spanish foreign minister had been true to his word, and in a move that infuriated Judge Garzon the Spanish government refused to pass on a request for judicial review of Mr Straw's decision. But just as the general appeared to be heading for the airport the Belgian government, in a move that enraged the foreign office and Mr Straw, entered the legal fray. Egged on by Judge Garzon, the Belgian government launched judicial review proceedings against Mr Straw's decision not to release the medical reports. The home office had made what could have been a potentially disastrous mistake in its dealings with the general's lawyers. Officials had offered to keep the report completely confidential, even going so far as to refuse to disclose them to the countries wanting to extradite the former dictator. It was not much, but for the groups hoping to reverse Mr Straw's decision it was a legal chink of light that could be exploited in the courts. After two high court hearings a panel of three judges ruled that the medical report should be released in confidence to the extraditing states. Within hours of the report arriving in Madrid it appeared in full in three Spanish newspapers. The finger of suspicion pointed at the Spanish government, although it denied any involvement. But by releasing the report the government was able to get through to the Spanish public what it had been saying all along: Pinochet should be allowed to go home. While the legal manoeuvring and posturing continued in London the Chilean military swung into action to plan "Operation Return". After so many months of inaction, now was the Chilean military's chance to shine. Pinochet would have been proud of the planning of the operation. A Boeing 707 equipped with a mobile hospital was dispatched to Bermuda, where it waited on the tarmac for a week before finally arriving in the UK. What happens to Pinochet now is a matter of conjecture. Mr Lagos has promised to allow the Chilean judiciary to do what it will with him, but the consensus among most observers is that as long as he does not try to re-enter public life by taking his seat in the senate he will be allowed to live out his days in peace, in marked contrast to the hullabaloo that surrounded his 16- month enforced stay in Britain. One thing, however, is for sure: he will never leave Chile again. And that, perhaps, will be the former dictator's final and lasting legacy. The man who ordered the murder of more than 3,000 people has ensured that former heads of state cannot hide behind state immunity to avoid prosecution for crimes committed in office.

webTitle: Right rejoices as general's foes vow to keep up fight

fields.headline: Right rejoices as general's foes vow to keep up fight
fields.standfirst:
Thatcher welcomes end to 'vendetta'

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Lady Thatcher led a chorus of rightwingers welcoming the release of General Pinochet after 16 months in British custody. The baroness, Gen Pinochet's most prominent supporter in Britain, accused the Labour government of having conducted "a political vendetta" that had done much damage.
fields.body:
Lady Thatcher led a chorus of rightwingers welcoming the release of General Pinochet after 16 months in British custody. The baroness, Gen Pinochet's most prominent supporter in Britain, accused the Labour government of having conducted "a political vendetta" that had done much damage.

But dismay was expressed by survivors of his regime and by representatives of human rights organisations including Amnesty International, all of whom had wanted him to face trial for the torture and murder of thousands of people during his years in power.

Lady Thatcher, who demonstrated solidarity with the dictator by having tea with him soon after his arrest, and addressed a rally last autumn, read a short statement outside her London office saying Britain had rewarded the general badly for his help during the Falklands war.

"His health has been broken, the reputation of our courts has been tarnished and vast sums of public money have been squandered for a political vendetta," she said.

The question of his facing trial was a matter for Chile, not Britain, she added.

The other prominent rightwing supporter was Lord Lamont, the former Tory chancellor, who said: "This has gone on too long and reflected no credit on British justice or the British government." He added: "No evidence has been offered against him. The only evidence is the evidence of victims."

The Conservative leader, William Hague, accused the government of wasting taxpayers' money on "student politics" aimed at "pleasing Labour activists and Guardian leader writers".

But Amnesty challenged the "irregular" procedures followed by the home secretary, Jack Straw, in allowing Gen Pinochet to go home on medical grounds.

Overall it saw the case as a triumph for international law: "The fact that Augusto Pinochet was arrested - almost unthinkable just 17 months ago - has sent a powerful message: no one is above international law, even when national laws offer protection from prosecution."

The Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture described Mr Straw's decision as a piece of political expediency that had allowed an arch-torturer to escape justice.

Sheila Cassidy, a British doctor who was tortured in Chile, said: "I have no personal animosity towards him. But I feel very strongly on behalf of the families of the 'disappeared' and on my own behalf that he should have stood trial."

Dr Cassidy, who was tortured for treating a victim of Gen Pinochet's regime, said an important opportunity had been lost to try to heal the wounds felt by the families of the disappeared.

The Liberal Democrat home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, shared Amnesty's view that while disappointed Gen Pinochet would not be tried, the law lords' ruling was an important international precedent. It showed the need for an international criminal justice court.

webTitle: Two years in the life of a former dictator

fields.headline: Two years in the life of a former dictator
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText:
March 1998
Pinochet steps down as head of the Chilean army and becomes a senator, with a guarantee of parliamentary immunity for life
fields.body:
March 1998
Pinochet steps down as head of the Chilean army and becomes a senator, with a guarantee of parliamentary immunity for life

September
The 82-year-old general undertakes a private trip to London for back surgery

October
The Spanish judges Manuel Garcia Catellon and Baltasar Garzon, investigating Pinochet in connection with the torture and disappearance of Spanish citizens during the Pinochet regime, contact Interpol. British police arrest a sedated Pinochet at the London clinic

November
On Pinochet's 83rd birthday five law lords rule by 3-2 that he is not immune from prosecution

December
Jack Straw allows the extradition process to go forward, but the law lords' ruling is set aside after allegations of bias on the part of one of the five, Lord Hoffmann. He failed to declare links with Amnesty International

January 1999
A new panel of seven law lords is appointed to hear the Pinochet case again. British supporters of Pinochet, including Lord Lamont and Lady Thatcher, launch a campaign defending his human rights record

March
By a 6-1 majority the laws lords rule that Pinochet must face extradition to Spain, but that he is immune from prosecution for crimes committed before 1988, when a change in British law rendered 'extraterritorial' torture illegal

April
Straw says there are no compassionate grounds to halt proceedings. A new arrest warrant is served on Pinochet

May
Judicial review of extradition process denied

July
Pinochet undergoes electro-cardiogram

September
General undergoes brain scan followed by neurological tests

October
After four-day extradition hearing at Bow Street, magistrates commit him on 35 charges to await Straw's ruling. Pinochet excused from appearing after court hears he has suffered two minor strokes

November
Home office asks for Pinochet to have medical examination

January 2000
Pinochet undergoes medical tests to assess his fitness to be extradited. Based on the results Straw says he is 'minded' to release him

February
Belgium tries to force the release of Pinochet's medical report. High court rules that the report should be disclosed under conditions of 'strict confidentiality' to Belgium, France, Spain and Switzerland. Leaks to newspapers disclose that the general is suffering brain damage

March
Straw declares Pinochet will not be extradited. The general leaves for Chile

webTitle: MI5 spied on Tallulah's romp with Eton boys

fields.headline: MI5 spied on Tallulah's romp with Eton boys
fields.standfirst: Home office secrets: Headmaster covered up for 'immoral' screen and stage star to avoid scandal for school, thwarting attempt at deportation Full text of the Tallulah Bankhead memo
fields.trailText: The home office tried to throw the American movie actress Tallulah Bankhead out of Britain as a danger to public morality after MI5 called her "an extremely immoral woman" who had indulged in "indecent and unnatural practices" with Eton schoolboys, according to confidential files released by the public record office today.
fields.body:
The home office tried to throw the American movie actress Tallulah Bankhead out of Britain as a danger to public morality after MI5 called her "an extremely immoral woman" who had indulged in "indecent and unnatural practices" with Eton schoolboys, according to confidential files released by the public record office today.

The five involved, one the son of a lord and another of a baronet, had to leave the public school, but the headmaster kept the scandal secret by refusing to cooperate with a special branch inquiry - thus thwarting official attempts to have the star thrown out.

She was the most popular West End actress of her time and a friend of Ivor Novello. Her husky "Hello Dahling" is now a theatrical cliche. Tallulah, or "TB" as she appears in a home office file, was alleged to have entertained the boys at the Cafe de Paris hotel in Bray on the Thames - said to be a hot rendezvous for the "smart and fast set".

Whispers of scandal percolated through the theatrical profession in the 1920s, but the authorities' lurid suspicions remained secret until today. A confidential MI5 report to the home secretary in August 1928 states:

"The charge against Miss Tallulah Bankhead (an American aged 26) is quite simply (a) that she is an extremely immoral woman and (b) that in consequence of her association with some Eton boys last term, the latter have had to leave Eton.

"As regards (a) according to informant, she is both a Lesbian and immoral with men. Informant believes she comes from a respectable American family, her father, a senator, having turned her out of the house when she was young owing to immoral proclivities.

"It is also said she 'kept' a negress in America before she came to the country in 1925 and she 'keeps' a girl in London now. As regards her more natural proclivities, informant tells me that she bestows her favours 'generously' without payment. Informant added that her 'circle' is a centre of vice patronised by at least one of the most prominent sodomites in London."

The MI5 officer, identified only as FHM, said it was common knowledge at Eton that five or six boys had been convicted of "breaking bounds" for associating with Miss Bankhead. He said they included Lord Rosslyn's grandson, the third son of Sir Matthew "Scatters" Wilson (whose two older boys had already been sent down), and a boy named Parsons.

"TB was seen at Eton frequently last term. I hear from another master that one or both of Sir M Wilson's older sons used to motor down with her to see the third son who was then smuggled away for the afternoon under a rug in the car. It is said this was the start of a TB Eton boys' clique."

William Bridgeman, first lord of the admiralty, made discreet inquiries, but the headmaster, Dr CA Alington, told him: "No information could be obtained at Eton, and no inquiry or action that the home office could make or take regarding TB could embarrass Eton."

Special branch detectives spent two very pleasant Sundays visiting the Hotel de Paris to collect evidence. They found "well over 100 expensive motor cars" at Bray, hotel daily takings in excess of £4,000, and TB being a habitual visitor - but nothing to corroborate the alleged "indecent and unnatural offences".

MI5 secured a private letter to Eton parents in which the head denied anybody was expelled but admitted two boys had been dismissed and three disciplined.

FHM, lacking the evidence to throw Miss Bankhead out of Britain, noted: "The headmaster is obviously not prepared to assist the home office - he wants to do everything possible to keep Eton out of the scandal."

webTitle: Police believe nun invented rape attack

fields.headline: Police believe nun invented rape attack
fields.trailText: Detectives believe that a nun who said she had been raped and injured after leaving a Christmas party made the story up.
fields.body:
Detectives believe that a nun who said she had been raped and injured after leaving a Christmas party made the story up.

The woman, 37, was found with injuries so severe that she lost three pints of blood and required life-saving hospital treatment. Police believe she suffers from Munchausen's syndrome, and inflicted the wounds on herself to get attention.

Scotland Yard is considering bringing charges against the nun for wasting police time and have interviewed her "as a suspect".

She was found just after midnight on December 22 last year in a pool of blood on a building site in Finsbury Park, north London. She told officers she had been repeatedly raped, slashed with a broken bottle or serrated knife and left for dead.

Detective inspector Richard Jack had described the rape as the "most vicious and nasty attack" he had experienced in his career.

A police hunt costing up to £50,000 was launched and a man arrested and released. The nun described an attacker to police and gave a harrowing account of the alleged incident to a tabloid newspaper.

Scotland Yard said yesterday the rape and assault investigation had been ended and that no suspect was being sought. "Officers from CID Holloway interviewed the alleged victim under caution [on Wednesday] at the police station," a spokeswoman said. "She was not arrested.

"Consideration is being given to the submission of a file to the crown prosecution service regarding the alleged wasting of police time. A decision over whether to submit a report will be reached in the next two days."

A "thorough" police investigation of the allegations had not found any evidence to support the nun's claims, she said.

The nun went to police after attending a party for a charity for the homeless. Earlier in the evening she rang her convent, the Servite Sisters order in Chelmsford, Essex, to say she would be late in returning.

Officers now believe she drank heavily in a central London pub and then took a taxi to Finsbury Park.

Suspicions about her account grew, and after an assessment by a police profiler her allegations were treated as false.

Simon Wessely, professor of psychiatry at King's College hospital, said cases of Munchausen's syndrome were so rare that little was known about sufferers. One possibility was that they "like being the centre of attention; there is a dramatic quality to it. These are people who can't just go to a doctor or psychiatrist and say I need help; they can't ask for it directly.

"There is also the view that these people are masochistic and get pleasure from inflicting injuries on themselves. I'm not so sure about that.

"The third view is that people get a satisfaction from fooling doctors or the police. There is also the view that the motives are completely unconscious."

The Daily Mail quoted the nun as saying that she hoped her attacker "rots in hell": "I can remember the fear. It was so painful. I remember begging him to stop. I was unconscious for a while, so I don't know how much time passed."

webTitle: Study casts doubt on Down's blood tests

fields.headline: Study casts doubt on Down's blood tests
fields.trailText: Blood tests are no more likely to detect a baby with Down's syndrome than the combination of the mother's age and ultrasound checks, a study of more than 31,000 pregnancies has revealed.
fields.body:
Blood tests are no more likely to detect a baby with Down's syndrome than the combination of the mother's age and ultrasound checks, a study of more than 31,000 pregnancies has revealed.

Down's is the commonest form of mental handicap, and the risk of a Down's baby rises with the age of the mother. Serum screening as a test for Down's was proposed in 1992 and by 1994 half of all obstetricians in England and Wales had offered it to women in their care.

David Howe and colleagues at Princess Anne hospital in Southampton report in the British Medical Journal today that they examined the antenatal detection rates of Down's syndrome among all women booked for delivery at the hospital in the six years up to the end of 1998.

Blood screening had never been compared with the standard tests, which depended on a judgment of risk according to age, followed by ultrasound scans to reveal anomalies which could then be con firmed by amniocentesis. Altogether 57 cases from 31,000 pregnancies were detected antenatally. There were 17 undetected cases and in seven of these, women refused invasive testing. Most of the cases detected in younger women followed ultrasound screening.

The overall detection rate, by both methods, was 68% - much more effective than assumed in demonstration projects for the blood tests. That meant, the scientists argue, that the benefits of blood tests might be less than originally supposed. "Before any new methods to identify Down's syndrome are introduced, the techniques should be tested in properly controlled trials."

fields.headline: Why Trotsky was denied asylum
fields.trailText: Britain refused asylum to the Russian revolutionary Leon Trotsky in 1929 because the Labour government feared alienating Joseph Stalin, de facto dictator of the Soviet Union, according to cabinet papers released by the public record office yesterday.
fields.body:
Britain refused asylum to the Russian revolutionary Leon Trotsky in 1929 because the Labour government feared alienating Joseph Stalin, de facto dictator of the Soviet Union, according to cabinet papers released by the public record office yesterday.

Trotsky tried four times to come to Britain after he was expelled from Moscow, including asking to live in the Channel Islands in 1934. The top home office civil servant advised the cabinet on that occasion he would need watching as well as protecting: "He has failed to impose his ideas on the [ruling] politbureau in Russia but he has not abandoned them; the idea of Trotsky in quiet retirement is comic."

His request stirred parts of the labour movement and such figures as HG Wells, the Webbs, JM Keynes, CP Scott (editor of the Manchester Guardian), GB Shaw, Clem Attlee and James Maxton.

Trotsky was famous as the man who led the Red army to victory in the civil war, and as an eloquent Marxist author, but he was outmanoeuvred by Stalin on Lenin's death and his supporters were persecuted or liquidated. Stalin was to succeed in having him assassinated in 1941.

Arguing for asylum, HG Wells said Trotsky had a "trenchant literary power" and his extraordinary career gave him a "hold on the public imagination"; living in Britain with "a constitution that has not broken down, and an army that has not broken up" would help change Trotsky's "present state of mind". Wells reminded ministers England was the "home of so-called dangerous opinions as well as of lost causes".

Trotsky - dubbed The Man Whom Nobody Wants - first applied after Labour's election win in 1929. The Manchester Guardian, as go-between for Trotsky's friend, Mme Paz (Magdelaine Marx), and the home secretary, JR Clynes, passed on undertakings he would not be politically active.

"Trotsky's supporters in other countries, France and Germany, would be encouraged and it would have its effect on their communist parties ... he would almost certainly become a centre of intrigue against a goverment with whom we want to enter into friendly relations. And, wrote Clynes, the mass of the British public regarded Trotsky only as "one of the Bolsheviks who made the Russian revolution" and would see his admission as "shaking hands with murderers".

webTitle: Body exhumed:  Samples taken from remains of GP's patient

fields.headline: Body exhumed:  Samples taken from remains of GP's patient
fields.standfirst: Police investigating the deaths of five patients of a Carlisle GP yesterday exhumed the body of one of them,  writes Kirsty Scott.
fields.trailText: Samples for forensic testing were taken from the remains of Keir Hamilton, 18, when they were removed from his grave in Upperby   cemetery, Carlisle. He and four other young men died from alleged overdoses of the heroin substitute methadone while under the care of John Gordon, 50, who was arrested last week on suspicion of manslaughter.
fields.body:
Samples for forensic testing were taken from the remains of Keir Hamilton, 18, when they were removed from his grave in Upperby cemetery, Carlisle. He and four other young men died from alleged overdoses of the heroin substitute methadone while under the care of John Gordon, 50, who was arrested last week on suspicion of manslaughter.

Detective chief inspector Peter Kirkbride of Cumbria police said further exhumations were unlikely at this stage because police had the information they needed on the deaths of the other four.

Dr Gordon has agreed not to go back to work until after the investigation and has been bailed until June.

He said yesterday from his home in Burgh by Sands: "The event of this morning must have been extremely distressing for the families concerned. I can only stress that I will continue to cooperate fully with the police in the hope of bringing their investigations to a speedy conclusion."

webTitle: Riddle of woman's body in chains

fields.headline: Riddle of woman's body in chains
fields.standfirst: Police check missing persons files after discovery on Suffolk beach
fields.trailText:
A home office pathologist last night carried out a postmortem on a young woman whose naked body was found weighted down with chains on a beach near Lowestoft, Suffolk.

It was revealed the woman had drowned, but further tests were being carried out on the body to establish if foul play was involved.

Detectives are trying to identity the body, found by a woman walking her dog yesterday morning.
fields.body:
A home office pathologist last night carried out a postmortem on a young woman whose naked body was found weighted down with chains on a beach near Lowestoft, Suffolk.

It was revealed the woman had drowned, but further tests were being carried out on the body to establish if foul play was involved.

Detectives are trying to identity the body, found by a woman walking her dog yesterday morning.

Police sealed off part of the beach after the body was discovered at about 7.15am on the high tide mark beneath cliffs at Kessingland. A home office pathologist, David Harrison, and forensic experts made an examination of the scene which is in an area popular with swimmers and close to several holiday camp sites.

The body was taken to the James Paget hospital at nearby Gorleston for a full post-mortem. A Suffolk police spokesman said they were treating the death as suspicious.

Yesterday officers were checking a list of missing persons in Norfolk and Suffolk and appealed for anyone who recognised the description of the woman to get in touch. Police said they were considering a number of possibilities including foul play and suicide, but a spokesman emphasised that a murder investigation had not been launched.

A police spokesman said: "There is no obvious cause of death and it is not for us to speculate. We must keep an open mind.

"There are a number of possibilities. Hopefully, the situation will be clearer when we have the results of the post-mortem examination."

Mystery surrounds the discovery, with police refusing to disclose details about how the woman was chained or what sort of chains were used. It is also unclear where the woman's body may have entered the water although it is believed to have been washed up by a combination of recent high tides and strong winds shifting material from the seabed.

Great Yarmouth coastguard said: "The body was found at around the time of high tide in the Lowestoft area. The tides have been higher than normal because they are approaching spring tides and there have been strong south-westerly winds.

"The tides would have been the deciding factor on the position where the body was washed up, but it is impossible to guess where the body might have gone into the sea as at this stage it is not known how long it was in the water."

Ivy Carter, a pensioner who lives nearby, said: "We are used to pieces of flotsam and jetsam like old driftwood turning up on the beach - but nothing like this.

"The woman could have gone into the water anywhere before being washed up here. It is absolutely shocking," she said

The woman is described as white, in her late teens to early 20s, about 5ft 6ins-5ft 8ins tall, of slim build with short hair.

The police spokesman said: "All we can say is that it appears the body had been weighted down with chains. No age or identity is known for the woman at this stage.

"Checks are being carried out to see if she fits the description of any known missing person. I cannot say how long the body appears to have been in the water.

"We would appeal for anyone knowing someone who fits this description to contact us immediately, particularly if they do not know the current whereabouts of the person."

webTitle: Met says it is beating corruption

fields.headline: Met says it is beating corruption
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard believes its biggest ever anti-corruption purge has uncovered serious misconduct by between 110 and 120 officers - only half the number estimated by the former commissioner, Sir Paul Condon.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard believes its biggest ever anti-corruption purge has uncovered serious misconduct by between 110 and 120 officers - only half the number estimated by the former commissioner, Sir Paul Condon.

The investigation, which began five years ago, is continuing, but both Sir John Stevens, the current commisioner, and his deputy, Ian Blair, said yesterday they believed most of the Met's corrupt officers had been identified.

They said it would be another 18 months before the current batch of corruption cases went through the courts, but they felt the force was now on top of the problem.

A total of 75 people have been charged with corruption so far, including 26 serving police officers and 11 former officers.

Out of the 26 serving officers, there have been five convictions, one acquittal and one is awaiting sentence. Sixty-nine serving Met officers are suspended because of continuing corruption-related investigations.

Mr Blair said criminals would always try to lure officers into corruption, and he thought it was "no surprise" that some had succumbed. "Organised crime needs corrupt officers to operate," he added.

The deputy commissioner admitted the Met had not pursued corruption with enough vigour in the early 1990s. He recalled being in charge of one of Scotland Yard's anti-corruption squads - complaints investigation branch two - in 1993, when the unit was a "sleepy hollow."

He said: "I am absolutely clear that the situation has changed out of all recognition. We are entirely aware of the depth of corruption issues. We will not allow ourselves to get in the position we were in four or five years ago."

Mr Blair said the 257 officers who were investigating corruption within the force were among "the best the Met has got" and that some of their work to root out corrupt officers had been "breathtaking" and "audacious."

Sir John said convicting corrupt detectives was extremely difficult, because trained officers would not be caught out easily.

His predecessor, Sir Paul Condon, said there was a "significant minority" of corrupt officers serving in the Metropolitan police. He claimed there were up to 250 in the force - about 1% of total numbers.

However, Sir John said yesterday the actual number of corrupt officers was nearer 0.5% of the force.

He said: "All the work that we have been doing has confirmed that that is the case."

He added that Mr Blair would review staffing in the three discipline office departments in the coming months, but that there would be no cut in numbers before then.

webTitle: RUC investigates child sex ring claim

fields.headline: RUC investigates child sex ring claim
fields.trailText: The RUC yesterday revealed that it was investigating claims that underage girls from a Belfast residential home are taking part in a Northern Ireland-wide prostitution ring.
fields.body:
The RUC yesterday revealed that it was investigating claims that underage girls from a Belfast residential home are taking part in a Northern Ireland-wide prostitution ring.

Social services confirmed that it was involved in the investigation, which is expected to last several months.

Inquiries focus on possible paramilitary involvement. Police are convinced loyalists in particular are behind much of the prostitution that is growing rapidily in the province.

The girls in the ring are said to be as young as 13 and are equipped with mobile phones and provided with taxis to ferry them to and from male clients. The RUC refused to name the young people's centre or the source of the allegations. But sources said the children in the ring were vulnerable, apparently seduced by the lure of easy money.

They are alleged to arrange rendezvous in upmarket ho tels throughout Northern Ireland. One report yesterday said their customers were aware beforehand the girls were under age, and there were claims that wealthy clients wre flying in to have sex with the girls.

A spokesman said: "The RUC can confirm that officers from its child abuse and rape inquiry unit are investigating claims teenage girls in care have been involved in prostitution. The investigation is at an early stage but a number of lines of inquiry are being followed." A spokesman for the department of health and social services said: "We can confirm there is an investigation going on. It is being carried out in accordance with the joint protocol between police and social services."

Linda Wilson, director of Barnado's child charity in Northern Ireland, described the allegations as deeply worrying. But, she said, they were not unexpected: "We are talking about children who are already in the care system and are therefore vulnerable."

webTitle: World's oldest woman lives in Staffordshire

fields.headline: World's oldest woman lives in Staffordshire
fields.standfirst: Born in 1885
fields.trailText: The world's oldest woman was named yesterday as Eva Morris, 114, of Stone in Staffordshire.
fields.body:
The world's oldest woman was named yesterday as Eva Morris, 114, of Stone in Staffordshire.

Her birth certificate states her life began in Newcastle under Lyme on November 18, 1885. She was given the title by the Guinness Book of Records after it rejected a Dominican woman claiming to be 125.

Britain also has the world's oldest man, Harry Halford, born on June 15, 1891 in Leicester where he still lives, though his title is also disputed, from Japan.

Mrs Morris worked as a domestic help in Stafford. She was widowed in the 1930s and her only child. Winnie, died of cancer in 1975, aged 62. Only when she got a chest infection at 107 did Mrs Morris leave her flat and enter the Autumn House nursing home in Stone.

A friend, Margaret Moult, said that Mrs Morris, who is deaf and partially sighted, had replied "Oh! am I?" when told by nurses of her fame.

According to Mrs Moult, Mrs Morris attributes her long life to work, exercise, boiled onions and a daily tot of whisky with her cup of tea. "She used to enjoy a cigarette and rode a bicycle, but she's never had a day's illness apart from chest infections, which are down to old age," Mrs Moult said.

Elizabeth Israel of Dominica claims she was born on January 27, 1875 but has no birth certificate, although other documents may be accepted. If so, she would be the oldest person ever; the past holder, Jeane Louise Calment, died in 1986 at 122. Guinness World Records is waiting confirmation that Sadayoshi Tanabe of Kawasaki was born in 1889.

fields.headline: Praise for new Radio 4 boss
fields.standfirst:
Staff welcome the first big appointment of Dyke era
The future of the BBC: special report
fields.trailText: Radio 4 staff were yesterday celebrating the appointment of Helen Boaden as the station's first female controller for 20 years. Ms Boaden, currently head of current affairs and business programmes for BBC news, will take over from James Boyle when he stands down at the end of the month.
fields.body:
Radio 4 staff were yesterday celebrating the appointment of Helen Boaden as the station's first female controller for 20 years. Ms Boaden, currently head of current affairs and business programmes for BBC news, will take over from James Boyle when he stands down at the end of the month. The last woman to head the station was Monica Sims, who took up the post in 1978.

Ms Boaden was the first choice of producers and programme makers inside the network, keen to see stability after the sometimes stormy reign of Mr Boyle. Her background in news and current affairs gained her support among those who resented Mr Boyle tinkering with the station's flagship news programmes.

Ms Boaden is the first key BBC appointment since Greg Dyke became director general, and the elevation of a respected and experienced programme maker will be seen as a decisive break with the Birtist past. Mr Dyke has vowed to spend more time listening to programme makers and less to management consultants.

Speaking on the World at One, Ms Boaden described the station as "my lifeblood", and outlined her vision for the future: "Radio 4 stands for quality, for a state of mind. It's not about class; it's intelligent, openminded, witty and funny. Listeners will get programmes that feed that state of mind."

Ms Boaden has a solid track record in radio. She joined the BBC in 1983 as a news producer at Radio Leeds, later becoming a reporter and then editor on the weekly current affairs programme File on Four, for which she won a Sony award. She was also a producer and presenter of Woman's Hour.

John Humphrys, a presenter on the Today programme, welcomed the appointment: "Her track record is as someone who takes news and current affairs seriously. She's been a reporter, a presenter, a producer, so she knows and understands radio. She doesn't speak from some theory dreamed up God knows where. She understands the medium and, crucially, knows how much good radio costs."

Ms Boaden beat off challenges for the post from Anna Carragher, head of broadcasting at BBC Northern Ireland, Rod Liddle, editor of Today, and Mark Damazer, head of political programmes for BBC news.

She will face lobbying from within news and current affairs, particularly for the reinstatement of the World at One's 40-minute lunchtime slot. Under Mr Boyle the programme was reduced to half an hour.

Yesterday Ms Boaden refused to discuss scheduling, but said she would consult widely before making any changes. "Any changes will be made in partnership between programme makers and audiences. They're the most important people," she said.

It is thought highly unlikely that the new controller will attempt the sort of sweeping changes that earned her predecessor the opprobrium of listeners.

"It's inconceivable they'll let her tear it all up and start again, as they did with Boyle," said one insider.

Mr Boyle was cast as the scourge of middle England and the chattering classes alike during his three-year tenure. The introduction of a new schedule in March 1998 enraged both constituencies. The Today programme was lengthened and Today in Parliament shunted into a long-wave berth. Most contentiously, the Archers was moved from 1.40pm to 2pm on weekdays, prompting an avalanche of complaints.
