It is thought highly unlikely that the new controller will attempt the sort of sweeping changes that earned her predecessor the opprobrium of listeners. "It's inconceivable they'll let her tear it all up and start again, as they did with Boyle," said one insider. Mr Boyle was cast as the scourge of middle England and the chattering classes alike during his three-year tenure. The introduction of a new schedule in March 1998 enraged both constituencies. The Today programme was lengthened and Today in Parliament shunted into a long-wave berth. Most contentiously, the Archers was moved from 1.40pm to 2pm on weekdays, prompting an avalanche of complaints.

webTitle: Pinochet flies home a free man

fields.headline: Pinochet flies home a free man
fields.standfirst: Human rights groups criticise Straw decision to release ex-dictator but hail precedent that no one is above the law Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Augusto Pinochet was due to set foot on Chilean soil this morning for the first time in more than 17 months, bringing to an end any realistic chance of prosecuting the former dictator for crimes against humanity.
fields.body:
Augusto Pinochet was due to set foot on Chilean soil this morning for the first time in more than 17 months, bringing to an end any realistic chance of prosecuting the former dictator for crimes against humanity.

Last night human rights groups criticised Jack Straw's decision to halt extradition proceedings against the general on medical grounds, but declared that the Pinochet case was the most important precedent for international justice since the Nuremberg trials.

Amnesty International, which has been at the heart of attempts to bring Gen Pinochet to justice, said: "The fact that Augusto Pinochet was arrested - almost unthinkable 17 months ago - has sent a powerful message: no one is above international law, even when national laws offer protection from prosecution."

The departure of the Chilean airforce jet carrying the 84-year-old general from RAF Waddington in Lincolnshire at 1.15pm yesterday brings to a close one of the most intense legal and political dramas of modern times.

The general was informed of the decision that brought the saga to an end at 8am yesterday, when the home office faxed his lawyers with the news that the home secretary had decided not to extradite him.

Mr Straw, who has spent the past week considering representations on the medical report that found Gen Pinochet had suffered extensive brain damage as a result of a series of strokes, said nothing had persuaded him to change his original assessment that the general was unfit to stand trial.

News of the decision was greeted with derision by those still hoping that the former Chilean dictator would be put on trial, but in Santiago supporters of the general, many of whom had been up since the early hours waiting for the announcement, reacted with joy.

As soon as the solicitor general had announced that no charges would be brought against Gen Pinochet in the British courts he was free to go. Although Spain, Belgium, France and Switzerland - who all have outstanding extradition warrants against him - could theoretically have launched last-minute legal challenges to the the decision, none was forthcoming.

Baltasar Garzon, the campaigning Spanish judge who has orchestrated international attempts to bring Gen Pinochet to justice, made a final, futile attempt to stop the general leaving Britain, faxing a nine-page request to the crown prosecution service asking for an immediate appeal over Mr Straw's decision.

But Spain's foreign minister, Abel Matutes, reiterated the long-held position of the Spanish government that it would not authorise a legal challenge to Mr Straw's decision. The CPS said it could only act on instructions received through official diplomatic channels.

Joan Garces, a lawyer for Spanish victims of Gen Pinochet's regime, described Mr Straw's decision as "a political deal allowing for impunity".

Bernard Bertossa, the Geneva state prosecutor who filed an arrest warrant for the general's arrest, said he was extremely disappointed by the ruling. The Belgian foreign minister, Louis Michel, said the lengthy legal battle served "to show dictators past and future that history can catch up with them".

The incoming Chilean president, Ricardo Lagos, insisted this week that Gen Pinochet could be put on trial in the country. "If that were not the case, it would mean that our democracy is castrated," he said. But most outside observers expect Gen Pinochet to fade into the political background as he lives out his final days.

Defending his decision in the Commons yesterday, moments after the general's plane had taken off, Mr Straw said that throughout the saga he had been keenly aware of the gravity of the crimes committed by Gen Pinochet and of the desire for justice by those who suffered at the hands of the former Chilean regime.

But he said: "The trial of an accused in the condition diagnosed in Senator Pinochet, on the charges which have been made against him in this case, could not be fair in any country, and would violate article six of the European convention on human rights."

Mr Straw added: "This case has understandably aroused great debate and feeling, and its impact has been felt worldwide.

It has established, beyond question, the principle that those who commit human rights abuses in one country cannot assume that they are safe elsewhere. That will be its lasting legacy."

In a move that is likely to have far-reaching implications for future extradition cases, Mr Straw announced he intended to publish a consultation paper on options for streamlining extradition procedures in Britain.

After the decision Tony Blair told the cabinet that Mr Straw had dealt with the Pinochet affair "right by the book".

Lady Thatcher, a staunch supporter of Gen Pinochet throughout, said his reward from the government for being a friend of Britain during the Falklands war was "to be held prisoner for 16 months".

fields.headline: Melodrama that has cost millions
fields.standfirst: The bill £4m to protect general is most expensive item Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Sixteen months of round-the-clock protection by special branch, three House of Lords hearings, a high court ruling and various magistrates' appearances has turned the Augusto Pinochet saga into a multimillion-pound legal melodrama.
fields.body:
Sixteen months of round-the-clock protection by special branch, three House of Lords hearings, a high court ruling and various magistrates' appearances has turned the Augusto Pinochet saga into a multimillion-pound legal melodrama.

But the final bill is not as high as claimed by the general's supporters - who have argued that the spiralling cost to the taxpayer was as good a reason as any to halt the extradition proceedings.

Estimates of the expenditure that will have to be met by the British authorities have ranged as high as £17m, but a detailed analysis shows that the true figure is less than half that amount.

By far the most expensive element of the case has been the estimated £4m it has cost to protect the general, who has spent much of his incarceration under armed police guard at a rented mansion on the Wentworth estate in Surrey. A team of special branch detectives, reputedly costing more than £70,000 a week, have guarded the general round the clock to prevent him from breaking his bail conditions as well as guard him from would- be attackers.

While the heavy security presence has not been welcomed by all of the estate's wealthy residents it has had one beneficial effect: since the police set up camp in such large numbers crime in the area has disappeared. The home office has contributed an extra £200,000 to the Met and Surrey forces.

The cost of renting the house itself, estimated at £10,000 a month, has been met by the general and his supporters.

The first Lords hearing was overturned on appeal after it emerged one of the law lords, Lord Hoffmann, had undeclared links with Amnesty International. The costs of the hearing and the appeal, totalling some £1m, were met by public funds. For the second Lords hearing, which ruled that Pinochet could be tried for crimes committed after 1988 when Britain signed up to various international treaties, each side met its own costs, estimated at £500,000.

The crown prosecution service, which has been acting on behalf of Spain and is obliged under European law to pay the costs incurred in the UK, has spent under just over half a million pounds on the case.

Jack Straw has relied heavily on a team of treasury solicitors plotting a course through the legal minefield, spending just under £200,000, although after Belgium's successful judicial review of the home secretary's decision not to release the medical reports that figure is likely to be much higher.

The tally so far

Crown prosecution service

Counsel's fees £353,000

Interpreter's fees £4,200

Other costs (CPS staff time, photocopying etc): £238,000

Treasury solicitors

Disbursements including counsel's fees £70,000

Other costs £18,000

Home office

Counsel's fees £144,000

Solicitor's fees £36,000

Medical examination

£5,501.25

Lord chancellor's office

First House of Lords hearing £270,935.89

Lords appeal £151,361.30

High court hearing

£31,328.39 (so far)

Police

Security costs (estimated) £4m

Total £5,322,326.83

Pinochet's costs

Legal fees £800,000-£1m

Rent on house in Wentworth £160,000

webTitle: University revokes leave for speech at racist forum

fields.headline: University revokes leave for speech at racist forum
fields.standfirst: Stephen Lawrence: special report
fields.trailText: Leeds university moved to quell a growing racism row yesterday when it revoked permission for one of its academics to make a speech attacking the Stephen Lawrence inquiry to one of America's most influential far right organisations.
fields.body:
Leeds university moved to quell a growing racism row yesterday when it revoked permission for one of its academics to make a speech attacking the Stephen Lawrence inquiry to one of America's most influential far right organisations.

Frank Ellis, a lecturer in the Russian and Slavonic studies department, was told he would not now be given leave to address the American Renassiance conference in Virginia this month after the Guardian revealed the organisation's racist ideology and the subject of Dr Ellis's speech.

Dr Ellis was originally told he could make the trip on work time as long as he made clear he was speaking in a personal capacity. But amid mounting concern from students and staff the university reversed the decision. In a statement, it said: "The event is not an appropriate academic conference for Dr Ellis to attend during working time. Dr Ellis has been told that he does not have leave to attend the conference, and that he will be expected to discharge his normal academic commitments at Leeds during this period."

The matter is unlikely to rest there, however. The lecturer could not be contacted for comment yesterday but there was speculation that he still intended to address the conference. Student leaders were seeking meetings with the university management to discuss the implications of Dr Ellis's views.

In his speech Dr Ellis's was intending to attack what he terms the anti-white "racial hysteria" which has gripped Britain since the murder of the black teenager and the publication of the Macpherson report on the botched police inquiry.

Previous conferences have attracted supporters of white supremacist organisations, including the Ku Klux Klan.

The Guardian and the anti-fascist magazine Searchlight revealed yesterday that Dr Ellis has written articles for the hard right British publication Right Now! in which he supports racist theories.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Lucy Rouse's TV gossip.
fields.body:
The real gossip this week comes from new BBC1 comedy drama, Monarch Of The Glen. Described by its producer, Douglas Rae of the appropriately named Ecosse Films as "Local Hero meets Notting Hill", the frolic-fest is a hotbed of luvviedom, it seems. Not only does the series star Richard Briers, it also brings a host of up-and-coming thirtysomethings to the screen.

First among these is, of course, Alastair Mackenzie - already familiar to viewers from Pyschos. But lurking there amidst the supporting cast is another Scot who appears intent on rivalling Mackenzie for celebrity.

He first hit our screens a few months ago as the dimpled-cheeked face fronting the latest Vodafone campaign. Landing a part in the heather of the Glen is his biggest turn yet. So it's only fair to speculate that the exposure may have gone to his head. But rumours that the customary twinkle of Briers' eye was dimmed by abuse shouted across the rolling Scottish hills are, we understand, wide of the mark.

Meanwhile, a battle of the daytime divas is raging behind the closed doors of BBC 1 and ITV. Controllers at both channels have squared up other over who first had the idea of putting children up for adoption via the intimate medium of TV. Jane Lush, BBC controller of daytime, has taken pains to point out just how "ground-breaking" A Family Of My Own was when it aired in January. Only to be rebutted by one Wendy Nelson, former producer of Central TV's Find A Family which, it seems, broke the ground in "finding homes for children in care" in 1992.

Regardless of whether a few cases of fosterless children are too sensitive a subject for broadcast to the masses (Who Wants to Be Loved? strikes us as a bit raw for mainstream TV), the argument could be settled by comparing the broadcasters' commitment to their respective shows. The BBC scrambled to film its series over November and December before putting it out throughout January. While Central (now part of Carlton) broadcast the show for three years.

 Lucy Rouse is editor of Broadcast Magazine

fields.headline: A stranger in paradise
fields.trailText: Pipe Dreams | Holby City
fields.body:
Two scenes of cultural dislocation... one: David, an Englishman, probably in his forties, wincing as a wooden pipe is shoved up one nostril by Yanomami tribespeople so that he can join them in their ritual consumption of hallucinogenic drugs.

Two: Tapir, a wary-faced 22-year-old Yanomami boy, fishing with Roger Daltrey by a lake in England. Tapir looks very small. Daltrey's hair looks very large.

David Goodale, writer/ producer/director of Pipe Dreams (BBC2) tells us about his "trip". Nose running, he points at his boots and says that they look like his feet standing there without his body. He also tells us everything else about his journey to Venezuela to fulfil a four-year-old promise to Tapir to take him to England.

Perhaps this is the problem. The more David talks about Tapir's experience, the more Tapir himself remains an enigma, never more so than in the odd semi-musical sequence which forms the centrepiece of this documentary. Tapir on a sofa in Ticehurst, East Sussex watching Teletubbies. Tapir at the zoo. Tapir at a medieval pageant. Tapir playing golf. Tapir eating fish and chips. The aforementioned Tapir/Daltrey scene. Tapir stony-faced and lost-looking at a Who concert. England looks frighteningly trashy.

We seem to find out a lot about Goodale, a likeable, self-deprecating soul with an obvious enthusiasm for his subject, but rather less about Tapir, his tense, slight figure bowed under the weight of Goodale's anxious determination to explain his experiences in voiceover.

There are revealing moments when the camera is (almost) allowed to speak for itself. Tapir's eyes darting everywhere at the noise and the traffic when he and David first arrive in a large Venezuelan town. Tapir keeping a straight face whilst David hilariously pantomimes use of the lavatory.

The best scenes of all are those after Tapir returns to Erimawiteri, his village. Here Goodale stands back a bit and we see Tapir giving away his newly-acquired goods and explaining his own experiences through photographs to the other villagers, relaxed and animated in a way he never was during the postcard experiences Goodale orchestrated for him, in control of the narrative for once.

There is a sense of muddle about Pipe Dreams; part of it seems to want to be a humorous video diary - about Goodale's ineptitude in the rainforest, a sweaty middle-aged white man deserted by porters, about his mock- heroic battle with Venezuelan bureaucracy to obtain a passport for Tapir. Part of it is striving to tell us something about Tapir and his people. But the chance to listen and observe is somehow lost under the flow of Goodale's well-meaning chatter.

Back at Holby City (BBC1), things seem a bit soggy after the departure of the supremely improbable consultant, Mr Jordan, in a sports car and a cloud of self-righteousness. The Casualty-esque love of didactic plot mirroring made for a rather tortured storyline involving Dr Kirstie surprising (the commendably irritable) Dr Tash in the loo poking at a breast lump. Cue admission of lady with breast cancer, who has recently had a miscarriage and whose husband turns out to be having an affair with her GP. There was some moral here somewhere, because Dr Tash eventually made an appointment to have her lump checked out and the husband was revealed as immature and rejected by both wife and GP. The rival plot involved the blonde doctor making concerned goldfish faces at Sammy-the-Brick, a boxer with a dodgy ticker and an even dodgier manager who was trying to make him carry on fighting. Even the wooden-faced urbanity of the excellent Mr Meyer ("How long have you been a pugilist?") couldn't resuscitate this one, although he did get to do a very fine bit of eyebrow acting when asked by the dodgy manager, "What if you got it wrong?" Sacrilege. It may be that the departure of Mr Jordan leaves some space for Old Woody to expand his character into a third dimension. But not this week.

Mr Barratt, still as sensitive and long of chin as he was in his Casualty days, got the jolly filler plot. This involved him dishing out camouflage gear to various doctors and nurses for what was eventually revealed to be a planned Adventure Escape Course. No doubt we'll get to see this next week, but my hopes for it aren't that high after Mr Meyer refused to attend.

webTitle: In the end, it was swift and efficient

fields.headline: In the end, it was swift and efficient
fields.standfirst: Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: If the Pinochet saga was made remarkable by the seemingly interminable legal wrangling, appeals and counter appeals, the end will be remembered for its speed and efficiency.
fields.byline: Stuart Millar, Martin Wainwright, Will Woodward and Jamie Wilson
fields.body:
At 8am on the dot yesterday, the fax machine at the London offices of law firm Kingsley Napley whirred into life, printing out a Home Office cover sheet.

A few seconds later, Michael Caplan, General Augusto Pinochet's solicitor, took the call on his mobile phone from his clerk relaying the news that everyone connected with the former dictator had waited so long to hear: Jack Straw had decided he would not be extradited.

If the Pinochet saga was made remarkable by the seemingly interminable legal wrangling, appeals and counter appeals, the end will be remembered for its speed and efficiency.

Within five hours of news that the general was free to go, he had left the Wentworth estate in Surrey, that has been both his home and prison for the last 15 months, and he was safely aboard his Chilean air force jet, having wrong-footed hundreds of angry opponents and dozens of news organisations.

The drama began early. Before first light, small bands of protesters had gathered in the rain outside the home office and opposite the main entrance to the Wentworth estate, where many of them have gathered noisily almost every weekend since the general moved in. Banging drums and chanting anti-Pinochet slogans, they shattered the well-heeled tranquility.

Inside the rented mansion, Pinochet, who had passed the previous evening watching the ATP tennis tournament from Santiago, was joined by his solicitor at 6.30am to await the decision.

By then, there were already clear signs that he could soon be on his way home. Since the middle of January, his specially converted Chilean air force Boeing 707, had been waiting at RAF Brize Norton in Oxfordshire, and it was assumed that he would leave Britain from there.

When reporters began arriving outside the perimeter fence, however, they found the plane had gone. Urgent inquiries to the base were put through to an officer who explained patiently that the jet had left "in the dark" at 5.30am. And when pressed, he conceded that they did not expect it to be returning.

The first phase of the Metropolitan police's meticulously-planned Operation Exit had succeeded. The next stage was equally successful.

A little before 9.45, the cameras and the demonstrators at Wentworth were denied their chance when the general's eight-car convoy turned left instead of right at the end of his cul-de-sac and slipped out of the estate through a back exit.

Surrounded by two marked police Volvos, a Range Rover and two motorcycle outriders, Gen Pinochet's bullet-proof Volkswagen Sharan headed on to the A30, before picking up the A1 and speeding north to RAF Waddington in Lincolnshire, where the general's plane had been waiting since 6am.

Its engines were started at 12.43pm, as soon as the convoy swept onto base, and at 1.14 it was airborne.

Only aircraft buffs formed a ragged farewell party in the pouring rain.

Charlie Perks, 47, who owns a mobile caravan park by the base, commented: "I would have expected some protesters here given all the fuss, but it was deadly quiet. The police cars flew past and I tried to get a glimpse through the tinted windows but couldn't see Pincochet - it was a bit disappointing I suppose."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The Sail | The Brit Awards
fields.body:
If you wonder why you pay for BBC, listen to The Sail (11.0am, Radio 4), one of those inspirations which bright producers occasionally have in the bath. Number 4 Boathouse in Portsmouth Naval Dockyard houses a yellowing and tattered canvas of 4,320 square feet. It was HMS Victory's fore topsail at Trafalgar, holed by French cannon balls. In three programmes the manufacture of the sail is used to recreate the social and industrial history of the period.

For the first time the Brit awards are being broadcast live from the Earl's Court arena in London. Radio 1 starts its five hours of continuous coverage at 6.0pm with Pete Tong interviewing some of the hopefuls before the results are announced. The needle match of the evening, of course, comes when former Spice Girl Geri Halliwell and Mel C (still with the group) jostle to be named best British female vocalist. Jo Whiley chats to all the winners.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Streets Of Fire | Woman Of The Year | Manhunter | Desperate Measures
fields.body:
Streets Of Fire

(Walter Hill, 1984)

9.15pm, Carlton Cinema

Made during the MTV years, this "rock'n'roll fable" is set in an 80s version of a futuristic 50s-style society where rules are meant to be broken. Diane Lane plays the pop singer and ex-lover of Tom Cody (Michael Paré), who must rescue her from a biker gang amid The Blasters' riffs. Willem Dafoe is the pack leader who wants her back.

Teri Grenert

Woman Of The Year

(George Stevens, 1942) 3pm, TCM The first inspired pairing of Spencer Tracy and Katharine Hepburn. He's a no-nonsense sports hack, she a high-flown political columnist pontificating on the banning of baseball. The gender politics don't bear close examination (when will she settle down and be a good wifey?) but the pair clash beautifully and comically, thanks to Michael Kanin and Ring Lardner Jr's Oscar-winning script.

Manhunter

(Michael Mann, 1986) 10pm, FilmFour Five years before The Silence Of The Lambs, Brian Cox played the infamous Hannibal Lecter in this adaptation of Thomas Harris's novel, Red Dragon. The story is similar to Lambs: FBI man Will Graham (William Peterson) enlists the aid of the brilliant, imprisoned people-eater to track down another serial killer, the Tooth Fairy. A glossy but darkly oppressive thriller.

Desperate Measures

(Barbet Schroeder, 1998) 10.10pm, Sky Premier Here's another locked-up baddy with Hannibal the Cannibal much in mind. Michael Keaton's multiple murderer McCabe is devious, intelligent and pain-resistant, dislocating and replacing his thumb at will as part of his escape attempt. Thing is, though (it goes without saying) cop Andy Garcia needs McCabe's bone marrow to save his sick son (it could happen, honest), and must get him back before the rest of the force kills him. The clunking plot is almost rescued by the droll, OTT performances and Schroeder's slick direction.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Guinness ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Guinness ad says about you.
fields.body:
The ad: Remember the silly dancing man spot for Guinness from several years ago? Well, this new ad almost resurrects the idea, but features a whole cast of real "off the street" nutters executing a range of daft moves as they drink bottles (yes, it comes in bottles with widgets now) of the creamy stout. Basically, they all take it in turns to jig around gormlessly on a makeshift stage to a catchy dance track. The ad ends with one holding up a card that carries the endline: "Dance with it".

The jargon: Guinness's problem is that it has always been an awkward, heavy pint for a crowded Friday-night bar, but this commercial is aimed at dramatising its new portability in bottled form - as well as showing that Guinness gives you a sort of zany sense of confidence.

Personality: You are younger, more sociable and more easy-going than the traditional Guinness pint-drinker, who is targeted by the beautifully-crafted main brand advertising (like the famous 'surfer' spot).

Financial status: You are pre-family, metropolitan, have plenty of disposable income and are generally quite prosperous. But bottled Guinness is not premium-priced - it's positioned head to head against the likes of Budweiser and Becks.

Telling lifestyle detail: It's possible that you have 18 studs through your ears and listen to grunge rock, or that you shop at Karen Millen. No generalisations can be made.

Other relevant data: The commercial was shot at Bethnal Green Town Hall. The 'stars' all responded to ads in listings magazines round the country saying: "Have you got two left feet and can you clear a dance-floor in 10 seconds?" They turned up for what they thought was an audition, only to be told later that they had in fact been filmed.

webTitle: Tongue twister Scottish parliament goes native

fields.headline: Tongue twister Scottish parliament goes native
fields.standfirst: Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: He has grappled with the awkward semantics of section 28 and struggled with complex interpretations of student finance but yesterday Donald Dewar met his linguistic match in Scotland's native tongue.
fields.body:
He has grappled with the awkward semantics of section 28 and struggled with complex interpretations of student finance but yesterday Donald Dewar met his linguistic match in Scotland's native tongue.

Headphones clamped to his ears, and brow furrowed, the first minister listened carefully as the Scottish parliament held its first debate in Gaelic for more than 600 years.

Domhnall (Gaelic for Donald) and his other English-speaking colleagues had the benefit of a simultaneous translation for the debate - which heard impassioned pleas for the language to be cultivated and promoted - as only three of the 129 members of the Scottish parliament are native Gaelic speakers.

The last Scottish parliament was dissolved in 1706 and speaking Gaelic within its walls would have been frowned upon as too parochial. The Gaelic minister, Alasdair Morrison, said yesterday: "There are many precious components in the heritage of Scotland. But none is as ancient, profound and worthy as the Gaelic legacy."

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

The Downing Street fox. Few have seen the shadowy creature said to scamper regularly outside No 10 - until yesterday when first pictures were published. The photgrapher had waited eight nights to capture the fox on camera.

Bad day

Gwyneth Dunwoody, who complained of being bombarded when she takes her Commons seat. The Labour MP, who usually sits directly under the press gallery, said she had been the target of stray pens and notebooks falling from above.

Spoilsport of day

Teddy Taylor. The Tory MP caused panic amongst colleagues when he suggested all bars in parliament should be shut. He said Westminster was plagued by long hours and too many places to drink.

Today

Commons: Second reading of backbench bills on health service commissioners, and food labelling.

webTitle: ITV accused of discarding 2m news viewers

fields.headline: ITV accused of discarding 2m news viewers
fields.trailText: ITV managers were yesterday accused of "throwing away" 2m viewers in one year for the sake of less than £70m extra in advertising revenue by scrapping News at Ten.
fields.body:
ITV managers were yesterday accused of "throwing away" 2m viewers in one year for the sake of less than £70m extra in advertising revenue by scrapping News at Ten.

As network chairman Leslie Hill conceded to a commitee of MPs that it could take up to three years for the evening schedule change to bed down, it emerged that the combined audience for ITV's two evening news programmes had fallen from 11.4m to 9.4m since the 10pm bulletin was axed a year ago.

ITV chiefs faced a grilling from the Commons culture, media and sport committee, in the latest episode of a sustained conflict between MPs and the channel over the abolition of News at Ten.

After seeing its initial recommendation that the programme should stay ignored by the Independent Television Commission, the committee has returned to the subject as the regulator prepares a review of the first year of the revised schedule.

Following the changes, the channel's advertising revenue has risen by £100m, of which "at least £50m, and perhaps as much as £70m" were down to moving the news bulletins, Mr Hill told MPs.

Committee chairman Gerald Kaufman, quoting ITC viewing figures, said: "For the gain of advertising of £100m, which obviously means a great deal to you, you've thrown away 2m viewers."

ITV concedes that audiences for its Nightly News programme at around 11pm are lower than it hoped at, around 3.2m. Mr Hill admitted that the quality of programmes leading up to the new bulletin had not been "sufficiently successful" to guarantee a strong inherited audience. The scheduling and the flexible timing of the programme had also been a problem, he told MPs.

ITV managers point to a 300,000 rise in viewers tuning into uninterrupted sports coverage and films at 10pm, a figure rising to 721,000 since the autumn schedule started last September.

They claim scheduling changes were essential to halt a continuing slide in evening audiences and advertising revenues. If the channel was forced to revert to its original programming, it would have less advertising and would enter a vicious circle of "less spending on programmes, less quality, less home grown programmes", Mr Hill told the committee.

He acknowledged that viewers would take time to become used to the change, claiming his wife still sometimes turned on the television expecting news at 10pm. But he told Mr Kaufman: "This is an exercise which may take up to three years. We still believe that, if we get the programming right between 7pm and 11pm, we will get a bigger audience for the Nightly News."

fields.headline: Not waving, but a warning
fields.standfirst:
Pinochet's departure should send a message to dictators everywhere

Pinochet on trial: special report
fields.trailText: A few hours after one mass-murdering general touches down to safety in Chile, another will be in handcuffs in the dock in the Hague to hear an international court pass judgment on his crimes.
fields.body:
A few hours after one mass-murdering general touches down to safety in Chile, another will be in handcuffs in the dock in the Hague to hear an international court pass judgment on his crimes. In Senegal, the former dictator of Chad stands charged with torture on the Pinochet precedent, while pressure builds for international prosecutions of surviving Khmer Rouge leaders and the generals responsible for East Timor massacres. Pinochet has served only one noble purpose in his life - that of helping the world to work out how to put tyrants on trial.

The Pinochet precedent marked an astonishing advance for global justice. It identified the Achilles' heel in the armour of state sovereignty - that legal fiction which had always protected political criminals. They no longer have immunity to charges of genocide and torture, because every state has an international duty to hunt down perpetrators of these crimes against humanity.

The House of Lords judgments in Pinochet have been hailed around the world. Only last month they became the basis for charges against Hassan Habri, who fled to Senegal in 1990 after murdering 40,000 during his reign of terror in Chad. As a result of the Pinochet arrest, international human rights law is no longer a pious fiction: it is actually capable of enforcement.

It is worth remembering that this could not have happened without Jack Straw, or at least a British government which was prepared to let the law take what turned out to be a momentous course.

Had Pinochet gone instead to New York for medical treatment and to take tea with Henry Kissinger, the US authorities would not have touched him. If brought before any court, criminal or civil, the state department would have followed its practice of issuing a letter of instruction to stop the proceedings. Although France, Belgium and Switzerland have very recently climbed on the "prosecute Pinochet" bandwagon, they were uninterested until the UK showed the way. The last thing the Spanish government wanted was a trial, and it has done its best to sabotage its own prosecutors.

The home secretary came under intense diplomatic pressure to let Pinochet go prematurely. Every powerful enemy of human rights weighed in on his behalf, from Jesse Helms and Dr Kissinger to the Vatican. Even Fidel Castro (mindful of the Cuban gulag) attacked Britain venomously last year for offending the sovereign dignity of Latin American states by detaining his mortal enemy.

So we can take considerable pride in the government's handling of this affair, from Scotland Yard's capture (after a tip-off from Hugh O'Shaughnessy in the Guardian) a few hours before he planned to flee the country, to its denouement. The home secretary quite rightly decided, on compelling medical evidence, that it would be oppressive to put on trial a man so brain-damaged that he could not understand the evidence or instruct his lawyers.

It would of course have been preferable to have sought the approval of the court which was due to hear Pinochet's appeal on March 20, although that would have been a foregone conclusion. Jack Straw's 7,000 word statement contains a few mistaken assumptions (Pinochet's apparently sensible demeanour is explained away by his high level of original intelligence, although the record suggests that he possesses a low cunning) and there is a failure to appreciate that the inquisitorial system in Spain places much less pressure on a defendant than trial by judge and jury in England. Given the diagnosis of irreversible brain damage after his strokes last October, however, justice could not be seen to be done under any system. If Pinochet does cartwheels in the streets of Santiago, it will be British medicine rather than law that will be the laughing-stock.

There is, of course, the richest of ironies that a dictator who denied human rights to the thousands he killed and tortured ends his life as the pathetic beneficiary of human rights standards. It is a poor reflection on our extradition procedures that he could play for time for so long. But the real lesson of Pinochet's escape from justice should be a renewed determination to round up other perpetrators of genocide and torture while they remain healthy.

That means pressure on Saudi Arabia to disgorge Idi Amin for trial at the Old Bailey, to be followed into the dock by Milton Obote who lives vulnerably in Zambia. Colonel Mengistu, the mass-murdering Marxist of Ethiopia, will not have Robert Mugabe to protect him in Zimbabwe for much longer, and Baby Doc Duvalier is on the loose somewhere in the south of France. The Nazi-loving ex-dictator of Paraguay, Alfredo Stroessner, is in retirement in Rio, and the penthouses of Panama are packed with mass-murdering Latin generals in exile.

Meanwhile, juxtaposed today with Pinochet's arrival in Chile will be the verdict on the much-decorated Croatian General Blaskic, tried for war crimes involving the killing of thousands of Serbs in the Krajina. He is the first powerful figure to be tried by this UN court. Nato must support it by arresting the indicted Bosnian Serb leaders Karadic and General Mladic, before they, too, start suffering strokes.

The struggle for global justice is far from over: of the 120 nations which agreed in 1998 to set up an international criminal court, only seven have so far ratified its statute. The revelry of the Pinochinistas as they welcome their brain-damaged hero should serve as a spur. That is the only consolation that can now be offered to Pinochet's victims: the knowledge that for tyrants of his ilk, the future is not what it used to be.

Geoffrey Robertson QC is the author of Crimes Against Humanity, Penguin

That means pressure on Saudi Arabia to disgorge Idi Amin for trial at the Old Bailey, to be followed into the dock by Milton Obote who lives vulnerably in Zambia. The Nazi-loving ex-dictator of Paraguay, Alfredo Stroessner, is in retirement in Rio, and the penthouses of Panama are packed with mass-murdering Latin generals in exile. That is the only consolation that can now be offered to Pinochet's victims: the knowledge that for tyrants of his ilk, the future is not what it used to be. fields.headline: Jim Bailey
fields.standfirst: A good man in Africa, he financed and energised Drum, the hugely popular magazine that challenged apartheid
fields.trailText: Jim Bailey, who has died aged 80, was an originator of Drum, the South African-based magazine founded in 1951, and became its inspiration, its most active promoter, and, almost immediately, its sole financier. The magazine quickly became the voice of black unrest, of segregated misery, of political aspiration
fields.body:
Jim Bailey, who has died aged 80, was an originator of Drum, the South African-based magazine founded in 1951, and became its inspiration, its most active promoter, and, almost immediately, its sole financier. After early issues, it was not reaching the African readership for which it was intended. It was a white man's magazine for black men's eyes, and was not working. "Your tribal music," Jim realised, had to become "our music". Forget kraals, folktales, and patronising, if well-meaning, talk of the African. Instead, bring in jazz, girls, boxers, and the cruelties of apartheid.

Drum then took off, ably edited by Anthony Sampson. "Mr Drum" was its in-house hero, usually a most courageous staffer named Henry Nxumulo, who exposed farms where flogging was rife, or where payment was made in alcohol. He even went deliberately to jail, enabling a photographer to acquire (from a nearby rooftop) proof of indignities meted out to inmates.

The magazine quickly became the voice of black unrest, of segregated misery, of political aspiration. Of course, it was there to record the 1960 Sharpeville massacre, when a protest rally ended with 56 dead and 162 wounded, all shot by the police.

In continuing to finance the magazine, Jim Bailey made serious dents in the fortune he had inherited from his father, Sir Abe Bailey, the Johannesburg gold millionaire. With Drum so often pilloried in many quarters, a similar erosion might have reduced the courage he inherited from his mother, an aviation pioneer who flew solo from London to Cape Town in 1928, returning the following year via western Africa. His upbringing in South Africa was certainly untypical, with parents often absent and a father possibly more interested in his racehorses than his own bloodstock.

That father, worrying distantly about the turmoil in Europe, wrote anxiously in May 1937 to his friend, the then chancellor of the exchequer Neville Chamberlain, only to be told that the situation was "exasperating . . . but we must not take it too seriously". "This fatuous sentiment," wrote Jim, when using it as a frontispiece for a book of his wartime poems, "was the death warrant for nearly all my friends and some 50m people."

Educated at Winchester and Oxford, Bailey joined the Royal Air Force as a pilot in September 1939. During the Battle of Britain he served with 264 Squadron, and then with 85 Squadron, from which 25 (out of 37) pilots were killed. Peter Townsend was also a survivor of that unit, and a pilot more respected by Jim than any other, writing a foreword to one of his books.

Bailey initially flew the Defiant, with a rear-facing gun turret, a fighter which "flew forwards and shot backwards", but - in his opinion - was never properly used. Then he switched to Hurricanes, flying at night over Britain's burning cities, though without radar to help him find the enemy. Finally, it was the formidable twin-engined Beaufighter, which suited him very well. When moving up Italy, in the final stages of the war, he took a hive of bees with him to ensure good honey.

The war ate increasingly into him the further it regressed in time. In particular, he remembered a fellow pilot, Gordon, who experienced engine trouble when both were returning from a foray over Norway. Slowly, Jim watched as the other plane flew nearer and nearer to the sea, and the image seared into his brain. His wartime poems are savage in their repressed blatancy.

"Young, blond, teenage airgunner/ whom I saw in a Lincoln bar/ whose beauty held me captive/ whom I worshipped from afar:/ the cannon shells of a nightfighter/ neither see nor spare,/ and when his kite got home one night,/ they took a hose and washed him/ down from his turret chair."

When Drum had been successfully launched, with an extraordinary, multi-talented bunch - largely from the soon-to-be destroyed Sophiatown - Jim attempted to make it continental and established offices in the rest of Africa. I took over the western section, based myself loosely (in the back of a truck) within Ghana and Nigeria, and sold the magazine to a rapacious readership, eager for this very African production.

Jim was often a companion, loving it when locals asked if he knew the boss - his clothes and manner causing their mistake. He also saw them buy even single pages, their appetite so acute, and dreamed of a continent-wide publication. To help this longing he met presidents, ministers, journalists, musicians and great quantities of potential readership.

Alas, Africa got in the way of his dream. Its distances were too huge, its roads and railways too often temporary. Worse, a Nigerian is not noticeably interested in Sudanese or Zambian affairs - any more than, or even less than, the average Briton cares for Finnish or Turkish politics.

Jim poured money into the magazine. He sold his huge inherited farm in the Karroo, and started other journals to bolster Drum's finances. But his precious publication was often banned, its crusading style even less welcome in the new nations than in the old South Africa. In the end, bit by bit, it had to go.

His other passion was a conviction - based on tremendous scholarship - that the new world, notably its southern section, had been visited from Europe, long before Columbus ever made the journey further north. The tin for the Bronze Age came largely, or so he argued, from the Amazon basin. Countless statues had Negro faces. Numerous legends told of the old-new world interaction. Coins and inscriptions had been found.

As a consequence of this obsession - which he detailed in his books The God-Kings and Titans - Bailey was no more in favour of hidebound historians unwilling to change their views than he was of repressive governments, or of wartime blunderers (whom he blamed for Gordon's death) - or, indeed, of Neville Chamberlain. But to friends he was terrific, with a laugh that went rolling down the street, and with stories of idiocy or excellence. There will be multi- coloured thousands in Africa who will mourn the passing of this very special man.

He married Barbara Epstein in 1962. She and four children survive him.

Cameron Duodu writes: In 1960, while South Africa's apartheid government was mowing down Africans at Sharpeville, I was an editor in the Ghana Broadcasting Corporation's newsroom. One day I was told that Jim Bailey wanted to see me.

Now, Drum was fascinating. While it was possible to dismiss the paper as a lightweight publication that used titillation to win a wide readership - it always had a beautiful girl on the cover - titillation was, in fact, Drum's camouflage. Perhaps the most famous picture ever published in Africa was its photograph of black South African prisoners being forced into a naked "tausa" dance - to ensure that they had hidden nothing in their rectums.

Ghana's edition of Drum was nothing like as adventurous but, under editor Henry Ofori, its incisiveness had led President Kwame Nkrumah to ban it. But I went to see Jim Bailey.

What I didn't expect was the nature of the man. He was dressed in khaki shorts that looked slept in, and a shirt whose sleeves had been rolled up to the shoulder - like a New York waterfront teamster. His blonde hair and large, expressive face also stood out. But it was when he opened his mouth that all preconceived notions collapsed. He had a foghorn voice, and an accent that mixed Oxford, Yorkshire, Cockney and South African. He belonged to two worlds - the curse-infected polo ground on the South African veldt, and the 1941 RAF officers' mess. There was also the restraining influence of the boardrooms of those companies whose shares had been bequeathed to him by his Cecil Rhodes-type father.

Bailey had a loud, head-thrown-back, attention-grabbing laugh that exploded out of him. The laugh featured whether he was sipping a beer in a dingy Lagos nightclub, a Johannesburg shebeen or a svelte hotel dining-room.

"I want you to join Drum," he told me. I said I would. But then came talk about money. Bailey never touched the subject himself, and I was reduced to sending him messages through Christian Gbagbo, a photographer whom Drum was to make famous. After a lot of to-ing and fro-ing, Christian came back with the message: "He will pay what you want, but if, after three months, you do not justify your pay, then you and Drum will part company."

I was expected to leave a sheltered civil service job to work under such conditions. I did. And although I was to learn that Drum agreeing to pay, and actually paying, could take quite a number of days, I stayed with the company for five years.

It was a delicious time. The crafty Bailey had neglected to tell me that Ofori had left and that I, aged 23, was to be the new editor - this, in a political atmosphere so charged that Ofori had thought it wise to remove himself to the United States. But I didn't regret it, for through Drum I became a frontline Pan-Africanist.

I travelled to Nigeria to meet my counterpart there, Nelson Ottah; I went to Northern Rhodesia (now Zambia) and on from there to interview Sir Roy Welensky, then second only to Hendrik Verwoerd as a villain in the eyes of black Africa. In Salisbury, Southern Rhodesia (now Harare, Zimbabwe), I made a lifelong friend in Noel Mukono, also of Drum. I was his guest as plans were made by himself and other associates to split from Joshua Nkomo's Zapu and form Zanu, Zimbabwe's ruling party. I also interviewed two of Africa's (then) heroes: Jomo Kenyatta and Hastings Banda.

Bailey was an ideal employer for a journalist. If the story was good, you rode high - though your expenses would be queried all the same. "Every employee," he told me, "aspires to make his employer pay for him to have a bloody good holiday while pretending to work."

The one unmistakable impression I got from Bailey was that he regarded every human being as his equal (despite his money) and that he judged individuals by their performance. He hated humbug, thus his excessively informal style.

There was, however, a dark side. He liked to suggest stories that portrayed Africa as stuck in a time-warp. One I resisted was a deftly thrown hint that cannibalism was part of the process of achieving power in Sierra Leone and Liberia. He also saw the troubles in the Congo and other African disaster areas not as the inevitable consequence of imposing foreign rule on a people and leaving them to compete, without rules, for resources, but as a throwback to Africa's atavistic past. I never ceased to argue with him; the last time, in 1990, we had a six-hour session, watered by good Cape wine, in the study at his beautiful farmhouse in Lanseria, South Africa.

Bailey was not afraid to put his thoughts, however outlandish, on paper. F As In Flight (1961) gave an inkling, in verse, of what it was like to be a 19-year-old RAF fighter pilot. The Sky Suspended (1990) developed the ideas he had gathered on war, whilst participating. And, in Sailing To Paradise (1995), he explored his eccentric ideas about the cultural affinities of coasts - from West Africa to the Inca coast.

Bailey once told me a story that may serve as his epitaph: a farmer once took in a young, very rich city dweller as a paying guest. For his first dinner, he gave instructions to the farmer's wife as follows: "I want the juiciest steak from your best cow, your best potatoes, your finest mushrooms and the tenderest beans and cabbage from your vegetable beds. Don't worry if you have to disturb your routine of harvesting crops to get them for me - cost will be no object." The farmer, who had been listening from an adjoining room, shouted back at the city slicker: "And I'll buy the muck off you."

I can still hear Bailey laughing uproariously at his own joke. Across Africa, many an ear will be the poorer for the silencing of that laugh.

Jonathan Glancey adds : The first time I really got to know and love Jim Bailey was playing Cardinal Puff, an absurd, wartime RAF drinking game into the small, very drunken hours, in an air-conditioned burger joint in the Fourways shopping mall on the fringe of Johannesburg. Why ex-Squadron Leader JFC Bailey, DFC, chose to drink in this sanitised eaterie, must remain a puzzle. As must this Olympian "himself" to those who find it hard to imagine how one man can have lived so many lives, crossed so many historic paths.

Jim must have drunk in every shebeen worth its name from Kampala to Cape Town, despite being born into a stupendously wealthy family, his father a Randlord, crony of Cecil Rhodes and financial backer of Winston Churchill in his wilderness years. He played polo at Kirtlington Park, fished and shot with the gamekeeper, Alan Howe, on the family estate at Bletchington, yet the drum of Africa was the soundtrack of his mature life. Black Africa got under his ghost-white skin. He settled there for good in 1946.

In publishing Drum, Jim shaped the first black African magazine and, being the man he was, he went to meet his public - a 5m readership at its peak - in tin shacks and hot alleyways, hearing stories first-hand and finding writers for his editors in the same stews. His was a powerful intellect - his books on Bronze Age civilisations are wonderful. He was sardonic, stubborn, very grand and wickedly funny. But no snob. With Jim you had no idea who might pop by for breakfast at his farm, whether Nelson Mandela or one of the few of the first writers and photographers who survived Drum.

In 1990s London we went dancing at the Metropolitan Grand until four in the morning. The young women, black and white, adored him. He had great charm and looked in those last years like a cross between an old hippy and an Old Testament prophet.

It was hard to get close to Jim. He was scared of love. He was bloody lucky to have found Barbara Epstein, his second wife, a talented pianist who loved him through roller-coaster years and was the only woman, his extraordinary Anglo-Irish mother aside, to have had his measure. He is lucky to leave such talented children and step-children.

He wrote beautifully - poetry, history, his wartime memoirs. He was shot by a Junkers 88, threatened with death, survived an assasination attempt in South Africa and lived to see the apartheid he hated come apart and Mandela, an old friend, in power.

At Easter 1939, he hitch-hiked through the Austrian Alps with some pals. They fell in with Luftwaffe pilots. Jim hated the idea that they would soon be killing one another to satisfy the perverse desires of racist politicians. Jim was able to make a friend of anyone who could tell a joke, spin a yarn, stop him from being bored.

Here's Jim at his delicious best, transcribed from my slightly drunken scrawl: "In its heyday, Drum had no rival. An attempt was made by some black Americans to launch a magazine. They flew around Africa by first-class jet, staying in smart hotels, while we drank with locals in shebeens. Because they were black, they thought they understood Africa better than the rest of us, black and white together. It didn't work, which, for your fun, reminds me of a story told me in Ghana of the wealthy black American businessman who visits Africa in search of his roots.

"He meets the chief who, standing on his dignity, will only talk to him through the witch doctor. The American says how happy he is to be in the land of his forebears. The witch doctor says the chief says he is happy too. The American says his heart leaps to be back among his own people. The witch doctor explains, looking rather sheepish, that the chief's heart leaps too. But, what the chief really said was "Here's a rich American, let's strip him!" I think that's the situation the chaps found themselves in. A black skin alone doesn't an African make". Head thrown back, Jim howls like a hyena.

James Richard Abe Bailey. magazine publisher, author, historian, poet, born October 23 1919; died February 29 2000

fields.headline: Derroll Adams
fields.trailText: For at least one generation of folk-music enthusiasts the genial figure of Derroll Adams, who has died aged 74, evoked a restless rural America, the landscape of John Steinbeck's The Grapes Of Wrath, the depression photographs of Walker Evans or Woody Guthrie's songs.
fields.body:
For at least one generation of folk-music enthusiasts the genial figure of Derroll Adams, who has died aged 74, evoked a restless rural America, the landscape of John Steinbeck's The Grapes Of Wrath, the depression photographs of Walker Evans or Woody Guthrie's songs.

Though his own acquaintance with Guthrie was brief, Adams spent several years as the musical partner of one of his greatest admirers, Ramblin' Jack Elliott. The two men's years of performing in Europe, and records, like their shared album Roll On, Buddy, introduced many listeners to Guthrie's work and to that of his country-music forerunners Jimmie Rodgers and the Carter Family, as well as to traditional songs of the American south.

Adams was born in Portland, Oregon, which inspired his best-known composition, the anti-war song Portland Town. He grew up, he recalled, "all over the northwest. My home was the back seat of a car." Returning to Portland after wartime naval service, he attended art school, where, he said, "I became aware of the social part of life, racial equality, all those things, and that was really my introduction into folk and country music." He began playing banjo at political rallies, then, moving to California, fell in with folksingers such as Guthrie, Cisco Houston, Odetta and Pete Seeger.

He first met Elliott in the early 1950s, at a house party. "Everybody said we had to play together. We ended up doing Muleskinner Blues, the only song we could think of that we both knew. It went over like a ball. From then on, Jack and I became friends." A few years later Elliott offered to pay his way to Europe if he would join him there. They played at London's Blue Angel club for three months, then busked around Europe.

Adams's warm, deep singing and unpretentious banjo-picking blended happily with Elliott's lighter voice and more intricate guitar-playing and, in a Europe little accustomed to original American folk musicians, they were folk-scene stars. Adams also worked with the Scottish singer Alex Campbell.

Through Elliott and the Guthrie connection, he became slightly acquainted with Bob Dylan, and appears briefly in DA Pennebaker's film Don't Look Back, shot during Dylan's 1966 British tour. Adams was drinking heavily and, after a particularly ramshackle gig, found himself no longer welcome in English clubs. By 1969 he was seriously ill, but with the help of his third wife, Danny, he recovered and settled in Belgium. He was in England in 1972 for the Cambridge Folk Festival, and celebrated his recovery in a new album, Feelin' Fine.

Though ignored by most popular music historians and encyclopaedists, Adams impressed many other musicians. The friends who flew into Antwerp for his 65th birthday concert give an idea of the circle that had formed around him: as well as Elliott, they included Bert Jansch, John Renbourn, Danny Thompson and artists from all over continental Europe. Andy Irvine, who worked with Adams and Elliott early in his career, went on to be a founder member of the influential Irish band Planxty, while Donovan acknowledged his debt to Adams in Epistle To Derroll.

In recent years he had given up public performing and devoted himself to his large, boldly coloured paintings. He is survived by Danny and his daughter Rebecca.

Derroll Adams, folk musician, born November 27 1925; died February 6 2000

webTitle: Aborigine ground cleaned up following British nuclear tests

fields.headline: Aborigine ground cleaned up following British nuclear tests
fields.trailText: The huge, costly and controversial clear-up of British nuclear test sites around the Maralinga aboriginal settlement has been completed, ending a long-running dispute with Australia.
fields.body:
The huge, costly and controversial clear-up of British nuclear test sites around the Maralinga aboriginal settlement has been completed, ending a long-running dispute with Australia.

The Australian government said the joint operation with Britain, which involved the relocation of 300,000 cubic metres (399,000 cubic yards) of plutonium-contaminated topsoil in the remote outback site in the south Australian desert, is now over.

Australia's federal resources minister, Nick Minchin, said that the £43m rehabilitation of the outback site, which was used to test British nuclear weapons between 1952 and 1963, had been completed on time and within budget.

He also said that the land was now safe for the traditional owners, the Maralinga Tjarutja people, to travel and hunt across the three former test sites of Taranaki, TMS and Wewak.

But 120 sq km (46 sq miles) around Taranaki are still considered too contaminated to allow for continual habitation.

"The nuclear tests at Maralinga were a legacy of a time when Australians appreciated neither the importance of the land to its traditional Aboriginal owners, nor the value of our continent's diverse environment," said Senator Minchin during a visit to the region on Wednesday. "The Maralinga Rehabilitation Project is a clear symbol that those times have passed."

Maralinga, which in the Aboriginal language means "thunder", once housed hundreds of British scientists and service personnel involved in tests the largest of which had a yield of 25 kilotons.

A royal commission in the 1980s heard evidence that aborigines had been poisoned by a large black cloud which followed some of the weapons' tests.

After long discussions between the two governments the commission's findings led to the ambitious clean-up operation.

The aboriginal people's administrator, Archie Barton, said the community would continue to regard the area with caution and was working with the state and federal government to ensure the return of all the Maralinga lands to their traditional owners.

"We have submitted a business plan to the federal government for the Maralinga village to make it a resource centre, because education remains the key," he said.

The Australian Conservation Foundation, an environmental body, had accused the Australian government of using a cheap option to clear the site. The method changed from in-situ vitrification, which uses an electric current to fuse the rock, to excavating and reburying the debris under landfill.

webTitle: Protests at new killing by NYPD of unarmed black man

fields.headline: Protests at new killing by NYPD of unarmed black man
fields.trailText: The schism in relations between minority communities and the police grew wider yesterday after another unarmed black man was shot dead by an officer, sparking further protests on the streets of America's biggest city.
fields.body:
The schism in relations between minority communities and the police grew wider yesterday after another unarmed black man was shot dead by an officer, sparking further protests on the streets of America's biggest city.

Malcolm Ferguson, 23, a paroled drug-dealer, was killed only a few hundred yards from where four white officers shot dead Amadou Diallo, a black street-trader, just over a year ago - an event which has become a touchstone in the debate over the price to be paid for slashing crime figures.

About 100 demonstrators squared up to police in the Bronx after the latest shooting, which came five days after the officers who fired 41 shots at Diallo - hitting him 19 times - were cleared of all charges against them, including murder.

Ferguson, who was shot in the head by a narcotics officer in the Bronx, had been arrested in the protests that followed last week's verdicts.

"Clearly we want answers," said Ruben Diaz Jr, a state assembly member for New York City borough. "It's amazing how this just happened after this community just dealt with the Diallo shooting."

But there were differences between the two cases. Diallo, who had no criminal record, was shot dead in the entrance to his block of flats. Ferguson, who died three blocks away, had been arrested nine times, ran from the police and was shot by a Hispanic officer, Louis Rivera. Six packets of heroin were found on his body.

However, Ferguson's cousin, Michael Pace, said: "It doesn't matter. Did he have a gun? Did he have intent to harm the police? No."

Khari Alajadae, one of the protesters, said: "I think it's totally disrespectful. They [the police] come into the neighbourhood like thieves in the night - but there is no respect for people of colour. I just think it's something that will happen and continue to happen."

It was not clear whether Officer Rivera fired intentionally as he struggled with Ferguson.

Only hours after Ferguson's death, Diallo's parents and the Rev Al Sharpton, the black activist, were in Washington lobbying the justice department.

They want federal criminal charges to be filed against the four officers, in line with the precedent set when Los Angeles policemen were acquitted of the notorious beating of Rodney King.

But legal experts believe it is unlikely that another trial would be successful, because the prosecution would have to prove that the officers wilfully deprived Diallo of a right protected by the constitution.

Failure to lay federal charges or a second acquittal of the officers could provide yet another flashpoint.

webTitle: Sleepy lawyer helps free condemned man

fields.headline: Sleepy lawyer helps free condemned man
fields.trailText: A man who has spent 16 years on death row in the United States is likely to be released in the next few days.
fields.body:
A man who has spent 16 years on death row in the United States is likely to be released in the next few days.

But his freedom does not represent a rare case of compassion in Texas, which executes more people than any other state. Calvin Burdine, 46, owes his release to an attorney who fell asleep during his original trial and to prosecutors who missed a deadline for a new hearing.

Burdine was sentenced to death after being found guilty in 1984 of stabbing to death his former housemate, W T Wise, 50, the previous year. The two men had had a homosexual relationship.

An inquiry five years ago showed that Burdine's attorney, Joe Cannon, who has since died, was asleep for long stretches of the trial and failed to provide adequate legal representation. He made no objection when the prosecution told the court: "Sending a homosexual to the penitentiary certainly isn't a very bad punishment for a homosexual."

Last year Judge David Hittner, of the US district court, threw out Burdine's conviction and gave prosecutors 120 days to retry him. The deadline passed in January and on Wednesday the judge ordered his release within five days, saying: "Burdine suffers irreparable harm each day that he is imprisoned in violation of the US constitution."

However, Burdine could still face a retrial. Prosecutors said they would file an immediate appeal and expressed confidence that the move would keep Burdine in his cell.

Robert McGlasson, Burdine's current attorney said: "He and I both understand that with the state of Texas anything can happen, but we hope that come Monday Calvin will be having a home-cooked meal with his family."

Speaking last month about a possible release, Burdine said: "The state of Texas don't have to worry about Calvin Burdine. We've got 80 acres in Oklahoma and I can get out there and fish and relax - out of sight and out of mind. I don't want them to think I'm going to roar down those streets and in those bars. I'm not like that any more."

webTitle: Life of neglect that led to school shooting

fields.headline: Life of neglect that led to school shooting
fields.standfirst: Kayla Rolland was the victim of a six-year-old killer. The six-year-old killer was a victim of poor America
fields.trailText: Kayla Rolland was the victim of a six-year-old killer. The six-year-old killer was a victim of poor America
fields.body:
Delving into the squalid circumstances that led a six-year-old to gun down a girl in his class, the US public is experiencing an uncomfortable reminder of a forgotten underclass left behind by the country's much-vaunted economic miracle.

While the US is enjoying its 108th month of continuous growth - driven by computer wizardry and Wall Street optimism - in Mount Morris, the scene of the crime, there is no evidence of this general sense of wellbeing.

Reporters who descended on the boy's house found a single-storey wooden building with the remains of a couple of cars jacked up outside, no glass in the windows, and blankets in place of curtains.

The boy (who has not been named for legal reasons) was left there with his elder brother and uncle about a fortnight ago when his mother, Tamarla Owens, was evicted from their house. Mrs Owens, a long-term drug addict, went to stay with friends. The boys' father, Dedric Owens, was in jail for burglary.

According to neighbours in the working-class Michigan suburb, the shack was a crack-house - a 24-hour drug market, where crack cocaine was sold, or sometimes exchanged for guns. Dealers and addicts came and went, while the brothers had to fend for themselves.

Not surprisingly, the six-year-old killer had a reputation as a troublemaker at nearby Buell elementary school. He got into fights and, according to his father, once stabbed a girl with a pencil. But nothing was done about him or for him. The boy told his father he hated his classmates and when Mr Owens heard there had been a shooting, he told police he had had a "cold, sinking feeling" that his son had been involved.

It was still not clear what sparked the playground squabble between the boy and Kayla Rolland, also aged six. When he had gone to school on Tuesday, the boy had thrust a gun with its three bullets, found under some blankets at his home, into his trouser pocket. He waited until the end of a lesson, when his class was lining up to leave the room, and pulled out the pistol, pointing it at one classmate and then whirling round, as if on a television cop show, firing a single bullet at Kayla. It hit her in the chest and she died less than an hour later. The boy then put the gun in his desk and walked to the school administrative office.

"As much as a six-year-old can, I think he realised that he had done something naughty, but I'm not sure that he understood the enormity of what had actually occurred ... and appeared to take this as some sort of [thing] that just kinda happens like on television," Arthur Busch, the county prosecutor, said as the boy sat drawing pictures under the eyes of social workers. "He is a victim in many ways."

He appears to have been a victim of a litany of symptoms which keeps places like Mount Morris trapped. He was a victim of parental neglect, drugs, a society in which prison expenditure is growing fast while spending on schools and welfare programmes is being eroded. All that and the simple absence of money.

In 1989, the maverick documentary-maker Michael Moore made a film called Roger & Me, about the collapse of the car industry and the consequent death of Flint, the town of which Mount Morris is a dependent suburb.

The car manufacturers have since struggled back to their feet, with fewer workers and more robots, while hi-tech businesses and service industries have picked up the slack in employment.

But for many of those made redundant in the 1980s, with no access to retraining, it has not been so easy.

"When you put abject poverty together with easy access to guns, you have a recipe for this kind of violence," Mr Moore told a radio talk-show.

Profound poverty in an era of plenty may have set the scene for the killing, but America's gun culture made Kayla's death inevitable.

The .32 pistol used in the killing had been stolen in December, and had been left lying around the house by a 19-year-old lodger, Jamelle James, who turned himself in on Wednesday and was yesterday charged with involuntary manslaughter.

In a country whose homicide rate is nearly six times greater than Britain's, Mr Busch said yesterday: "I hope that this prosecution sends a message to America that those guns you think make you safer, make our community more dangerous," he said yesterday.

fields.headline: You call that Jewish food?
fields.standfirst: Salt beef, bagels and chicken soup . . . for many of us, that's Jewish food. But now a completely different tradition of cooking is in the ascendant.  Jay Rayner explains why chopped liver is losing out to falafel, roast aubergine and humus
fields.trailText: Salt beef, bagels and chicken soup . . . for many of us, that's Jewish food. But now a completely different tradition of cooking is in the ascendant.  Jay Rayner explains why chopped liver is losing out to falafel, roast aubergine and humus.
fields.body:
In the foodie lexicon there can be few more oxymoronic phrases than "Jewish cuisine". It suggests refinement. It suggests delicacy. It suggests a whole bunch of things that Jewish food has rarely ever met, let alone been on nodding terms with. Jews joke about it. Here's the definition of Jewish keep-fit lessons: you eat three bowls of chicken soup with matzo balls, put your hand on your chest and say, "Feel the burn." That's how delicate Jewish food is. Today, the only place you are likely to find anything approaching real Jewish cuisine is in the home of the Cohen family of Paris. It will be where they do the cooking.

This, of course, is all a little unfair. Granted, chopped liver and gefillte fish, latkas, salt beef and bagels - what we in Britain and much of America take to be Jewish food - are to light, healthy eating what Slobodan Milosevic is to the Nobel Peace Prize. But they are only a part of the Jewish food story. Like everything else where Jews are concerned - politics, the observance of the religion, the quickest way to drive from Golders Green to Edgware - there are always splits and differences of opinion.

The fact is that what we think of as Jewish food in Britain is only the cooking of the Ashkenazi, the Jews of Germany and eastern Europe, from where much of the community in this country originates. Despite the density of the actual dishes that comprise it, the Ashkenazi culinary canon is actually rather a thin, etiolated affair compared to the extraordinary cookery of the Sephardi Jews, who come from the Iberian peninsula, the Mediterranean and the Middle East.

On Sunday I will sit down before a Jewish Book Week audience, alongside the Jewish cookery writers Claudia Roden, Evelyn Rose and Judy Jackson, and we will try to decide whether there really is still such a thing as Jewish food. Doubtless there will be disagreement. (It is said that if you put two Jews in a room you get three opinions; put 100 Jews in a room and Oi!, but the noise.) A lot of people there will, I'm sure, bemoan what they see both as the vulgarisation and the eclipsing of the great standards of Jewish food in Britain, as the younger generation increasingly turns away from the religious observances and the commands of the laws of Kashruth upon which almost all of Jewish cookery is based.

Their concerns are undoubtedly fair. Great changes have taken place. Four years ago Bloom's of Whitechapel in London's east end was forced to close down after the Beth Din, the Jewish rabbinical court, withdrew its kosher licence. It was certainly the right time. The Jews of the east end had long ago fled the grime of Commercial Road for the peace and privet of the suburbs. Last year the old restaurant's managing director, Michael Bloom, himself moved a little west to Farringdon and set up a new salt beef bar, only this time without a kosher licence. It was too much hassle to have one and anyway his new City-worker clientele didn't care whether a rabbi had muttered over their lunch or not. (The other branch of Bloom's in Golders Green is still in business.)

At the same time as Bloom's left the east end a few of the staples of Ashkenazi food have left behind their roots and undergone a kind of New York-ification. They have become simply a part of the mainstream, without any reference whatsoever to their religious-cultural beginnings. Pret a Manger now sells a pastrami and dill pickle sandwich alongside its BLTs. Frozen oven-cook latkas are available at Tesco. British Midland Airways serves smoked salmon and cream cheese bagels as a snack on its internal flights. Bagel bars like Bagel Express are popping up on every corner - and you can be certain the company's original business plan made no reference to a guaranteed clientele based on the size of London's Jewish community. Sure, there is Ashkenazi food out there but it's hardly what you'd call authentic

Yet this is only half the story, because while Ashkenazi food is in, if not decline, then a curious state of flux, Sephardi food is booming. This is hardly surprising. The roster of Ashkenazi dishes grew up as a direct response to the privations of life in the shtetls. As a result it's generally about as light and fluffy as, ooh, whipped lead. Pickling a good lump of beef in brine may not be the most elegant method of food preparation, but it's a fair way to preserve animal proteins through the long eastern European winters.

Sephardi food, by contrast, is light and sunny. It's about grilled meats and cous cous, marinated vegetables and humus, stuffed peppers and roast aubergines and, like the Sephardi Jews themselves, comes from all points of the compass: Iran and Iraq, Morocco and Spain, Turkey and Syria and Egypt. It is, in short, so very much more in tune with Britain's increasingly eclectic tastes than Ashkenazi comfort food could ever be. And so while Blooms in Whitechapel closes, a new restaurant like Kinneret in Edgware opens, offering a wide menu of Sephardi dishes.

Perhaps the most telling development is the recent appearance of what is, by any definition, Sephardi cooking on non-Kosher restaurant menus, even if it doesn't flaunt itself as such. In London the rise of achingly hip eateries like Momo and Moro, Tajine and Souk, Midi and the estimable Sofra Cafe chain have made it increasingly difficult to escape the influence, and therefore the tastes, of the Jewish Mediterranean. By contrast in the nine months since I took over as the Observer's restaurant critic, I have not once been offered a dish that came even close to being a witty re-interpretation of Ashkenazi food. Boeuf salé en crte , anybody? I don't think so.

The interest here in the food of North Africa and the Middle East mirrors a major change that has occurred in the eating habits of Israelis. When it was founded in 1948, Israel was a strangely European country, somehow transplanted to the Levant, because that was the background of most of the Jews who first settled there. Hence the majority of its restaurants were classically Ashkenazi.

In recent years, however, a massive influx of Jews both from the Middle East and North Africa has led to a sudden growth in the Sephardi population. With it has come the food. It is now about as easy to find a bowl of chicken soup with knaidlach in Tel Aviv as it is a bag of pork scratchings. Instead, it's all schwarma kebabs, falafel and humus. Is it likely that this shift in Israel - the Levantathising of the country, if you like - has had no impact on what British Jews are eating? I doubt it.

The Jewish mothers of Britain may well find all this change very unnerving, but they can at least take comfort from one unalterable truth. Regardless of whether Jews are eating Ashkenazi food or Sephardi food, they can always be counted upon to eat a lot of it. Gentiles drink. Jews eat. It's what we do. This intense relationship between the Jewish palate and stomach is best summed up by a single entry in Claudia Roden's marvellous Book of Jewish Food, which manages to cover both sides of the Jewish culinary coin. It is very short and comes right at the beginning of the recipe for chopped herring. It reads: "Serves 14."
