fields.headline: No: 1587
fields.standfirst: Ian Smith
fields.trailText: Ian Smith
fields.body:
Age: 80.

Appearance: Stony-faced, grey-suited, glass-eyed public-school headmaster.

Description: Farmer, long-superseded prime minister of the former Rhodesia (he unilaterally declared the country's independence from Britain in 1965) and stalwart of "Where Are They Now?" columns.

Where is he now? In Zimbabwe, where this week he launched a scathing attack on President Robert Mugabe - calling him "dangerously incompetent" and "senile" - and charitably offered to stand in next month's parliamentary elections for an anti-Mugabe opposition group.

Sour grapes? Smith has enough to fill a vineyard, but Mugabe has been acting more oddly than usual of late. Following a recent visit to London, he accused Blair of masterminding his ambush by "gay gangsters", after he ran into an OutRage! demo. But Mugabe's appalling record on human rights, fair elections and press censorship, not to mention Zimbabwe's catastrophic economy, are more probable reasons for the growth of opposition.

And Smith evokes memories of a golden era? And when exactly was that? The bloody 13-year guerrilla war that followed his Unilateral Declaration of Independence, in which 30,000 people died? Or Smith's hatred of communists, whom he blamed for propagating the notion that his regime was racist and he was a white supremacist?

Was it? Well, anyone could vote - just as long as they owned sufficient property, which black people were kept from doing.

Sounds like Mugabe has little to worry about. Indeed, except that the president has just suffered the most crushing electoral setback of his 20-year tenure. Despite being a veteran at fixing elections, Mugabe omitted to design a cunning electoral college when he put his new (and more power-grabbing) constitution to the public last month; 55% of them voted against.

Do say: "Why on earth hasn't this human rights-abusing country been expelled from the Commonwealth?"

Not to be confused with: Smith and Jones, Aerosmith, FW de Klerk.

webTitle: Why won't our 24-year-old leave home and be independent?

fields.headline: Why won't our 24-year-old leave home and be independent?
fields.trailText: My 24-year-old son has been a worry since school. Due to an injury sustained while drunk, plus a period of mental instability, it took him an extra year to complete his university studies but he eventually gained a social sciences degree.
fields.body:
My 24-year-old son has been a worry since school. Due to an injury sustained while drunk, plus a period of mental instability, it took him an extra year to complete his university studies but he eventually gained a social sciences degree.

He returned home for a year, living off benefits. He did little around the house and had meals cooked and washing done for him. Then he joined a Christian community and with their support seemed to become more independent. He found work and somewhere to live.

All seemed well until he rang a few weeks ago to say he had flu and wanted to come home. He has not said whether he is coming back permanently, but I do wonder. I feel that at the first hint of illness he is giving up. Now I'm afraid he will go back to square one. We were enjoying having our home to ourselves again and feel this is now threatened.

Set parameters

Your son is now 24, and you cannot expect him to continue depending on you. You must make him realise that as an adult he must stand on his own two feet. You are partly to blame in doing all his washing and cooking for him the last time he stayed at your home and letting him think that he need not contribute in any way.

I suggest that you allow him to come home only for the duration of his illness. Tell him you'll be happy to take care of him while he is unwell, but that as he recovers he will be expected to start helping around the house with the chores. Make it clear that once he has fully recovered, he will be expected to return to his previous dwelling. If that is not possible, offer to help him find somewhere else to live. Your son is old enough to understand that you and your husband are now entitled to some space and time for yourselves.

Good luck.
L Schooneman
Netherlands

Don't indulge him

Several years ago, when I was a 24-year-old graduate, I found myself in a similar position. Your son is a young man experiencing a crossroads in his life. If you feel that he is an imposition he will sense this.

University can be a very challenging time. We feel obliged to be having the "time of our lives", yet we are also fully aware of the parental sacrifices that have secured our place, and there is a very real pressure to be happy and successful as a result.

Leaving and taking the next step can be a very isolating and disorientating process and many of my friends had similar concerns - although in my case perhaps the fact that I am female made it easier because we discussed our worries and insecurities which definitely helped.

I would advise against indulging him too much - he can do his own washing for a start! Instead offer him a safe, loving environment which also grants him the space to find his own way and make his own choices. Do not underestimate his vulnerability in this graduate no man's land. And please, as parents, support him in this fragile time when he probably needs you more than ever.

For my parents and I it certainly took some time to adjust, but with efforts in communication by all, I remember it as a happy experience when we spent some quality time together as adults.

I wish for all three of you the same. Good luck.
Name and address withheld

It will work out

I would say your problem is not unfamiliar to many parents of young men. Based on my own experience of having three sons of about the same age as yours, this is my advice, worked out by trial and error and more or less successful:

Welcome your son home as you are lucky that he feels he can turn to you in a crisis. Give him reasonable time to "recover". Perhaps we all deserve a bit of time to take stock, but not for weeks on end and not without contributing to the household chores.

During this period start to talk about, and then insist, that your son gets a job. There are plenty of awful jobs to be had if nothing great turns up; telesales is a good one. Dreadful as these jobs are, at least he'll be with other young people in similar circumstances and his options will soon become obvious; you can stay in these awful jobs for a long time, lots of young people do and they do offer a sort of comradeship and/or he can think about what to do next.

While your son is still at home, insist he pays something towards his upkeep, however unnecessary or petty of you may feel this is. We asked for £20 a week, leaving enough cash for some freedom and, very important, to start saving to put a deposit on a place of his own.

Work out how long it will take him to get the cash to move out and set a date allowing a bit of leeway. Insist he start looking for accommodation well in advance of that date and help where you can. If the date keeps being put back - put up your "rent".

It is really important to keep a good relationship going during this phase, which isn't easy. If necessary involve other family members to help apply gentle but consistent pressure for the move.

Help with the move, invite him around often. Offer direction and guidance if it is wanted, but insist he does not live with you anymore.

If you are lucky things will move on, your son will "get a life" and remember this period as the end of an era. Or, as with us on more than one occasion, he may come back and you will have to do it all again. But at least the ground rules are laid. It does work out eventually.
Name and address withheld

fields.headline: Next week
fields.trailText: My ex-partner will soon move to the US, taking my daughter, who is four and a half, with her. This move has been presented to me and the family courts as being for two years to further my former partner's career, but I have doubts this is true.
fields.body:
My ex-partner will soon move to the US, taking my daughter, who is four and a half, with her. This move has been presented to me and the family courts as being for two years to further my former partner's career, but I have doubts this is true.

I have discovered that her employment in the US is under a permanent contract, rather than a fixed-term two-year contract, as originally presented, and she will not give any firm commitment - more a vague "intention to return after two years". Also she is engaged to a US citizen at the same company. I believe the idea of moving for two years was to mislead me and the court welfare officer so she could be granted permission to take my daughter.

My dilemma is over what to do in order to cause the least emotional harm to my daughter. For the past 18 months she has lived with me at least four days every two weeks, and since last July for 2-3 weeks at a time while my ex-partner has been in the US we have a very close relationship. The only contract proposed is a weekly telephone/video call, a stay of five weeks each summer and a week at Christmas.

Would it be kinder to my daughter for me to just admit defeat and fade away, painful as that will be, rather than inflict the potential confusion and conflict of trying to maintain a relationship in the face of distance and negative influence from my ex and her partner?

fields.headline: 'The Oscars? Oh no, not again...'
fields.standfirst: Janet McTeer has just been nominated for her role in Tumbleweeds. And, Anita Chaudhuri discovers, she's disappointed - to put it mildly
fields.trailText: Janet McTeer has just been nominated for her role in Tumbleweeds. And, Anita Chaudhuri discovers, she's disappointed - to put it mildly
fields.body:
When Janet McTeer strides into the lounge of one of London's less fashionable hotels, the resident pianist chooses that moment to strike up "When You Wish Upon a Star..." It seems like a particularly fitting way to greet an actress who has, after a 16-year slog working in British theatre and TV, earned this year's surprise Oscar nomination for her Hollywood debut. Her portrayal of a wayward southern belle in Tumbleweeds, a low-budget mother-daughter buddy movie, has enthralled American critics, not least for her honey-drenched Carolina drawl.

McTeer, 38, is not remotely starry-eyed about either the nomination or the music. "That piano is driving me nuts," she growls and sinks deeper into her sofa where she begins a series of distracting neck rolls. How did she feel when she heard about her nomination? She screws up her face as if she's just bitten a lemon. "Disappointed. I felt disappointed and very unsure about my future."

This is a curious response. Even if she doesn't win, her performance as Mary Jo, the exuberant, emotionally battered mother who drags her 12-year-old daughter across America in search of husband number five will give her a host of opportunities.

"Look," she says sternly. "I did Tumbleweeds for fun. I did it because I loved it and I hardly even got paid. I only earned £3,000 for the whole thing. Now suddenly I'm no longer being treated like an actress. Instead I have become a marketing tool and I feel very uncomfortable with that. There's no space for me to express myself. Every time they take my picture they want to put me in a low-cut dress because I've got big tits. Or else they want me in a ballgown. It really sucks."

The thought of McTeer in a ballgown is rather comical. At six foot one, with her sharp crop and crisp, no-nonsense diction, she is defiantly ungirly. In the flesh she is far closer to Helen Hewitt, the gritty prison boss she portrayed in The Governor than the flirty leading lady of Tumbleweeds. As an actress, she is compelling because she can bring both childlike vulnerability and brittle sexual power to the same role, as she memorably did as Vita Sackville-West in TV's Portrait of a Marriage, and as a very un-doll-like Nora in A Doll's House. The latter earned her a Tony award during its two-year Broadway run and caught the attention of Gavin O'Connor, first-time director of Tumbleweeds.

She says she will attend the Academy Awards out of loyalty to him. "When I heard about the Oscars, I thought, oh fuck, not that again. I'd just been through it with the Golden Globes. There was a line of press a mile long - two hours later, when I got to my table, everyone had finished dinner so I was starving. But I do realise it's good for the film, so I won't pretend to have flu. I'll go through with it."

Has she bought a frock? She pulls another grim face. "Yes, but it's all a nightmare. I did one chat show and that was a disaster. I'm not Jim Carrey. I mean, I can be as funny as the next person on a Friday night with three glasses of wine inside me but I can't do it in front of all those people."

Actually, she doesn't seem remotely funny to me, but maybe it's just interview nerves. She's more than happy to fulminate about the Hollywood system, but getting her to talk about anything more personal is exhausting. Was she, I ask, the eldest child in her family? She squirms. "No," she almost whispers. What then? "Youngest." Of how many? Long pause. "Two." Brother or sister? "Sister." I try another tack. What experience did she draw on for Mary Jo's generous, nurturing relationship with her daughter. "Well that just comes from being a nice person." It takes a moment to realise she's cracking a joke.

To prepare for the role, she went to live in North Carolina at her own expense for two months to understand the world her character had rebelled against. "Mary Jo had a traditional upbringing where she was expected to be one thing when, in actual fact, she as a person was something else. That's a huge conflict." Was it a conflict she had experienced?

"Yes I was slightly outside everything when I was growing up. My mother jokes that I was exchanged at birth. She brought us up to have traditional values. She was absolutely not part of the 60s generation. She might have hummed along to the Beatles but she didn't go out and smoke pot. I remember having huge rows with her and my father about women's position in society even when I was 13."

McTeer grew up in York, where her father worked for British Rail. She sold coffees at the Theatre Royal and felt an immediate sense of kinship with the actors. At 18, she was accepted by Rada.

"Going to Rada was such a shock, a vast change. I had gone to an all-girls school, lived in a nice little house and then suddenly I'm in the middle of London living in a bedsit next door to the editor of some porn magazine. And I was around boys for the first time, which, frankly, I couldn't handle. I didn't have any brothers and I'd never had any kind of exposure to boys. It came as a horrible shock to find that they were not these glamorous, mysterious creatures but that they had feet of clay." Her contemporaries at Rada included Sean Bean and James Wilby, while Kenneth Branagh was a couple of years ahead.

Quite how those early experiences impacted on her current relationships is an issue she refuses to be drawn on. She has lived in the same London flat for 15 years and that is all she will say. "It's ridiculous. Now all people want to know is who I'm sleeping with." Did she identify with Mary Jo's need to base her self-esteem on being with a man at all costs? She looks at me incredulously. "I did not," she replies crisply. "But thanks for asking." Then she hoots with laughter. Another little joke.

"It's naive to think there is a woman in the world who isn't brought up to believe that they are waiting for their soulmate. You even see it in Disney. Look at Pocahontas. The girl is always waiting on the river bank for the pretty boy to turn up. But, in real life, there aren't many people who don't want to feel loved, to be in some kind of partnership, whether it's with a man, woman or dog." But whether McTeer shares her life with man, woman or dog must on this occasion remain a mystery because she will not elaborate further.

Does she feel there's a common link between the characters she plays? "Yes, I think they are all women waking up to a sense of self or self-esteem, but doing it in very different ways." Why is she so drawn to these characters? "I find it very interesting to look at how some women base their self-esteem on sexual attractiveness and how ultimately they discover that that can be very unfulfilling.

"Of course, everyone is playing that game to a certain extent. I mean there's nothing wrong with wanting to be attractive - I'm wearing lipstick, so are you, but it's a very fine line." I smile nervously. What does she mean by that? "If you cross that line, if you give sexual favours to a man just because he's handsome and buys you champagne, there's a huge price to pay, as Mary Jo discovers."

Will she move to Hollywood I ask, changing the subject? "Not in a month of bleeding Sundays. It's not going to happen." Too late, she's back venting her spleen against the evils of Hollywood. "The trouble with Hollywood is that people make assumptions. People assume I want to be famous, they assume I want to do a big studio picture. I don't. I don't want people to recognise me in the street."

Does she get recognised at the moment? "No!" she exclaims indignantly. "It's been one of the great mysteries of my career. Here I am, six foot one with a striking, strong face and people walk right past me. I mean, how many six foot broads are there for God's sake? Even when I was doing A Doll's House on Broadway, I'd come out and there would be crowds waiting at the stage door. They'd push me aside without realising who I was."

She has made another independent film, Waking The Dead, directed by Keith Gordon and also co-stars in Christian Levring's Dogme film The King is Alive. "That was a wonderful experience." Next she intends to stay at home and write a screenplay following an abortive attempt to work on a script for A Doll's House. "I had my first run in with American money and it had to be abandoned. Now I want to write something of my own."

Although she says she's really "a theatre person", she adds: "I'd like to work with Pedro Almodovar. He was at the Golden Globes and he looked miserable," she says gleefully. "So did Sam [Mendes], so it's not just me." She gets up to depart and suddenly looks at me in panic. "You won't make me out to sound like a complete bitch, will you?" She's learning.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: Go | All About My Mother | Nanook of the North
fields.trailText: Go | All About My Mother | Nanook of the North
fields.body:
Go
Rental and DVD £19.99
Columbia Tristar Cert 18
****

Another Doug Liman gem. It's stylistically adventurous, has audacious technique to go with the dynamic pacing the title suggests, and the same kind of speedy storytelling and original characters that characterised his fine Swingers. But it's not remotely Swingers II. Go has a different writer (John August) and an entirely different cast, largely pinched from TV (Dawson's Creek, Ally McBeal, Party of Five and even Grange Hill, whose alumnus, Desmond Askew does just fine).

Like Swingers, the plot of Go is almost incidental. It's the characters who take over, leading us into all kinds of unexpected and quirky happenings. It all happens over 24 hours, starting on Christmas Eve. Checkout girl Sarah Polley is threatened with eviction but Askew offers to let her do his shift to make extra cash, which lets him go to Las Vegas with his mates, which in turn... but find the rest out yourself.

Liman comes back to this pivotal scene at regular intervals, but sets off with different participants each time. As a result, Go has been likened to Pulp Fiction, but it's much closer to American Graffiti re-shot in the style of Mystery Train. In essence it's a youth movie with a rave and a drug deal mixed up in the events, but with none of the earnest, self-consciousness striving for teen cred that usually implies.

Liman has a deft touch and a very funny, nervy comedy sense. There probably isn't a scene quite as crack-up hilarious as Swingers' escalating phone messages panic, but the impromptu Macarena, the "shot for a shot" scene, the creepy dinner party and the stoned conversation with a cat all come close. Things skim by and you need to stay more alert than some of the participants to follow it all: as one character says: "It's all connected. Oh, yes." In a very good cast, Polley is, as usual, outstanding (she was a key figure in Egoyan's Exotica and The Sweet Hereafter) and Timothy Olyphant's drug dealer gives Go a real sense of danger too.

All About My Mother
Retail £15.99
Fox Pathé Cert 15
****

Not quite as astonishing as his last, Live Flesh, but another very impressive Pedro Almodovar movie, filmed with the relaxed air of a man in top form. His camera never makes a false move. The first of his 13 films to be shown in competition, it won the best director award at Cannes.

Typically, it's both flamboyantly outrageous and warmly nostalgic of old Hollywood. The juxtaposition is there from the beginning as a couple watch a dubbed version of All About Eve and the woman is suddenly asked: "Would you prostitute yourself for me?" And soon, tragedy directly follows a stage performance of A Streetcar Named Desire.

These characters, too, depend on the kindness of strangers. This is a woman-centred and talky film, with a warm feeling for female solidarity, but it never bores. Attention is required, and rewarded, in a labyrinthine plot which the director has described as "screwball drama". Almodovar throws in his full range of prostitutes, junkies and transsexuals - this will surely be the most adult 15 cert of the year - but it never feels like he's trying to shock, these are just people he's interested in. It's ultimately a non-judgmental and life-affirming film dedicated to "actresses who have played actresses". In his mature period, Almodovar is increasingly coming to resemble Fassbinder - a role that badly needed filling.

Nanook of the North
Retail £15.99
BFI Cert E
***

Robert Flaherty's silent film about Eskimo culture practically invented "documentary" in 1922. You might expect it to be redundant now, but its story of "the most cheerful people in all the world" still packs a punch both for the harshness of life ("Nyla chews Nanook's boots to soften them" says a caption) and the evident warmth of its family. Hunting is the main activity and Nanook's efforts to pull a very large seal out of a very small hole are tragicomic. There's no brutality on show but modern audiences may be more alarmed by Nanook's kids eating lard.

fields.headline: Frances Fisher
fields.trailText: Frances Fisher
fields.body:
What was your first film?

The first film I saw was also the first film I acted in. I was an extra in Spartacus aged 11.

What's your favourite film and why?

Spartacus, because it got me my SAG (equivalent to Equity) card.

When did you last walk out of a film?

Never - I walk out on men, never on a film.

What's the most erotic moment in cinema?

Tony Curtis and Larry Olivier in the milk bath scene in Spartacus.

What's the most annoying habit?

When people try to eat more than one piece of popcorn at a time.

When was the last time you snogged in the stalls?

I watch the movie, I never snog.

What's your favourite dialogue?

"Tonight we march on Rome": Kirk Douglas in Spartacus.

Which actor would you like to be?

Kirk Douglas. He made such an impression on me in my early years.

Which actress?

Jean Simmons, for the same reason.

Which film character?

Spartacus.

When was the last time you cried?

Last night when I couldn't see the films I wanted.

When was the last time you hid under your seat?

Whenever there's a scary scene in a film.

Would you ever team up with Clint Eastwood again on screen after True Crime?

Yes, if he did a remake of Spartacus.

Did you base your PR character in The Big Tease on real life experiences with your own publicists?

Absolutely.

 Frances Fisher appears as a publicist in The Big Tease, which is now on general release.

fields.headline: Tales from the script
fields.standfirst: John Gregory Dunne on the perils of adventuring in the screen trade
fields.trailText: John Gregory Dunne on the perils of adventuring in the screen trade
fields.body:
In 1988 husband-and-wife writing team John Gregory Dunne and Joan Didion were hired to script an adaptation of Golden Girl, Alanna Nash's biography of US broadcaster Jessica Savitch. Six years later a finished movie eventually emerged - the Robert Redford-Michelle Pfeiffer vehicle Up Close and Personal. Dunne chronicled the whole nightmarish process...

A Buyer's Market

It was a buyer's market. Once profligate in developing scripts, only a fraction of which ever went into production, the studios, having humbled the writers in the strike and thinned their inventory of expensive development projects, were in a feisty, fee-cutting mood. Speculative scripts, on the other hand, many of them written during the strike (the only kind of screen work WGA [Writers Guild of America] members could do, since it was without recompense), were the rage.

The beauty of a spec script was that it was finished, could be read and discarded at a sitting if found wanting, and put into production quickly if desirable. The bidding wars on the hotter spec scripts, mainly action thrillers like The Last Boy Scout, Radio Flyer, and Ultimatum, sent prices through the roof; a million dollars became the floor bid when an auction was held.

Toward the development project, however - the project adapted from a book or a play or a magazine article and then nurtured into a screenplay - the studios in this post-strike era brought an accountant's green eyeshade. WGA rules mandate that writers receive a significant portion of their fee upon signing - in other words, before a word is written - and the balance of their first-draft payment upon delivery to the studio.

The inexorability of these payments is what makes studios sullen, and they try to control the script in endless meetings, often with as many as a dozen people present, all of them offering their ideas about what the script should be. To attend one of these meetings is to understand the cold truth of the saying that a camel is a horse made by a committee.

Neither John Foreman [the producer who hired Dunne and Didion] nor we were under any illusions that Golden Girl would be an easy sell. There had been a time in the late 60s and early 70s, the period of Darling and Easy Rider and Midnight Cowboy, when the life of Jessica Savitch would have been an eminently feasible subject for a film, with the possibility of a considerable profit if the budget was strictly managed.

Her story was a perfect cautionary gloss on the perils of the counterculture - a small-town girl with more ambition than brains, an overactive libido, a sexual ambivalence, a tenuous hold on the truth, a taste for controlled substances, a longtime abusive Svengali relationship, a certain mental instability, a glamour job, and then in 1983 a final reckoning, at age 35, that seemed ordained by the Fates - death by drowning with her last lover in three feet of Delaware Canal mud after a freak automobile accident.

This was not a tale, however cautionary, much valued in the climate of the late 80s, when high concept - a picture that could be described in a single line, such as Flashdance (blue-collar woman steelworker in the Rust Belt becomes a ballerina) or Top Gun (cowboy Navy jet jockeys train and love at Mach 2), pushed along by a hit-music track - was in vogue. Studio after studio passed on Golden Girl. Then, shortly after Thanksgiving 1988, John called from Los Angeles to say that he had received a nibble from an unlikely source - the Walt Disney Company.

The Monster

Once known mainly for its animated features and the cartoon shorts of Mickey Mouse and Donald Duck, WDPc (as Walt Disney Pictures is referred to in its contracts), with Michael Eisner as its CEO and Jeffrey Katzenberg its head of motion-picture production, had become a Hollywood powerhouse.

After a string of tightly budgeted commercial hits, Disney was on a roll, and believed it had found a formula, sure-fire as long as that formula - family entertainment that did not too rigorously tax the imagination - was controlled by its own executives. The bottom line was king and the audience that mattered was the company's stakeholders, with whom Disney enjoyed an extraordinarily profitable fiduciary rapport. To the studio's studied indifference, the brand-name actors and film-makers used to getting top dollar and their own way tended to bring their wares elsewhere.

Toward those members of the creative community not coveted by other studios, Disney's attitude was to take no prisoners. Late one evening, at a back table in Le Dome, a Sunset Strip restaurant much favoured by the industry, a producer and a writer we knew were arguing vigorously against the changes the studio was demanding in a picture already in production. The president of the Disney division overseeing the picture suddenly demanded silence. He was, he said, forced by the writer's intransigence to take the monster out of its cage.

In the silence that ensued, the division president reached under the table, pretended to grab a small predatory animal from its lair, and then, as if clutching the creature by the neck first, exhibited his empty, clawlike hand to the people around the table. He asked the screenwriter if he saw the monster, and the writer, not knowing what else to do, nodded yes.

I'm going to put it back in its cage now, the executive said, drawing each word out, and I never want you to force me to bring it out again. Then he mimed putting the monster back into its cage under the table. When he was done, the executive asked the writer, "Do you know what the monster is?"

The writer shook his head.

The executive said: "It's our money."

In time, after a run of box-office failures, the executive himself met the monster, and was fired the way studio presidents are fired: he was allowed to work out his contract as a Disney independent producer.

Meet & Greet

The reputation for being difficult to deal with was something Disney actively encouraged at that time. With [Disney studio head Jeffrey] Katzenberg its point man, the studio had taken a consistently hard line during the strike, and there was little collegial spirit among the people who worked there, some of whom referred to Disney as Mouschwitz or Duckau, after its two most famous cartoon characters.

Though we had been adamant about not attending pitch meetings, John Foreman called to ask if, since Katzenberg was going to be in New York on December 9, we would agree just this once to meet with him. I was reluctant. I did not think Golden Girl the sort of picture Disney would ever make, and a meeting with Katzenberg sounded like a waste of time.

Joan was practical: she said my cardiac distress, however optimistic the prognosis, was still an unknown factor that might kick in at any moment; we needed the health insurance, and this was the only card on the table. Together we prepared Golden Girl down to a one-sentence pitch: the story of an ugly duckling with nothing much going for her who reinvents herself at great effort and greater cost into a golden girl.

On the appointed day, Joan went to see Katzenberg by herself. It is well to remember that Hollywood is largely a boys' club. The presence of a woman at a studio meeting tends to make male executives uneasy. Whenever Joan and I are at a script conference, the questions are invariably directed at me; for years Joan was tolerated only as an "honorary guy", or perhaps an "associate guy", whose primary function was to take notes.

This mind-set is prevalent even to this day. "Is John there?" an executive's assistant will say over the telephone when calling for his master. "This is Joan." "Tell John to call when he gets home."

We have always maintained contractually that as screenwriters (our only professional collaboration), one of us equals both, and her going solo to meet Katzenberg would establish that premise with Disney. There was also the thought that my continued lack of enthusiasm for the meeting might prove contagious. Hobbled by a household accident that had taken most of the skin off her right shin from knee to ankle (a heavy tabletop had fallen on her leg while she was checking a storage closet), and unable to get a cab, Joan walked 14 blocks through the snow to Disney's Park Avenue offices.

The purpose of such a meet-and-greet is to allow the executive to size up the supplicant. Katzenberg had not read Golden Girl, but he was aware of the less savoury details of Jessica Savitch's life. He liked the ugly-duckling idea; it was the kind of narrative he wanted, and he was also responsive to the television background against which it would be played.

And it was clear that an uplifting story that would make an audience feel good about itself was not going to encompass any allusion either to Savitch's suicide attempts or to the lesbian episodes in her life.

Then there was Ron Kershaw, the antisocial, alcoholic news director who was her lover, mentor, and tormentor through most of Savitch's professional career (and through both of her marriages). Something of a genius broadcast gypsy, Kershaw skipped from city to city and channel to channel successfully reconfiguring news departments, and finding new Galatea reporters and anchors on whom he could work his magic.

"She only existed electronically," Kershaw told Alanna Nash about Savitch, and it was he, according to Golden Girl, who taught her the smile that became her on-the-air trademark. "You've got to show teeth," he told Savitch. "Teeth is vulnerability in primates, whether you're a chimp or Dan Rather." Kershaw was also an aggressor, who, when he was not feeding Savitch cocaine, regularly beat her black and blue.

Still, Disney was willing to go to a first draft before offering any specific suggestions, which would then, of course, have the force of law. When we left Burbank that day, this is what we knew: that as long as WDPc was footing the bills, Jessica Savitch would cease to be a factor in the Jessica Savitch screenplay. To persist in writing her story under Disney's rules would be like writing a biography of Charles Lindbergh without mentioning the kidnapping and murder of his son, the trial and execution of Bruno Hauptmann for those crimes, and Lindbergh's flirtation with fascism and America First.

What we did not know was that it would take six more years, four more contracts, two other writers, and 27 drafts of our own before the picture that resulted from this meeting reached its first day of principal photography.

fields.bodyText: In 1988 husband-and-wife writing team John Gregory Dunne and Joan Didion were hired to script an adaptation of Golden Girl, Alanna Nash's biography of US broadcaster Jessica Savitch. Six years later a finished movie eventually emerged - the Robert Redford-Michelle Pfeiffer vehicle Up Close and Personal. Dunne chronicled the whole nightmarish process... A Buyer's Market It was a buyer's market. Once profligate in developing scripts, only a fraction of which ever went into production, the studios, having humbled the writers in the strike and thinned their inventory of expensive development projects, were in a feisty, fee-cutting mood. Speculative scripts, on the other hand, many of them written during the strike (the only kind of screen work WGA [Writers Guild of America] members could do, since it was without recompense), were the rage. The beauty of a spec script was that it was finished, could be read and discarded at a sitting if found wanting, and put into production quickly if desirable. The bidding wars on the hotter spec scripts, mainly action thrillers like The Last Boy Scout, Radio Flyer, and Ultimatum, sent prices through the roof; a million dollars became the floor bid when an auction was held. Toward the development project, however - the project adapted from a book or a play or a magazine article and then nurtured into a screenplay - the studios in this post-strike era brought an accountant's green eyeshade. WGA rules mandate that writers receive a significant portion of their fee upon signing - in other words, before a word is written - and the balance of their first-draft payment upon delivery to the studio. The inexorability of these payments is what makes studios sullen, and they try to control the script in endless meetings, often with as many as a dozen people present, all of them offering their ideas about what the script should be. To attend one of these meetings is to understand the cold truth of the saying that a camel is a horse made by a committee. Neither John Foreman [the producer who hired Dunne and Didion] nor we were under any illusions that Golden Girl would be an easy sell. There had been a time in the late 60s and early 70s, the period of Darling and Easy Rider and Midnight Cowboy, when the life of Jessica Savitch would have been an eminently feasible subject for a film, with the possibility of a considerable profit if the budget was strictly managed. This was not a tale, however cautionary, much valued in the climate of the late 80s, when high concept - a picture that could be described in a single line, such as Flashdance (blue-collar woman steelworker in the Rust Belt becomes a ballerina) or Top Gun (cowboy Navy jet jockeys train and love at Mach 2), pushed along by a hit-music track - was in vogue. The bottom line was king and the audience that mattered was the company's stakeholders, with whom Disney enjoyed an extraordinarily profitable fiduciary rapport. To the studio's studied indifference, the brand-name actors and film-makers used to getting top dollar and their own way tended to bring their wares elsewhere. Toward those members of the creative community not coveted by other studios, Disney's attitude was to take no prisoners. Late one evening, at a back table in Le Dome, a Sunset Strip restaurant much favoured by the industry, a producer and a writer we knew were arguing vigorously against the changes the studio was demanding in a picture already in production. The president of the Disney division overseeing the picture suddenly demanded silence. He was, he said, forced by the writer's intransigence to take the monster out of its cage. In the silence that ensued, the division president reached under the table, pretended to grab a small predatory animal from its lair, and then, as if clutching the creature by the neck first, exhibited his empty, clawlike hand to the people around the table. He asked the screenwriter if he saw the monster, and the writer, not knowing what else to do, nodded yes. I'm going to put it back in its cage now, the executive said, drawing each word out, and I never want you to force me to bring it out again. Then he mimed putting the monster back into its cage under the table. When he was done, the executive asked the writer, "Do you know what the monster is?" The writer shook his head. The executive said: "It's our money." fields.headline: Life before the war
fields.standfirst: Ten years ago, Arthur Howes filmed the Nuba, a proud independent mountain people in Sudan. Then came a genocidal civil war. He went back to tell a story the west is ignoring
fields.trailText: Ten years ago, Arthur Howes filmed the Nuba, a proud independent mountain people in Sudan. Then came a genocidal civil war. He went back to tell a story the west is ignoring
fields.body:
Ten years ago, I made a series of films with the Nuba people of Sudan. I promised to return to show them there but the escalation of the civil war and the refusal of an entry visa made it impossible for me to return until last year.

I first lived in the Sudan in 1980, when I left a teaching post in a dysfunctional south London school to become an English teacher in Kadugli in the Nuba mountains, which occupy an area roughly the size of Scotland. They are a lush, fertile oasis in central Sudan.

The inaccessibility of the mountains had kept the Nuba people isolated and protected from the rest of the country. Until the 19th century, the mountains had defended the Nuba from the slave raiders of the north and during the 17-year civil war, between the north and the south after independence from Britain in 1955, the Nuba mountains remained uninvolved and unscathed.

Nuba society was co-operative and egalitarian. Every single person I knew in the mountains could play a musical instrument. The rainfall there is plentiful and the good soil ensures sufficient food throughout the year.

After living for two years in the Sudan, I left to study film at the National Film and Television school. Six years later, I returned to work as a camera operator for a Sudanese film director, who has to remain anonymous. His film aimed to highlight the abuse of Islamic laws that had been implemented in 1983 by the now-deposed president Gaafar al-Nimeiry.

The director hoped working with a foreign crew would help if filming got rough. The political situation had changed drastically in Sudan: after 10 years of peace, there was war in the south again. The Sudanese People's Liberation Army (SPLA) were fighting against the policies of Arabisation and the implementation of Islamic laws, which included stoning to death for adultery, amputations for theft and death for apostasy - the crime of renouncing Islam. This was causing massive unrest in a country with over 300 ethnic groups and a 40% non-Muslim population.

In December 1983, 3,000 people in Khartoum witnessed a public amputation: two soldiers dressed in surgical theatre aprons chopped off the hands of two young men with sterilised knives. The chopped hands were raised for a cheering public to see.

Two years later on January 17, 1985 in Kober prison, there was a public hanging, of a popular, charismatic 76-year-old Islamic philosopher and teacher Mahmoud Mohamed Taha. This execution was an pivotal moment in Sudanese history. The country would never be the same again.

Taha's "crime" was his unwillingness to repent publicly for issuing a pamphlet arguing against the religious establishment and the misuse and appropriation of Islamic laws. He argued for a progressive Islam, acknowledging the emancipation of women.

What happened to his body after the execution, nobody knows. But all versions agree that his body was never granted a correct Islamic funeral; the corpse was denied and taken by helicopter, possibly cut into pieces and scattered over the Red Sea or that the body was flown over the desert north of Omdurman and dropped from a great height - ultimately denying him a grave and eradicating a possible place of pilgrimage or shrine for a martyr.

The execution was presided over personally by Dr Hassan Turabi, who was then both minister of justice and head of the Muslim Brothers - later to be known as the National Islamic Front (NIF). The execution provided Turabi with political ascendancy. It was the beginning of a roller-coaster of violence and oppression and the end of hope for a democratic secular society in the Sudan.

Our filming in Khartoum had to stop. The director had become ill with anxiety and hepatitis and our guide, John Luke, a Catholic southerner from the Dinka tribe, had been wrongfully accused and amputated for stealing a piece of balsa wood from the university of Khartoum, and was now facing death threats.

The exposed film was left in a fridge in Khartoum and, with a group of Nuba friends, we fled the insecurities and politics of Khartoum and travelled south to the benevolence and sanity of the Nuba mountains. The amputations and execution of philosophers and intellectuals in Khartoum did not seem to be affecting our friends in the mountains, still peripheral to the main currents of Sudanese politics.

During this time, we made a film called Kafi's Story. The account of a young man from Torogi in the Nuba mountains who travels to Khartoum to earn money to buy a wedding dress for his second wife. Kafi took the cassette recorder and talked and talked. This intimate monologue narrates the film. His concerns were for his domestic arrangements; the infidelity of his first wife and his marriage to a second. One morning, we witnessed the arrival of the army garrison. The next day we heard that the mountains were being referred to as War Zone 2. The SPLA was advancing. The mountains became vulnerable, no longer strong enough to resist the disruption. On many nights, we could hear the gunfire in the distance between the army and the SPLA.

With the beginning of the rainy season and the end of filming, we left. I promised to return within two years with a projector and generator to give the films their first screening in the mountains.

Within weeks of our departure, I heard that Kafi's village (Torogi) had been the battleground between the SPLA and the government forces. According to SPLA radio, the Nuba population had been used as shields for the army. I applied to the Sudanese embassy in London for a visa but I was refused. The situation in the Nuba mountains deteriorated and the civil war in Sudan intensified. I re-applied for a visa but was refused again. Despite a government information blackout, fragments of news occasionally leaked out. Within a year, 60,000 Nuba people had been driven away from their homes. By 1993, after repeated raids and destruction of villages, the Nuba mountains were suffering the most severe man-made famine in the Sudan. No food relief was being allowed in.

Two years ago, with a new passport, I obtained the visa and a press pass that allowed me to photograph the celebrations in honour of the NIF that were to be held in the capital, Khartoum. I had no permission to visit the Nuba, but I knew that in the endless peripheries, in the shanty-towns of Khartoum, I would find my Nuba friends.

No fighting had ever occurred in Khartoum. The civil war had been restricted to the Nuba mountains, to southern Sudan and to the east and west of the country. With the exception of a new airport, brightly painted minarets attached to new mosques and some ostentatious palatial homes for the very rich - with satellite dishes and high walls - Khartoum seemed derelict. What I had once known as a cosmopolitan city now looked empty and silent. Everything was broken.

I filmed the military parade. Above us on a podium were the architects of the regime, Dr Turabi, the ideological backbone, and his head of state General Basheer. They were surrounded by heavy security while a crackling amplified voice with feedback repeated relentlessly "Allah Akbar, Allah Akbar" (God is great, God is great).

First came the horses, followed by soldiers, tanks, bicycles, more soldiers, camels, flags, military bands and in the middle of this parade were the children. A group of at least 100 Nuba kids, dressed identically with Sudanese flags pinned to their breasts, were from the peace camps. It is estimated that over 15,000 Nuba children have been forcibly taken away from their parents and taken to peace camps in a government programme for forcible religious conversion, and a pernicious tool for dismembering Nuba society and identity - the children undergo military training and eventually become accomplices in the destruction of their own communities.

Throughout the following year, my search for old friends took me to the squatter settlements in the outskirts of the northern cities, to the mountains where the Nuba resistance holds out and to the refugee camps on the Sudan/ Kenyan border.

In all three locations, I found old friends I knew from the days of Kafi's Story. In all three locations, I screened the films for the very first time to Nuba audiences, and in all three locations, I witnessed and heard of the genocidal war - the limbs that had been cut from the innocent, the scars of crucifixions, the burns on bodies of children, the pain of mothers and the aloneness of the Nuba. Nuba Conversations is an account of this journey and a testament to their courage, dignity and strength, and to the suffering they continue to endure.

They have been ignored by the world. They are a people of grace and goodness but of no monetary interest to the west. It is now more than 10 years since the government offensive against the Nuba population began, but only in June 1999 did the first UN assessment mission take place in the Nuba mountains. Despite their two short visits, no UN aid nor UN human rights monitoring has ever occurred there.

On a daily basis, the Nubas continue to be punished by the NIF regime with impunity. Why? Because they do not conform to the ideal version of Turabi's world. Because the vibrancy of Nuba culture defies the narrow cultural norms of a homogenised Arab-Islamic Sudan. Because the Nubas are black and the Arab mask does not fit.

After every horror of the 20th century we promise ourselves never to allow this to happen again. Now is the time to act. What can we do?

 Nuba Conversations and Kafi's Story are showing as part of The Human Rights Watch international film festival at the Ritzy cinema, Brixton, London SW2 at 12.30pm tomorrow. The next day we heard that the mountains were being referred to as War Zone 2. The SPLA was advancing. The mountains became vulnerable, no longer strong enough to resist the disruption. On many nights, we could hear the gunfire in the distance between the army and the SPLA. With the beginning of the rainy season and the end of filming, we left. I promised to return within two years with a projector and generator to give the films their first screening in the mountains. Within weeks of our departure, I heard that Kafi's village (Torogi) had been the battleground between the SPLA and the government forces. According to SPLA radio, the Nuba population had been used as shields for the army. I applied to the Sudanese embassy in London for a visa but I was refused. The situation in the Nuba mountains deteriorated and the civil war in Sudan intensified. I re-applied for a visa but was refused again. Despite a government information blackout, fragments of news occasionally leaked out. Within a year, 60,000 Nuba people had been driven away from their homes. By 1993, after repeated raids and destruction of villages, the Nuba mountains were suffering the most severe man-made famine in the Sudan. No food relief was being allowed in. Two years ago, with a new passport, I obtained the visa and a press pass that allowed me to photograph the celebrations in honour of the NIF that were to be held in the capital, Khartoum. I had no permission to visit the Nuba, but I knew that in the endless peripheries, in the shanty-towns of Khartoum, I would find my Nuba friends. No fighting had ever occurred in Khartoum. The civil war had been restricted to the Nuba mountains, to southern Sudan and to the east and west of the country. With the exception of a new airport, brightly painted minarets attached to new mosques and some ostentatious palatial homes for the very rich - with satellite dishes and high walls - Khartoum seemed derelict. What I had once known as a cosmopolitan city now looked empty and silent. Everything was broken. I filmed the military parade. Above us on a podium were the architects of the regime, Dr Turabi, the ideological backbone, and his head of state General Basheer. They were surrounded by heavy security while a crackling amplified voice with feedback repeated relentlessly "Allah Akbar, Allah Akbar" (God is great, God is great). First came the horses, followed by soldiers, tanks, bicycles, more soldiers, camels, flags, military bands and in the middle of this parade were the children. A group of at least 100 Nuba kids, dressed identically with Sudanese flags pinned to their breasts, were from the peace camps. It is estimated that over 15,000 Nuba children have been forcibly taken away from their parents and taken to peace camps in a government programme for forcible religious conversion, and a pernicious tool for dismembering Nuba society and identity - the children undergo military training and eventually become accomplices in the destruction of their own communities. Throughout the following year, my search for old friends took me to the squatter settlements in the outskirts of the northern cities, to the mountains where the Nuba resistance holds out and to the refugee camps on the Sudan/ Kenyan border. In all three locations, I found old friends I knew from the days of Kafi's Story. In all three locations, I screened the films for the very first time to Nuba audiences, and in all three locations, I witnessed and heard of the genocidal war - the limbs that had been cut from the innocent, the scars of crucifixions, the burns on bodies of children, the pain of mothers and the aloneness of the Nuba. Nuba Conversations is an account of this journey and a testament to their courage, dignity and strength, and to the suffering they continue to endure. They have been ignored by the world. They are a people of grace and goodness but of no monetary interest to the west. It is now more than 10 years since the government offensive against the Nuba population began, but only in June 1999 did the first UN assessment mission take place in the Nuba mountains. Despite their two short visits, no UN aid nor UN human rights monitoring has ever occurred there. On a daily basis, the Nubas continue to be punished by the NIF regime with impunity. Why? Because they do not conform to the ideal version of Turabi's world. Because the vibrancy of Nuba culture defies the narrow cultural norms of a homogenised Arab-Islamic Sudan. Because the Nubas are black and the Arab mask does not fit. After every horror of the 20th century we promise ourselves never to allow this to happen again. Now is the time to act. What can we do?  Nuba Conversations and Kafi's Story are showing as part of The Human Rights Watch international film festival at the Ritzy cinema, Brixton, London SW2 at 12.30pm tomorrow. Festival box-office: 0171737 2121 Nuba Conversations has a special screening at Cinema du Reel at the Pompidou Centre, Paris, on March 18 and 19.

fields.headline: The curse of Frankenheimer
fields.trailText: The curse of Frankenheimer
fields.body:
Well, good riddance to February. If the calendar year were a city, all the most pungent industrial complexes, the grungiest trailer parks, all the sewage-treatment works, all the hogfat-rendering plants, and all the Special Brew corner drunks and junkies, every last one of them would be found in the benighted, black-skied subsection called February town.

Everyone's waiting for something to happen and the only certainty is that nothing they're waiting for will ever happen in February.

The studio bigwigs are waiting for the Oscars, and the stars are itching to get back on location, away from their spouses. Me, I'm just waiting for the clocks to go forward; but, like everything else, it won't be happening in February.

You'd think you could count on the movies as a source of distraction, a means of fast-forwarding through the boredom two hours at a time, $7.50 a shot. Well, you can't. It's still going to be February when you come out - and it's more than likely that you just saw a shitty movie.

And probably the same shitty movies as last week, since the box office chart remains largely unchanged. The Whole Nine Yards still squats on top of the pile, while the Ephron sisters' Hanging Up dropped from number two to four thanks to bad word-of-mouth (and bulging barf-bags too, I'll wager).

Elsewhere, there are those movies still clinging on from last week: The Tigger Movie (I've already got my tie-in Tigger slipper-shoes and I'll fight the man who mocks them) at number six and Scream 3 at eight.

Then there are The Cider House Rules and American Beauty, Oscar contenders rolled out to graze some last-minute cash. And at five is the sub-Alien sci-fi thriller Pitch Black, which appeals to those members of the teenage male audience who believe their dates will give it up a lot quicker if they're scared half to death.

Bad plan, fellers, because Pitch Black isn't frightening. Better get 'em drunk instead.

Which leaves us with the only two new releases: John Frankenheimer's Reindeer Games and Curtis Hanson's first movie since LA Confidential, Wonder Boys, with Michael Douglas.

For me, the best line of dialogue from the entire 1990s came from a Frankenheimer film (I know - I'm as surprised as you are), last year's slick Euro-thriller Ronin. After multiple betrayals, double-crosses and murders, a perfidious Russian techie-spook named Gregor (the magnificently reptilian Stellan Skarsgard) laments the way things have turned out, a state of affairs for which he himself is largely responsible: "Look at us all. What could have been conducted in polite, collegial fashion is now fucked into cocked hat."

Actually, Skarsgard says "farked into cocked het", but no matter. The point is that Frankenheimer, who hasn't made many great movies, can usually be relied on to produce one or two golden moments like that in most of his movies.

Frankenheimer's curse has been that all his best work came in the first few years of his career, before the 60s were two-thirds over. And it didn't help that the first to go over big was also, unarguably, the only masterpiece he's ever made: The Manchurian Candidate.

It was a film so attuned to the pathologies of its time - the emerging saturation-media landscape, the rise of a fanatically anti-communist, John Birch-like right, and the twin spectres of coup d'etat and political assassination - that one's surprised to find it as fresh and sharp now as it was then. George Axelrod extracted from Richard Condon's bestseller a degree of political savvy largely absent from more po-faced political thrillers of the time such as Fail-Safe.

Along with Gore Vidal's The Best Man (directed by Franklin Schaffner in 1964), it's one of the few movies about politics that audiences have grown into, rather than out of. Each film had to wait 20 years until we had become as cynical and jaded about politics as they already were.

Frankenheimer never bettered it, but Seven Days in May and Birdman of Alcatraz were intelligent and gripping, quintessential, issues-based liberal films of the 60s. And in 1966 he came close, with the nightmarish Seconds, in which John Farrow (then just off the blacklist) submits to a rejuvenation programme and emerges in his new life as disturbed swinging bachelor Rock Hudson. It's one of the neglected classics of its era, prefiguring the paranoia and anxiety of the Watergate era.

Sadly, for every The Gypsy Moths (which had Deborah Kerr topless at 50) there's a Dead Bang or a Black Sunday, and for every The Fixer, there's a Fourth War or a 99 and 40/100 Percent Dead. And Frankenheimer's career went off the rails in the 1970s, when, by his own confession, he was half-drunk half the time and all drunk the rest. I know he was pissed up when he approved that last title.

Ronin wasn't deep or even very brainy, but it was good, solid Frankenheimer. Reindeer Games lingers in a similar heist-and-betrayal milieu, but it isn't good anything. Frankenheimer is directing a script by Ehren Kruger, who wrote Scream 3 and deserves to be nicknamed Mister Twist for the contortions he puts his characters and audiences through.

There's something deeply undignified about a man pushing 70 associating himself with jejune material like this, a violent robbery comedy that might as well be called Scream 4: Casino Heist.

Frankenheimer is also stuck with the largely charisma-free Ben Affleck, whose ascent to stardom continues to mystify me. There seems to be a fat man inside him straining to get out - and anyone who remembers his rotund bully from Dazed & Confused will know that he's since shed about 50lb - which works out to about a crate of Fight Club soap. I'm praying he piles the weight back on and disappears from the screen into podgy obscurity.

As for Wonder Boys, it only rose to number seven, despite good reviews. I wasn't rabid for LA Confidential (I'm a Chinatown guy right down the line) and I hated The River Wild, so I haven't raced to see it yet.

I did once meet director Curtis Hanson at a big Hollywood party and he was every inch the perfect gentleman, despite the fact I spent our entire conversation labouring under the misapprehension that he was LA underground filmmaker Curtis Harrington. Oh, I wince to recall it...

fields.headline: Don't spurn the sporran
fields.standfirst:
A cunning plan to make Scottish university students pay fees by a post-graduation endowment could prove to be a model for other services

Devolution in Scotland: special report
fields.trailText: Messrs Blunkett, Blair and Brown may be congratulating themselves that a settlement on student fees has been reached north of the border. The 20 leading universities that make up the "Russell group" are busy discussing extra fees - in the post-election future. A few students are revolting. Not many votes lost.
fields.body:
Messrs Blunkett, Blair and Brown may be congratulating themselves that a settlement on student fees has been reached north of the border. The 20 leading universities that make up the "Russell group" are busy discussing extra fees - in the post-election future. A few students are revolting. Not many votes lost.

But ministers should not be complacent. Almost by accident as part of the fees fudge, the Scottish parliament may have invented a radical new tax. It is a vehicle that could speed happily through the of ficial limits on taxation powers imposed by Westminster to limit the impact of devolution.

None of the parties involved intended this and few politicians seem to have realised the significance of what they have done. Yet it cannot be long before they spot the potential. If the new tax regime works for higher education, why not for health or transport and whole raft of public services? Given popular support, it might even be used to transform Scotland into a very different country from its southern neighbour.

To recap: Edinburgh's Labour-Lib Dem coalition threatened to run aground on the rock of tuition fees for students; the latter had pledged to abolish them. They sent for Edinburgh tax lawyer Andrew Cubie to report, to buy time. The Cubie committee proposed a "graduate endowment".

Instead of paying fees upfront, students would pay the £3,000 cost of their education after graduation into a fund which (Cubie hoped) would be earmarked for universities. "Endowment" had respectable echoes. Graduates, Cubie suggested hopefully, might mark their respect for a good Scots education by contributing to this endowment; business and industry might also chip in. The idea found favour in Scotland but did not quite suit the coalition. Labour found it too expensive. For the Liberal Democrats it was still too close to retrospective fees. The upshot, after weeks of bargaining, was an amendment. There is to be a special kind of higher education fund: graduates would be required to make a financial contribution but their payments would be dedicated to the support of poor students. They would pay into a ringfenced account - out of the treasury's reach.

It is quite an innovation, mixing the Lib Dems' hypothecated education tax and Labour's redistributionist ambitions. Lindsay Paterson of Moray House, Edinburgh, sees no reason why things should stop there. While the Scottish parliament's tax-raising powers are strictly circumscribed by the devolution settlement - and Labour is pledged not to use them anyway - egalitarian charges for public services is legally and politically feasible.

Take dentistry. People pay dental charges: why not put the money into a fund subsiding treatment for those on low incomes? For Scots, a redistributive, communitarian solution to the problems of funding the national health service could well have more appeal than private insurance options. Car charges to curb city traffic and subsidise public transport are another possibility.

"The scope is endless. None of these is a 'tax' - in fact you could eventually lower Scottish income tax," Profes sor Paterson suggests. The Edinburgh executive might use the Cubie method to give local authorities more responsibility without raising council tax, allowing them to create endowment funds for public services. The administration of these funds might even be contracted out, say to Standard Life. "A privatised tax collection system in the interests of redistributing wealth? Well, we live in a non-ideological age."

If the mechanism exists, does the political will? The appeal to Labour leftwingers and Lib Dems frustrated by the apron strings of Westminster is obvious and it has something of Gordon Brown's redistribution by stealth about it.

Scottish Conservatives now argue the parliament should have full tax powers to make it behave responsibly - and charging the customer is not an alien concept as far as they are concerned. The Scottish Nationalists might like the element of social justice in the scheme, though they of course have no wish to see a devolved parliament working too well.

The Cubie committee's tour around Scotland to gather public reaction showed a consensus for public action to deal with social problems. This tax lawyer and former spokesman for the Scottish CBI was able to talk openly about redistributing funds from middle-class parents to poor students in a way that New Labour dare not for fear of offending the Daily Mail. (And indeed Cubie's proposal to cut back on loans for the well-off and bring back meaningful grants for students from low income families proved too much for Blair's party.)

The Scottish public had utopian hopes of the new parliament. They believed education would improve and so would the economy and just about everything except the weather, despite its very limited powers. Disillusion has naturally set in. The true test, however, is whether the Scottish parliament manages to make enough small changes over the next decade to make a difference.

There are hopeful signs that a more inclusive politics could emerge. The Cubie committee's consultations with the public - and the civic organisations so rigorously excluded during the Tory years - are being repeated in preparing for forthcoming bills on crofting and education. The latter might incorporate the United Nations declaration on the rights of the child, obliging schools to consult children.

It could reinvigorate Scottish democracy. Napier University is looking at ways to harness information technology not just for electronic voting but for "e-consultations" and opening out the lobbying system to the general public.

The Cubie tax (sorry, endowment) could prove a model for other progressive measures. It isn't in the same league as that other small nation - Singapore - which puts 25% of its national income into research and education, but it might prove to be a start.

 Donald MacLeod is editor of Guardian Education

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: • The Echelon Corporation, whose headquarters are in Germany, have asked us to point out that they have no connection with the US government, and, in particular, that they have no connection with the US government's Echelon spying network, the subject of a report on page 15, February 24. We are happy to do that.
fields.body:
 The Echelon Corporation, whose headquarters are in Germany, have asked us to point out that they have no connection with the US government, and, in particular, that they have no connection with the US government's Echelon spying network, the subject of a report on page 15, February 24. We are happy to do that.

 In a report, pages 2 and 3, Jobs & Money, February 26, on individual rights to see medical files, we mentioned the access to medical reports act. We should also have mentioned the access to health records act, which gives additional rights to both NHS and private patients, provided there would be no danger to the patient from the information revealed.

 The organisation referred to in Sex and salvation, our G2 lead yesterday, pages 2 and 3, is the Lesbian and Gay Christian Movement, not the Gay and Lesbian Christian Association. Susanne Riess-Passer, the subject of Pass notes, page 3, G2, yesterday, was born in Braunau (not Braunlau).

 Footnote: the following passage appeared in an article, page 16, G2, March 1, "There's a photograph of uncle Peter in Buenos Aires, in a dashing white South American suit and correspondent shoes." That should, of course, have been co-respondent shoes, defined in Collins Millennium as "men's two-coloured shoes, usually black and white or brown and white" (from co-respondent, a person cited in a divorce case where adultery was an issue). In the same piece we meant to say Teck (not Tek), as in the Prince, or Duke of Teck.

 It is the policy of the Guardian to correct significant errors as soon as possible. Please quote the date and page number. webTitle: Index finger of fate points at old-timers

fields.headline: Index finger of fate points at old-timers
fields.trailText: The impact of the second industrial revolution will be emphasised next week when one in 10 stalwarts of the FTSE 100 index is likely to be ditched in favour of new-economy stocks.
fields.body:
The impact of the second industrial revolution will be emphasised next week when one in 10 stalwarts of the FTSE 100 index is likely to be ditched in favour of new-economy stocks.

The casualties could include many corporations - such as Imperial Tobacco, Whitbread and Scottish & Newcastle - whose histories predate the second world war. The new boys will include a couple, such as Thus and Freeserve, whose roots reach little further back than last year's conflict in Kosovo.

Out could go Allied Domecq, the world's second-biggest drinks company with a turnover of £2.5bn. In will come Kingston Communications, the Hull telecoms company with big internet ambi tions, but annual sales of just £150m.

Gaining or maintaining FTSE 100 status is of increasing importance to company managements. Inclusion in the top 100 means the growing number of institutional investors who track the index are automatic buyers - which bolsters the new entrants' share price. Conversely, relegation from the stock market's equivalent of the premiership means fund managers are forced to sell.

It can cause other problems too. Alliance & Leicester, for instance, which is another tipped to take the drop next week, is likely to find it far more difficult to recruit a top banker to fill its vacant chief executive's seat if it is ousted from the big league.

The details of which companies will come and go will not be revealed until next Wednesday and the decision will be based on Tuesday night's share prices. Any firm ranking outside the 111 most highly valued companies is bound to be expelled, while corporations inside the top 90 will be safe. So, for man agers keen to keep their status, there is still much to play for.

Several of the companies have been lobbying analysts and investors in recent weeks and the timing of Scottish & Newcastle's Center Parcs sell-off, which boosted the brewer's share price, was helpful.

But at yesterday's prices Thames Water, Hanson, PowerGen and Associated British Foods were also heading for the dump bin, while handheld computer company Psion, computer services group Baltimore Technologies and biotech plays Celltech and Nycomed were ready to join the FTSE 100 big hitters.

By Wednesday Nycomed had become the country's 82nd-biggest company by market capitalisation with Celltech 85th. Celltech's entry would be significant, marking the first time a pure biotech stock will make it into the FTSE 100. British Biotech came close but fell from grace following its controversial product setbacks in 1998.

webTitle: Co-op finally puts survival on agenda

fields.headline: Co-op finally puts survival on agenda
fields.standfirst: CWS and CRS merger vote brings longstanding conflicts into the open
fields.trailText: Tomorrow's vote on the merger of Britain's two biggest co-operative societies, the Co-operative Wholesale Society and Co-operative Retail Services, is about to change the face of an £8.4bn organisation which once ruled the country's food retailing market.
fields.body:
Tomorrow's vote on the merger of Britain's two biggest co-operative societies, the Co-operative Wholesale Society and Co-operative Retail Services, is about to change the face of an £8.4bn organisation which once ruled the country's food retailing market.

What is taking place is an intriguing rebirth of the 116-year-old co-operative movement. The prime minister last week blessed the establishment of a commission to review the structure, control and management of the organisation which links 47 societies. It is only the second review in the co-op's history and a whispering campaign began that it was a "quasi-government" inquiry.

In private conversations Labour MPs said the commission's review was linked to party funding and noted the likelihood of an election being called in the next 18 months. "They were going to look at the relationship with them in terms of party funding," said one MP, who requested anonymity.

The Co-operative Party was founded in 1917 to boost the political interests of the movement in association with the Labour party.

Tony Blair is only too aware of the power the coop's political wing holds. The Co-operative Party's vote ensured Frank Dobson's endorsement as Labour's candidate for London mayor.

Pauline Green, chief executive of the Co-operative Union, said she "had heard such [funding] rumours but they're nonsense".

She said: "The co-op has some agreements with co-op-sponsored MPs and various bodies of the co-op may make donations in various forms. But there's no suggestion of anything else."

The establishment of a commission has been marred by complaints by one co-op member, Barbara Rogers, that the Co-operative Union was not consulted. Ms Rogers, who is a former CRS director, claims that the co-operative movement is being hijacked "by a marginal group".

She points the finger at Graham Melmoth, chief executive of the CWS.

"The start of a commission without consulting the different elements of the movement reflects how it's going to be in the future if this merger goes ahead," Ms Rogers said. "The commission is going to be looking particularly at amalgamations which is very much Melmoth's agenda to mop up surrounding independent societies."

Personal attacks

Mr Melmoth declined to comment ahead of Saturday's vote. He is expected to wait until the CWS board meets next Wednesday. His thoughts on the commission's establishment are that it will "help us identify opportunities to modernise and change so that our unique consumer-owned organisation is clearly successful both as a business and in its contribution to the life of the country".

Mr Melmoth was the architect of the commission's establishment after discussions with senior Labour party members last summer. Supporters of Mr Melmoth describe as ludicrous any claims that the CWS was planning to take over the whole movement.

"Personal attacks on Graham Melmoth who for more than three and a half years has pulled the movement together and to strengthen it is just totally unfair," said one co-op insider. "He of all people has done more to improve the co-op."

Andy Meehan, chief executive of CRS, has been silent on his society's view of the commission, preferring CWS to take the lead. The feedback from the meetings of CRS's 26 regional councils last month suggests Saturday's vote will be overwhelmingly in favour of bringing the two groups together.

The ailing CRS, which last year reported an operating loss of almost £60m, needs a partner, and this was recognised by the board and its members. The savings on staff, technology and joint buying, distribution and warehousing systems will be large.

Mike Godliman, director of sales and marketing at retail analyst firm Verdict Research, said: "I think it's definitely a good thing that this vote is happening. It should have happened 20 years ago. They would have gained so much as an organisation if they could have operated as one unit rather than separate units."

The lack of cohesion among the movement's 47 societies and the criticism that some have been run as local fiefdoms rather than commercial entities is at the core of the movement's diminishing success. Until the second world war co-operative societies accounted for a quarter of the British grocery market. Nowadays it still runs a total of 4,730 stores which include food retailing, funeral parlours, motor dealerships, travel agencies, shoe shops, opticians and the Co-op Bank among others, involving an annual £8.4bn in turnover.

Nevertheless, the transformation in the retail landscape to one of cut-throat competition and over-service by superstores has affected the co-op's retailing arm.

"They need to be focused on neighbourhood retail," Mr Godliman said. "They cannot compete at the superstore level with the likes of Asda and Tesco. But they have a trusted brand and strong links to the community."

While the business case for the marriage of CWS and CRS is clear, there remain concerns about its governance. Some CRS members feel the combined group will become dominated by CWS. Writing in the Co-op News, David Chambers, a CRS member from north Wales, described the merger as a "disaster".

The co-op's very future as a mutually owned organisation was under threat as recently as 1997 when the entrepreneur Andrew Regan tried to privatise it. Mr Regan's bid, however, did have the benefit of shining the spotlight on the movement's commercial problems. Three years later those issues are finally being addressed.
