fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: Leading shares closed higher for a third consecutive session yesterday, extending this week's rally to 332 Footsie points, thanks a strong showing on Wall Street and a firm performance by our own British Telecom.
fields.body:
Leading shares closed higher for a third consecutive session yesterday, extending this week's rally to 332 Footsie points, thanks a strong showing on Wall Street and a firm performance by our own British Telecom.

With Shell and BP Amoco also chipping in with good gains, the FTSE 100 ended the session 67.2 points higher at 6,432.1.

The strength was not confined to the blue-chip index, however. Both the FTSE 250, up 60.2 points at 6,676.8, and the FTSE Small Cap, 47.7 points better at 3,421.9, closed at all-time highs as did the TechMark 100, up another 110.3 at 5,452.73.

BT picked up 79p to £11.74, delivering 26 Footsie points and helped on the day by news that telecommunications was being dropped from the controversial utilities bill.

Cable & Wireless was also in sparkling form, closing 68p better at 542p. Following the sale of C&W's associate, HKT, the discount that has always been traditionally applied to C&W stock has vanished.

Rio Tinto, up 97p at £10.44, ended the session as the best-performing top 100 stock, lifted by firmer metals prices. Billiton move 26p higher to 289p for the same reason, while Anglo American gained 122p to £30.59.

Other prominent risers included Hilton Group, 24p better at 285p. Investors are still excited by plans to develop Ladbroke's internet interests.

Oil stocks were in demand as oil ministers from Saudi Arabia, Venezuela and Mexico met in London to discuss oil output curbs. Shell added 16p to 451p and BP Amoco gained 14p to 501p.

Kingfisher saw a gain of 32p to 542p, with followers excited by news on the public offering of Libertysurf, the French internet service provider in which the UK retailer holds a 45.5% stake.

But against this Rentokil crashed another 18p to 157p as a slew of broker downgrades followed Wednesday's badly received year-end figures. Rolls-Royce was also among the prominent fallers, giving up 17p to 191p after yesterday's results.

Marks & Spencer, down 12p to 248p, gave up most of the gains seen late on Wednesday when the latest bid rumour swirled around dealing desks. France's Carrefour was reported to have denied any interest in the British stores group.

Elsewhere, technology group Limit crashed 24p to 90p as investors had their first chance to react to a profits warning issued late on Wednesday.

fields.headline: Legendary Investments
fields.trailText: Jeans entrepreneur Shami Ahmed yesterday got off to a flying start in his new career as chief executive of a quoted dot.com business.
fields.body:
Jeans entrepreneur Shami Ahmed yesterday got off to a flying start in his new career as chief executive of a quoted dot.com business.

The man who gave the world Joe Bloggs denims saw his Legendary Investments make a sparkling stock market debut - with the shares racing from their offer price of 2p to 11p.

It was one of several technology and dot.com debuts yesterday. Intechnology, a company which plans to exploit business-to-business internet ventures and where entrepreneur Chris Akers is on the board, rocketed from 25p to 270p.

New science and technology television operationEinstein Channel rose to 58p from an offer price of 10p, while telecoms equipment maker Dataflex Holdings climbed to 294p, an impressive upgrade on its float price of 195p.

Mr Ahmed's AIM-listed concern, which raised just over £3m, is an internet investment company. Not clever, it would seem, when Mr Ahmed is on record saying that "the internet bubble is going to burst" and that he reckons 90% of internet companies will go bust.

But Mr Ahmed reckons he can sort the wheat from the chaff. He has signed up two fellow directors - former Thorn chief Michael Frye and Smit Berry, the founder of equitylink and Sharepages.com - and the three men bought 65.6m shares, racking up a paper profit of more than £6m in the first hours of trading.

Mr Ahmed has handed control of his rag-trade and property empires to his brother and says he will be devoting his energies to Legendary.

webTitle: Alchemy joins cold war to be Storehouse suitor

fields.headline: Alchemy joins cold war to be Storehouse suitor
fields.trailText: Venture capital group Alchemy has emerged as another potential suitor for Storehouse, the retailer encompassing Mothercare and Bhs group which revealed last week it had received several possible bid approaches.
fields.body:
Venture capital group Alchemy has emerged as another potential suitor for Storehouse, the retailer encompassing Mothercare and Bhs group which revealed last week it had received several possible bid approaches.

Alchemy, run by entrepreneur John Moulton, is a potential partner for the supermarket group Iceland, which confirmed it had made a tentative approach to Storehouse about buying Bhs.

Iceland recently struck a deal with Storehouse to open 100 foodhalls in Bhs outlets, and is understood to be concerned to protect its expansion plans now that the group has announced that it has received approaches for Bhs and Mothercare.

Iceland's chairman, Malcolm Walker, believes he can take on M&S in town centres with his chilled and fresh food offer. A source said no price had been discussed and that talks were still at an early stage.

Iceland's shares have been hit by news of Mr Walker's apparent interest in the ailing stores. Last night they closed 5p down at 251.5p, after an 18.5p decline on Wednesday.

Sources close to Iceland insist Mr Walker has no intention of getting involved with fashion retailing and would draft in expertise or a partner to run that side of business. Alchemy is regarded as the likely partner.

Storehouse shares, languishing at around 30p before it made its bid approaches public, closed up 1p at 46p.

Retail experts say a takeout bid for the whole organisation, including Mothercare, would have to top 70p but few potential bidders would want to be lumbered with Bhs's stores portfolio.

fields.headline: Rolls targets cruise line market
fields.standfirst: Warship engines could work quiet revolution in luxury market
fields.trailText: Rolls-Royce is considering plans to fit a range of gas-turbine engines it is developing for a new generation of American and British warships to the growing worldwide fleet of cruise liners.
fields.body:
Rolls-Royce is considering plans to fit a range of gas-turbine engines it is developing for a new generation of American and British warships to the growing worldwide fleet of cruise liners.

Sir Ralph Robins, Rolls chairman, said a number of cruise companies had expressed interest in replacing diesel-fuelled engines with the gas-turbine WR21 which the British group is developing for the UK, United States and Japanese navies.

These engines, which will power the new carriers and destroyers, are far less noisy than the diesel versions and are likely to please the rapidly expanding numbers of passengers on cruises.

Reporting an 11% rise in pre-tax profits last year to £360m and reaffirming Rolls' commitment to double-digit growth this year, Sir Ralph said the group would swiftly boost sales at its marine propulsion business to £1bn a year.

Sales have already more than doubled to £800m after last year's acquisition of Vickers, a world leader in marine propulsion, and Sir Ralph said these could be increased further by a series of smaller acquisitions.

But the Rolls chairman indicated that the group is poised to sell off the Vickers defence business, which makes the army's Challenger 2 tanks, with both US and European groups already interested. The timing of the sale will depend, Sir Ralph said, on the outcome of bids for an initial £1bn contract for 200 tanks being ordered by Greece.

Experts believe the German group Krauss Maffei, maker of the Leopard tank, is front-runner to secure the order, which has been delayed until after the Greek general election next month.

Sir Ralph expressed irritation at the market's failure to reward Rolls' consistent earnings growth but the shares, which hit 305p last June, fell a further 17p, more than 8%, to close at 191p.

Investors took fright at a further £80m in restructuring costs, including an estimated loss of 1,600 jobs on top of the same number in 1999.

fields.headline: BT displays the dinosaur tendency
fields.standfirst: Threat to mobile phones auction
fields.trailText: Threat to mobile phones auction
fields.body:
Just in case any of us had forgotten, British Telecom gave us a reminder yesterday that there are still some parts of of this former state-owned monopoly which privatisation and deregulation just have not reached.

And Sir Peter Bonfield should know that the mindset that comes in threatening to take legal action to halt the auction of third generation mobile phone licences would be better suited to a 70s union boss, than an executive at the top of a company right at the cutting edge of technological change.

In addressing the threat of one company owning two new licences, the Radiocommunications Agency has sensibly amended the rules to take account of Vodafone's temporary ownership of Orange. It was a situation which could not have been foreseen when the original auction rules were written.

First Mannesmann swallowed Orange. Then Vodafone swallowed Mannesmann but promised to spit out Orange as part of the deal.

The idea that Vodafone and Orange will collude in some way during the auction to BT's disadvantage is surreal. Both businesses are bitter rivals and will continue to be after Orange has been sold.

If BT had its way, one of Britain's most innovative mobile phone groups would be excluded from the most exciting development in its industry by an accident of timing. This would clearly be wrong. So, too, would any action which would delay the introduction of the new mobile phones. Britain cannot afford to give up the small lead it has in this field just so a potential competitor to BT can be excluded.

It would appear that BT regards competition with abhorrence even though it likes to portray itself as at the forefront of the telecom revolution. At heart it is still bureaucratic, slow and overcautious.

It is worth remembering how it lost MCI to WorldCom in the US because it tried to talk down an already agreed bid price. It is worth noting, too, how it has allowed Freeserve and AOL to dominate the internet access market in Britain.

Quite a lot of skin and hair is bound to fly as the auction for the new licences gets under way on Monday.

Bidding will be high and no mobile operator worth its signal can afford to be left on the sidelines. Yet, while we have all got used to the privatised utilities having to be reminded that their quasi-monopolistic position requires them to take notice of their customers as well as their shareholders, BT is not doing its customers any favours at all by trying to delay the introduction of a new layer of technology which promises - to put it bluntly - to improve Britain's prosperity.

But Sir Peter should also know that his company is misreading the needs of his own big shareholders at the same time.

They own shares in all his rivals as well as BT and have nothing to gain by one big telecoms firm threatening to squander one of the few technological leads Europe has over America.

Rather than authorising whingeing letters to the DTI, he would be better advised to focus on the reason his share price has been going up over recent days. It's because speculators think BT is going to be taken over.

Natty NatWest

We might have expected the deal-making department at NatWest to have gone to sleep now that the Royal Bank of Scotland takeover is down to the mopping up stage.

But the banking subsidiary popped up yesterday with a little internet deal that looks much more interesting than most of the e-tosh that banks tend to push out nowadays.

NatWest is paying some £23m for a 13% stake in one of its software suppliers, a Channel Islands-based software company called WorldPay, and the plan now is to develop internet services for NatWest's small business customers.

Banks, by their very nature, are leery of many of the business-to-business internet firms springing up, offering to automate supply chains and the like.

fields.headline: Sugar pitches for couch potatoes
fields.trailText: Tottenham Hotspur chairman Sir Alan Sugar yesterday voiced fears that televised football could result in increasing numbers of stay-at-home supporters and pledged to freeze turnstile prices next year in an attempt to keep Spurs supporters flooding through the White Hart Lane gates.
fields.body:
Tottenham Hotspur chairman Sir Alan Sugar yesterday voiced fears that televised football could result in increasing numbers of stay-at-home supporters and pledged to freeze turnstile prices next year in an attempt to keep Spurs supporters flooding through the White Hart Lane gates.

Average gates at Spurs' home matches topped 35,000 in the six months to the end of January - compared with 33,700 in the corresponding period last year - and the club sold a record 18,600 season tickets, up 3,000 on last year.

But Sir Alan, knighted in the new year's honours, said: "We have to recognise that the future revenues of the club will soon come from other forms of income. The televising of so many matches offers a tempting alternative to attending a live match for football supporters.

"Attendances at some other clubs are already showing signs of decline and we would prefer to have White Hart Lane bursting at the seams every match."

The Spurs chairman was reporting half-time profits of £2m, down from £2.8m a year ago - partly a result of the club taking a one-off hit of £1.6m to pay off unwanted players.

Sir Alan said he had handed development of the club's website to BSkyB's new media ventures unit. "This will take the burden of responsibility of updating the site away from the club and into the hands of a dedicated team of experts."

It is the latest deal Sky has done with a premiership club to increase its influence in soccer - which sells more satellite dishes on the back of football than any other type of programming. The broadcaster now stakes in clubs including Manchester United, Manchester City, Leeds United and Sunderland, and BSkyB's shares rose 96p or 5.5% to 1840p yesterday as the Spurs details were confirmed.

webTitle: US under pressure as price of oil soars

fields.headline: US under pressure as price of oil soars
fields.standfirst: The issue explained: oil prices
fields.trailText: Oil prices yesterday shrugged off heavy hints of increased production and surged back towards $30 a barrel, a 200% increase on their level of just 14 months ago.
fields.body:
Oil prices yesterday shrugged off heavy hints of increased production and surged back towards $30 a barrel, a 200% increase on their level of just 14 months ago.

The rise is likely to increase pressure on the United States to release some of its huge strategic petroleum reserve to help shield Americans from soaring energy costs.

A critical three-nation summit in London yesterday headed by Saudi Arabia's oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, ended with a commitment to increase supplies at the Vienna summit on March 27 of the 11-nation Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

No figures were given but the market consensus was for the tough cuts package of 4.6m barrels a day to be slimmed to about 4.3m barrels, with further production increases should the price fail to respond.

Markets, however, took the view that any easing of the strict quotas agreed in March 1999 could be too little, too late. Brent crude for April delivery - the benchmark North Sea price - rose from $29.06 a barrel on Wednesday to $29.42. In New York, some crude prices broke through the $30 barrier.

The White House has been bombarded with protests about the increased cost of heating during winter and the administration fears even louder cries should summer motoring holidays spiral in cost through price rises. The strategic reserve, set up in 1975 after the first oil crisis, is thought to hold about 540m barrels, about one month's US consumption.

Drawdown from the reserve can be authorised by the president in the likelihood of a "severe energy supply interruption" or in the event of a price rise that would have "a major adverse impact" on the economy. One alternative to outright sales from the reserve is "swap" deals on commodity markets that would, technically, leave the reserve intact but help to hold down prices.

Mark Redway, analyst at the broker Greig Middleton, said swaps "might make sense ... and the US government ought to make some good money out of [such deals]".

Yesterday's meeting included Venezuela and Mexico. The latter is a key player in the Nopec group of countries which, while not members of the cartel, support its efforts to smooth the market.

Mexico is crucial also as a member of the North American Free Trade Area, its economy being deeply integrated with the US.

In that sense, it might be seen by Opec hardliners Iran, Kuwait and Libya as America's Trojan horse, and indeed yesterday oil minister Luis Tellez refused to quash rumours that Mexico might break from Opec and increase its output unilaterally. "That we will have to see," he said.

Mr Naimi said: "There is need for additional production. The issue is when and how much."

webTitle: Royal chief 'not pleased' as bonus evaporates

fields.headline: Royal chief 'not pleased' as bonus evaporates
fields.trailText: Bob Mendelsohn, the millionaire American chief executive of Royal & Sun Alliance, will be denied his performance-related bonus for last year, as will most of his staff.
fields.body:
Bob Mendelsohn, the millionaire American chief executive of Royal & Sun Alliance, will be denied his performance-related bonus for last year, as will most of his staff.

Mr Mendelsohn, who took over the top job in December 1997, could have received a £225,000 bonus on top of his £620,000 salary and "expatriate" benefits of £190,000.

Admitting he was "not pleased" with the fall in the insurer's operating profits in 1999 to £566m from £602m, he said: "My fortunes ride with the group".

Along with others in the sector, RSA's shares drifted lower last year while the profits were hurt by claims for storm damage.

He is in the middle of plan to improve the group's performance by 2001 and made clear that the group would consider selling off businesses which might help it reach its promises to shareholders - currently £400m short of target.

"Substantial" jobs cuts are expected in the United States, where it recently bought Orion and he refused to rule out further losses in Britain. The group will also spend £40m on a British internet venture.

RSA was formed through a merger of Sun Alliance and Royal Insurance in 1996 that has often been tagged as one of the least successful industry mergers.

Constantly cited as vulnerable to takeover, Mr Mendelsohn insisted RSA had not received any approaches and had not solicited any.

He acknowledged, however, that general insurance was currently out of fashion on the stock market, although the shares gained 7.25p yesterday to 350p.

webTitle: U-turn on water and telecoms 'sickens' top Tory

fields.headline: U-turn on water and telecoms 'sickens' top Tory
fields.trailText: The government was yesterday forced into a humiliating withdrawal of the telecom and water industries from its utilities bill following concerns over duplication of regulation.
fields.body:
The government was yesterday forced into a humiliating withdrawal of the telecom and water industries from its utilities bill following concerns over duplication of regulation.

Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers announced that the bill, intended to provide a better deal for consumers and boost regulation, would now cover gas and electricity alone.

The decision to include the other two elements in separate legislation provoked a row in parliament after Mr Byers was accused of going back on a manifesto commitment.

Conservatives condemned the decision as an "outrage" and an "affront to democracy" as one backbencher ripped up a copy of the bill. Liberal Democrats attacked the changes as a "shambles".

Opposition spokeswoman Angela Browning lambasted Mr Byers for his constant refusal to apologise for the decision. "If I hear the secretary of state say once more he makes no apology I think I shall puke."

The government insisted it had responded to the concerns of business. However, opposition MPs say that, while the changes are logical, ministers failed to heed warnings months ago that the legislation needed changing.

The utilities bill, which is at report stage in its passage through the Commons, was intended to cover the four privatised utilities. It aims to achieve a fair balance between the interests of consumers and shareholders, provide new powers for regulators and establish an independent consumer council for each utility sector.

The legislation was showcased in last November's Queen's speech as the department of trade and industry's flagship bill, intended to bring down electricity prices, in particular, by 10%.

Following the government rethink, regulations dealing with the telecommunications industry will now be dealt with in communications white paper published later this year.

Regulations for water will be dealt with in a water bill expected in this autumn's Queen's speech.

 Mr Byers yesterday won European Commission agreement to a fast-track decision on the government's £152m aid package for Rover's Longbridge car plant.

fields.headline: Sautter jibe at UK 'tax haven'
fields.trailText: French finance minister Christian Sautter yesterday attacked the City, saying UK opposition to a cross-border tax on savings made it a de-facto "tax haven".
fields.body:
French finance minister Christian Sautter yesterday attacked the City, saying UK opposition to a cross-border tax on savings made it a de-facto "tax haven".

Speaking at a news conference, he said: "Tax harmonisation is a European priority. It is important we make progress towards tax harmonisation." He said the City was a haven for non-EU savers and EU citizens who are not resident in the UK.

webTitle: Clinton enters row over IMF job

fields.headline: Clinton enters row over IMF job
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton has waded into the row over selecting the new head of the International Monetary Fund by defending American opposition to the choice favoured by the European Union.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton has waded into the row over selecting the new head of the International Monetary Fund by defending American opposition to the choice favoured by the European Union.

There were signs late last night that Germany's Chancellor Gerhard Schröder was preparing to withdraw his first choice, deputy finance minister Caio Koch-Weser, in the face of American opposition.

Mr Clinton said: "I think the Europeans should lead the IMF - and it would suit me if a German led the IMF. Nobody is playing any games here."

He added he would not support IMF interim managing director Stanley Fischer's attempt to win the top IMF post, despite having "enormous respect" for his work.

Following President Clinton's remarks, Mr Koch-Weser was given little hope of success by European Commission president Romano Prodi. He said last night the German had "no chance left".

As the IMF's board met in Washington last night to stage an informal straw poll on Mr Koch-Weser and the two other candidates, Mr Schröder's aides acknowledged that there would have to be a reassessment of the situation if he failed to secure enough support at the meeting.

With America and Europe agreeing that the new leader should be a European, neither American Mr Fischer, the IMF's caretaker boss, nor Japan's Eisuke Sakakibara was expected to gain enough backing to stay in the race.

Sources suggested that, in the absence of US support for Mr Koch-Weser, Europe would quickly have to come up with an alternative candidate to prevent losing the initiative.

The front-runners are thought to include two Italians, the treasury minister Giuliano Amato and his department's top civil servant, Mario Draghi.

Although he is an acknowledged financial expert, Mr Draghi lacks his boss's public profile and political skills.

fields.headline: Eurostar admits go-slow on profits
fields.trailText: Eurostar is still losing money and is not expected to break even until at least 2003, David Azema, chairman of the company, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Eurostar is still losing money and is not expected to break even until at least 2003, David Azema, chairman of the company, said yesterday.

Finances will not be published until a reorganisation involving British, French and Belgian interests is completed. But the British section is expected to lose £75m this year.

The service still outmatches airlines in popularity, with a 62% share of the market on the Paris run and 40% to Brussels.

It has returned four of its 31 trains to the French and Belgian railways to cut costs and reported a slowdown in revenue growth from 28% in 1998 to 6%, yielding £393m, last year. Passenger numbers were up from 6.7m to 7.05m.

Mr Azema announced several improvements, including a reduction in check-in time to 10 minutes for all holders of fully flexible tickets.

Phase two, scheduled for next year, involves refurbishment of terminal facilities at Waterloo, Gare du Nord and Brussels Midi.

The third phase, starting next year and finishing in 2003, will centre on restyling the train interiors in time for the opening of the first stage of the Channel tunnel high-speed rail link. This will cut journey time to Paris by 20 minutes to 2 hours 35 minutes.

Mr Azema admitted Eurostar must cut costs. "During the coming months we will endeavour to ensure commercial viability and the future growth of business," he said.

fields.headline: Heineken bid admission refreshes Bass
fields.trailText: The phoney bidding war for two of Britain's three biggest brewers burst into the open yesterday when Heineken, the Dutch drinks producer, admitted it was planning an offer for Bass's beer operations which include the best-selling Carling Black Label.
fields.body:
The phoney bidding war for two of Britain's three biggest brewers burst into the open yesterday when Heineken, the Dutch drinks producer, admitted it was planning an offer for Bass's beer operations which include the best-selling Carling Black Label.

The statement by Heineken's chairman, Karel Vuursteen, cast an immediate shadow over the future of Whitbread's beer company, roughly a third of whose earnings come from brewing Heineken under licence in the UK.

Whitbread, Britain's third-biggest brewer, has said it is looking to offload its beer company, but the value of the business could plunge if Heineken were to succeed with a bid for Bass's brewing and remove its licence deal from Whitbread.

That would not only hit the likely sale price for Whitbread's beer company but could affect earnings of the en tire group as the price its pubs and restaurants pay for Heineken would almost certainly be increased.

The Dutch company is believed to be unhappy with the sales of Heineken, whose share of the UK market has slumped to around 3%.

South African Breweries, which is also believed to be planning an offer for the Bass breweries, said earlier this week that it will bring forward the flotation of its hotels and casinos to raise about $500m to put on the table. Denmark's Carlsberg - itself rumoured to be a target for Anheuser-Busch of the US - is said to be in the running for Bass's beer operations.

Bass saw its shares rise by 25p to 736p after Heineken's declaration yesterday while Whitbread rose 3p to 537p. The market believes Interbrew of Belgium, whose top selling Stella Artois lager is brewed under licence by Whitbread in the UK, will make a bid before long.

That would not only hit the likely sale price for Whitbread's beer company but could affect earnings of the en tire group as the price its pubs and restaurants pay for Heineken would almost certainly be increased. The Dutch company is believed to be unhappy with the sales of Heineken, whose share of the UK market has slumped to around 3%. South African Breweries, which is also believed to be planning an offer for the Bass breweries, said earlier this week that it will bring forward the flotation of its hotels and casinos to raise about $500m to put on the table. Denmark's Carlsberg - itself rumoured to be a target for Anheuser-Busch of the US - is said to be in the running for Bass's beer operations. Bass saw its shares rise by 25p to 736p after Heineken's declaration yesterday while Whitbread rose 3p to 537p. The market believes Interbrew of Belgium, whose top selling Stella Artois lager is brewed under licence by Whitbread in the UK, will make a bid before long.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Dr Doom calls it a day at P&D
fields.body:
Dr Doom calls it a day at P&D

Tony Dye, the Phillips & Drew fund manager dubbed "Dr Doom" for his longstanding bearish stock market stance, yesterday confirmed his retirement after 17 years at the underperforming group. His departure was announced as part of the wider restructuring of the fund management operation which is part of UBS, the Swiss bank.

P&D is to merge with the bank's other institutional fund management operation in the US, Brinson Partners, which will eventually lead to the departure of group chairman Gary Brinson.

Two accused in Coutts case

Two businessmen were charged yesterday with stealing more than $32m (£20m) from Coutts and Co, the blue-chip bank at the centre of a criminal investigation in New York.

Coutts, whose client list includes the Queen and Elton John, allegedly lost the money after loans to the two men were not repaid. Jack Banks, aka Jacques Benquesus, and Larry Weltman are accused of pretending to have the necessary licences to buy gaming companies in the US to convince Coutts to lend them money. Charges of grand larceny and fraud allege that they illegally inflated the value of their company, which provided paper for lottery tickets and other parts of the gaming industry.

ECB keeps rates steady

The European Central Bank kept all its interest rates steady yesterday, confounding speculation that it might rush to support the euro with its second tightening in four weeks.

The ECB kept its key refinancing rate unchanged at 3.25%, the marginal lending rate at 4.25% and the deposit rate at 2.25%. The euro dipped briefly but rapidly bounced back to trade just above $0.97.

Profits up 7% at Norwich Union

Norwich Union, which announced a merger with rival insurer CGU 10 days ago, reported a 7% rise in annual profit yesterday and said margins on life and pensions business were maintained.

Norwich said achieved pre-tax operating profit was £717m ($1.13bn ) for the 12 months to December 31, up from a previous £670m.

fields.headline: Debussy: La Mer
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Debussy's La Mer.
fields.body:
La Mer, composed between 1903 and 1905, is Debussy's most popular and widely performed concert work. If impressionism means anything at all in music then this score is its epitome in orchestral terms.

The music of La Mer may conjure up many of the sensations associated with the sea: the titles of the three "symphonic sketches" - "From dawn to midday on the sea", "Play of the waves", "Dialogue of the wind and the sea" - show how explicit the inspiration was. But Debussy was as concerned with building self-contained musical forms. The work can certainly be appreciated as an abstract quasi-symphonic shape. The ideal interpreter of La Mer, then, needs to realise the sensuous, delicate colourings of the orchestration at the same as giving it a rigorous structural backbone.

A handful of recordings stand out, two of them by Pierre Boulez. His earlier version (Sony Classical) sounds undernourished now, breathtakingly lucid in its detail but without the suppleness of phrasing of its successor (DG).

Herbert Von Karajan (DG) has no problems with the sound world in his 1964 recording; he brings every nuance to vivid life, though he can overpoeticise what can be taken much more at face value, while Esa-Pekka Salonen (Sony Classical) takes a starkly dramatic approach, sometimes at the cost of the music's more delicate moments. But the perfect balance is struck, perhaps surprisingly, by Bernard Haitink with the Concertgebouw Orchestra.

The symphonic rigour comes naturally to Haitink, but he also has a wonderful ear for the score's precious sonorities; now his account is available as part of a mid-price two-disc set that contains equally convincing accounts of Debussy's other major orchestral works, which makes it unbeatable.

Key Recording Haitink (Philips 438 742-2) (2CDs)

webTitle: Set In Darkness by Ian Rankin

fields.headline: Set In Darkness by Ian Rankin
fields.standfirst:
(Orion, £16.99), digested in the style of the original
Buy it at BOL
fields.trailText: D I Rebus, a hard-drinking, hard-smoking, divorced Edinburgh cop with a disabled daughter, does things his way. DI Derek Linford does things the boss's way.
fields.body:
D I Rebus, a hard-drinking, hard-smoking, divorced Edinburgh cop with a disabled daughter, does things his way. DI Derek Linford does things the boss's way.

Both are seconded to the police liaison team for the new Scottish parliament at Queensberry House. Linford smells trouble when an unidentified corpse turns up behind a sealed-up fireplace in Queensberry House. A few days later, the body of Roddy Grieve, a prospective MSP, is found in the grounds. A tramp commits suicide in Waverley station leaving behind more than £400,000 in a building society account. Edinburgh is like that.

Grieve comes from a well-known Scottish family. His mother, Alicia, is a famous artist; his brother, Cammo, is a Tory MP. His sister, Lorna, is an ex-supermodel married to Hugh, an ageing rock dinosaur. His brother, Alasdair, went missing 20 years ago. Edinburgh is like that.

Rebus goes digging, helped by his loyal foot soldiers, DS Siobhan Clarke, DS Ellen Wylie and DS Grant Hood. Rebus has always fancied Lorna, and one night they go drinking. He wakes up to find her in his flat. Did they have sex? Edinburgh is like that.

Wylie and Hood discover that Barry Hutton, nephew of the Edinburgh arch-villain Bryce Callan, who has long since decamped to the Costas, was part of the construction team working at Queensberry House in 1979 when the fireplace was sealed. Hutton is now a successful property developer. Edinburgh is like that. Big Ger Cafferty, who Rebus put away, has got an early exit from Barlinnie, having swapped X-rays to show he is dying of cancer. Cafferty is an old mucker of Callan's. The supertramp turns out to be Freddy Hastings.

Hastings and Grieve were frontmen for Callan in the late 70s, buying up property in anticipation of a "Yes" vote in the devolution referendum. Grieve and Hastings had been ripping off Callan and went on the run when the vote went against them. Edinburgh is like that.

Hutton was operating the same scam 20 years later. Linford gets beaten up following Hutton to a pub. Rebus is on to Archie Ure, a bent councillor on the planning committee who was expecting to clean up when he became MSP. But Roddy Grieve got the nomination. So Grieve had to die. Ure dies of a heart attack during Rebus's interrogation. Edinburgh is like that.

Cafferty takes Rebus for a showdown with Hutton. Hutton attacks Rebus who passes out. He wakes up to find Hutton missing. He knows Cafferty has killed him. "Find the body," says Cafferty. Edinburgh is like that.

And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested: DI Rebus untangles intrigues involving suicide, gangland murders and political corruption over 20 years, but doesn't get his man. Edinburgh is like that. Final score: Rebus 1, Edinburgh 1.

fields.headline: Agnes Browne
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: As a director, Huston lacks the sure touch that Alan Parker had with similar material; her movie is an unhappy succession of false notes
fields.body:
Anjelica Huston's second feature as a director, Agnes Browne - about a feisty widowed mother-of-seven in 60s Dublin - signals its dire fate very early on, when she is shown gazing excitedly at a poster for a Tom Jones concert, but, bafflingly, never otherwise evincing the slightest enthusiasm for Jones's oeuvre. The heart sinks. Can it really be true that, like Wilson Pickett in The Commitments, Tom is going to have to resolve the plot at the end, like a rockin' deus ex machina? The effrontery of this device takes a lot of beating, especially considering that Jones appears in the film without any extra make-up, playing his 60s self. That, as PG Wodehouse once said, pretty well walks off with the Huntley and Palmer.

Huston herself gives an outrageously hammy performance as the indomitable Agnes, marching around the streets with a lot of other women in authentic 60s street-scene get up. With that large, handsome head encased in a scarf, pushing her pram full of stuff around, fag in mouth, quacking away in Berlitz Irish, she looks almost like some sort of weirdo art installation from another era entirely.

As a director, Huston lacks the sure touch that Alan Parker had with similar material; her movie is an unhappy succession of false notes. She is being improbably pursued by Pierre (Arno Chevrier), a Gerard Depardieu-lookalike, who, in his hunky, entrepreneurial way, is opening a modish French bistro down the road - pioneering stuff for 1967. She is bullied by the money lender, Mr Billy (Ray Winstone), who at one stage gets his nasty underling to punch Agnes's small son in the stomach. He writhes around on the ground in agony. For different reasons, I felt like doing the same thing.

fields.headline: Midnight
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Fills the smaller space of TV drama comfortably enough, but stretched out onto the big screen it looks a little thin
fields.body:
In this age of movies pumped up to three-hours-plus Michelin Man dimensions, Midnight, at a running-time of just 64 minutes, is a stripling - a novella among blockbuster novels. This is the new feature from Walter Salles, who brought us the highly-regarded Central Station. Here he is co-directing with Daniela Thomas, and this is based on two very different experiences of New Year's Eve, 1999 in Rio, and in its final scenes it is reminiscent of Don McKellar's millennial jeu d'esprit Last Night.

Maria (Fernando Torres) is a teacher of hearing-impaired children whose boyfriend appears to have deserted her. Meanwhile, in another part of the billion-footed city, a fugitive prisoner has been sprung from jail in an establishment-inspired conspiracy to murder someone on the outside threatening to expose a corrupt scam. They run into each other, fatefully, on the stroke of midnight, on a rooftop overlooking Copacabana beach. This is a film with drama, movement and a convincing sense of place, but somehow it adds up to less than the sum of its parts. Originally one episode of a 10-part French television project, Midnight fills the smaller space of TV drama comfortably enough, but stretched out onto the big screen it looks a little thin.

fields.headline: Show Me Love
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A tender, well acted, well observed and intelligent domestic emotional drama
fields.body:
A drama about Swedish teenage lesbianism - and one which was originally called Fucking Amal - might lead the prurient to expect something crude. But Show Me Love is a tender, well acted, well observed and intelligent domestic emotional drama in which there is one brief, fully-clothed all-female kiss and that's it. Elin (Alexandra Dahlström) is a pretty 16-year-old girl stifled by the sheer provincial dullness of her life in the town of Amal, which she bitterly reviles: hence the original title.

A dark and moody girl called Agnes (Rebecka Liljeberg) is agonisingly in love with her. Things proceed from there, with many a witty and affectionate aside about the sheer awfulness of being a teenager. There is also a nicely sympathetic performance from Axel Widegren as Agnes's father, Oskar, doing his level best to understand.

fields.headline: Tumbleweeds
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: It's a dull script with no ideas, but McTeer certainly does an excellent job
fields.body:
Tumbleweeds, directed by Gavin O'Connor, is the film that got the British actress Janet McTeer her Oscar nomination this year - and good luck to her. She gives an honest, gutsy performance with a convincing Southern belle accent as the free-spirited woman who leaves her violent husband, and takes off with her 13-year-old daughter to start a new life in San Diego. If it all sounds familiar, this is because the movie is an almost exact copy of Anywhere But Here, the recent picture starring Susan Sarandon, also about a mother and daughter in similar circumstances: the mother far more adventurous than the prim, conservative daughter.

Unfortunately, Anywhere But Here was interesting in the way this isn't: dramatising real tensions between mother and daughter with much more drama and nuance, and showing the daughter's difficult growth into a young woman. In Tumbleweeds the daughter stays young and cute - we hardly get up to her first period - and her relations with her mama are boringly untroubled as well. It's a dull script with no ideas, but McTeer certainly does an excellent job.

fields.headline: Ikinai
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A very unsettling picture, arrestingly original, and possessed of a distinctive, seriocomic tone
fields.body:
Hiroshi Shimizu is a debutant director, a former assistant to Takeshi Kitano, and his Ikinai is an unexpectedly moving essay on the nature of death. A group of people, united by a grim wish to commit suicide, decide to fake their own death on a phoney tourist sightseeing tour in Okinawa. The plan is that the bus will crash at a notorious accident blackspot, and their relatives will pick up a handsome insurance cheque.

But it all goes wrong when an unsuspecting girl joins their party, and the leader of the plan ruthlessly insists that the scheme must go ahead, as her tragic presence will be all the more convincing in the event of an investigation. Rumbling through the winding streets, the group assumes the determination of a civilian kamikaze mission, achieving, as they head for the edge of a cliff, a strange, liminal sense of what it is to exist. Shimizu has created a very unsettling picture, arrestingly original, and possessed of a distinctive, seriocomic tone.

fields.headline: The best troop scene
fields.standfirst: Three Kings
fields.trailText: Three Kings
fields.body:
Kuwait, 1991. Outside a US army camp, TV reporter Adriana Cruz (Nora Dunn) attempts to record a news story.

"Music is high," she announces to camera, "and spirits are soaring, as these young troops..."

Cut to a TV inside the camp, with Cruz's face on-screen.

"...celebrate the liberation of Kuwait."

Back to Cruz outside the camp. She lowers her microphone.

"Did I just say soaring? How did it sound?"

Back inside the camp, around 50 soldiers are having a party. Troy Barlow (Mark Wahlberg) sits on the shoulders of his comrades, wearing an impromptu head-dress and bawling along to Public Enemy's I Can't Do Nuttin For Ya, Man. Walter Wogaman (Jamie Kennedy) hovers between two boomboxes, playing DJ. The assembled soldiers cheer , spitting beer into the air. Conrad Vig (Spike Jonze) dances wildly to the music, and then, delivering a high kick into the air, falls flat on his back. A moment later, as Troy and Walter dance in tandem, Conrad joins them; he wears a broad grin on his face, but can't quite get the hang of the steps.

Cut to Troy, Walter and Conrad, their arms around one another as a colleague wields a Polaroid camera.

"Take a picture! Take another one!"

See also: Full Metal Jacket, Apocalypse Now, The Manchurian Candidate, Dead Presidents

Don't see also: Rambo

Pointless trivia: When Spike Jonze won his MTV award for Best Video - after directing Fatboy Slim's Praise You - his gong was picked up by Promo's star dancer, Richard Carfay; Jonze would neither confirm nor deny that he and Carfay were the same person.

fields.headline: Three Kings – review
fields.standfirst: Peter Bradshaw salutes Three Kings, an action-packed war movie that's intelligent too
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: A strange flavour, but this is an enjoyable and intelligent action film
fields.body:
David O Russell's Three Kings is an unexpectedly entertaining film about the most boring event in modern history: the Gulf war. This was a military adventure that is popularly conceived to be a virtual-reality, postwar war - although, unlike the recent Nato action against Serbia, it did involve a quaint ground-troop invasion, and Three Kings finds itself in this more old-fashioned military context.

The film conflates a number of generic approaches. It sometimes has the acid-trippy, alienated feel of an Apocalypse Now or a Platoon; it sometimes affects the grandstanding, busily appalled humour of M*A*S*H; occasionally it strives for the grandeur associated with the theatre of 1939-45: there is a scene in which a tank mightily turns its barrel on a troublesome sniper that is lifted straight out of Saving Private Ryan.

Three Kings is set at the moment of victory itself: Saddam has surrendered. American servicemen, their sword of valour never, as it were, tempered in the fire of real combat, are in a strange, volatile mood: relieved, euphorically triumphant, oddly frustrated. It is their uneasy task now to enforce a pax americana, which involves accepting the abject surrender of thousands of Iraqis while encouraging a putative rebel faction to rise up against the Ba'athist regime. All of this, while drifting aimlessly about in the desert landscape fringed with burning wells, and trying to think of ways of keeping the media encampment happy.

In the midst of all this grisly modernity, what do two soldiers, Sergeant Troy Barlow (Mark Wahlberg) and Staff Sergeant Chief Elgin (Ice Cube) discover, but an old-fashioned treasure map! Tonnes of hidden Kuwaiti gold bullion liberated by the Iraqis and now begging to be taken by some enterprising Americans. Their map is commandeered by Major Archie Gates (George Clooney) and they set off behind enemy lines to swipe the gleaming yellow bars.

Exactly how the hell they expect to convert them into exchangeable currency for use back home is not a question that weighs heavily on us. Instead, we enjoy the stylish cinematography of Newton Thomas Sigel, and Russell's very adroit management of both the military set-pieces and the internal tensions of the hero group, which actually includes another renegade American soldier (like The Three Musketeers, there are really four of them) - this is Conrad Vig, a leering good-ol'-boy played by Spike Jonze.

All around them, in every direction, the level sands stretch vastly away, and this gives everything a weird and faintly surreal air. Russell's screenplay has a lot of snap. At one stage, Chief Elgin bitterly objects, as an African-American, to other ranks' use of the phrase "sand-coon" to describe the enemy: " 'Towel-head' and 'sand-jockey' are perfectly good substitutes!" Such fastidiousness is a little strange for the former gangsta rapper Ice Cube, but he himself is really quite impressive in this role, and, catching up with Wahlberg, has graduated convincingly to the screen from the world of music.

They give appreciably happier performances than Clooney, who appears to have arrived having, in Woody Allen's time-honoured phrase, just taken his handsome lesson. This film would appear to require George to act up a Desert Storm: he has to be a plausibly embittered, cynical soldier prepared to risk his pension for this crazy, greedy scheme. But, secondly, he must have a streak of pure gold bullion in his heart, and be ready to risk the prize to help his new buddies and, indeed, the Iraqi civilians, while maintaining a manly emotional reticence about just what a fantastic guy he's being. Needless to say, it's this second aspect that George is keenest on. And it is clearly a bit of a wrench not to be able to get his stethoscope out at any time.

Irony and historical perspective are provided when it sinks into the minds of our heroes that America is, in a sense, the author of this chaos. America had armed and trained Saddam in the days when it took Iraq's side against Iran; and now it was casually encouraging anti-Saddam rebels to risk everything in an uprising. But the film does not touch on the actual bombing of Baghdad and its cowering civilians - a manoeuvre intended to create these revolutionary conditions - and Three Kings is always careful to indict the political rather than the military establishment. (There are no walk-on roles for blithering British officers, incidentally - though I would have liked to have seen a representation of John Major in the desert wearing his woolly jumper.)

Three Kings has the lineaments of a wised-up anti-war film, but with an undercurrent of warmly lenient, sentimental admiration for the American fighting man: it makes for a strange flavour, but this is an enjoyable and intelligent action film.

fields.headline: Signal failure
fields.standfirst: Resourceful robbers,
fields.trailText: Resourceful robbers,
fields.body:
On the wrong side of the tracks
Whilst in no way condoning robbery, it's fair to say that some robbers at least temper their misdemeanours with a certain panache. One such is John Howe, who recently stood trial at Luton Crown Court for robbing a railway signal box at Aspley Guise in Bedfordshire. Mr Howe, 45, of no fixed abode, had raided the box with friend Paul Paget, threatening signalman William Freitag with an iron bar before forcing him to lie face down on the floor and tying him up. As they set about loading Mr Freitag's car with stolen goods, however, the terrified signalman pointed out that the 6.02 London Express was due to pass at any minute, and that the level crossing barriers were still closed. Lesser criminals might have ignored his warnings, concentrating instead on simply getting away with their loot. Not so Mr Howe. Donning his victim's official railway hat and jacket he went outside, flagged traffic to a halt, pulled open the barriers, and then stood blowing his whistle and waving as the train flew past. Once it was safely through he closed the barriers again, returned to the signal box, filled in Mr Freitag's log book and then finally made his escape. He and his colleague were eventually arrested in Durham, and sentenced to four and five years in prison respectively. "He'd always wanted to work on the railways," said one friend. "Robbing signal boxes was in a sense his way of saying 'Give us a job.'" Milton Keynes Citizen

Taking the puss
Those of us who suspect that cats are getting it far too good these days had our worst fears confirmed this week when the National Trust lashed out £327 to build a special cat-flap at one of their properties in the Cotswolds. The flap was inserted into the door of a garden shed at Snowshill Manor for the exclusive use of a white moggy named Tino. The latter had, over the years, grown increasingly dissatisfied with his existing flap, a functional but rather uninspiring affair in brown plastic. Rather than simply telling him to get on with it, however, or, better, having him put down, the National Trust caved-in to Tino's petulance and designed him a brand new deluxe flap framed by a hand-sculpted wooden portico with scalloped edges. After planning permission had been granted by the local council the flap was duly installed, and, to date at least, appears to have met with its owner's approval. "It really does swing beautifully," said Denise Edwards, the manager of Snowshill. "Tino adores it." Rumours that the pampered pussy will also be getting a Chippendale cat litter and Wedgwood milk dish are, as yet, unsubstantiated.
Gloucestershire Echo

Howls of Windsor Terror is stalking the streets of Windsor - or at least one of the streets of Windsor - in the form of a rogue traffic bollard. The bollard, which is automatically activated, was installed nine months ago in order to close off Peascod Street to all traffic except the town's buses. If a bus approaches an electronic signal is dispatched and the bollard sinks into the ground, rising again as soon as the bus has passed and blocking the road to other vehicles. Unfortunately, motorists driving directly behind buses often fail to see the 'Authorised Vehicles Only" signs at the entrance to the street. As a result they follow the buses into it only to be speared by the rising spike, which shoots up underneath their cars like a harpoon into the belly of a whale. "I turned left in my Nissan Cherry," explained one old lady, "And the next thing I knew there was a crunching sound and I had this big fat metal thing between my legs. It was very traumatic." So far there have been over a dozen such incidents, although fortunately no one has yet been injured. "Like all the council's traffic schemes," said one irate local, "It's a complete and utter load of bollards."
Slough and Langley Observer

The path less travelled
This week's prize for Britain's Most Pointless Public Footpath goes to Bucks County Council, who recently opened a path that leads unsuspecting pedestrians and cyclists straight into a brick wall. The path was designed to help residents of the Fairford Leys estate in Aylesbury walk to their local Tesco without having to cross a series of busy and dangerous main roads. Unfortunately, before they started constructing the path, the council failed to consult with the owners of land on a nearby retail park to confirm they had no objection to the path crossing their property. As it happened they did have objections, with the result that the path was unable to continue through to its intended destination, instead meandering aimlessly around for a while before eventually stopping dead against the side of a large factory. The official Public Footpath sign at the start of the path has now been taken down, as has another, unofficial sign declaring "Abandon Hope All Ye Who Walk Down Here."
The Bucks Herald

Letter of the Week
How utterly shocking to read of schoolchildren being targeted by appalling drug-peddling scum who are not fit to breathe God's air, let alone be allowed to circulate freely in society. Great hope then when I also read that a special police team is being set up to hunt down this filth. What joy to think of them being caught and properly punished! But then, alas, I came down to earth with realisation that no matter the effort involved in bringing them to justice, this would all be down the pan when they came to court, where some bumptious oaf would tell them that they 'had come within a whisper of a custodial sentence'. How long before we read of judges saying 'I am giving you credit for cleaning your teeth, brushing your hair, not kicking the arresting officers, not urinating in the court waiting room, and not trying to flog drugs to the Bench, all of which gets you enough Brownie Points to be let off with a few hours of community service. Collect your free gift on the way out.
Name and Address Supplied
Barnsley Chronicle.

fields.headline: Warwickshire stalwart resigns in despair
fields.trailText: Accusations from a leading county administrator that the England and Wales Cricket Board is guilty of blinkered and outdated leadership have brought a strong reaction from Tim Lamb, the board's chief executive.
fields.body:
Accusations from a leading county administrator that the England and Wales Cricket Board is guilty of blinkered and outdated leadership have brought a strong reaction from Tim Lamb, the board's chief executive.

"I have found trying to run the finances of a first-class county an almost impossible task," said John Whitehouse, Warwickshire's chairman from 1994-98 and their treasurer until yesterday, when he severed his links with the first-class game because of his increasing disillusionment. "We are never sure what money we can expect to receive from the ECB. Also there appears to be no long-term strategy."

Whitehouse, a former Warwickshire captain, added that he felt the final straw had been the ECB's reaction to Michael Atherton's recent comment that the county game was a waste of time. "Rather than listen to the views of a respected figure, the ECB seemed more concerned with how he should be disciplined."

Lamb responded: "His comments about the lack of financial foresight are very hard to accept. There has been a lack in the past but just a few weeks ago the board's new finance director Stephen Atkin went to Edgbaston to discuss the subject with the Warwickshire people, one of whom was John Whitehouse."

fields.headline: Briddish rock hunks
fields.standfirst:
Bush
Hammersmith Palais, London
****
fields.trailText:
Bush
Hammersmith Palais, London
****
fields.body:
Bush have long been a source of wonder in this country. How could a troupe of blatantly derivative Nirvana-heads from west London become the only current English band most Americans have ever heard of? Even Oasis can't fill the megadomes that Bush pack every time they do one of their sweeps of the Midwest, and singer Gavin Rossdale is rock royalty over there, proving the potency of a few angsty tunes and a Briddish (now actually mid-Atlantic) accent.

Kerri Haza, a 22-year-old who's flown over from Pennsylvania for this short UK tour, has the answer: "It's his animal magnetism." It's her eighth Bush gig, but the first time she's seen Rossdale and his anonymous sidekicks at such excitingly close quarters. Compared to the hangars they normally play, the Palais is a cupboard, so Rossdale's magnetising vibes have only a short distance to travel between stage and back wall. And yes, there is something about those boy-bandish cheekbones, and the unironic way he thanks us for our "positive energy". When he dedicates Letting the Cables Sleep to an HIV-positive friend - "He's doing fine now" - it's clear he's a pleasant person, too. That probably explains the phalanx of long-stemmed blondes with backstage passes.

But what of the music? Another pleasant surprise. Nobody could ever call Bush's grinding gloomcore innovative, but they invest it with so much feeling that they can no longer be written off as grunge wannabes. Greedy Fly shows them to have a streak of goth a mile wide, which Rossdale carries off with aplomb (not easy), while Mouth combines heaviosity and grace more deftly than any of their Seattle heroes. We could have done without the lead-booted Spacetravel, from current LP The Science of Things, mostly because earnest anti-Labour diatribes and moshing teenagers don't mix. But the diamond-bright Everything Zen, inspired by Rossdale's envy of Suede's success, of all things, has a stomp-along chorus that's reason enough for it to exist.

Rossdale makes a grand rock star, too. All those stadium gigs have trained him to work a crowd, and he's got the knack of seeming both aloof and touchable. He makes his way deep into the crowd halfway through the ludicrously-titled Insect Kin and a circle magically opens around him. Kerri pushes her way through and returns looking radiant: "Definite animal magnetism," she swoons. Anyone who can do that to an audience should be taken seriously.

webTitle: TUC attacks Brown claim of jobs for all who want them

fields.headline: TUC attacks Brown claim of jobs for all who want them
fields.trailText: The TUC yesterday launched a strong attack on Gordon Brown's claim that there is work available for every job seeker when it said 4m people were looking for employment.
fields.body:
The TUC yesterday launched a strong attack on Gordon Brown's claim that there is work available for every job seeker when it said 4m people were looking for employment.

Accusing the chancellor of using discredited figures to back up his "on yer bike" message to the jobless, the TUC said that there was a clear regional divide between the prosperous south and the depressed north.

The hard-hitting report will come as an embarrassment to Mr Brown as he prepares to set off on Monday for a tour of unemployment blackspots. It reflects growing tensions between the government and its traditional allies on the left, who are concerned that Labour is losing touch with its heartlands.

John Monks, TUC general secretary, said: "It would be a mistake to think we now have full employment because there is one registered unemployed person for every estimated va cancy. The real figure shows there are four people who want a job for every vacancy."

The "hidden jobless" total - 4m according to the TUC - is four times the number registered as claiming unemployment benefit. Mr Monks said there was no room for complacency about unemployment, even though the claimant count has fallen by nearly 300,000 since Labour came to power.

On Tuesday, the treasury used the claimant count figures to show that the number of vacancies in the economy is almost equal to the number of unemployed people. In an echo of Norman Tebbit's famous call to the jobless to get on their bikes and find a job, Mr Brown said: "I say to the unemployed who can work - you must now meet your responsibility to earn a wage."

The chancellor came under immediate attack from the Tories, who accused him of using figures that Labour denounced when it was in opposition as "fiddled". Before the election, Labour promised it would use the internationally approved measure of joblessness, based on the quarterly door-to-door survey of 160,000 households which asks people if they are looking for work.

The TUC said its measure of the "hidden jobless", which counts not only those who say they are actively looking for work but also those who say they want a job, was a more accurate measure of unemployment. "No one much trusted the claimant count unemployment figures under the last government. It would be a mistake to start believing them now," said Mr Monks.

The report warns that there are still sharp differences between prosperous regions such as the south-east and more depressed regions such as the north-east.

"This report will provide uncomfortable reading for almost everyone involved in the economic policy debate," said Mr Monks. "While prosperous regions have their depressed areas, and there are affluent suburbs in every region, there are clear differences between Britain's regions."

fields.headline: Dancer in the machine
fields.standfirst:
Yolande Snaith Theatredance/ Maximum Machine
The Place, London
***
fields.trailText:
Yolande Snaith Theatredance/ Maximum Machine
The Place, London
***
fields.body:
Yolande Snaith's latest work, Maximum Machine, is set in a mad inventor's attic, with ropes and pulleys hanging from wooden beams, and archaic measuring devices stacked in corners. Its six dancers are wearing outfits assembled from centuries of discarded fashion, and are engaged in obsessive, Heath Robinson experiments. A woman in a hooped skirt and aviator's helmet lies strung between metal harnesses, trying to figure out the most efficient way of swimming through space while a man in a leather apron and goggles paces the stage with a measuring wheel.

There's a Swiftian air of intellectual derangement about all of their activities - people intent on elaborating their private systems with little regard for the real world - and its a derangement Snaith wittily pursues. In the work's middle section, her experimenters engage in scrupulous investigations of their own bodies. A women raises and lowers her leg while another measures the angle it forms and two men practice wrestling holds. Together, the dancers try to function as a dancing machine, disciplining their moves into choreographed unison as one man helplessly attempts to compute their activity.

Machines also go haywire and Snaith diverts into comedy as the dancers' experiments turn destructively manic. But its in these "humorous" sections, that the weakness of the work is most evident, for its here that the dancing is most exposed as repetitive and slight.

Snaith is an original. Her sets (conceived with Barnaby Stone) are works of art, ingeniously put in motion by her dancers and her ideas are both clever and magical. But her choreography always remains secondary to her stagings and in this, as in all her shows we long for her fantasies to be elaborated by more sophisticated, imaginative dance. If bodies are machines and dancers are scientists then she could surely invent more ambitious moves than the basic steps and gestures offered here.

Still, despite its choreographic limitations Maximum Machine remains one of Snaith's best works, rich in historical and intellectual allusion and with a conclusion that's oddly touching. Four dancers stand gazing at the stars while the flying woman continues her vain attempts at flight and the man with the measuring wheel wanders ineffectually round the stage. Here in a single image is the blind faith of the lonely scientist, chasing after elusive truths while the world looks on with indifference, or ridicule.

Until tomorrow, then at the Hexagon, Reading (0118 960 6060) on 8 March.

fields.headline: Poetry in song
fields.standfirst:
Renée Fleming/ Claire Bloom
Barbican Hall, London
**
fields.trailText:
Renée Fleming/ Claire Bloom
Barbican Hall, London
**
fields.body:
American composers have been obsessed with Emily Dickinson. Her poetry contains so much more than appears on its unassuming surfaces, so much impacted passion and fiercely penetrating observation that it seems to cry out for musical reinforcement, and it is hard to think of an equivalent English writer (Housman perhaps?) who has been so extensively explored by composers here.

That whole spectrum of Dickinson settings, spanning most of the 20th century, was the starting point for Voyager: "My business is to love", an evening of Dickinson settings interspersed with extracts from her poems and diaries, which had been put together by the soprano Renée Fleming, with the linking text compiled by William Luce. Fleming sang (17 songs altogether, accompanied by Helen Yorke) and Claire Bloom read, within a kind of semi-theatrical framework directed by Charles Nelson Reilly.

It was all done with the best of intentions. But the stagey little exchanges between singer and actress were sometimes cringingly twee, and though Dickinson is a great poet of almost iconic significance in the United States this didn't tell us anything that we didn't know about the music she has inspired, except that an awful lot of it is second rate. When the words themselves are so scarily unassuming, it's all too tempting for composers to try to unpack all that compressed intensity in grand gestures which only destroy the words they love. Settings by Ricky Lee Gordon, Robert Beaser, Lee Hoiby and Jake Heggie added nothing and took away quite a lot, while those by André Previn and Michael Tilson Thomas were more conscientious, though in the end no more revealing.

One tiny song by Ned Rorem did catch the spirit more faithfully, but there is one Dickinson masterpiece, Aaron Copland's Twelve Poems of Emily Dickinson, composed in the late 1940s, and Fleming included three of those songs in her sequence. They towered over everything else in the programme in their directness, their perfect meshing of poetic tension with the music, and their self-effacing willingness to put the words first. Fleming delivered them lustrously, as she did all her contributions, but had she just sung the whole cycle and nothing else, we could all have gone home an hour and a half earlier and learnt far more about Dickinson - and music as well.

webTitle: Britannia pays out £80m to stay mutual

fields.headline: Britannia pays out £80m to stay mutual
fields.trailText: Britannia building society, the UK's second biggest, yesterday revealed that it has handed back £80m to its 2.25m members in its battle to fend off attacks from carpetbaggers.
fields.body:
Britannia building society, the UK's second biggest, yesterday revealed that it has handed back £80m to its 2.25m members in its battle to fend off attacks from carpetbaggers.

The benefit, worth an average of £44 to each member, is the fourth return of capital to members by Britannia and follows a failed bid by carpetbagger Michael Hardern and 300 members to force the society to convert last year.

Yesterday Britannia said 1999 profits rose by 9.6% to £135.2m, with mortgage lending up 43% to £1.9bn and savings inflow a record £800m.

It also revealed that it is to begin an internet operation this summer but that it will be low key compared to the launch of If by Halifax and cahoots by Abbey National.

Finance director Neville Richardson said around 25% of Britannia's customers have access to the internet. But he added: "We do not believe in launching a separate brand with all the associated marketing costs. Our existing brand is strong enough."

Britannia will continue to invest in its branch network rather than force members to use web-based services. "We see our 193 branches as fundamental to the business and they all make a profit. The vast majority of our customers want to go into branches and deal with people, not machines."

Revenue in 1999 edged up from £272m to £287m but profits were boosted by the £41.7m gain from the sale during the year of Britannia Life and a stake in Britannia Asset Management.

fields.headline: Link rules out £2.50 sting
fields.standfirst:
Chief executive believes ATM double charge will not happen
The issue explained: cash machine charges
fields.trailText: The chief executive of the embattled Link cash machine network yesterday responded swiftly to government concerns about high fees for cash withdrawals by playing down the prospect of a £2.50 "double charge".
fields.body:
The chief executive of the embattled Link cash machine network yesterday responded swiftly to government concerns about high fees for cash withdrawals by playing down the prospect of a £2.50 "double charge".

It is understood that in a four-page letter to the secretary of state for trade and industry, Stephen Byers, Link's chief executive, John Hardy, also pointed out that it would be "illegal" for Link to tell the 34 banks and building societies which are part of the network at what level to set the price for cash withdrawals.

While Mr Hardy is understood to have pointed out that each member of Link decides whether to charge a fee and at what level, he said that the "office of fair trading can and should, of course, intervene if the members overcharge".

He is also thought to have insisted that the decisions taken at Tuesday's controversal Link board meeting were intended to increase competition and take into account views of the authorities.

However, Mr Hardy, who declined to comment last night, is understood to have told Mr Byers that the "double charging" which would have raised the prospect of a £2.50 fee was not possible this year because controversial surcharges will not be introduced until next year.

By then, "a system to prevent the potential conflict between disloyalty charges and surcharges will be in place". The prospect of the £2.50 charge arises from a customer paying a £1 surcharge which Barclays wants to levy on its rivals' customers when they use its machines as well as a "disloyalty" fee of up to £1.50 charged by their own bank or society.

However, Sir Brian Pitman, the chairman of Lloyds TSB, told Mr Byers yesterday he shared his concerns about "double charging".

"We promoted the proposal to postpone access fees [surcharges] to non-customers until January 2001 and as a matter of urgency we are presently trying to encourage the members of Link to outlaw double charging," Sir Brian said in a letter to the secretary of state, who, along with the prime minister, has threatened the banks with multi-million pound fines for any anti-competitive behaviour.

Sir Brian did, however, defend the bank's right to levy a charge on its rivals' customers using its cash machines but said the level of the charge had yet to be determined other than that it would be "competitive".

"We have invested heavily in our ATM [cash machine] network for the benefit our customers and we do not believe that we should subsidise our competitors," Sir Brian said.

Abbey National also backed the "surcharging" route yesterday, saying it would scrap its £1.50 disloyalty charge from next year and introduce a surcharge instead.

However, Abbey appeared to set itself on a collusion course with Don Cruickshank, who is conducting a review of banking competition for the treasury and recommended that banks should charge no more than 30p for cash withdrawals.

Abbey admitted it was "highly likely" its charge would be more than 30p, but emphasised that the level of the fee had not been decided.

"The size of the fee will be determined in due course, taking into account the costs of our investment in our own network," Abbey said.

Bank of Scotland, however, pledged to continue not to levy any charge on its own customers or those of its rivals when they used BoS cash machines.
